Project Title: Sustainable WASH in the Koshi Affected Resettled Community

Impact: Improved living condition of the resettled families
Outcome: Open defecation free settlement;  Improved health condition of 235 resettled households.

Project Title: Integrated Shelter Assistance for 225 Landless Households Affected by Koshi Flood
Input: Identification of landless victim by Koshi Flood;  Coordination with stakeholders including Nepal Basobas Basti Samrakshan Samaj, UNDP, Government (DDRC) and donor agencies;   Mobilization of community and Conduct various trainings for livelihood improvement. ;  Design of lowcost housing, suitable for local condition;  Construction of 235 lowcost shelters.
Outputs: Construction of 235 low-cost housing for registered landless families;  Technical training on construction of low-cost housing;   Develop saving schemes among the community.
Impact: First of its kind in Nepal to support housing for disaster victims as a Recovery Project and a model for replication;   Secured land tenure and housing rights.
Outcome: Improved living condition of targeted families;  Ensured partnership among community, community based organizations and local district government;  Strengthened resilience of community to cope with the disaster in future;   Increased economic self reliance through access and control over financial resources;  Developed organizational capacity of communities to enhance self reliance, build confidence and solidarity.

Project Title: WASH Lifesaving Support Project- Preventing deaths of vulnerable population (children and women) through lifesaving WASH promotion and response (CERF Nepal Project)
Input: Social mobilization on repair and maintenance of water and sanitation infrastructures including re-formation water and sanitation users groups (WSUG) under the supervision of WSUG with technical support from WSSDO;   Protection, repair and maintenance of water supply systems that will include intakes/pipes in hilly VDCs, and shallow-tube wells repair or installations of elevated hand pump in Terai VDCs;   Installation of 4 rain water harvesting/ water conversation in public;  Installation of temporary latrines for 80 deprived households;  Social mobilization and awareness campaigns with WASH supply distribution in the Marginalized community of 24 project VDCs to raise community awareness on the health benefits of safe water, good sanitation and hygiene practices;  Water quality testing for the 10 small water supply systems repaired/maintained/protected.
Outputs: About 12,000 people will be aware on WASH;  Hygiene Supplies distribution to 39,000 households;   Protection, repair and maintenance of water supply systems that will include intakes/pipes in hilly VDCs, and shallow-tube wells repair or installations of elevated hand pump) in Terai VDCs;   At least 10 piped drinking water systems in the hilly VDCs of Doti district will be repaired benefiting about 3,000 people;   Repair and Maintenance of Water Supply Systems;  80 temporary latrines to deprived households to promote good sanitations; around 480 people developed proper sanitation habits;   Four demonstration Rain Water Harvesting Systems;    10 water supply systems with "Water Quality Testing" practise on regular basis.
Outcome: 10 damaged small water supply systems repaired/protected/maintained in the VDCs of Doti and Kailali benefiting around 3,000 people directly;  30 hand pumps or latrines in flood prone districts of Kailali and Kanchanpur will be repaired/maintained and elevated as appropriate benefiting around 900 people directly;  4 rain water harvesting tanks installed and water conservation practices demonstrated within the community benefiting about 2,000 people;  80 temporary latrines installed benefiting around 480 deprived populations;  WASH knowledge, attitude and hygiene practices of the communities in 24 VDCs improved through social mobilization campaign benefiting around 39,000 households (238,000 people) directly or indirectly;  Safe water practice demonstrated for the 10 small water supply systems that have been repaired/protected or maintained.

Project Title: Acquisition of 3 Turbo-Prop(MA 60)and 5 STOL(Y12E)Aircraft from AVIC International Holding Corporationof China to Nepal Airlines Corporation.
Lifesaving Initiatives for Flood Affected People in 10 Village Development Committees of Kanchanpur District (CERF Nepal Project)
Input: Social mobilization for improved hygiene practices;     Repair of 5 small water supply projects/systems;    Hygiene supplies transportation and distribution;    Installation of elevated latrines and HP;    Installation of rain water harvesting/water conservation in public places;    Installation of temporary latrines for deprived households;    Water quality testing and disinfection.
Outputs: Capacity building of FCHVs and other volunteers including Sphere training to Government Line agencies; Live saving education campaign; Personal hygiene promotion;     Hygiene Supplies distributed to beneficiaries;    5 Small Water Supply Schemes repaired;     10 Elevated Hand pumps and/or 10 Elevated Latrines constructed;    Three Water Conservation schemes installed at public places;     40 temporary latrines are constructed for deprived households;     Water Quality Testing is conducted for installed water supply systems by the project and disinfection measures taken for microbial contamination.
Impact: Reduction in annual record of outbreaks and preparedness mechanism in place in coordination with local stakeholders.
Outcome: 150 local volunteers (FCHV and other) trained on water, sanitation and hygiene promotions and 40 government line agency officials trained in Sphere    5 small water projects/systems repaired and prepared for emergency period;    10 elevated hand pumps and latrines ready to be utilized during the emergency period;    3 rain water harvesting systems demonstrated in public places and are upscaled by communities and local authorities;    40 temporary latrines installed in deprived households and sensitized the locals on importance of sanitation facilities;    12,250 households received WASH supplies to be utilized during the period of emergency;    Water from repaired water systems tested and assured for drinkability (disinfected) and practised on regular basis;    200 households practices personnel hygiene practices and reduced the occurances of outbreaks;    147,000 ordinary people aware through education campaigns conducted through local media, volunteers, school systems and the sensitization level increased.

Project Title: Dissemination of Nepal National Water Plan and Water for Asian Cities Program through Media in Nepal

Outcome: Media started prioritizing WATSAN as an important issue

Project Title: Support to Mitigate the Negative Effects of High Food Prices on Local Rural Populations in Ten Districts
Input: Productive saftey nets with the aim of maintaining an improving agrricultural infrastructure in order to raise agricultural productivity  Support to increase staple food availabilty for extremely vulnerable households  Support farmers to adopt improved agriculturral practices through capacity building of the Farmers and the MOAC.  Monitoring system for food secrutiry and disaster risk management  Project implements in 10 distircts Baitadi, Bajhang, Darchula, Doti, Kailali, Sindhuli, Udyapur, Dolpa, Jumla,and Kalikot.
Outputs: Increased staple food availabitly for extremely vulnerable households,  Increased productivity through building of local capacity   Enhanced monitoring system for food secrurity and disaster management system of MOAC
Impact: The food security of 200944 farmining households enhanced,  The effects of soaring food prices mitigated through the provision of improved qaulity seeds of staple crops, cereals, vegitable and pulses
Outcome: To sustainably mitigate the impact of high food prices on 200944extremely vulnerable farming households in ten districts of Nepal  To increase the food secrurity of 200944 targeted vulnerable and rural housholds of ten districts in Eastern, Central, Mid-Western and Far western regions of Nepal
District: - Baitadi (Baitadi) - Bajhang (Chainpur) - Darchula (Darchula) - Dolpa (Dolpa) - Doti (Dipayal) - Jumla (Jumla Khalanga) - Kailali (Dhangadhi) - Kalikot (Kalikot) - Sindhuli (Sindhuli Madhi) - Udayapur (Gaighat)

Project Title: Promotion of Quality Cocoon Production and Processing Project
Input: The main activities are capacity building of farmers on mulberry plantation, cultivation, harvesting, post-harvesting, and market promotion of silk items and NGO capacity building to organize and support farmers.
Outputs: 1. The standardized technology for Quality Cocoon Production, Cocoon Quality Inspection and post cocoon harvest is established. 2. The capacity of Seri-farmers, Government technicians and NGO staff for promoting Quality Cocoon Production and Cocoon Inspection technology are strengthened. 3. The linkage among Governmental Agency, NGO and Private Entrepreneur are strengthened.
Impact: 1. The model for quality cocoon and silk production are replicated to other parts of Nepal 2. The income of seri-farmers and workers around seri-farmers is increased through the improvement
Outcome: Quality Cocoon Production in the target/model area is verified through capacity building and strengthening of the linkage among seri-farmers, Government technicians, NGOs, Private entreprenieurs and other stakeholders

Project Title: Technical support and dissemination of alternative fuel firewood and oil
Input: Main activites will be training, expert support and equipment support to produce bio-briquet.
Outputs: 1. Improved bio-briquet production in target area. 2. Cooking oven and bio-briquet burner improved. 3. Bio-briquet recognized in target area and its use promoted.
Impact: Increase of bio-briquet production and use in rural and urban areas.
Outcome: 1. Stable production of high quality bio-briquet. 2. Improved income of bio-briquet producers. 3. Use of bio-briquet promoted.

Project Title: Promoting Quality Eduction through Community Based School Management

Capacity Building of Water and Sanitation User’s Committee (WSUC) for Pro Poor Service Delivery in Selected Five Small Towns and Development of Management Information System for all Towns: Tulsipur, Birendranagar, Kohalpur, Attariya and Mahendranagar.
Input: Capacity building activities in various disciplines to WUSCs for sustainable delivery of safe drinking water supply and sanitation services;  Support for pro-poor service delivery by establishing modest financial mechanism;  Establishment of water quality monitoring system and improvement in water quality;  Development of Billing Software;   Initiate awareness program for private tap connection and toilet construction;  Develop MIS of all 29 towns.
Outputs: Increased technical and management capability of WUSCs for better service delivery;  Increased sanitation and water supply coverage for the poor through establishing mechanisms of Revolving Fund;  Improved environmental sanitation conditions through implementation of Community Led Total Sanitation (CLTS) programmes and awareness programmes;  Acceleration of private tap connection;  Establishment of water quality monitoring system;  Develop MIS of all 29 towns.
Impact: Sustainable pro poor service delivery by WUSCs
Outcome: Capacity of WUSCs in technical and management aspects has been enhanced and water and sanitation services are delivered to communities more efficiently and adequately;  Health and Hygiene conditions of the communities have improved through the utilization of revolving fund schemes to establish tap connection and sanitation facilities at the poor households also;  Poor and disadvantage communities will have access to improved drinking water and sanitation services with enhanced knowledge and capacity through CLTS and SLTS;  Water and sanitation services have reached as target set by the STWSSSP;  Water Quality Monitoring System operated and managed by community;  Sustainable functioning of water supply facilities installed by the project with improved water quality;  Management Information System (MIS) of all 29 towns developed and updated regularly to maintain database system for progress monitoring of the STWSSSP.
District: - Banke (Nepalgunj) - Dang Deukhuri (Ghorahi) - Kailali (Dhangadhi) - Kanchanpur (Mahendara Nagar) - Surkhet (Surkhet)

Project Title: Demonstration of Community Rain Water Recharge Techniques in Patan, Nepal
Input: Improvement of traditional pond recharge system 3 selected ponds namely Nhu Pukhu and Saptapatal Pukhu at Lagankhel in Lalitpur;   Installation of at least 20 community level recharge wells and pits;  Establishment of rain water harvesting demonstration site at Nhu Pukhu of Patan;  Capacity Building at municipal level, community level and household level.
Outputs: Establishment of Pond Management Committee;  Survey and Design for Establishing Pond Recharge System in Purnachandi Pond, Saptapatal Pond and Nhu Pukhu;  Establishment of Pond Recharge System in Purnachandi Pond;    Installation of Recharge Wells and Recharge Pits;  Installation of Pond Recharge System at Nayekhyo;    Establishment of the Rainwater Harvesting Demonstration Site at Central Zoo.
Impact: Upscaling of ground water recharge techniques
Outcome: Rate of groundwater recharge increased in selected locations through the established recharge pits;   Local people manage and utilize rainwater;   General mass are aware about RWH system through promotional activities and resource materials;   Research on the potential area for recharge conducted and the design of recharge pits on hand;   Municipal staff capacititated in RWH system.

Project Title: Integrating Water and Sanitation Services to Urban Poor Communities in two Municipalities of Nepal
Input: The project aims to support the following number of people of the poor urban settlements based on the poverty mapping report and field assessment of Kamalamai and Itahari Municipalities:   A total of 5 settlements in wards 11 and 12 with population of 3193 (623 households(HHs)) where more than 65% people are below the poverty line;  A total of 17 settlements of urban poor and squatter communities in four different wards with population of 911HHs.   The major activities are-   Based on the preparation and assessment of water, environmental sanitation and hygiene improvement plan, provide safe water, affordable adequate sanitation and hygiene education to the targeted people of Kamalamai and Itahari Municipalities;  Reduce the burden of collecting water, ensure equity of distribution, increase optimization of water use and reduce water borne diseases as well as increase dignity;  Increase the capacity of civil society groups and 2 municipalities to work together to effectively implement water and sanitation improvement plans and promote environmental sanitation;  Based on the lessons learnt, contribute in effective engagement and influencing municipal and central level urban water and sanitation programming and monitoring activities.
Outputs: Preparation of participatory water, sanitation and hygiene improvement plans for the selected communities of 2 municipalities;   Implementation of water and sanitation facilities that will support in improving the environmental health and sanitation situation and sanitation practices of the target communities;   The projects will also demonstrate good practices and technologies for replication in other municipal areas;  Reduction in the point prevalence rate of water-borne diseases and among target households by 15%;  Increased coverage of water and sanitation facilities resulting through increased awareness and capacities of both government and non-government actors to deliver services as per plans.
Impact: Institutionalize pro poor water and sanitation governance at municipal authorities
Outcome: Based on the preparation and assessment of water, environmental sanitation and Hygiene improvement plan, provide safe water, affordable adequate sanitation and hygiene education to following people of Kamalamai and Itahari Municipalities;  Reduce the burden of collecting water, ensure equity of distribution, increase optimization of water use and reduce water borne diseases;   Through the achievement of a sanitized urban environment and improved hygiene behaviour practices reduce public health risk and diseases, as well as increase dignity;   Increase the capacity of civil society groups and 2 Municipalities to work together to effectively implement water and sanitation improvements plans and promote environmental sanitation;  Based on the lessons learnt, contribute in effective engagement and influencing Municipal and central level urban water and sanitation programming and monitoring activities.

Project Title: TA 8173-NEP: Strengthening Public Management Capacity
Input: Enhancement of efficiency, transparency and integrity of public expenditures.    Fiscal discentralization and Good Governance.    Easy access of people to public goods and services
Outputs: Improved local budget and fiscal management.    Strengthening sub-national fiduciary risk management.    Enhancement of public procurement system.    Strengthening accountability.
Impact: Effectiveness of delivery of public goods and serveces in Nepal, especially at the local level will be improved.
Outcome: The efficiency, transparency and integrity of Nepal's public finance will be enhanced.

Project Title: TFD-10/NEP/003: Improving nutritional status of children by demonstrating kitchen garden model in schools and its vicinity, Palpa
Input: Community people will start vegetable and mushroom farming after technical and input support. There will be one kitchen garden in each family, not less than in 0.3 rapani (20 ropani=1 Ha) of land at household level and one common farm in leaseland in five ropani. There will be vegetable farming in around 20 ropani of land, small plastic house in each HH for mushroom farming and 1500 fingerlings will be intorduced in the poud.
Outputs: The expected out put of the project are as follows:      - Students and teachers of Laxmi school will be trained on kitchen gardening and nutrition   - 39 HHs of the community and students/techers of school will be trained on kitchen gardening and mushroom farming   - Vegetable farming (kitchen gardening) will be started in around 30 ropani land   - One combined learning plot will be established by the community   - Rain water harvesting pond will be constructed to help conserve water and to utilize for irrigation as well as for fish farming.   - revolving fund in the community will be established   - Nutrition status of the 92 school children and community people will be improved consuming various seasonal vegetables, including mushroom and also earn additional income by selling remaining products.
Impact: The overall impact of the project is to improve the nutritional status of the project community people.
Outcome: To trained Technical training on vegetable/kitchen gardening, Mushroom farming and fish including marketing.

Project Title: 51-11444001-KAT (Education) Improving literacy for sustainable development with particular focus on women and disadvantaged groups within the framework of LIFE
Input: Improving literacy for sustainable development with particular focus on women and disadvantaged groups within the framework of LIFE
Outputs: N°  Performance indicator(s)  (a maximum of three)  Means of verification  (data source) (Optional)  Programmed benchmark  (on basis of baseline data if available (1))      1  Capacity of CLC members strengthened         UNESCO progress reports, NFEC annual progress report     50 CLC members trained on CLC management and identified skills development         2  Reading habit of local community members enhanced  UNESCO progress reports, NFEC annual progress report     2500 community members benefit from 25 reading corners/libraries      3  Linkages between CLCs and CMCs established     UNESCO progress reports, NFEC annual progress report     10 CLCs and CMCs establish linkages in two selected districts.      (1) The baseline is to be indicated next to the benchmark in brackets.             Expected Result N°2:   Selected members of disadvantaged groups become functionally literate and learn appropriate livelihood skills for empowerment. NFEC improves coordination and partnership with literacy and non-formal education providers through advocacy and networking.        N°  Performance indicator(s)  (a maximum of three)  Means of verification  (data source) (Optional)  Programmed benchmark  (on basis of baseline data if available (1))      1  Number of persons acquired functional literacy skills       UNESCO progress reports and NFEC annual report  100 persons acquireed functional literacy skill      2  Coordination and partnership among literacy and NFE providers improved.     UNESCO progress reports and NFEC annual report  cordination and partnership enhansed with 30 literacy and NFE vproviders
Impact: Training of CLC management committee members and Social Mobilizers' enhanced their knowledge and understanding on CLC management, leadership, fund raising, IG activities, community mobilization etc. contributing to develop CLCs as potential venue for the delivery of NFE services and promotion of learning environment at community level.    Use of draft CLC management hand book in training and collaboration with NFEC contributed in finalizing the hand book, incorporating the feedbacks from the training. NFEC and other NGOs are using this hand book for the traing of CLC managers.    Strengthening CLCs in the management of libraries /reading corners develops their capacity on managing libraries/reading corners effectively and to develop the reading habit of community members, contributing to engage in lifelong learning and create a literate environment. The training package designed during the project to provide training on library management will be used to provide training to other CLCs.    Development of tri-lingual approach in literacy programme provides opportunity to illiterate adults from disadvantaged and linguistic minority groups to learn in their mother tongue (L1), opening their horizon to move towards learning their local dominant language (L2) and to national language( L3). This innovation is helpful in expanding literacy opportunity to the people from disadvantaged cast and ethnic groups to acquire literacy skills in local as well national language contributing in raising the level of literacy. This also enables neo- iterates to communicate to the local as well as broader community.     Events organized on the occasion of IML Day, WTS campaign and EFA GAW raise the level of awareness of parents, children, teachers, literacy facilitators and literacy graduates and improve partnership with government, NGOs and civil society organization, contributing to work together for achieving the goals of EFA.    Challenges/lessons learnt:     Developing materials in Tri-lingual approach pose considerable challenge in terms of human resources, especially at local level.    There is an enormous need of resource (human as well as financial) to develop capacity at all levels.    Application of knowledge and skills gained requires strong committeemen of participants and constant support from centre and field level offices.    Cost effectiveness and sustainability     Collaboration with NFEC and local NGOs in sharing the cost has contributed to the cost effectiveness and sustainability    Involvement of CLCs, NFEC, DEOs and local NGOs has developed ownership towards the programme, contributing to its sustainability
Outcome: Building capacity of CLC management committee members including Social Mobilizers enhances leadership, management and sustainability skills for the effective service delivery and promotion of learning environment at community level.     Building capacity of CLCs in the management of libraries /reading corners develops knowledge on managing effective libraries/reading corners at CLC level to provide better services to the community embers including neo literates.     Developing modality of tri-lingual approach in literacy programme strengthens the provision of basic education for ethnic minority people through relevant and comprehensive functional literacy programme. This underpins mother tongue, local language (different than mother tongue) and national language (different than mother tongue and local language) for being able to communicate to the local as well as broader community.     UNESCO's global initiative on Adult Learning Documentation and Information Network (ALADIN) contributes to develop networking among key governmental and non governmental organization including libraries for documentation and sharing knowledge to promote equitable access to appropriate learning and life skills in accordance with EFA goal 3.   Challenges/lessons learnt:     There is an enormous need of resource (human as well as financial) to develop capacity at all levels.    Application of knowledge and skills gained requires strong committeemen of participants and follow up support from centre and field level offices.    Collaboration with Department of Education and NFEC in sharing the cost has contributed to the cost effectiveness and sustainability    Involvement and CLCs has develop their capacity and ownership contributing to sustainability
Donor Agency: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

Project Title: 51-12400015-KAT (Education) Support Nat effort for assessing secondary education policy in light of School Sector Reform Prog (SSRP)
Input: Support National efforts for assessing secondary education policy in light of School Sector Reform Programme (SSRP)
Outputs: A study on secondary education conducted and strategies to improve access and participation of girls and disadvantaged groups proposed and discussed among policy makers and programme implementers.     Annual Strategic Implementation Plan (ASIP) and Status Report, Department of Education,   UNESCO progress reports     A study report produced and education officials at both central and regional levels informed of the findings and participated in the policy discussion               A study on secondary education conducted and strategies to improve access and participation of girls and disadvantaged groups proposed and discussed among policy makers and programme implementers.     Annual Strategic Implementation Plan (ASIP) and Status Report, Department of Education,   UNESCO progress reports     A study report produced and education officials at both central and regional levels informed of the findings and participated in the policy discussion               Number of persons including GFPs trained on inclusive education and gender within the framework of SSRP             ASIP and Status Report, UNESCO progress reports     250 persons trained      2  Number of advocacy materials produced and disseminated.     ASIP and Status Report, UNESCO progress reports     2 types of advocacy materials developed, produced and disseminated
Impact: A study on transition from primary to secondary education was undertaken to provide policy support to MOE. This is a part of UNESCO HQ's initiatives to prepare UNESCO policy briefs on secondary education. Key findings of this report will be shared among policy makers and programme implimentors to improve access and participation of girls and disadvantaged groups in secondary education.     In support of UNICEF the study report on Situation Analysis of Gender Responsive Budgeting in Education Sector was published. This study was undertaken jointly by MOE, UNICEF and UNESCO. A workshop was organized to disseminate the findings of the study to policy makers and practitioners     In partnership with DOE and UNICEF three days training to gender focal points was provided in five development region of the country. The training focused on promoting inclusive education and gender equality in school education.      Support provided to DOE, inclusive education section in to provide three days training on sign language and inclusive education to school teachers and education officials at district levels. National deaf association facilitated the training     Updated version of GENIA toolkit was translated into Nepali languages and distributed. Advocacy and dissemination of the GENIA toolkit were undertaken jointly with the government counterparts and UNGEI especially UNICEF and UNFPA.     In collaboration with the MOE, the National Planning Commissions and the University Grants Commissions of Nepal, a two days conference on higher education was organized. The contents of the conference included governance and management, financing, aces and equity and quality of higher education. Experts from IIEP- Paris and World Bank provided support.
Outcome: Progress     The study on transition from primary and secondary education enhanced the understanding of policy makers and programme implementers' to improve policies and strategies for increased acess and participation of girls and disadvantaged groups in secondary education. The study indentified lack of indicators in relation to measuring the progress on transition from primary to secondary education.    The study report on situation analysis of Gender Responsive Budgeting in Education Sector provided insight to the MOE in gender responsive planning and implementation of their programme activities    Capacity building of gender focal points will enhance their knowledge and skills to ensure gender responsive planning and implementation of programme.    Training on inclusive education and sign language to teachers and education officials provided orientation on newly developed sign languages and different aspect of inclusive education, contributing to improve teaching learning at schools.    Dissemination of gender toolkit has enhanced has understanding and knowledge among gender focal points, education officials, NGOs and civil society organizations on gender related issues and programming through gender lens.    The conference on higher education provided inputs to MOE for the development of a comprehensive higher education policy in Nepal.   Challenges/Lessons learnt;     Frequent transfers of trained Gender Focal Points at central and district levels have adverse effects on the effective implementation of the programme and promotion of gender related activities     It is difficult to implement the findings and recommendations of studies due to lack of capacity and slow systemic reform process. Reaching schools to improve teaching learning is a huge challenge that requires sustained efforts.     Involvement of relevent organizations contributues to reach broader audiences in the promotion of inclusive education and gender equality.   Cost Effectiveness and Sustainability    Collaboration with Department of Education and UNICEF in sharing the cost has contributed to the cost effectiveness and sustainability.
Donor Agency: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

Expected Result N°2:   MOE have developed a national framework on equivalency programme in the context of SSRP and have tried out an alternative model for the support of out-of-school and drop-out children to achieve UBE        N°  Performance indicator(s)  (a maximum of three)  Means of verification  (data source) (Optional)  Programmed benchmark  (on basis of baseline data if available (1))      1  National framework and alternative model for EP developed.           National framework on EP, modular package, UNESCO progress reports  A national framework on EP and one alternative model for out-of-school and drop-out children developed.
Impact: Provided support to MoE for the translation and adaptation of an Advocacy Kit for Promoting Multilingual Education: Including the Excluded into Bhojpuri language. The kit is published and distributed for wider sharing and advocacy.    A Memorandum of Cooperation (MOC) established among UNESCO, UNICEF, Save the Children and the Embassy of Israel (MAHSAV) with a view to enhance capacity of education officials and ECCE providers, assist in materials development and improvement of quality ECCE services in Nepal.    The brochure and programme of the world conference on ECCE translated and disseminated for advocacy and awareness raising.    International days (International Literacy Day, International Peace Day, World HIV and AIDS Day, World Teacher's Day, etc.) celebrated. The ASPNet Nepal, the Education Journalist Group (EJG) and the Nepal Teacher Union played significant roles while celebrating these days.
Outcome: Continuous advocacy of Multilingual education improved understanding of key policy makers & MLE practiceners on MLE to include in their action plan.    This booklet provides brief information about the list of the published materials on language issues, their authors and annotations
Donor Agency: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

Project Title: 51-13443003-KAT (Education) Supporting national efforts for integrating education for sustainable development in a sector wide framework
Input: Supporting national efforts for integrating education for sustainable development in a sector wide framework

Impact: The Education for All Mid Decade Assessment (EFAMDA) has highlighted the needs for better co-ordination, evidence-based planning and monitoring the progress and achievements by identifying disparities at national and local levels. Furthermore, the School Sector Reform Programme 2009-2015 aims at tracking key results in the area of school education especially for girls, children from disabilities and disadvantaged and marginalized groups. For this, focus is given for data analysis and results-based monitoring at all levels. In this regard, the UNESCO Kathmandu Office will continue to work with the Ministry of Education/Department of Education in the area of EMIS and education and federalism.
Outcome: Information generated by consolidated report 2009-2010 provides time-series, disaggregated data for tracking progress and achievements on EFA in light of the school sector reform plan 2009-2015. Such information inform policy makers and development partners for evidence based planning and monitoring for achieving the goals of EFA.   Training of key education officials on EPSSiM contributed to track budge and monitor financial expenditures aiming at equitable achievements   Capacity building of MOE officials and teacher enhanced their knowledge and understanding on school record keeping and management contributing to improve the quality of data and their proper use.   Involvement of key education stakeholders in policy dialogue in respect to education and federalism enhanced their capacity to inform debate on key thematic areas for improved delivery of education under the federal system   Challenges: Use of information in evidence based planning, and management of education still remains a challenge. Transmission of skills and knowledge from central to local level (District, School and community) demands adequate human and financial resources.   Lesson learned: Collaboration with Department of education has contributed to cost effective ness and sustainability
Donor Agency: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

Project Title: 55-11140028-KAT (Communication & Information) Developing free, independent and pluralistic media based on MDIs
Input: Increase Awareness and Promotion of Freedom of Expression through World Press Freedom Days and translation of standard UNESCO's publications in Nepali
Outputs: N°  Performance indicator(s)  (a maximum of three)  Means of verification  (data source) (Optional)  Programmed benchmark  (on basis of baseline data if available (1))      1  Awareness of freedom of expression   and access to information  Adoption of both the model curricula and MDIs by local national actors, policy makers, UN agencies and media development organizations as tools to ensure successful result-oriented coordination in media development work.  World Press Freedom Day organized twice (2010 and 2011);   Information and training material on freedom of expression and access to information (2) translated and distributed across the country.      2  Acceptance of professional and ethical   standards and of self regulatory media   accountability systems.  Adoption of both the model curricula and MDIs by local national actors, policy makers, UN agencies and media development organizations as tools to ensure successful result-oriented coordination in media development work.  Professional and ethical standards reinforced across the country in close collaboration with media and their associations;   Publications available electronically in Nepali on UNESCO Kathmandu's website.      (1) The baseline is to be indicated next to the benchmark in brackets.
Impact: The main focus has been introducing the concepts of MDI and the Model Curricula to Nepal. Both were translated to Nepali and 500 copies were printed and distributed to universities, colleges, media organizations, government and media professionals. In addition, a national workshop was organized in July for the Model Curricula.   The participants of the Curricula workshop welcomed the Curricula in a positive note and agreed that the use of the curricula could boost the country's media sector. The consultation on 19 and 20 July 2010 brought together representatives of journalism training institutions and trainers and experts in journalism education from several universities in Nepal.   Participants identified issues and concerns that may affect the adaption of the model curricula. A lack of qualified teachers to teach courses listed in the curricula was a common concern. Key stakeholders in the area of media education in Nepal will now work on adaptation strategies, including examining curricula adaptability in terms of courses, curricula-infrastructure, and teaching and learning resources.   UNESCO will work closely with Tribuvan University, Kathmandu University and the Press Institute of Nepal to facilitate the adaptation of the curricula. Support for the adaptation will be applied for fromIPDC.    The World Press Freedom Day was celebrated in Nepal by organizing three workshops in Kathmandu (18 May), and Biratnagar and Nepalgunj (20 May). The events that all came under the motto Dialogue on Freedom of Information: The Right to Know were initiated by the UNESCO Office in Kathmandu and organized in close cooperation with OHCHR Nepal, the Nepal Press Institute (NPI), the Federation of Nepali Journalists (FNJ), the National Information Commission of Nepal and other media organizations.   Participants in the events in Kathmandu, Biratnagar and Nepalgunj highlighted the importance of freedom of information as a tool for empowerment, its role to enable protection and achievement of other rights and its contribution to transparency, accountability and the fight against corruption   Participants also stressed the importance of access to reliable information, the provision of accurate and unbiased information to citizens and the role of media as a platform for public debate and interaction between civil society and policy-makers.
Outcome: Global Priority Gender Equality expected result(s):   Gender perspectives in media content promoted through UNESCO-supported media training  UNESCO-supported training programmes, especially safety training for journalists, offered on an equal basis to women  Member States supported in creating an enabling environment for free and independent media and in building media capacity that avoids stereotyping women  Member States supported in the application of gender-sensitive indicators for media  Women's involvement in conflict resolution, peace-building, and reconstruction broadened through better access to information
Donor Agency: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

Project Title: 55-11340016-KAT (Communication & Information) Foster editorial independence and quality programming in community media and public service broadcasting
Input: Foster editorial independence and quality programming in community media and public service broadcasting
Outputs: N°  Performance indicator(s)  (a maximum of three)  Means of verification  (data source) (Optional)  Programmed benchmark  (on basis of baseline data if available (1))      1  Public service broadcasting based upon   editorial independence facilitating access to   information and knowledge, civic education   and good governance.  Adoption of regulatory framework conducive to editorially independent public service broadcasters (e.g. Agenda for change; MDI etc.)  In Nepal: regulatory framework conducive to editorially independent public service broadcasters adopted; quality of journalism enhanced in the country: PSB accountability systems strengthened
Impact: Preliminary Study:  An initial study focusing on the current status of the broadcasting sector of Nepal was conducted and a background paper entitled 'Current Status, Feasibility and the Way Ahead of PSB in Nepal' was prepared. The background paper is an outcome of the preliminary research study of the existing situation of broadcasting sector with regard to Public Service Broadcasting (PSB) in Nepal. The paper takes account of substantive comments received from experts and stakeholders of broadcasting reforms. The research is focused on identifying the current situation of broadcasting sector including contemporary trends and problems. The background paper has made efforts to analyze the status, opportunities, challenges and way forward of PSB in Nepal.   The aim of the paper is to contribute to stakeholders' understanding of the sector to facilitate the process of outlining PSB Bill in Nepal. The paper highlights some of the key challenges and feasibilities of PSB in Nepal, presenting extensive information and data to ease the development of theme papers on policy, structure and content of PSB in line with the Media Development Indicators (MDIs) developed by UNESCO. The paper is a gateway of the project 'Outlining National Policy for Public Service Broadcasting (PSB) in Nepal'.   Meetings with Stakeholders:  meeting with parliamentarians, concerned government officials, i.e., representatives from Ministry of Information and other government's bodies and State broadcasters (Nepal Television and Radio Nepal) have been organized. The consultative meeting with individual experts was also organized to ensure their engagement in the process.   National Thematic Workshop:  Freedom Forum brought together 65 persons including media professionals, educators, CA member, senior government officials and other media stakeholders in the workshop on January 24 to discuss and draw inputs for PSB in Nepal. The workshop based on background research paper entitled 'Status, Feasibilities and Way Ahead of PSB in Nepal' was held in Nepal Television (NTV) Hall engaging Federation of Nepali Journalists (FNJ), Chapter of NTV as a key stakeholder. A power point presentation was discussed among the participants and their inputs and deliberations were recorded to incorporate them while drafting bill and policies on PSB. The workshop was successful in fostering a debate and sensitizing various stakeholders including state and non-state actors. The workshop was concluded with a conclusion that all the stakeholders will leverage the effort of introducing PSB in Nepal.   Theme Papers Development:   The task of developing theme papers on the areas of structure, content and policy of PSB has been accomplished. A paper on structure was framed by Radio Nepal Director Tapanath Shukla while community radio activist Raghu Mainali developed paper on content part of PSB. Freedom Forum has developed another paper on PSB policy. The theme papers have addressed all major aspects, required state policy, structure and mechanism and content of PSB. The papers will be presented in the second workshop, which will finalize the recommendations for outlining policy for PSB.
Outcome: Global Priority Gender Equality expected result(s):   Member States supported in creating an enabling environment for free and independent media and in building media capacity that avoids stereotyping women  National information policies formulated and implemented in a gender-inclusive manner
Donor Agency: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

Media Development Indicators;   Nepal's new constitution;   Content of IPDC's projects;   Outcome of MDIs assessment, workshops and roundtables.  At least 4 IPDC projects submitted, of which 2 are community media projects, and inputs to the country programming in line with the media development indicators; country programming and project documents indicate a discerning pro-poor approach to community media and high level of gender sensitivity on media development issues.
Impact: - The MDI process was launched in Nepal in September with a national workshop with Wijayananda Jayaweera from the headquarters introducing the concept to the Nepali media professionals. In the workshop, media professionals in Nepal welcomed the planned assessment of the country's media landscape, when they met on 28 September 2010 in Kathmandu. Participants recommended that the MDI process be used in an innovative partnership approach involving national, regional and international collaboration. This inclusive approach will ensure that the varied aspects of media development are represented and that the best expertise available is brought into the development of the media in Nepal. KAT Office is currently in the process of preparing for the ToR and creating the Steering Committee in order for the assessment to take place in 2011.   - KAT Office submitted two proposals to IPDC, one on establishing a community radio, and another one on introducing the Journalism model curricula in Nepal through the Tribhuvan University.  Progress achieved against the expected results of the activity including challenges/lessons learnt, cost-effectiveness and sustainability as of: - The MDI process has started slowly, and will only kick off in 2011. However, already in 2010 some important background work was done, in terms of involving the local media community in the process. By organizing the national workshop, and by inviting local media experts in the steering committee, we believe we can create sustainable

Project Title: 55-22404028-KAT (Communication & Information) Developing strategies for using ICTs in knowledge acquisition and sharing
Input: Developing strategies for using ICTs in knowledge acquisition and sharing
Outputs: N°  Performance indicator(s)  (a maximum of three)  Means of verification  (data source) (Optional)  Programmed benchmark  (on basis of baseline data if available (1))      1  Quality and impact of teaching and learning processes through ICT's in CMCs and ICT's used to foster training of facilitators in CLCs.  Number of trainings and joint activities implemented at CLC/CMCs level.  Effective integration of ICTs in processes of teaching and/or learning in at least 4 districts; minimum 1 community of practice established.      2  Enhanced skills and knowledge of local people in using ICT tools through the use of CLCs and CMCs facilities.  Number of programmes on literacy, life-skills.  Effective integration of ICT tools in the local community through literacy and life-skills learning programmes.
Impact: Nepal is going through an important period of democracy building with the Constitution making-process. Thus, it is crucial to have a well-informed population with access to accurate and independent information from diverse sources, with an understanding of what decision-making processes are happening around it, and most importantly with a voice. Although the quality and diversity of media are increasing in more populated areas, this is not true in remote areas. Community media centres (CMCs) and learning centres (CLCs) are important in the fight to support democracy and reduce poverty through different sources of information, particularly in isolated rural areas. A network between such entities could strengthen their impact and role within communities. If these stations are to provide vital communications and learning services, fulfilling the challenge of fostering and developing a transition to democracy building, they must have the appropriate skills and resources and a solid network.   UNESCO Kathmandu will establish again its strong intersectoral character between CI and ED. This activity fulfills the need of promoting and fostering strategies for increasing the use of ICTs in knowledge acquisition and sharing in Nepal, in particular through the CI-led intersectoral platform on Fostering ICT enhanced learning.   Modalities of action:  Building Bridges is an activity which has already been explored during the biennium 2008-2009 and needs to be taken forward in the next biennium. Its aim is to increase the capacity of CMCs in Tansen, Budhanagar, Lumbini and Madonpokhara and create new CMCs in existing Community Radios of Kapilvastu and Janakpur in order to provide opportunities for marginalised communities to be associated with local CLCs and participate jointly and through a sound community network to the ongoing democratic and peace-building process in Nepal.  Modalities of actions include:  1. Strengthen communication capacities of community media and learning centres primarily in rural areas, focusing on skills-building training for CMCs practitioners and CLCs members.  2. Increase operating links among CMCs and CLCs through programmes concerning current peace-building and democracy-related issues. The joint CMC-CLC network will help communities sharing experiences between community multimedia and learning centres, and strategizing means for communication, information, awareness and participation. CLCs will be able to learn about how CMCs can be used creatively and CMCs will learn how to link community media to existing learning centres. CLCs promote learning through grassroots facilities and activities, but often lack of media facilities and multimedia applications to support them. CMCs can combine traditional and new technologies - for example radio and television with internet and CD-ROMs - to enrich and extend the impact of information and communication at the local level using also existing CLCs. This is why capacity building and closer integration among these centres are critical.   Target groups:  Primary target groups of this project are socially marginalized members of the communities in selected districts (Janajatis, Dalits, Women, Limbuwans, Madhesi, and Muslims).
Outcome: An 8-day training on digital library management was organized for 20 representatives from CMCs and CLCs. The training focused on the Greenstone Digital Library Software, covering also areas related to establishing websites and online libraries.
Donor Agency: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

Impact: Developing mother tongue based literacy materials in Awadhi and Maithili had contributed for accelerating mother tongue based literacy programme in order to ensure literacy for all.     Involvement of local experts to develop mother tongue based literacy materials contributes in contextualizing cultural elements that are relevant and motivating to the learners contributing to their active participation and improved learning.     7 days long intensive training followed by 3 days refresher training of literacy facilitators ensures effective implementation of literacy programme at community level     Use of mother tongue based literacy materials contributes to raise awareness and develop interest among community members to learn and improve their reading, writing and numeracy skills.    Challenges/lesson learnt:     The project demands for collaboration with various stakeholders to get their support, comments and feedback. Organizing consultations with key stakeholders has provided opportunity to share and disseminate information to them.     Frequent transfer of key education officials both at central and district level affected the coordination of project activities, delaying the decision making in the selection of project sites, identification of authors and local partner NGOs     The constant development of capacity at both national and sub-national levels, development of mother tongue based literacy materials, imparting literacy through mother tongue, evidence-based planning and monitoring and involvement of local people through community-based organizations such as CLCs are key to achieving sustainability in non-formal education and literacy related programmes.
Outcome: A basic literacy packages in Maithili languages was developed and being pilot tested.    Reference materials for the basic and post literacy courses in Awadhi language are being developed.    Total of seven days training was conducted to 50 literacy facilitators of two districts Dhanusa and Rupandehi.    Capacity building CLC management committee members and Social Mobilizers will enhance in the effective planning and service delivery.    50 classes are being piloted in two project sites enrolling more than 1000 learners, the majority being disadvantaged, lower caste groups and women.    International Literacy Day celebrated with various programmes

Project Title: 54-11200083-KAT (Culture) Supporting national efforts for effective implementation of the WH Convention in Nepal
Input: Supporting national efforts for effective implementation of the WH Convention in Nepal
Outputs: N°  Performance indicator(s)  (a maximum of three)  Means of verification  (data source) (Optional)  Programmed benchmark  (on basis of baseline data if available (1))      1  Improved management of World Heritage Sites, particularly Kathmandu and Lumbini  Reports of site authorities, UNESCO progress Reports  Site managers/authorities from 2 cultural heritage sites and 2 natural heritage sites      2  Improved World Heritage periodic reporting processes  Periodic reports, UNESCO progress reports  Site managers/national authorities for cultural heritage and natural heritage sites
Impact: The two cultural and two natural World Heritage Sites in Nepal face various challenges. One is weak coordination and lack of necessary communication among relevant line authorities whose inappropriate decisions make it difficult to achieve the objectives of the convention. Site level authorities are not sufficiently able to respond to practical problems in respect to managing the WH sites. This is worse in some cases due to uncertain management under the local trust without sufficient monitoring from a higher government level. There is also no credible mechanism that bridges development plans with conservation approaches.   In this regard, the UNESCO Kathmandu Office will support the State Party in building capacity and cooperation among relevant departments/authorities and site managers by reviewing existing development and conservation management plans, operational processes and monitoring systems, training in institutional and legal aspects of management that deal with WH site, with emphasis on challenges posed by development. The major components of this activity would be as follows:     Operationalizing the Integrated Management Plan developed for Kathmandu Valley World Heritage Site: reviving the Coordinative Working Committee, and site-monitoring system as well as integrating disaster risk and tourism management components into the IMP, continuing of appropriate training of site managers alongside municipal officers     Completion of the integrated management plan for the Lumbini World Heritage Site: this includes review of the existing institutional, legal and economic arrangements for necessary amendment and augmentation (leading to revision of the Lumbini Development Trust Act) in parallel with project activities on the site in cooperation with the Lumbini Development Trust (LDT) and the Department of Archaeology; it would include finalization of the Statement of OUV, minor modification of the boundaries which is also linked to the result of archaeological investigation to be funded by JFIT; establishment of a cooperation agreement with the Asian Development Bank and the Government of Nepal regarding the implementation of the Kenzo Tange Master Plan and restructuring and capacity-building of the LDT     Technical assistance to the Nepalese authorities to hold national expert group meetings for natural and cultural heritage sites for the review of WH Convention implementation in the country, particularly as part of the periodic reporting process in the Asia-Pacific Region, and to involve both sides in establishing tentative lists (mixed sites, tentative list for natural sites) and to secure useful exchanges of experience, particularly from the national parks sector   Women's participation will be encouraged within the process. Cooperation with relevant ministries, line authorities and concerned expert national agencies like IUCN will be enhanced to encourage them play their respective roles (advisory, monitoring or consultative or executive as per respective specialization) during planning and implementation of programs/projects within WH boundaries and surroundings. Exchange of experience with World Heritage site managers in the region will be encouraged through effective cooperation with the UNESCO offices in the sub-region and region.
Outcome: 1) Regular monitoring of WHproperties in close cooperation with site management to ensure appropriate implementation of the WHConvention which included:  1.1 Consultation with communities, park management and Department of National Parks and Wildlife Conservation (DNPWC) to address the issues of electricity supply and road access for Madi region between Chitwan National Park (North) separated by Reu River and Indian border (South);  1.2 Briefing of UNESCO's actions to the Minister of Culture, Department of Archaeology (DoA), Lumbini Development Trust (LDT) and Ambassadors of China, Japan, Sri Lanka, Myanmar and Thailand in view of brining coherent action in and around Lumbini;  1.3 Coordination with ADB country office to ensure adequate monitoring of WHproperty during implementation of ADB project; for its project component in Lumbini (whose implementation will start next year), ADB has envisaged to establish a WH Site Management Plan Review Panel consisting of LDT, UNESCO and DoA and agreed to communicate UNESCO on project progress including UNESCO's involvement on its loan review missions, which takes twice a year;  1.4 Required guidance and alert to the concerned authorities on the WH processes and requirements through meetings and information sharing, especially with regard to the State Party's reporting need about any intention or plan to undertake or to authorize in an area protected under the Convention major restorations or new constructions affecting the outstanding universal value of the property;   (2) Preparation and Implementation of Integrated Management Plan (IMP) for World Cultural Heritage properties:  2.1 Kathmandu Valley WH property:  2.1.1 The established management plan has ascertained periodic on-site meetings of Coordinative Working Committee (CWC) among site managers of 7 monument zones under the chair of the DoA that discusses issues and reviews action-plans;  2.1.2 For effective and sustainable implementation of the IMP, close monitoring of issues and improvement in the existing processes including awareness among line ministries/departments through discussions/workshop and integration of components such as tourism and disaster risk management are essential sub-sets, in which our technical assistance shall continue;  2.2 Lumbini World Heritage property:  2.2.1 IMP preparation process started in 2008-2009 had led better understanding of the site status, critical issues and required actions pertaining to site management and conservation, however, pending completion of the plan with necessary frameworks (management structure/coordination mechanism) establishment and its adoption at national level, to which our technical assistance to the state party will be strengthened through JFIT project, a 3-year project (2010-2013) including activities related to archaeological research, conservation of archaeological remains as well as review of Kenzo Tange plan for the Sacred Garden;  2.2.2 Additional appropriation to the regular budget was made to conduct a study on the Sacred Garden in view of supporting the preparation of an Interim Plan for the Sacred Garden. Contract with potential experts/institution will be established;   (3) Capacity building of cultural and natural heritage site managers through:  3.1 Consultation with and sharing of information to relevant ministries and its departments/authorities, on-site direct interaction and status review with site level management;  3.2 Periodic meeting of the recently established World Heritage Site Managers Forum (WHsmF) consisting of site managers from all 4 WH properties to raise awareness about various useful WH processes and implementation requirements;  3.3 Sub-regional Dehradun workshop where 2 national focal points from DNPWC and DoA were trained in preparing the retrospective Statement of Outstanding Universal Value (SOUV) and periodic reporting for the implementation of the WH Convention in Asia and the Pacific (under WHC support and Kathmandu office close coordination);  3.4 WHsmF next meeting in July will be disseminating outcome of the sub-regional workshop to all site managers and necessary technical assistance will be provided to enable the national focal points to drive the above process;  3.5 A follow-up national workshop in August 2010 (assistance to DoA and DNPWC) to hold further consultations among site authorities (entities: municipalities/trust/village development committee), national focal points and site managers to draft the retrospective Statements of Outstanding Universal Value (SOUV: August 2010-January 2011) for all 4 properties and to respond the Periodic Reporting questionnaires (Section I and II: August 2010 - July 2011) as well as to help reporting the progress to the WHC on a regular basis;   (4) Publication/Translation work:  4.1 Translation of Operational Guidelines into Nepali language will be executed upon receiving the amended version after adoption by the World Heritage Committee at its 34th Session in Brasilia;  4.2 Production of an easy to understand comic style information leaflet (in Nepali language targeting literate and illiterate community) on WH properties in Nepal aimed at explaining the value of WH movement and its impact on the day to day life is under discussion with respective site managers;  4.3 As a part of publication series on outcomes and lessons learnt during various WH training workshops (Hampi 2008, Kathmandu 2009, Galle early 2010), the 2nd series on WH Site Managers Experience Sharing Workshop with special focus on Kathmandu Valley World Heritage site is under preparation and publication is foreseen early next year;  4.4 Few publications in plan have to be further discussed with concrete actions for next year;     Progress achieved against the expected results of the activity including challenges/lessons learnt, cost-effectiveness and sustainability as of:   As a result of regular monitoring of the properties, though at a very slow speed than required, reporting about happenings and development/infrastructure projects in plan or on-going in and around the world heritage sites from respective site managements is being done, allowing opportunity to discuss the possible impact and required assistance with the World heritage centre. Due to very limited governmental officials engaged in world heritage related issues, as well as feeble inter-sectoral coordination among governing bodies, weakness of heritage management exists, which is a challenge to ensure timely reporting. More efforts are being invested to aware them of the operational guidelines and processes;     In Kathmandu Valley, the established IMP works as useful tool with increased awareness about World Heritage protection among limited line-miniseries, although needs improvement to ensure adequate monitoring and reporting. In Lumbini, there is increasing understanding of the processes among management staff, but real result awaits the establishment of required management framework, its adoption and implementation;     Increased site managers' awareness and enhanced cooperation through frequent interaction meetings/ consultations aimed at their capacity improvement in World Heritage processes, but national level training workshop is important for wider awareness among decision making levels. Relevant publications production and dissemination is in plan, to aware general public also. There is also need to strengthen executive roles of relevant departments in heritage management areas to ensure operational level coordination and awareness;     Besides above, broader issues impacting upon World Heritage properties such as uncontrolled industrial expansion, pollution, increased poaching in natural sites etc are matters of monitoring beyond present capacity in absence of appropriate arrangement at inter-ministerial level for coordination to ensure efficient reporting and action taking;    Timely drafting of retrospective Statement of Outstanding Value, improved maps in response to retrospective inventory as well as improved national response to the periodic reporting questionnaires is expected after the national workshop and its continued monitoring (August 2010 - July 2011);     Collaborative efforts with relevant departments or partners should be explored given the very limited resources (both human and financial) of the Culture Unit.
Donor Agency: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

Project Title: 54-12200039-KAT (Culture) Support for strengthening national policies for safeguarding Nepal's intangible cultural heritage in the spirit of 2003 Convention
Input: Support for strengthening national policies for safeguarding Nepal's intangible cultural heritage in the spirit of 2003 Convention
Outputs: N°  Performance indicator(s)  (a maximum of three)  Means of verification  (data source) (Optional)  Programmed benchmark  (on basis of baseline data if available (1))      1  Ratification of the Convention  Deposit of Instrument of Ratification   Policy drafted to implement the Convention   Report of the relevant ministry     2003 Convention ratified and policy adopted (Baseline - not ratified)      2  Number of related government departments/ divisions setting up required institutional arrangements for safeguarding of Intangible Cultural Heritage in the spirit of the Convention  Operational framework of related departments and their reports        (1) The baseline is to be indicated next to the benchmark in brackets.             Expected Result N°2:   Capacities and networking of national, local institutions and their specialized personnel strengthened for the safeguarding of intangible cultural heritage in Nepal, prioritizing heritage at risk        N°  Performance indicator(s)  (a maximum of three)  Means of verification  (data source) (Optional)  Programmed benchmark  (on basis of baseline data if available (1))      1  Numbers of specialized agencies and civil society organizations identified involving in various levels of intangible cultural heritage (ICH) protection and general classification of preliminary nature of ICH domain prevails in the country  Review report of present state of knowledge on intangible cultural heritage of Nepal and evaluation report        2  Number of identified specialized agencies and civil society organizations participating actively in the network established for the development of standards and methodologies for inventorying and documentation  Workshop proceedings, UNESCO progress report
Impact: (1) Assistance to the ratification of the 2003 Convention  1.1 Few distinct pro-activities of 2008-09 (3-day event to valorize Dalit culture on "Music of the Gods: The intangible cultural heritage of Nepal's musical castes"; dissemination of convention texts to all Constitutional Assembly 601 members that secured cabinet endorsement on the proposal to ratify the convention in 2009; then translation and publication of booklets comprising both English and translated Nepali texts) and its early 2010 dissemination including relevant information materials obtained from the HQ to the Ministry of Federal Affairs, Constituent Assembly, Parliamentary Affairs and Culture(MOFACAPA&C) were some assistance provided that led to the successful presentation of the agenda in the Nepalese Legislative Parliament that approved the proposal to ratify the convention in January 2010;  1.2 Assistance provided to the ministry in formal ratification process through monitoring and guidance in the official deposition of the instrument including bridging among ministries involved (Ministry of Law and Justice and Foreign Affairs) for necessary documentation;   (2) Advocacy for the promotion of the 2003 Convention  2.1 Consultation meeting held with the culture secretary of the ministry in view of discussing the actions that the ministry is undertaking to implement the Convention, meantime inviting them to venture a joint awareness raising workshop for the general implementation of the Convention;  2.2 On-going consultation with the New-Delhi cluster office and HQ for necessary technical guidance and support materials in view of organizing the awareness raising workshop early September 2010 is shaping its way;  2.3 Commissioning a "working paper" by a relevant local expert in view of presenting the possible framework for the administration, preservation and information management of intangible heritage at different levels in Nepal within the framework of implementing the 2003 Convention is soon to undertake to be made available for discussion during the September workshop;  2.4 Necessary advocacy for the promotion of the Convention is being provided through applicable means such as during meetings with relevant partners, presentation at training workshop, that the Ministry of Federal Affairs, Constituent Assembly, Parliamentary Affairs and Culture is recently conducting in respect to preparing the intangible heritage inventory etc;  2.5 Further dissemination of Convention booklets in English and Nepali texts and information kit (which is under re-printing process jointly with the New Delhi office) will be underway for outreaching wider intangible heritage managers, preservers/practitioners and owners etc;   (3) Assistance to the implementation of the 2003 Convention  Given the very diverse and vast scope of this subject, after the outcome of the awareness raising workshop and based on available resources (fund and regional/international resource person), following task would need to be strategically undertaken as applicable within the 2003 Convention framework in building a common understanding for the administration, preservation and information management of the intangible heritage:  3.1 Basic framework preparation for national inventory making: framework for identification(by nature, by context, or by else) and defining various elements of Intangible Cultural Heritage (criteria that define the inherent values and forms a basis for categorization/classification), parameters for assessing the state of conservation/endangerment (of processes, linkages, knowledge and practices, than end-products) and indicative nature of actions for its maintenance/revival/preservation through periodic review of the state of knowledge building upon the study initiated in 2009 and extensive discussion for validity and appropriateness;  3.2 Governance of the intangible heritage:  - Assisting the State Party in view of establishing a management system/ institutional arrangement that defines a administrative framework governing/coordinating the related tasks, especially to carry the process of preparing a national inventory which is a complex, exhausting task as well as to help defining the extent of governance;  - Assisting in networking (wiki-tool as applicable) of necessity groups/ institutions/ experts and relevant training/capacity building in view of strengthening institutional capacities in national inventory making, periodic review of research and studies in the subject that would ultimately facilitate the listing process as well as relevant policy elaboration.
Outcome: ER 6: Member States' capacities to safeguard intangible cultural heritage for the development of the concerned communities strengthened  ER 7: Awareness of the importance of safeguarding intangible cultural heritage increase
Donor Agency: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

Project Title: TCP/NEP/3303-Improving national carp seed production system in Nepal

Conduct surveys and hold stakeholder workshops as necessary.   5. Perform project-related financial, economic, social, poverty reduction and institutional analyses   6. Prepare a small-scale area development program for project-affected areas   Conduct stakeholder workshops and surveys as necessary.
