Development of Local Authorities in promoting Public Health institutionalization of good practice through healthy settings. 6. Identification of public health problem and guidance for prevention. 7. Capacity building for food borne diseases surveillance, strengtheing of prevention and control systems, and food hazard monitoring. 8. Increase national capacity to set and update national policy and regulations, and to interact with international food standard processes (CODEX), WTO (SPS) and emergency (AI).
Outputs: 1. Evidence-based assessments, norms and guidance on priority environmental health risks associated with Water Sanitation and Hygiene prepared or updated and MDGs monitored. 2. Evidence-based assessments done on environmental burden of disease and guidance prepared for mitigation.   3. Promotion of public health in urban setting enhanced through capacity building and networking.   4. Health sector capacity enhanced to identify , adopt and prevent public health problems resulting from climate change   5. Coordination mechanism to improve capacity in the area of food safety, food security and nutrition strengthened   6. To support capacity building, awareness and operational research activities through adaptation of global norms and guidelines to prevent, assess, monitor and respond to all forms of malnutrition in an integrated way   7. National nutrition program strengthened through implementation of national Food Based Dietary Guidelines and a strengtehned implementation of the IYCF strategy   8. Improved capacities for monitoring food hazards and risks   9. Support knowledge management and development of appropriate regulatory framework for food safety.
Impact: Promote a healthier environment, intensify primary prevention and influence public policies in all sectors so as to address the root causes of environmental threats to health. To improve nutrition, food safety and food security throughout the life-course and in support of public health and sustainable development.
Outcome: 1. Evidence based assessments made, and norms and standards formulated and updated on major environmental hazards to health (e.g., poor air quality, chemical substances, electromagnetic fields, radon, poor quality drinking water and wastewater reuse)          2. Technical support and guidance provided to Member States for the implementation of primary prevention interventions that reduce environmental hazards to health, enhance safety and promote public health, including in specific settings (e.g. workplaces, homes or urban settings) and among vulnerable population groups (e.g. children).          3. Evidence based policies, strategies and recommendations developed, and technical support provided to Member States for identifying, preventing and tackling public health problems resulting from climate change.          4. Partnerships and alliances formed, leadership built and coordination and networking developed with all stakeholders at country, regional and global levels, in order to promote advocacy and communication, stimulate intersectoral actions, increase investment in nutrition, food-safety and food-security interventions, and develop and support a research agenda.          5. Norms, including references, requirements, research priorities, guidelines, training manuals and standards, produced and disseminated to Member States in order to increase their capacity to assess and respond to all forms of malnutrition, and zoonotic and non-zoonotic foodborne diseases, and to promote healthy dietary practices.          6. Capacity built and support provided to target Member States for the development, strengthening and implementation of nutrition plans, policies and programmes aimed at improving nutrition throughout the life-course, in stable and emergency situations.          7. Systems for surveillance, prevention and control of zoonotic and non-zoonotic foodborne diseases strengthened; food-hazard monitoring and evaluation programmes established and integrated into existing national surveillance systems, and results disseminated to all key players.          8. Capacity built and support provided to Member States, including their participation in international standard-setting in order to increase their ability to assess risk in the areas of zoonotic and non-zoonotic foodborne diseases and food safety, and to develop and implement national food-control systems, with links to international emergency systems.

Project Title: SENEP1004175 - Communicable Disease Surveillance and Response/Malaria/Essential Health Technology
Input: 1. Sustain elimination of leprosy as a public health problem from Nepal. 2. Capacity building at district level for effective implementation and monitoring of National Kalaazar Elimination Programme in 12 affected districts. 3. LF elimination programme and surveillance monitoring supported. 4. Community based vector surveillance and control strategy for dengue and other emerging urban based vector-borne diseases. 5. Prevention and control of major and emerging zoonotic diseases of public health importance in Nepal. 6. A simiplified national integrated diseases surveillance system for ep0idemic-prone diseases developed and implemented. 7. Laboratory human resource capacity for communicable diseases diagnosis strengthened. 8. Quality and infrastructure of selected laboratories improved. 9. Optimize operational procedures of control of communicable diseases. 10. Implementation of core capacities for IHR implementation. 11. Strengthening of alert and response system for use in epidemics and other public health emergencies for IHR implementation. 12. International public health security improved. 13. National operation plan for preparedness and response to an influenza pandemic implemented. 14. Health capacity for appropirate Dengue/DHF/DSS case management supported. 15. Infection control in referral hospitals for diseases with epidemic and pandemic potential supported. 16. National RRT capability to support to GOARN. 17. Technically sound National Strategy/Guideline/Policy documents to effectively enhance components of the national malaria control programme. 18. Strengthening case management of malaria through the effective transference of knowledge on national treatment protocols and current confirmatory diagnostic options. 19. Providing an enabling environment for the re-integration of a strong entomological component within the national malaria control programme to facilitate the effective targetomg pf ,a;aroa [revemtopm actovotoes/ 20. Strengthening support for effective delivery of informational and educational sensitisation campaigns to programme beneficiaries, and management of the national malaria control programme. 21. Creating an evidence base on which to enhance in-country mechanisms to maintain the quality of anti-malarials and RDTs. 22. Utilisation of an integrated approach to malaria related surveillance to effectively target national malaria control programme interventions. 23. Maintaining advocacy and technical assistance through effective partnership with the national malaria control programme and associated ntional, regional and global partners. 24. Advances in entomological operational research output with national/local collaboration. 25. Blood transfusion services strenghtned.
Outputs: Eliminate and further reduce the disease burden of Leprosy.          Further reduce the disease burden of LF, Kala azar, Japanese Encephalitis.          Integrated communicable disease surveillance system introduced          Enhanced national laboratory capacity for diagnosis of influenza and other communicable diseases          Integrated VPD surveillance strengthened          Enhancing research activities on Communicable disease and strengthening of TDR research          Strengthening of core competencies for compliance with the IHR          Preparedness plan for major epidemic and pandemics updated and implementation capacity strengthened          Strengthening of Infection control capacity of health care facilities for diseases for major epidemics and pandemics          Strengthening of the GOARN at national, regional and district levels.          Operation capacity to respond to pandemic influenza and/or other epidemic potential diseases.
Impact: To reduce the health, social and economic burden of communicable diseases
Outcome: Effective coordination and support provided to Member States in order to provide access for all populations to interventions for the prevention, control, elimination and eradication of neglected tropical diseases, including zoonotic diseases.          Policy and technical support provided to Member States in order to enhance their capacity to carry out surveillance and monitoring of all communicable diseases of public health importance.          New knowledge, intervention tools and strategies that meet priority needs for the prevention and control of communicable diseases developed and validated, with scientists from developing countries increasingly taking the lead in this research.          Support provided to Member States in order to achieve the minimum core capacities required by the International Health Regulations (2005) for the establishment and strengthening of alert and response systems for use in epidemics and other public health emergencies of international concern.          Regional and global capacity coordinated and made rapidly available to Member States for detection, verification, risk assessment and response to epidemics and other public health emergencies of international concern.          Effective response by Member States and the international community to declared emergencies situations due to epidemics and pandemic prone diseases.

Project Title: SENEP1003990 - Programme for Immunization Preventable Diseases
Input: 1. Effective immunization monitoring system in place. 2. RI services in remote and underserved areas, including municipalities improved. 3. Introduction of new vaccine assessment and implementation.
Outputs: Routine Immunization and introduction of new vaccine supported          Non-polio integrated vaccination campaign and outbreaks responses supported          Attainment of polio free status accelerated through support to surveillance, SIAs and lab containment

Outcome: 1. Policy and technical support provided to Member States in order to maximize equitable access of all people to vaccines of assured quality, including new immunization products and technologies, and to integrate other essential child-health interventions with immunization.          2. Effective coordination and support provided in order to achieve certification of poliomyelitis eradication, and destruction, or appropriate containment, of polioviruses, leading to a simultaneous cessation of oral poliomyelitis vaccination globally.

Communicable disease surveillance supported especially in emergency situations.          Coordination for concerted action in health sector emergency preparedness, response and recovery improved.          Capacity to respond to and recover from public health emergencies enhanced.

Project Title: Cultural Heritage Presevation "Bhaidegah Temple"
Input: The Cultural Heritage Preservation Group will be following the traditional practice and using traditional materials to bring the temple back to its original size and shape. As no drawings exist the reproduction of the temple will be made as authentic as possible based on the surviving historical photos, water color sketches and the original components of the temple. The reconstruction design of the temple will be based on the existing base in stone which will provide the ground floor plan with exact locations of the 20 timber columns. The rebuilding will take place on the intact foundation and stepped platforms, using some of the original struts as well as the original bronze finial.
Outputs: As the call for reconstruction to the original style originated from the local community, it is believed that the empowerment aspect can be achieved. There will be a direct socio-economic effect in terms of capacity building and employment of local craftsmen and artisans for the duration of the project, and they will get the opportunity to develop restoration skills through the project.
Impact: Goals:    By engaging all individuals and institutions who value the history and cultural heritage of Kathmandu Valley, the project aims to:   - Enhance the sense of ownership over the architectural heritage of the Valley and help revive historical interest in the Malla era.   - Bring the temple back to its original size and shape and restoring the historical integrity of the Patan Palace Square   - Enhance the local capacity to conserve and restore its cultural heritage   - To help providing continuity to the indigenous traditions by using original material and technique during the restoration process.
Outcome: The project expects to achieve the reconstruction of the temple and develop the capacity of a team skilled labour such as carpenters and masons, who will benefit the local community in the long term. It is hoped that this project can be a showcase that will inspire similar restoration work elsewhere in the valley. Furthermore, such restoration project will raise public awareness of the importance of protecting Nepalese cultural heritage.

Project Title: Preparing for the rehabilitation of Maoist combattants in the cantone
Input: The objective of the Project is "the provision of support services for the Maoist Army combatants in cantonments and the inhabitants of the surrounding villages is perceived by the interest groups affected as an example of the start of successful implementation of the peace agreement".
Outcome: - The expected results are considered to be realistic and will contribute significantly to the objective. GIZ is already established inside the cantonments and has built up a trust with the combatants. This is essential in the short transitional period ahead. GIZ have undertaken several surveys and have a good understanding of what the combatants need for the reintegration back into society.    Due to GIZ's history in the cantonments they can provide a quick response, flexibility, accountability, transparency and competency for the implementation of the project activities. GIZ will continue with both the former combatants and the community members of the receiving communities which is in line with 'do no harm' and conflict sensitive approach. This will ensure reconciliation process between the Maoists and the community members.

Project Title: Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC)in Asia.
Input: FAO has proposed to provide Euro 1,299,999 for the implementation Integrated Food Security Phase Classfication (IPC) in Asia; special focus to strengthen IPC capacity in four countries as a Technical Assistance.
Outputs: Improve food security programming through standardized food security classfication and analysis in four focus countries in Asia.    To introduce IPC for standarized classfication of food security for advocacy, planning, and response in food security and nutrition interventions at national and regional levels.
Impact: The Direct bebeficiaries of the action are food security experts at national and regional level, who will be trained on IPC as certified IPC analysts and trainers.   Most of the food insecure and vulnerable population in the country, including women and chiIdren, widows and female headed households, disabled and youth, who will benifit from improved programming and targetted actions enbaled by more coherent and reliable food securitiy information.
Outcome: Introduction and awareness-raising events in the four focus countries and in the regions organised    Regional capacity is increased with a pool of certified analysis available in each focus country, as well as a pool of certified IPC trainers at the regional level    Standardized analysis of the food security situation is available in each country.    Regional issues and application communicated and disseminated in ASEAN and SAARC regions and to the GSU.    A strategic plan of action and a regional follow-on project document for IPC in Asia over the medium-term will be prepared.

Project Title: Community Livestock Development Program (CLDP)
Input: A. Community Development and Capacity Building identification of livestock pockets by district Livestock Action Team by using poverty maps of the project districts; development of about 6,900 livestock groups with at least 35% women participation; social mobilization through local NGO's/CBO's ; community level extension by Community Livestock Assistants(CLS); capacity developement of farmer groups, DLS staff, partner NGO's/CBO's and livestock- based enterpreneurs. B. Livestock Productivity Improvement Fifteen livestock improvement models identified as suitable for small and resource poor farmers; livestock productivity improvement through intensive forage development, provision of veterinary and breeding services(with emphasis on promotion of private practice), financing through microfinance intermediaries C. Livestock Processing and Marketing Improvement and/or establishment of milk market infrastructure (chilling centres) and retail outlets (dairy shops); meat processing marketing infrastructure development(slaughter houses/slabs/meat shops). improvement and/or establishment of live animal market/ market animal collection centres. D. Project Management Services A multi-sectoral project interventions for improved livelihood of the project beneficiaries. E. Higher Altitude Livelihood Pilot Project Establishment of a central office led by a Project Manager, supported by technical assistance team to support project implementation.
Outputs: CLDP, funded by the Asian Development Bank, came into implementation in December 2005. The Department of Livestock Services (DLS) under the Ministry of Agriculture and Co-operatives (MoAC), Government of Nepal is the Executing Agency for livestock related activities and the Rural Micro-Finance Development Centre for micro-financing. The project focuses o the development of profitable and sustainable livestock enterprises and has two elements: (i) intensive livestock production (22 districts); and (ii) processing, marketing, and commercialization of livestock sector services (22 districts). A pilot livelihood program for the higher altitude was also formulated and implemented. Agreement Signed on: 8 April 2004 ( Nepali Date: 2060/12/26) Loan Amount: SDR 1,39,96,000 (NRS 1.46 billion) , US$ 2,06,29,964 Approved from Cabinet: 2060/12/16 a. Intensive Livetsock Production districts: Tanahun, Lamjung, Baglung, Gulmi, Argakhanchi, Palpa, Nawalparasi, Banke, Bardia, Surkhet, Pyuthan, Salyan, Dailekh, Rolpa, Rukum, Jajarkot, Kailali, Kanchanpur, Dadeldhura, Doti, Baitadi and Accham b. Processing, Marketing and Commercialization districts: Jhapa, Morang, Sunsari, Saptari, Siraha, Dhanusha, Mahottari, Sarlahi, Rautahat, Bara, Makwanpur, Parsa, Chitwan, Kathmandu, Lalitpur, Nuwakot, Kavre, Kaski, Rupandehi, Kapilbastu and Dang c. Multi-sectoral Higher Altitude Pilot Project: Jumla, Humla, Mugu, Darchula and Bajhang
Impact: The project aims to increase the per capita income (NRs 2,925 on 1995/96 prices) of poor households by 50 percent, animal productivity by 50 percent for milk and 30 percent for live animal off take, and establishing 1,700 livestock enterprises creating 5,000-6,000 new jobs.
Outcome: Overall objective is to reduce poverty amongst rural poor through gender and socially inclusive development. Its purpose is to improve the levels of food security, nutrition, incomes, and employment for 69,000 families (with an additional 95,000 indirect beneficiaries) through increased productivity of the livestock sub-sector in an environmentally sustainable and socially equitable manner, while enhancing the capacity of the people to manage an ongoing process of development.
District: - Achham (Mangalsen) - Arghakhanchi (Sandhikharka) - Baglung (Baglung) - Baitadi (Baitadi) - Banke (Nepalgunj) - Bara (Kalaiya) - Bardiya (Gulariya) - Chitwan (Bharatpur) - Dadeldhura (Dadeldhura) - Dailekh (Dullu) - Dang Deukhuri (Ghorahi) - Darchula (Darchula) - Dhanusa (Janakpur) - Doti (Dipayal) - Gulmi (Tamghas) - Humla (Simikot) - Jajarkot (Khalanga) - Jhapa (Chandragadhi) - Jumla (Jumla Khalanga) - Kailali (Dhangadhi) - Kanchanpur (Mahendara Nagar) - Kapilvastu (Taulihawa) - Kaski (Pokhara) - Kathmandu (Kathmandu) - Kavrepalanchok (Dhulikhel) - Lalitpur (Patan) - Lamjung (Bensi Sahar) - Mahottari (Jaleswor) - Makwanpur (Hetauda) - Morang (Biratnagar) - Mugu (Gamgadhi) - Nawalparasi (Parasi) - Nuwakot (Bidur) - Palpa (Tansen) - Parsa (Birgunj) - Pyuthan (Pyuthan Khalanga) - Rautahat (Gaur) - Rolpa (Liwang) - Rukum (Musikot) - Rupandehi (Bhairahawa) - Salyan (Salyan Khalanga) - Saptari (Rajbiraj) - Sarlahi (Malangwa) - Siraha (Siraha) - Sunsari (Inaruwa) - Surkhet (Surkhet) - Tanahu (Damauli)

Project Title: Regional TA: Design and Implementation of Policy Approaches to Address Risk and Vulnerability of the Rural Poor at the Country Level
Input: Develop Institutional Capicity in reviewing, analysing, formulating and implementating policy solutions for managing the risks and vulnerability faced by the rural poor, small and marginal farmers and the landless.
Outputs: -Studies and policy analysis reports prepared on topics surrounding risks and vulnerability faced by the rural poor, particularly small and marginal farmers and the landless of both genders.   -Stakeholder capicity stregthened in participating countries countries for policy analysis, dialogue, implementation and internalization.   -Stakeholder consultations held to share regional and national experiences and lessons on successful pro-poor policies to support smallholders in managing.
Impact: The programme will stimulate the poverty reduction process through increased institutional capicity to analyse , design and implement development policies to mitigate risk and vulnerability of the rural poor in the participating countries.
Outcome: Institutional Capacity enhanced in Cambodia, Lao PDR, Nepal and Vietnam to develop policy solutions for managing the risks and vulnerability faced by the rural poor, particularly the new risks posed by market integration, price volatility and climate change.

Project Title: Urgent Food Security Assistance to Severely Food Insecure Rural Households in Karnali-Bheri Regions of Nepal
Input: -Identification of target VDCs in each district in close consultation with local authorities/communities.   -Procrument and distribution of high quality cereal and vegetables seeds.   -Provision of technical backstopping to targeted farming families.   -Provide training in coordination with local bodies.
Outputs: -Immediate relief assistance to reduce hunger.   -The food and nutritional security status of targeted groups be enhanced.   -Marginalized households be enabled to produce own food.
Impact: 15,000 farming families in Rukum, Jajarkot and Kalikot districts owing less than 10 ropanis (approx 0.5 Ha) of land would be enabled to rapidly improve access to food.
Outcome: -A total of 15,000 households consisting of approx 70,500 individuals have undertaken agricultural activites that directly improve their food, nutrient and livelihood security.   -1,8000 hectares of rice have been planted and cropped and at least 4,815 metric tonnes of paddy have been produced by 10,000 small and marginal farmers.   -1,500 hectares of winter wheat have been planted to produce at least 3,234 metric tonnes wheat.   -15,000 summer and winter vegetable gardens planted, delivering improved food security to 15,000 households.

Project Title: TA 7967- (REGIONAL): Innovations for More Food with Less Water
Input: 1. Evaluation of emerging water saving technologies and institutional arrangements for replication in water-challenged countries and specifically in the selected irrigation systems.   2. Identification of water allocation and incentive mechanisms to ensure that the new technologies lead to real water savings.   3. Analysis of progress , performance, and prospects for private sector roles in water-conserving agriculture.   4.Design and costing of project components or pilot interventions to be implemented under ADB investment projects.   5. Performance benchmarking and monitoring systems established and training provided in selected systems.   6. Technical review and feedback by experts and policy makers, together with knowledge dissemination within and outside of ADB.
Outputs: 1. Submission of a policy report for inclusive and sustainable AFVC financing to the Governments of Bangaledesh and Cambodia.   2. Development of innovative AFVC finance business models for smallholder farms and SMAES in participating low income DMCs for deliberation by AFVC financial providers.   3. Application of a knowledge platform on innovative AFVC financing by selected DMCs.

Project Title: Sustainable Management and Development of NTFPs in Tarai and Siwalik Regions of Nepal

Project Title: Rural Energy Development Programme:REDP
Input: Technical Assistance  Financial Assistance : 3325,399 USD
Outputs: The main output is equitable access to environment and energy services expanded for poor, women and socially excluded groups. The Rural Energy Development Programme(REDP) was initiated by he united Nations Development Programme(UNDP) in 1996 initially implemented in 5 districts mainly hilly districts. The second phase of the programme started in 2003 and expanded to 25 hilly districts. the third phase started in 2007. The main objective of this programme is to contribute to peace process by building local capacity for sustainable community-manged and equitable rural energy service delivery for poverty alleviation, livelihood promotion and environmental protection. The major programme is promotion of the community micro hydro for rural electrification.
Impact: Energy and environment mainstreamed into national and local development planning with focus on gender, social inclusion and post conflict environmental rehabilitation. The impacts of the programme ara as follows:   Enhancement of rural livelihoods through   Increased income from off-farm and on-farm activities  end use promotion of energy produced from micro hydro and other renewable energy systems  Increased capital from savings and credit operations of the Community Organizaitons(COs).  Improved quality of life with access to electricity through   Improved helath due to reduction in drudgery, labor and smoke inhalation, and improved sanitation; better education of children due to the availability of brighter light at night (extension of study hours);   Increased awareness among the rural people about global activities via telecommunications and computers and resultant reduction in the feeling of 'isolation'  Establishment of infrastructure like electricity, schooling, potable drinking water and micro-enterprises  Improved environment in and around homes and communities.
Outcome: Energy and environment mainstreamed into national and local development planning with focus on gender, social inclusion and post conflict environmental rehabilitation.

Project Title: 467GLO1007.26 (ED) - CAP EFA: Capacity Assessment for Non-formal Education in Nepal
Input: According to GMR 2011, Nepal has illiterate population of 7.6 million (or 42% of the total) of whom 67 percent are women. Literacy rates vary by ecological regions with the Hills with highest literacy rate (55%) and the Mountains with the lowest (41%). However, the Terai has the highest number of illiterates followed by the Hills. Large disparities exist between male and female literacy rates in all age groups. According to the 2001 census, the literacy rate for six years and older males (66%) is 23 percentage points higher than that for the same age group of females (43%). The youth literacy rate (15 to 24 years) of 70 percent is significantly higher than the adult literacy rate (age 15 years and above) of 48 percent    The weak capacity in the Nepal education sector in general, and in literacy and NFE in particular, have been highlighted in recent studies, discussions, consultations, workshops and reports on education in Nepal. There is general consensus that the capacity of the Ministry of education in general and NFEC in particular is very weak to plan, develop, implement and manage programs aimed at increasing literacy and lifelong education. There is lack of capacity for evidence-based planning and lack of adequate capacity for managing the NFE sub-sector.    Nepal is one of the 20 CapEFA countries in the biennium 2009 - 2011 and is being engaged in the capacity development of Non-formal Education staff and CLC management committee members mainly focusing Education Sector Analysis for NFE sub-sector, identification of potential target group and beneficiaries, setting benchmark and target indicator values, and action planning for operationalization of reviewed NFE policy for achieving target indicator values. The outcomes of this effort resulted in the enhancement of capacity of leadership, ownership and harmonization; institutional capacity; organizational capacity; quality and equity; and knowledge-generation for capacity development in the NFE sub-sector as envisaged in Cap EFA Strategic Framework.  The concrete and tangible outputs that have evolved so far include: (a) National Plan of Action for developing and expanding CLCs, (b) Establishment of NFE-MIS in three pilot districts, (c) Reliable estimates of current literacy skills through literacy survey.    In this context, following a request from the Non formal Education Centre for UNESCO's support in the NFE sub-sector, it has been agreed that UNESCO will arrange for the continuation of support for capacity development in the implementation of the NFE Sub-sector Programme. As such identification of what key capacities are already developed/existing and what additional capacities are needed in the NFE sub-sector in order to enable the country to be on track with EFA goals by 2015 is crucial. Hence UNESCO Kathmandu aspires to further play an active role in assisting the MoE in the area of Literacy and non-formal education. In collaboration with MOE, UNESCO Bangkok, UNESCO HQ, UIL and other relevant partners, the Office will provide support to the MOE for the development of capacity development plan for literacy and NFE subsector in Nepal.
Outputs: Plan for Systematic Capacity Assessment    Capacity assessment report detailing existing and required capacities in the NFE sub-sector in Nepal    Capacity development response for short and medium term    Enhanced knowledge and understanding of capacity assessment and development among Capacity Assessment Team members and others engaged in the processes.
Outcome: Expected Result N°1:   The capacity assessment is undertaken to identify existing capacities in key NFE task areas (the capacity baseline), the on-going capacity gaps and the formulation of a response strategy reinforcing short-to-medium term initiatives for the identified strategic areas of the NFE sub-sector. Project Title: Rehabilitation of Devighat hydro Power plant
Input: Rehabilitation of Devighat Hydropower plant it

Project Title: Koshi Coridor 220KV Transmission Line
Panchthar Substation & Rural Electrification Project

The rice so procured is delivered to the people of the food deficit areas of Nepal through Nepal Food Corporation.

Project Title: Nepal Enhanced Capacities for Trade and Development Project (NECTRADE)
Input: EIF has provided US$ 905,200.00 as grant assistance to the Government of Nepal to implement Nepal Enhanced Capacities for Trade and Development Project.
Outputs: Under Tier 1 Project, Enhanced Integrated Framework (EIF - a joint initiative of the WB, IMF, WTO, UNCTAD, ITC and UNDP) programme, MoU between Ministry of Commerce and Supplies and the United Nations Office for Project Services (UNoPs) is the EIF Trust Fund Manager.
Impact: Enhanced capacity in the Government of Nepal to formulate, manage, implement and monitor Trade Related Technical Assistance (TRTA) in support of Nepal's trade development agenda,  Trade further mainstreamed into national development strategies,  NTIS recommendations implemented, and  Coordinated delivery of Aid for Trade in accordance with the identified and prioritized needs.
Outcome: The key objective of the project is to ultimately ensure faster growth of the country, alleviation of poverty through creation of jobs and enhanced sustainability of trade development efforts resulting in greater overall beneift to the Nepalese populace through enhanced global integration, trade development and proposed positioning of the country.
Secondary Sector Sub-Sector: General economic, commercial and labour affairs

Project Title: EC-Nepal, WTO Assistance Programme
Input: Fulfilling international SPS/TBT requirements is a major precondition for developing Nepal's economy and the export potential that exists for the agricultural sector as well as laying a solid foundation for the development of the manufacturing sector  Significant awareness rising on WTO issues on WTO issue and capacity development to address the challenges presented among government and private sector and the public is required along with a legislative review.
Outputs: Create an enabling and WTO-complaint environment for sanitary and phytosanitary measures (SPS) and technical barriers to trade (TBT) compliance. In particular addressing quality infrastructure issues facilitating product accepatance at international level and to improve the capacity of Nepal to export products of improved overall quality.  Build and broaden the capacity in Nepal to understand and implement WTO commitments and to have the ability move generally to appreciate and analyze key aspects of ongoing WTO negotiations of importance for Nepal  Under the Ec-Nepal WTO assistance programme ESCAP assists Euro 25000 to strengthening the WTO reference center. This technical assistance is to utilize the training program of component 2.
Outcome: Awareness and substantive knowledge about WTO issues improved Nepali officials, the business sector and civil society organization and means provided for them to take full advantage of the national trade policies formulated in the WTO context.  Improved compliance of legislative with obligation under WTO  Capacity of Nepal's export to comply with standards and certificate requirements strengthened by improving Nepal's standards infrastructure.  The TBT and SPS enquiry points' enquiry points' for standards dissemination established resulting in effective country participation in the WTO TBT and SPS regimes  WTO sector of ministry of Agriculture and cooperative (MOAC) strengthened
Secondary Sector Sub-Sector: General economic, commercial and labour affairs

Project Title: Assistance to the Peace Process in Nepal
Input: Establish weapons and combatants' registrations system for all cantonment sites  Recruit and train a team of nepali registration officers for each cantonment site  Concepts and procedures to assist the governement in the discharge of maoist army minor and  post May 2006 recruits  International Peace trust fund advisor and national technical advisor to support the Peace Fund Secretariat  Leadership development training to senior officials of the Ministry of Peace and Reconstruction
Outputs: Output 1: Registration of Maoist combatants and their weapons completed in accordance with the November 28 Agreement on the Monitoring of the Management of the Arms and Armies Output 2: A government-led Peace Fund with the technical assistance of UNDP and financial support of donors is established and functioning   Output 3: Discharged former-Maoist army personnel resume a civilian life in their communities of origin   Output 4: Support provided to Election Commission in coordinating international election observers and all related arrangements
Outcome: The objective of the Project is to support the Government of Nepal (GoN) in the implementation of the Comprehensive Peace Agreement (CPA) signed on 21 November 2006 between the then Seven Party Alliance and the Communist Party of Nepal/Maoist (CPN/M).

Impact: Healthy and fair sporting environment in Nepal through raising awareness about anti-doping

Project Title: Jaladh Integrated Watershed and Natural Resource Management Program
Input: The concept of Open Village School will be established under which 2600 villagers will receive training on eco-literacy, bio-intensive gardening, watershed literacy, livestock management, local history and geography, current affairs, natural pest management, primary health, women's rights, gender based violence and other topics.    525 people will get orientation on HIV/AIDS, sexual and reproductive health rights, natural resource management, democracy and other topics.    14 different training packages for illiterate people will be developed and distributed.    225 people within the villages will receive training/ develop skills in facilitation, teaching and organisation.    1,650 people will attend meetings and discussions.    Capacity building and infrastructure development will be provided to Jaladh Youth Club. Under the initiative, 950 school youth will receive training/ orientation in ecology, watersheds, history, the global challenges, agro-ecology, family planning, HIV/AIDS and sexual and reproductive health rights.    18 learning resource centres with audio-visual capacities will be established and managed    80 youth (both boys and girls) will receive training and develop skills in facilitation and organisation    470 (other) girls and boys will participate in meetings, village activities, advocacy and campaign work.    About 2699 people will receive Functional Literacy    Approximately three community based organisations and 10 village organisations will be established.    Apart from other regular study tours, information and documentation activities, the project will establish a 400 m2 of demonstration garden at the Life school center    Under Rural Workers and Crafts People's Programme (RWCPP) 200 landless will receive training on new technical skills and efforts will be catered towards providing and use rights to 200 others.    144 landless people will receive training/ basic skills in conducting meetings, basic primary health care, trade unions and other issues.    Participatory Conservation and Community Activities Programme (PCCAP) of the project will assist in preparing 100 village plan/projects    Group Partnership Programme (GPP) will help form and operationalise 18 cooperatives with lead representation from poor and socially excluded families    35 groups will receive training/ skills to improved their natural resource management capacity    The Whole Watershed Programme (WWP) hopes to ensure access of 100 households to natural resources. This also hopes to conserve and manage 200ha of currently fragile land.    Advocacy and Policy Dialogue Programme (APD) will provide training/orientation on basic advocacy skills to 500 men and women. Similarly, Advocacy campaign will be conducted for popular co-management of Churia
Outputs: 2600 villagers with improved skills, knowledge, attitude and self confidence within eco-literacy, bio-intensive gardening, watershed literacy, livestock management, local history and geography, current affairs, natural pest management, primary health, women's rights, gender based violence and other topics;    525 people with knowledge of HIV/AIDS, sexual and reproductive health rights, natural resource management, democracy and other topics;    14 different training packages of high quality for illiterate developed and distributed;    225 people within the villages with skills in facilitation, teaching and organisation;    1,650 people attend meetings and discussions.    950 youth with locally relevant knowledge within ecology, watersheds, history, the global challenges, agro-ecology and other issues;    18 learning resource centres with audio-visual capacities established and managed;    80 youth (both boys and girls) with skills in facilitation and organisation;    470 (other) girls and boys participate in meetings, village activities, advocacy and campaign work.    Existing functional literacy materials are revised and produced;    2600 people are functional literate in 4 contexts.    3 target group CBOs established and working;    10 village organisations established and working.    20 wall newspapers produced and distributed;    20 radio broadcasts produced and aired.    5 studies carried out.    400 m2 of demonstration garden managed;    200 workshops, trainings and seminars housed;    20 training/seminar programmes planned and run.    200 landless with new technical skills;    200 (other) landless people have obtained land use rights;    Watershed CBO for the promotion of the interests of the landless;    144 landless people with some basic skills in conducting meetings, basic primary health, trade unions and other issues.    100 village plans prepared with people;    100 village projects completed.    18 coops with lead representation from poor and socially excluded families formed and running;    35 groups have improved their natural resource management capacity.    100 households have secure access to natural resources;    200 ha fragile land is under conservation management.    500 men and women have basic advocacy skills;    Government acceptance of co-management as the solution for Churia conservation.
Impact: Improved livelihoods for the poor and socially excluded, particularly of women, Dalits (so-called untouchables) and Janajatis (indigenous populations).    Increased status at various levels, decision making power and influence on decision making, level of organisation, and utilisation of government services for the poor and socially excluded.    More productive, resilient, efficient and sustainable management of watershed resources by local communities.    Improved cooperation and collaboration between upstream and downstream stakeholders for equitable and effective co-management[1] of watershed resources.    Enabling policies, strategies and guidelines for effective co-management of watersheds in Churia region promoted            [1] Co-management is defined as the management of Churia Hills resources through collaboration of upper, mid and lower catchment populations, civil society organizations and government agencies.
Outcome: At least 10% of the small farmers' port folio of techniques and seeds has been increased.    The communities have collectively improved the management of at least 33% of their common natural resources.    At least 200 persons have obtained the skills for upper watershed management, value addition and marketing.    At least 10% of the women has increased their negotiation skills at household level    At least 10% of the small farmers, landless and women are members of the decision-making bodies of Community Based Organisations (CBOs) for the promotion of their interests.    At least 2 watershed wide CBOs for the promotion of the interests of small farmers, landless and women    Number of methods changed and used has been increased by at least 10%.    Protein production has increased by at least 10% due to reduction in lass and increase in N-fixation.    Number of trees growing has increased by at least 10%.    There has been at least one community level NRM activity in each village.    At least 6% of the upper watershed is under a management that reduces run off and erosion[1] by at least 33%.    Value of stock and production from the area under management has increased by at least 10%.    Women's decision making power over household cash has increased by 20%.    Women's participation in village gatherings has increased by at least 20%.    The ratio of women to men in village level institutions is at least 1:3.    The equality in terms of access to and control over natural resources has increased by at least 10% (increase in Gini Index).    Daily wage for unskilled work has increased by at least by 10% in fixed prices.    At least 10% of visits by governmental agencies within natural resource management in villages has been increased.    At least 10% of governmental support for the livelihood strategies of the landless and marginalized has been increased.    Mechanisms for participatory policy dialogue conducive for the co-management of watersheds in Churia region promoted.    Lessons learned from JIWAN Programme fed into broader Churia policy development through documentation, demonstration and sharing to contribute towards policy refinement for better management of Churia.          [1] Erosion is here to be understood as the load carried by the stream out of the area under management. There will in fact be some erosion within the micro watersheds but it will be trapped.

Project Title: Strengthening State and Civil Society Capacity for Comprehensive Response to HIV/AIDS (Bharosa)
Input: Mapping of community groups (2days*2 districts*30 person) per diem, food, local travel and stationery, staff travel cost to selected VDCs    Trainings of LRPs (20 days for 270 individuals ) per diem, travel cost, lodging    Interaction with community groups and CSOs by LRPs (2 districts, 270 LRP *10 events) per diem LRP, meetings snacks and tea.    IEC Materials /Safe passage kits    Create Revolving Fund    Training of CHBC workers: 270 people X 2 weeks residential trainings    Incentive to CHBC workers: per person Rs.10000per year (only 2 years)    Purchase of CHBC Kits: (270*2500)    Training of key community leaders on stigma and discrimination: (30 events )    Talk program and campaign by PLHIV and other professionals (2 events per year, per district) for all 3 years    Radio message (per month Rs.20000) for 2 years    Training of women networks in far west region (NFWORC) 30 persons, 3 days in each districts    Orientation to community groups at VDC level on resource mobilization and financial management (2 days for 540 persons) non-residential    Follow up and advocacy (per year one event for 540 persons) one day only per event    Sensitization and orientation workshop with district stakeholders (1 day orientation, 3 events in each districts)    Awareness/mainstreaming workshop to district line agencies workshop on national action plan to DACC (2 days workshop in each districts)    Bridging workshop at district level, including the focus group discussion (1 day workshop, 5 event per districts)    Follow up bridging workshop (5 events in each districts for 2 years)    HIV service need assessment (technical assistance fees and travel cost    VCT/ART/PMTCT strengthening through training    Technical support to prepare DARP plan (technical consultants) 10 days in each districts (fees and other associated cost)    Publication and disseminations of DARP.    Monitoring of DARP implementation bi-annual visit one year 2 and 3    Support to DACC and NCASC    Workshop on resource mobilization with district stakeholders (one event per district), 2 days workshop    Follow up and advocacy workshop on resource mobilization (1 event per year per district)    Learning and interaction visit of policy makers to the project district (5 persons, from national level, for 10 days for 2 districts) 2nd year and 3rd year    Interaction visit of PLHIV with service providers and networks such as NAPN+, National , NFWLHA (inter district) 2 events each year    Establish seed money under DPHO Basket fund for transportation, nutrition and other emergency support.    Orientation to health service providers on referral service, OI treatment, friendly service delivery (2 days 1 batch of 20 people in each districts)    Review workshop with health workers    Orientation workshop (project wise , 2 days ,30 participants) consultant for 5 days@15000    Migration, women and HIV (orientation at CO level) to CARE Staffs (consultant for 5 days)    Exposure and capacity building of project staff    National level conference (at Kathmandu), 1 event
Outputs: Communities and civil society organizations have strengthened capacity for improved prevention, care and support services    District stakeholders take leadership and incorporate HIV and AIDS into their respective development programs
Impact: To reduce the socio-economic impact of HIV and AIDS by increasing access to prevention, care and support services in Bajhang and Bajura districts of Far Western Region of Nepal by 2013.
Outcome: Communities and civil society organizations have strengthened capacity for improved prevention, care and support service    District stakeholders take leadership and incorporate HIV and AIDS into their respective development programs
Primary Sector: - OTHERS - SOCIAL - WOMEN, CHILDREN & SOCIAL WELFARE

Project Title: TA: Integrated Urban Development Project
Outputs: 1. Reliable afforable and effective municipal infrastructure development (a) drainage and sewerage systems improve; (b) urban roads and lanes improved; (c) solid waste management systems improved; (d) water supply systems improved; and (e) community development programs undertaken including health and hygiene eduteation, 3R promotion, skills trainings, and investment in small-scale community facilities. 2. Capacity of MPPW and project municipalities strengthened to deliver GESI results in their operations.

Project Title: Proposal on Acquisition and the use of Electronic Voting Machine (EVM) and other supports in the future Elections in Nepal
Input: The ECN is in need of the following euipments,accessories and support for the future elections in Nepal.     Electronic Voting Machines(EVM)    Study Tours and trainings    Vehicles and Trainings
Outputs: Output 1:   Study tour will help to understand its importance,reliabilities and other feature of EVM in elections. The political party's representative's visit is to increase their confidence in the EVM so that they are enriched with the knowledge and information on EVM.   Output 2:   The stakeholders and the political parties will gain trust and reliabilities on the use of EVM once the ECN staff members can be oriented on the trustworthiness of EVM after they acquire knowledge on EVM and it's usefulness.   Output 3:   The skilled and qualified technical manpower capable of operating and maintaining EVM will be available in ECN which is essential for ensuring the operation and the use of EVM without trouble.   Output 4:   Staff members in ECN will be motivated toward their job.   Output 5:   The experience of ECI can be transferred to ECN and the teams along with the working friendly relation between institutions and countries will be strengthened.
Impact: The decision of the election Commission,Nepal on the use of EVM in the future elections is an important step towards bringing reforms in the electioneering process in Nepal.The commission is committed tomaximize the use platform level technology to bring anticipiated reforms in elction management.It is believed that hte use of technology in managing elections in general and the use of EVM in polling particular rcpected to be an important milestone in achieving credible elections in Nepal
Outcome: This project helps to modernize the electioneering process in order to achieve the goal of free,fair,efficient,credible,transparent and ultimately the cost effective elections by replacing the age old balloe paper based manual voting system with electronic voting system and avail all other required logisticsm regard to the use of EVM to conduct elections in Nepal.

Project Title: Tax Governance Support Project (TGSP)
Input: Information Communication and Technology  Human Resources Development  Taxpayer Service/education  Specific Study
Outputs: Policy reform in the income tax, value addes tax and excise duty.  Broadening of tax base.  Improvement / Reform in physical and organizational structure of inland revenue office and the service centers.
Impact: VAT, ITx and Excise willl be fully integrated in ICT system. Exiting IT system of VAT and ITx will be up graded. IRD and IRO will be technically and logistically enriched. Professional, Competent and well motivated employee will deliver qualitative service to the taxpayers. Tax coverage and taxpayer's access to the IROs will be increased. The cost of collection of taxpayers and tax office will be further reduced and internal revenue mobilization will be enhanced. The overall internal monitoring and evaluation system of IRD will be strengthened and revitalised.
Outcome: By the end of the plan period, the contribution of income tax, value added tax and excise duty will be 5.63, 4.1, 2.78 percent respectively based on the gross domestic product  Revenue generation / collection will increase by 25.8 percent per annum  The number of VAT taxpayers will reach to about 100,000 and the number of PAN holders will reach to about 800,000.  Transaction costs of tax[payers will be reduced  Voluntary compliance will be increased significantly.

Project Title: Managing Risk through Economic Development
Input: To develop an effective and sustainable model of disaster risk reduction (DRR) in vulnerable communities of Nepal. This model will use hazard assessments, including climate modeling, to provide 3,000 households with a more sustainable DRR approach directly linked to their livelihoods, thereby mitigating the human and economic toll of natural disasters on their communities.    Mobilization of gender/ ethnically-balanced DMCs through a concentrated process that focuses on those aspects of traditional DRR programming that have demonstrated potential for sustainability post-intervention.    Training of DMCs in durable and sustainable techniques for mitigation, preparedness, response, and (if relevant) early warning.    Participatory vulnerability and capacity assessments (VCAs) carried out by DMCs with communities and local government that provide an evidence-based platform for selection of DRR activities.    Collaboration with climate expertise set up to a) assess long-term viability of proposed DRR activities, and b) determine if further risks need to be anticipated beyond those identified as priorities in the short-term.    Plant and crop product and services assessments (for bioengineering, improved land/ watershed management and other complementary approaches).    Local market assessments - tenure, high-demand/ high-value commodities cross-referenced with the plant/ crop species assessed for bioengineering, land/ watershed management and improved resiliency.    Engage local and sub-national governments and private sector actors with community/DMC representatives in community selection, vulnerability and market assessments, and subsequent resource mobilization and decision-making.    Facilitated planning of required risk mitigation measures and landscape-scale interventions.    Assess land ownership/ usage patterns of marginal lands and determine target households accordingly.    Train community groupsin protection and mitigation techniques and in the cultivation of disaster mitigating crops with strong income potential.    Implement planned mitigation measures (based on plant/crop species identified under Outcome 1), including cultivation of crops that contribute to chronic disaster mitigation, through bioengineering or improved land/ water management (based on market and technical assessments).    Train farmersin better seed varieties, improved planting techniques, new crops that are more resilient to local hazards.    Link local input suppliers, extension actors and other training entities to ensure sustainability of the services.    Establish maintenance plans for each mitigation measure, and where feasible, linked to economic opportunities from crops/products generated via these mitigation measures.    Support micro and small enterprises, as necessary, for local value addition prior to sales, or for aggregation/ collective marketing and sales.    Farmers, water and forest users and other localgroups formed, as necessary, to reinforce good technical practices and enhance market linkages/ economies of scale.    Based on assessment findings and implementation experience, information regarding plant and crop species suitable for disaster mitigation and income generation compiled into at least two resource manuals in local languages and English for use by local government officials, other communities and partner agencies interested in replication.
Outputs: Output 1.1: Disaster Management Committees (DMCs) are formed in 30 communities and capacity built on disaster risk management.   Output 1.2: 30 DMCs develop disaster mitigation plans that are informed by participatory disaster risk assessments (PDRA).   Output 1.3: Market assessments conducted in all target areas determine high-value/high-demand plants, crops or other products that are suitable for hazard mitigation purposes and/or are more resilient to likely shocks.   Output 1.4: Local governments, community/DMC representatives and private sector actors regularly participate in decision making on resource mobilization, mitigation measures, and crop/value-chain selection.   Output 2.1: Target households engage in production, value addition and sale or use of crops for hazard mitigation, increasing average annual incomes by 10%.   Output 2.2: 30 Micro and small businesses or associations are supported for production, value addition and/or collective marketing purposes.   Output 2.3: Households in 30 communities plan for maintenance, replication, expansion, and/or future cropping cycles.   Output 3.1: Information exchange across countries allows testing of various integrated DRR and economic development programming approaches in multiple environments.   Output 3.2: Dissemination of the learning document on integration of resilient local economic development to host governments and colleague NGOs.   Output 3.3: At least one evaluation or research paper on the multiplier effects of combining DRR and resilient local economic development is published by a third-party research institution.
Impact: To simultaneously reduce the human and economic toll of natural disasters while building resilience and reducing poverty.
Outcome: Outcome 1: Disaster Management Committees (DMCs) in 60 communities adopt practices for hazard preparedness, and where appropriate, early warning and contingency planning.   Outcome 2: DRR strategies that combine with market opportunities to mitigate risk and build resiliency in durable and sustainable ways provide a means of increasing economic opportunities while protecting assets.   Outcome 3: A tested, integrated DRR and economic development model is documented for learning and replication.

Project Title: Reducing the impact of HIV on men who have sex with men and transgender populations in Nepal
