Project Title: STRENGTHENING ACTIONS FOR FOSTERING RESILIENCE THROUGH EARLY WARNING AND RISK SENSITIVE PLANNING IN NEPAL (SAFER)
Input: Electronic display board installation at DEOCs;    Support equipment, lifesaving materials, communication equipment to district EOCs (Kanchanpur, Bardiya, and Chitwan) for developing SoPs in line with NEOC SOPs;    Support to NEOC/REOC (communication channel established and emergency telephone list preparation at NEOC/REOC, equipment support);    Small scale mitigation work    Exploration of Appropriate technology for installing landslide early warning;    Preparation of VDC Disaster Risk Management Plan based on MOFALD Guideline;    Supply of preparedness and response equipment (Life Jackets, Boats, Ropes, Tubes and storage facilities);    Trainings to staffs and stakeholders (Advocacy and policy, LDRMP, technical training on Hydrological data analysis, GIS training, Landslide EWS, CBDRR including CBEWS, GSI, PwDs, mainstreaming DRR into District Development Planning);    Technical support to other organizations on EWS, LDRMP, DPRP (DDRCs/DDCs, NGOs, INGOs, UN);    Support to DHM, DSCWM, MOFALD, and other concerned government agencies (Equipment, logistics, Team building, knowledge sharing on CBEWS);    Materials support to DDRCs members for Search and Rescue training;    Building capacity of NRCS to mainstream, assess, design and establish CBEWS;    Support for implementation of CBEWS guideline;    Design, drawing, cost estimate, and supervision small scale mitigation Work;    Mock Drill and simulation exercise in communities;    Support to district EWS (improving upstream linkages and verifying water level thresholds - upstream visits and meetings);    EWS technical equipment (Hand operated sirens, Megaphones, CDMA Phones and storage facilities);    Refresher training to task forces (First Aid and Search and Rescue);    Awareness raising activities (Door to door - 2 times, wall paintings, visibility boards, song competitions, flyer publications) (School awareness)    Activities for mainstreaming PwDs into DRR;    Joint advocacies at key annual DM/DR events (IDDR Day, Earthquke safety day, others) Emergency fund at VDC and District level;    Publication of knowledge and visibility materials;    Surveys and Evaluation.
Outputs: Linkages between national to community level stakeholders developed and strengthened    Methods and approaches for replication  and mainstreaming of CBEWS and risk  sensitive planning developed and adopted    Capacity of stakeholders and  communities at local level for sustaining  CBDRR and EWS increased
Impact: To reduce vulnerability, increase resilience and promote a culture of risk reduction among communities and institutions vulnerable to natural hazards in Nepal
Outcome: To enhance the capacity of  communities and relevant institutions  to strengthen DRR systems and  structure and replicate DRR  initiatives to ensure community  based risk management at local level

Project Title: Legal and Judicial Reforms to Strengthen Creditor Rights Project.
Input: Strengthening Judicial Delivery in Commercial and Banking Cases by Establishing New Commercial Bench, and  Obtaining Judicial Map and Judicial Assessment Report.
Outputs: The World had provided US$ 405000 as grant assistance to the Government of Nepal to build capacity of the judiciary in providing dispute resolution services in banking and commercial matters through commercial bench and data collection and analysis.
Impact: Capacity of the judiciary built.
Outcome: Setting up a new commercial bench at the Appellate and Supreme Court level including drafting procedures and manuals and installing a case management system for the commercial bench.   Carrying out training in commercial matters for judges and registrars for the effective implementation of the commercial bench including undertaking a training needs assessment and developing training modules which can be used to train the judges and support staff.  Carrying out judicial mapping of the geographical organization of the courts and assessment of performance and public percepiton of the judiciary.

Project Title: Enhancing Mobile Population Access to HIV/AIDs Service, Information & Support (EMPHASIS)
Input: Prevention services through establishing linkages with the existing government services in the source, transit and destination locations.    Treatment, care and support through establishing linkages with public and private service providers at source and destination points to ensure continuity of services across the continuum of mobility without interruption    Reducing the vulnerability of mobile women in sex work and wives of mobile men at the source areas    Establishing and strengthening community based organizations, local government and NGO's to reduce vulnerability of mobile populations    Linking NGOs and CBOs at source, transit and destination through use of appropriate information and communication technology and establishment of a database to connect between mobile populations and their families in source, transit and destination areas    Sensitizing and orienting people with whom mobile populations will come into contact such as transport organizations, highway hoteliers, traders, border security personnel, customs and other local officials at transit points; improving their ability and effectiveness in advising mobile populations, with a particular focus on the specific vulnerabilities and denial of rights faced by mobile women.    A regional research centre - the project envisages the establishment of a regional research centre on HIV and mobility, managed by The Overseas Development Institute (ODI), which will house all the information and data about mobility and HIV in the region and undertake specific research, surveys and studies on a regular basis to ensure availability and quality of information to support the efforts of evidence based advocacy at national and regional levels    Research studies - will be conducted to better understand the gender dynamics and gender based vulnerabilities of mobile populations and their family members    Monitoring and Evaluation - The project management unit will work with the research centre to monitor and evaluate the project, in order to guarantee that the learning cycle is active and constantly feeds into more effective implementation, resulting in better practice
Outputs: Good practice models will be developed for replication and scale-up to improve access to HIV prevention, treatment, care and support for populations vulnerable to HIV&AIDS who are mobile across Nepal and India    Enhanced capacity of government, NGOs, civil society organizations and communities to facilitate reduced vulnerability of mobile populations and their families to HIV&AIDS.    Evidence-based advocacy will be developed to inform decisions at national and regional policy level to create an environment of safer mobility for populations vulnerable to HIV & AIDS
Impact: Guided by the principle of having low-cost/high impact HIV and AIDS program, it is essential to work with the most at risk population, who largely constitute men and women from poor, vulnerable and socially excluded communities.
Outcome: Reduce vulnerability of migrants and their families to HIV across India and Nepal borders with special emphasis to difficult and out of reach environments. The project specifically will increase the knowledge and skills of migrants and their families to protect themselves from HIV through strengthening of drop in centers, improved livelihoods of economically poor women headed PLHA households and strengthening referrals through network mobilization
Primary Sector: - OTHERS - SOCIAL - WOMEN, CHILDREN & SOCIAL WELFARE

Project Title: Safe Passage
Input: CARE will provide capacity building inputs to enhance internal organization, financial management, governance analytical and advocacy skills. Twelve consultation meetings will be held with staff and board members of partners    CARE will organize five exposure visits of partners during the project duration. Twenty people (four per visit) will participate, representing each organization.     CARE will organize a 7-day Master Training of Trainers (MToT) for seven district-level partner staff during the first year. The follow up training of three-day will be provided during the second year. MToT will cover HIV-related topics on the prevention to care continuum.    The project will form or revitalize CSG in each VDC during the second year of implementation. In total, the project will facilitate the formation of 30 groups. The project will provide CHBC trainings to at least three people from each CSG. In addition, the project will provide care and support kits (first aid, IEC/BCC materials, and other supplies) to all groups.    The project will revitalize existing groups (formed under CARE's different projects), or form new groups and mobilize these groups for HIV and AIDS awareness. A total of 270 groups will be mobilized.    During the first year of implementation, district project partners will identify and mobilize 540 Peer Educator and Supporter (PES). In all three districts, one male and one female will be selected as PES per ward.    District NGO project partners will provide PES with training (information and skills) on HIV (prevention to care continuum), social mobilization, group facilitation, leadership, interpersonal communication, counseling, advocacy, referral, CHBC, etc. A total of thirty events of four-day long training will be organized in the first two years.    District project partner outreach workers will support male PES to host regular awareness-raising 'fairs' at DICs (at least one event per DIC each year from year two for a total of 40 events) and female PES to host yearly awareness-raising 'fairs'. These events will last four days and occur during periods when mobile population is most likely to be returning home (during the Dashain holiday).    Project outreach workers of NGO partners, with female PES, will identify 900 of the poorest, most vulnerable, and socially excluded women and facilitate capacity building during the second year of project implementation (with follow-up in the following year). The project will provide thirty, two-day orientations.    CARE will lead a participatory assessment during year two to determine the magnitude of economic need among PLHA, and explore potential IGA for feasibility, including a market survey.    NRCS and CARE will provide 100 PLHA members of CSGs in Doti with a 4-day skills training for IGA. In total, five events (20 participants each) will be held.     The project will then provide a matching fund towards the ten Doti CSG revolving funds, and facilitate support to 100 female PLHA. The project team will supply each CSG with NRs. 20,000.    Project will identify ten DIC facilities during the first year of project implementation and will equip each DIC with IEC/BCC materials (on display and for distribution), condoms, care and support kits, referral cards, multi-media equipment (TV and DVD), games and recreational equipment, etc. District NGO project partner outreach workers will manage and operate DICs.    The project will organization around 30 orientations to inform 300 participating health service providers and 1000 FCHV and PES about the needs and rights of PLHA and interpersonal communication for improved provider behaviour.    NAP+N and the advocacy task force will also lobby (ongoing) for improved logistical support, resources and equipment to facilities providing (a) VCT at the district hospitals, (b) ART at district hospitals, and (c) treatment for opportunistic infection at Primary Health Care Centres), Health Posts, and Sub Health Posts).    Lobbying for free education in collaboration with the district advocacy task force and other development agencies working in education.    The project team will consistently disseminate qualitative and quantitative findings at the local, district and national levels, through conferences, public hearings, policy dialogue, and other venues.    Annual meetings to review and reflect on practices and learning will be held.
Outputs: Increased capacity and awareness of local organizations, networks and mobility-affected people, to prevent and control HIV infection, and reduce the implications of it in their livelihoods    Increased skill and confidence of women and PLHA to demand and negotiate rights, services, and livelihood opportunities    Increased access to and utilization of services (prevention, treatment, care, and support) by mobile population and HIV and AIDS infected and affected population
Impact: To reduce the vulnerability and impact of HIV and AIDS on mobility-affected individuals and their families in Kailali, Doti, and Dadeldhura Districts of far western Nepal
Outcome: To contribute to strengthen organizational and technical capacity of (people living with and affected by HIV and AIDS (PLHA) networks and local non-governmental organizations (NGO) for HIV and AIDS responses by ensuring better access to services and information to mobile populations; empowering women to demand and negotiate rights, services, and livelihood opportunities; and developing a greater sense of accountability and commitment among government, service providers, and communities
Secondary Sector Sub-Sector: - Family and children - Social protection n.e.c.

Project Title: Women and Youth as Pillars of Sustainable Peace (WYPSP)
Input: Operationalize Four Peace Centers    Raise awareness on peace related issues of PVSEs    Capacity building of Peace Ambassadors and pressure groups of PVSEs    Train Para-psychosocial counselors, mediators and community journalists    Provide support to community peace groups and Peace Ambassadors to conduct different peace initiatives (including normalization activities and peace support)     Provide support to advocacy initiatives of local peace committee    Building of capacity and sharing of knowledge at institutional level    Raise awareness of media on issues related to conflict-affected PVSEs    Promote innovative peace initiatives of PVSEs    Document and disseminate success stories of PVSEs    Establish micro - macro linkages for policy dialogues    Provide Support to peace building advocacy initiatives at national level    Engage with political parties.
Outputs: Community level capacities strengthened through the establishment and strengthening of peacbuilding processes and mechanism.    Strengthened capacity of civil society organizations at the institutional and network level in the constitution-building and broader political process    Policy makers influenced at the policy level enabling integration of the rights and issues of the PVSE women and youth into the new political agenda.
Impact: To develop the capacity of civil society networks for engaging poor, vulnerable and socially excluded (PVSE) groups of women and youth in the process of influencing a democratic constitution in Nepal, leading towards sustainable peace and the achievement of their aspirations.
Outcome: By 2012, capacity of Shanti Malika peace network shall be strengthened in advocating for the rights of 500 PVSE groups of women and youth (particularly those affected by conflict) through the engagement of PVSEs (which is a critical aspect) in four districts of Gorkha, Dhading, Rupandehi and Kapilvastu.
Donor Agency: - CARE Nepal - Care International UK - European Union
Primary Sector: - PEACE AND RECONSTRUCTION - WOMEN, CHILDREN & SOCIAL WELFARE

Project Title: Child Protection and Development Project
Outputs: Objectives of the Project are as follow:   1) To provide long term protection of children.   2) To provide medical attention when needed.   3) To provide Nutritious food daily.   4) To provide Schooling for both older and younger children on a full time basis.   5) To provide Career counselling and guidance for when the child reaches maturity.   6) To Re-unite children with their family and village of origin.

Project Title: Sustainable Urban Environment (IUD-II)
Input: Participatory planning, including revision and rolling process of community plans presented to LAs and other stakeholders on an annual basis in all slums in the 3 towns where we have worked before, and in selected slums in the other 3 towns.    Establishment or strengthening of 2 town-wide slum dweller organisations    Capacity building training, and assessment of capacity and representativeness of the local organisations through annual review processes and tools for self-assessment    Particular focus on needs specific to the communities we are working with, and to marginalised sections within those communities.    Building the capacity of LA officials and elected representatives, and establishing systems so that expertise and approaches are passed on effectively to new post-holders    city-level forums for co-ordination between stakeholders, giving priority to the needs of slum dwellers, and allocating resources to support their priorities    City-level working groups established or strengthened to deal with specific issues    Leverage of resources to support community infrastructure priorities from LAs, national programmes and other stakeholders, with the proportion contributed by project resources declining over the course of the project    Delivery and management of community infrastructure services (water supply, improved drainage, cluster-latrines, internal roads and paths etc)    Exchange visits and other tools which help communities to effectively choose and adapt the types of technologies most appropriate to their situations    Promoting the uptake of household-level infrastructure (e.g. household latrines, biogas, home composting, water vending, and incremental housing improvements)    Income generation through service delivery with small enterprises in, latrine construction, pit emptying, and waste collection and recycling    Peer-learning workshops and building relationships    Sharing knowledge and good practices with national and regional municipal associations, networks of NGOs, and slum dweller networks    Providing materials (case studies and training modules) for national and regional training institutes    Influencing nationwide programmes to adopt elements of the project's approach for wider scaling up    Project regional workshops and visits for synthesising lessons from the 3 countries (Nepal, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka)    Dissemination of lessons regionally and internationally through conferences and publications
Outputs: Representative organisations of slum dwellers in 2 towns and 39 slums are able to formulate, implement, review and effectively engage with LAs and others about their participatory plans.    Local Authorities and other key stakeholders in 2 towns effectively use systems and adopt behaviours which mainstream the participation of poor communities in local decision-making and resource allocation for pro-poor infrastructure.    Prioritised infrastructure services are delivered in partnership with relevant stakeholders, in ways which are community-led, boost incomes and improve the urban environment, directly benefitting 24000 people.    Communities, LAs, Provincial, National and Regional Associations and others learn and adopt new practices through strengthened linkages at all levels
Impact: To build the capacity of 24179 slum dwellers and 2 Local Authorities (LAs) in local decision-making to plan, deliver and sustain community-led infrastructure services in Bharatpur and Butwal Municipality.

Project Title: Humanitarian Aid
Climate & Dev. Action Programme
Social Inclusion Research Fund (SIRF)
Input: Secretariate support to Social Inclusion Reserach Fund (SIRF) (funded by the Norwegian Government)    Support in institutionalisation of SIRF as an autonomous institute  Capacity development of research apprentices and research fellows on selected social inclusion/exclusion themes
Outputs: Research financing: Quality research on social inclusion agenda supported.  Capacity Building: Researchers from excluded groups (women, Madhesi, Dalits and Janajati) capacitated to carry out research on social inclusion agenda.  Advisory & Research Management  Public & policy debates based on social inclusion research findings stimulated  Coordination mechanism established with civil society and excluded groups' initiatives for policy and public dialogue.  Establishment and operationalisation of a national level institution supporting social inclusion research facilitated  National authority's capacity to develop cooperation and linkages with research councils of Norway including international institutions facilitated.   Interim Screening Committee/Board established
Outcome: National Authority (NA) having increased institutional capacity to gradually strengthen and consolidate social inclusion research financing and agenda setting.  National Authority (NA) taking the lead in facilitation of public debate and policy analysis and development on inclusion in state agencies

Project Title: High Impact Tourism Training for Jobs and Income (HITT) Programme
Input: This Programme is part of a Global/Regional Tourism Programme (implemented in Nepal, Vietnam, Cambodia in Asia and Benin, Ghana, Mozambique, and Mali of sub-saharan Africa)  Advisory and capacity development services to Tourisms enterpreneurs in Nepal aimed at:    Developing an integrated market driven tourism technical and vocational education and training targeting informal economy  Training Needs Assessment, Capacity Development (CD) plans and execution of CD interventions
Outputs: Informal tourism economy mapped  Opportunities and constraints for informal workers identified  Data and analysis shared and understood by key stakeholders and decision-makers  Direct links between informal and formal tourism sector and between training institutes and the tourism business community) established/strengthened  Core tourism job profiles, curricula and methodologies developed to equip target communities with the practical skills to maximum potential sustainable employment and income generation;  Programme adapted for, and implemented in, seven least developed countries in which tourism is a development priority  Enhanced capacity of TVET training institutes in each country with substantially increased outreach to target communities  8,000 men, women and youth seeking employment and SME opportunities in the tourism sector trained  Sustainable systems established for continued TVET implementation and growth after the programme concludes  Tools, methodologies, training materials, case studies and lessons learned documented and disseminated in support of domestic and international up-scaling
Impact: _  __To contribute to sustainable, scaleable, growth in seven least-developed countries in Sub-Saharan Africa and Asia through the development and implementation of an integrated, market-driven tourism TVET system targeting the informal economy.
Outcome: Innovative training methodologies for the informal tourism economy are developed, field tested , implemented, evaluated and disseminated in 7 countries   Improved professional, economic and social skills of participants are assessed; successful participants obtain certification  Participants improve their employability and/or their business skills; thus increasing their income and socio-economic position  Project participants initiate / establish/improve business relations with established tourism businesses  Project participants obtain formal employment  TVET systems in participating countries have improved accessibility and have adapted training and education methods effectively to the needs of informal workers and self employed in the tourism industry.

Project Title: Great Himalayan Trail Development Project (GHTDP)
Input: GHTDP is funded by DFID and SNV is providing technical assistance and capacity development support to government, non-government and private sector organisations for branding and marketing of Great Himalayan Trail for propoor benefits from the tourism activities along the identified trails in 5 districts (humla, Dolpa, Gorkha, Solukhumbu and Taplejung) of Nepal.    Technical sssistance and capacity development support to Marketing Task Force to develop and implement GHT Marketing Strategy  Technical sssistance and capacity development support to MoTCA for effective leadership and coordination for developing GHT Marketing Strategy  Technical sssistance and capacity development support to DDC and MoTCA to plan, innovate, coordinate and manage tourism development  Support DDC and MoTCA to conduct a competitive sector analysis on potential targeted districts  Support ground agents to Increase B2B linkages between Kathmandu TOs and MSMEs in 5 districts  Support DDC & MoTCA to establish flexible institution mechanisms to integrate private and public representation in GHT planning (e.g. task forces, Steering committee, TDC)  Technical sssistance and capacity development support to DDCs to invest in basic education and skills on tourism in the target GHT destinations  Technical sssistance and capacity development support to KTM TO to integrate sustainable supply chain management practices in their business operations
Outputs: International TOs market and promote GHT target destinations   International TOs market and promote GHT non-target destinations   GHT mainstreamed into public and private sector Nepal tourism marketing   MoTCA and Marketing Task Force effectively coordinate the implementation of GHT branding and marketing strategy   DDC & MoTCA effectively coordinate (tourism & tourism related) planning and investment by national stakeholders (public & private sector) in GHT targeted districts   DDC and MoTCA effectively coordinate tourism planning and investment of public and private sector actors in GHT target districts   Increased knowledge of the market for local goods and services among local MSME   MSMEs in 5 targeted districts improve range, quality and market orientation of goods and services   Increased demand from Kathmandu based TOs for locally supplied goods, services and staffs in GHT districts   DDCs invest in relevant basic education and skills training in the target GHT destinations
Impact: Kathmandu based TOs increase expenditure on local goods and services  Increase in expenditure by tourists in the targeted GHT districts    Scale: 1072 Primary MSMEs in targeted 5 GHT districts  Income increase of US$ 1.44 mil in targeted and US$ 3.45 mil in non-targeted districts by 2012  2,251 and 734 net additional jobs by 2012 in targeted and non-targeted districts  Increased access to safe water, improved road and bridge infrastructure, renewable energy and products for 80,000 people in the 5 districts who live along the main treks by 2012
Outcome: Increased number of tourist in non targeted GHT districts  Increased number of tourist days (# of tourist x average length of stay) in targeted GHT districts  Increased investment by private sector (local and KTM based) in GHT districts  Improved environment for private sector investment geared towards tourism in GHT districts

Project Title: Biodiversity Sector Programme for Siwaliks and Terai (BISEP-ST)
Input: Promoting good Forest governance as a means of enhancing Forest and biodiversity conservation and engineering livelihoods opportunities for poor Forest dependent people in the programme districts.
Outputs: BISEP-ST will be implemented in eight Terai Districts of the Central Development Region ; they are Chitwan , Makwanpur, Parsa, Bara, Rauthahat , sarlahi, Mahottari and Dhanusa .
Outcome: Work towards a self -sustaining forestry sector for biodiversity conservation and equitable economic development in the Terai and Siwaliks of Nepal.
District: - Bara (Kalaiya) - Chitwan (Bharatpur) - Dhanusa (Janakpur) - Mahottari (Jaleswor) - Makwanpur (Hetauda) - Parsa (Birgunj) - Rautahat (Gaur) - Sarlahi (Malangwa)

Project Title: (Improving) Functionality of Water Supply Services in Nepal
Input: Advisory and capacity development services to government, non-government actors at national and sub-national level for:    Improving enabling environment for functionality of water supply services  Improving performance of WSS actors for effective service delivery  Improving governance, gender equity, social inclusion, knowledge management and synergy (cross cutting)
Outputs: One national and four district action plans prepared to revive failing water supply schemes  Guidelines and decision making support tools prepared in four districts  Key actors/clients trained, prepared and monitored to effectively carry out major repair, rehabilitation and reconstruction  National, district and local allocation, disbursement and utilisation of financial resources for major repair, rehabilitation and reconstruction increased   Performance of clients in providing sustainable water supply services improved   Mechanism established to monitor performance of clients in providing water supply services in the context of minimum standards and guidelines  Inventory of existence and problems related to Water Users Groups, Village Maintenance Workers, O&M funds and tools prepared   WUGs, VMWs, system for O&M funds and tools at existing schemes in place and capable to deal with regular scheme operation and maintenance  WUGs and VMWs make use of external support and advice (in the context of post-construction support mechanism)  Post-construction support mechanism established  System for ongoing monitoring of functional status of existing water supply schemes established
Impact: Increased access of safe drinking water to 16,000 rural HH in five districts of Karnali
Outcome: Preconditions improved for effective repair, rehabilitation and reconstruction of failing water supply schemes in five districts  Quality of services improved to make existing, rejuvenated and planned water supply schemes work to their design capacity for their design period and serving all water users with quantity, quality, continuity and convenience  Capacity and preconditions of operators improved to deal with short and long term operation and maintenance of the scheme  Institutional set up and mechanism developed and adopted that effectively support and regulate ongoing implementation, operations and maintenance of water supply schemes and services
District: - Dolpa (Dolpa) - Humla (Simikot) - Jumla (Jumla Khalanga) - Kalikot (Kalikot) - Mugu (Gamgadhi)

Project Title: Climate and Carbon Funding in Renewable Energy Sector in Nepal
Input: 1. Establishment of the Climate and Carbon Unit (CCU) within AEPC; 2. Review of current DEPPs and DESRs and piloting of development of comprehensive DCEPs in three selected districts.
Outputs: Climate and Carbon Unit establihed in Alternative Energy Promotion Centre (AEPC)  3 District Climate and Energy Plans (DCEPs) prepared (Ilam, Mustang and Makawanpur)
Impact: Increased % of population benefitting from climate and energy resilience programmes
Outcome: DCEPs are integrated (prioritisation and resource allocation) in District Periodic Plans by DDCs  DCEPs implemented resulting in more climate and energy resilience approaches in development activities/programmes
Donor Agency: - Department for International Development - Stichting Nederlandse Vrijwilligers

Project Title: Raising Income of Small and Medium Farmers Project (RISMFP)
Input: Technical Assistance to RISMFP funded by ADB with following inputs/activities:   Establish agribusiness promotion grant imprest account by month 3 after loan effectiveness  Appoint IAP for grant awards - define operational procedures   Review applications   Disburse grants approved by IAP for cooperative strengthening, post harvest investment, farm input grants, and farm technology  Mobilize technical service providers as required  PMU and AEC pre qualify post harvest service providers, and national and local on-farm service providers   Implement awareness and market networking programs   Implement a market linkages program in two regions and develop supply agreement, identify farmer cooperatives develop business plans and grant applications  Design and implement the AMIS program  Design and implement post harvest training programs   Upgrade DADO, CASC and ARCs, on-farm services providers contracted   Contract on farm service providers, farmer group sensitization and market linkages program with training, production planning and grant applications  Mobilize new groups for DP and IP link to farmer cooperatives support training and grant applications  DADO-trained and implementing monitoring and impact assessment programs   Establish and implement project management arrangements including structure and procedures, staff recruitment  Select and train ASPs in HVC production, post-harvest handling and marketing, and awareness of gender, indigenous peoples, and climate change issues  Conduct overall project promotion and awareness campaign including study tours  Establish and operate PPMS  Train staff in ADB project procedures, 8 postgraduate trainees trained  Procure and operate vehicles and equipment  Prepare and submit project accounts and progress reports  Support DOA of MOAC in preparation of PCR
Outputs: HVC value chains in mid west and far west region supplying markets   Post harvest enterprises adding value to HVC production   Small and medium farmers producing HVC to meet supply agreements   Business plans for producing and adding value to HVC in the far west and mid west region.  HVC markets identified, value chain market information systems developed and post harvest investment proposals assessed  Farmer groups with market supply agreements, HVC production plans and HVC production and farm technology investment proposals   Grant Disbursement - Impact and Governance Assessed  Effective Project Management
Impact: Increased profitability of small and medium farmers in 10 Project Districts    Value added for HVC produced in Project districts increased by 15% by 2020.  Farm incomes of small and medium farmers increased by at least 20% in real terms by 2017 over 2011 baseline level by 2020.
Outcome: Increased production of HVC by small and medium farmers with greater involvement of women.    By 2017, small and medium sized farmers with 7,500 ha of supply agreements have increased their returns by 30% from high value commodities  By 2017, at least 200 HVC enterprise grants and 30 Farmer Cooperatives with HVC supply contracts and grower agreements with Farmer groups  Participating farmers producing on average 0.4 ha more HVC compared to 2011  Proportion of women's cash income contributing to family welfare increased by 60% from 2011 levels
District: - Baitadi (Baitadi) - Banke (Nepalgunj) - Bardiya (Gulariya) - Dadeldhura (Dadeldhura) - Dailekh (Dullu) - Dang Deukhuri (Ghorahi) - Darchula (Darchula) - Doti (Dipayal) - Kailali (Dhangadhi)

Project Title: Domesticated Forest Products Value Chain Development Programme (DFPVC)
Input: Development, consolidation and institutionalisation of pro-poor, inclusive and climate-proofed VC Approach   Consolidation and promotion of networks and partnerships for FP based enterprises  Promotion of pro-poor, inclusive and entrepreneurship-oriented enabling framework  Mainstreaming G4E, M&E and Climate change agenda  Resource mobilisation
Outputs: FP VCs    Facilitation of organisational and SIGE strengthening processes Capacity building of the key stakeholders for improved policy- influencing, production,, processing Building networks with business Exploration on new NTFP options Micro Small and Medium (MSME) Enterprise's strengthening through business planning, fund linkage, diversification and quality control Bamboo * Resource inventory and feasibility for three 3 community based processing centres assessed  Capacity building of industries on improved housing designs  Support enabling framework and capacity building for community-private sector partnerships Support networking for promoting bamboo inclusive business
Impact: 50, 000 households benefited from timber VCs by 2012 through increased annual income up to $240 000 especially for poor and disadvantaged  Inceased employment by 1500 with 25% poor and disadvantaged  880 000 $ income generated benefiting 10,000 households by 2012 out of which 30% are poor and disadvantaged  7500 households benefited through an annual income of $ 82 500  200 new jobs created with 50% belonging to poor and disadvantaged group
Outcome: * Forest products related institutions and public/private growers practice improved pre-production and sustainable forest management * Communities and networks/clients practice efficient and effective business planning, micro-enterprise development with pro-poor and community orientation * Improved policy and regulatory framework leads to increase in pro-poor and inclusive wood based enterprise development * Private sector-Community interfaced enterprises increase * NTFP groups and networks show improved access to service delivery * Benefit sharing amongst NTFP networks and groups is gender-based and socially inclusive * Improved policy, production, processing and value addition is effected * Improved products and market linkage (incl. Inclusive Business) * Functional and sustainable linkages built with other Service Providers * Established MSMEs are working on sustainable basis  * Bamboo resource inventory and capacities of three viable and efficient community pre-processing units established * Buy-back mechanisms for new products between pre-processing units and partners developed * Appropriate policy framework, guidelines for business-community partnership advocated  * AEC/FNCCI and bamboo industries adopt inclusive business. * Networks and partnerships for pooling and mobilizing resources established

Project Title: High Value Crops Programme (HVCP) - East
Input: Capacity building of cooperatives s & factories on organic practice & standards   Support Agro-vets companies and cooperatives to get engaged in organic input supply to farmers.   Facilitate the establishment of credit lines with factories and cooperatives   Facilitate the cooperatives to establish green leaf collection centres   IB brokering between anchor companies and their cooperatives   Capacity development of district level cooperative federations and a central federation for lobbying and advocacy.   Facilitate Public Private Dialogue concerning the existing tea policy   Technical Assistance to Ministry of Agriculture and Commerce to develop Organic Agriculture policy
Outputs: 4550 Small holder households receive services from factories and cooperatives on organic farming  2000 small holder households have access to organic inputs from either agro-vets or cooperatives  800 households received loan at least one time of minimum NPR 10,000 each from either the cooperatives or the factories for the purpose of buying organic inputs  At least 20 primary cooperatives will have at least 1 green leaf collection centre   51 cooperatives receive services from the district level cooperative federations  Central cooperative federation will actively continue lobbying and advocacy   Organic Agriculture policy approved and enforced by MoAC  The Tea Policy amended in light to organic and enforced
Impact: Increased income and employment of small holder tea farmers  Increased net income of small holder farmers (of 3,000 household by 17% and of 7,000 household by 5%)  Increased outreach of organic program intervention (10,000 household of which 3,000 direct and 7,000 indirect small holders farmers benefits)  Additional job (1,400 at farmer, 70 at cooperative, 90 at factory and 2,500 at pluckers) created
Outcome: Additional price for organic green leaf suppliers (farmers) secured.   Supply chain of organic tea industry strengthened to meet quality and quantity of organic green leaf and export volume.   Organic agriculture policy formulated and organic component of the policy incorporated into the national tea policy.

Project Title: Pro Poor Reduction of Emissions from Deforestation and Destruction of Forests (REDD)
Input: Contextual analysis, community mapping and cost benefit analysis of REDD   formulation of REDD management plan including benefit sharing mechanism   Capacity development related to REDD process   assessment of local REDD like payment mechanism and streamline them into national REDD framework for sustainability  Support multistakeholder's discussions and debate on REDD and benefit sharing mechanism  Capacity building of civil society and government line agencies through participation on national and regional workshops  linkage building of indentified civil society organisations, national authorities to national climate change forums   strengthen capacity of District Forest Coordination Committee (DFCCs) in REDD process discussions and partnerships   Analyse and document the learning of REDD into recommendations in order streamlise in national REDD framework   Develop Capacity development package on REDD for sub-national users   Support and strengthen sub-national multi-stakeholders on REDD consultation processes   Sub-national REDD learning platforms prepared and functional, and lessons   Documentation and publication on lesson learnt
Outputs: Establishment of pro-poor and socially inclusive national REDD framework supported based livelihood activities with selected communities   Equitable and socially inclusive REDD benefit ensured through sharing mechanism to initiate alternative livelihoods activities   Institutional arrangements developed for wider dissemination of knowledge and lessons learnt national
Impact: Improved local livelihoods of communities through REDD benefits
Outcome: Local communities are prepared and able to engage in alternative/sustainable livelihood options that reduce deforestation and forest degradation    REDD stakeholders strengthened and better organised to influence REDD policy, both nationally and sub nationally, with particular focus on equitable benefit sharing mechanism    Learning and Lessons on REDD documented, shared and disseminated at national and sub national level
District: - Bara (Kalaiya) - Chitwan (Bharatpur) - Dhanusa (Janakpur) - Mahottari (Jaleswor) - Makwanpur (Hetauda) - Parsa (Birgunj) - Rautahat (Gaur) - Sarlahi (Malangwa)

Project Title: B2B Programme
Nepal Children's Scholarship Endowment Program

Outputs: Output 1.1.: Out of school children identified and supported to bring them to school and scholarship  Output 1.2: Dalit and vulnerable children provided scholarship  Output 2.1: Percentage of school attendance of the scholarship recipients improved   Output 2.2: Increase pass rate of the scholarship recipients  Output 3.1.: Parent's involvement increased in scholarship activities.  Output 4.1.: Good practices and gaps of scholarship programs in the implementation made public.  Output 4.2. Increased policy consultation and dialogue for amendment and/or formulation of scholarship policy.

Outcome 2: Increased learning achievement among Dalit scholarship supported children and youths.  Outcome 3: Increased participation of the parents and school management committee to ensure the education of Dalit children. Project Title: Child Sensitive Social Protection
Input: Theme: :Livelihood, subtheme: Income and Asset Growth in support of nuitrition, healt and education
Outputs: To increase number of social protection initiatives for poor households, especially those with deprived or vulnerable children.
Impact: Children are able to regularly attend school, less engaged in labour that deprives their holistic development, better uptake of health facilities and have improved nutrition and food sufficiency
Outcome: Increased in number of social protection (SP) initiatives for poor households, especially those with deprived or vulnerable children, enhanced child sensitivity with parents, caregivers, the community, institutions and key service providers, Improved livelihood opportunities for the poorest households and Platforms and forums are supported/ established and influenced at various levels ( District and national) to promote willingness of the GoN to increase the number of social protection programmes and make them more conducive to children

Project Title: Protection of Children in Brick Kiln
Input: Child Protection , Protect against harmful child labour
Outputs: 1.To enhance and ensure protection of children working in brick kilns1  2.To rescue, rehabilitate and reintegrate child laborers working in brick kilns who are in abusive condition .  3.To strengthen legal and policy provisions to eradicate worst forms of child labor and particularly that in brick kilns
Impact: To contribute to eradicating child labor from brick kilns
Outcome: 1.Increased knowledge on child protection among children,parents ,employeer and contractor( Nayak)  2.Increased acess of child labour education,health,protection and sanitaion .  3.Rehabilitate and reintegrated.  4.Decrease number of new working children in Brick Factory.  5.Enhanced policy provisions and practice to ensure child labor free brick factories partilarly in brick factory.  6.Enhanced policy provisions and practice to ensure child labor free brick factories partilarly in brick factory.  7.Identifiedlegal and ploicy gap related to child labour particularly in brick kiln.

Project Title: Promoting Quality Education through Community Based School Management Follow-up
School Health and Nutrition Project
Input: The project supports piloting the implementation of School Health and Nutrition Strategy, prepares School Health and Nutrition Package, and disseminate it to feedback at the national level.
Outputs: 1. The provision of School Health Service Minimum Package is improved in target schools. 2. The health related knowledge, behavior and habits of shool-aged children are improved through school health activities in target schools. 3. School health activities are systematically and collaboratively executed and managed by concerned offices, committees and other stakeholders in the target districts. 4. A practical model is developed by the experience of the project and the plan of expanding the model in accordance with the National School Health and Nutrition Strategy is developed at the central level.
Impact: Health and nutrition status of school-aged children is improved in the target districts.
Outcome: 1. Utilization of school health services is increased among school-aged children in the target districts. 2. Implementation system of the National School Health and Nutrition Strategy is strengthened in the Ministry of Health and Population and the Ministry of Education.

Project Title: Promotion of Maternal and Child Health at 4 VDCs in Nawalparasi District
Input: Activities to strengthen knowledge on maternal and child health, financial responsiveness in women group, emergency transport system, sub-helth post medical care.
Outputs: 1. Improvement of knowledge related to Maternal & Child Health in target group. 2. Improvement of financial responsiveness in Women's group. 3. Urgent patient transport system established. 4. Improvement of medical care at sub-health posts.
Impact: Reduction of maternal and infant mortality rate.
Outcome: Improvement of Maternal and Child Health at target area.

Project Title: Creating Protective Environment for Children( CPEC)
Input: Child Protection: harmful child labor, children sexually abused and exploited and anti-child trafficking
Outputs: 1. Child protection systems at district and community level are effectively functioning to prevent and respond to violation of children's protection rights 2. School environment is child friendly, safe and protective 3. Law implementing agencies are effectively preventing and responding to cases of child rights violations 4. Children demonstrate enhanced capacity to protect themselves from violence, abuse and exploitation
Impact: By 2013, children are learning and developing in a safe and protective environment in Sindhupalchowk district of Nepal.
Outcome: By 2013, children's vulnerability to labour, marriage, trafficking, physical, sexual and emotional abuse, neglect and exploitation has reduced in 23 VDC's of Sindhupalchowk district of Nepal.

Project Title: Integrated Maternal Newborn, Child Health and Nutrition Project
Input: Maternal and newborn nutrition; Child Nutrition
Outputs: 1. Newborns, children and adolescents, particularly in under-served/ low-coverage populations, benefit from quality health and nutrition services at community level in SC working areas  2. Communities increasingly adopt healthy practices related to newborn, child and adolescent health and nutrition in the SC working areas
Impact: Increase in % of deliveries attended by Skilled Birth Attendants (SBA)  Increase in % of Recently Delivered Women and newborns receiving 3 postnatal visits  Increase in % of babies exclusively breast fed up to 6 months  Increase in % of newborns who were breast fed within one hour of delivery  Increase in % of infants 6 - 9 months of age who received breast milk and a solid/semi-solid food  Increase in % of children 6-23 months receive complementary foods 3 times per day with all 3 food groups  Increase in % of children  5 years with diarrhoea receiving oral rehydration therapy or increased fluids, with continued feeding  Increase in % of children  5 years with suspected pneumonia receiving antibiotics
Outcome: Newborns, U5s, maternal care and nutrition services at community level expanded  Improved quality of MNCHN services at facility and community levels  Health Management Information System (HMIS) strengthened at sub-national level  Increased knowledge of mothers and household decision makers on MNCHN practices and care-seeking

Project Title: Tackling HRH Crisis in Nepal through Informed Policy Decisions and Actions
Input: Health & Nutrition and Health System strengthen
Outputs: To enhance HRH research and policy advocacy capacity of CSOs and NSAs  To promote research for building knowledge base on HRH issues in-country, relating it to regional and global context  To instigate and propagate national and sub-national debates and advocacy campaigns on HRH issues through strategic alliance led by CSO  To strengthen capacity of public sector authorities for better and evidence-based design, implementation and monitoring of policies related to HRH management
Impact: To set the issue of HRH into the wider context of health system reform by engaging civil society organizations (CSOs) and non-state actors (NSAs) towards building the knowledge base for all and policy advocacy
Outcome: (a) Formation of CSOs and NSAs capable of generating and propagating evidence as well as raising stronger voice to support HRH policy design, implementation and monitoring; (b) Increased commitment and capacity of public sector authorities to work better towards tackling HRH crisis; (c) Strengthened health care delivery to the general population through improved HRH situation

Improved skills of facility-based health workers in management of newborn illness at health facilities in program districts.    Improved newborn care practices in homes in program districts.    Improved management of neonatal sickness at community level in program districts
Impact: · To reduce the maternal, neonatal, and child mortality.
Outcome: Trainned all front line health workers on newborn care and reduced morbidity management skills in program districts and trained to all focal teachers engaed in teaching through pre-service training on new born care

Project Title: PCR 1, IR 5: Capacity of Govt/ Stakeholders in disaster risk reduction, preparedness, response & recovery enhanced to ensure H&N status of children, adolescents girls & women during humanitarian crisis
Input: 1. Number of staff with knowledge and skills in Nutrition in Emergencies, health in emergencies and HIV AIDS in emergency available in Health sector 2. Strategic framework to respond to the health and nutritional needs (based on CCC and sphere standards) of at least 50% children and pregnant and lactating women in emergencies available by 2011 and outlined activities implemented in 2012 in all humanitarian crisis    3. Number of disaster prone districts with operational District Contingency Plan (DCP) including health and nutrition component that incorporates gender and equity issues in line with CCCs. 4. Stockpiles of emergency health and nutrition supplies available for 50,000 affected population including appropriate health and nutrition supplies for women and adolescence girls at strategic locations (Biratnagar for East, Bharatpur for Central and West, Nepalgung for Mid and Far West region
Outputs: The health and nutrition status of mothers, children and adolescents improved with focus on socially excluded and economically marginalized groups and equitable and participatory approach and implementation of high-impact cost effective proven interventions.
Impact: The Health and Population Ministry's vision or goal of the health sector is to improve the health and nutritional status of the Nepali population and provide equal opportunity for all to receive quality health care services free of charge or affordable thereby contributing to poverty alleviation (NHSP II); Enhance utilisation of quality health services by ensuring access and service utilisation of all citizens from various groups, areas and community. Reduce malnutrition problem by including it as multi sectoral issue to implement approaches effectively ( Approach Paper for 3 years interim plan, GoN, 2010)
Outcome: Socially excluded and economically marginalized groups including adolescents improved with focus on socially and economically marginalized group and equitable and participatory approach and implementation of high impact cost effective proven interventions.
District: - Achham (Mangalsen) - Bardiya (Gulariya) - Jajarkot (Khalanga) - Kanchanpur (Mahendara Nagar) - Mugu (Gamgadhi)

Project Title: Norad Cooperation 2011-2014
Input: Education, Child Rights Governance, HIV and AIDS and Humanitarian
Outputs: · To increase engagement of NGO coalitions and the National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) in child rights monitoring; and  improve the learning environment in schools and ECD centers    To improve the quality of education and access of the marginalized children to education    Contribute to creating and implementing favorable policy for safe, supportive and protective learning environment    To enhance the knowledge and skills of children and most at risk youth to protect themselves against HIV and AIDS and mitigate the impact through SoVAA.  Create a supportive environment for children affected by AIDS (CABA) within their communities    Strengthen DRR initiative by building capacity of staff, partners and increased stockpiling.
Impact: Improved quality of primary and basic education in SC working areas  Increased enrolment of out of school children (specially marginalized groups) in primary and basic education  Constitutional/legal provision made for i) Free and compulsory basic education, ii) students participation in SMC and iii) banning political activities and corporal punishment in schools  Improved implementation of CR related recommendations by the government  Increased NHRC monitoring and responses to child rights violation in Nepal  Children are able to voice out their concerns in their own leadership and their voices and concerns are heard  Number of CABAs infected and affected by AIDS receiving priority needs - quality HIV & AIDS related services  Disaster affected children's immediate needs fulfilled and their access to education and protection measures ensured also benefiting their family members.

Continuation of schooling thru education material support to CABAs  IGA skill training and seed money to CABAs families

Project Title: Providing HIV and AIDS education for illiterate women through community learning centres (CLCs)
Input: Development of learning material on HIV and AIDS in Nepali and local languages (Doteli and Tharu)  This learning material will be developed in reference to existing teaching learning materials and with special consideration to the local context. A national level consultant will be hired for developing the resource manual  (November 2010-February 2011)  Training of literacy facilitators:  Training will be provided to 80 Literacy Facilitators to build their capacity to plan and provide non-formal training to illiterate women on HIV and AIDS  (Feb -March 2011)  Testing of the learning materials in two CLC literacy classes (one per district)  (Feb 2011)  Revision and production of the learning material and its dissemination to other 80 groups through CLCs  (March- April 2011)  Organization of literacy classes (ca 20 women/class) to 80 groups through CLCs  ( Feb-Sept 2011)  Assessment on the knowledge on HIV and AIDS among participants  (April and Oct 2011)  Advocacy to the government for adopting the learning material on HIV and AIDS and to different literacy programmes  (Oct 2011)  Monitoring, follow-up, evaluation and reporting of the project  (December 2011)
Outputs: 1. 4000 copies of the learning material produced. 2. 80 literacy facilitators trained to use the learning material 3. 1500 illiterate women received education on HIV and AIDS through 80 literacy classes
Outcome: 1. Improvement in awareness on comprehensive knowledge on HIV and AIDS of the targeted illiterate women in mid- and far-western regions by 50%; 2. Basic literacy skills acquired; 3. Adaptation of the learning material by Government and its utilization by different literacy and HIV and AIDS prevention programmes.
Donor Agency: Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS

Outcome: # Beneficiaries: Over 34,000 primary and 129,000 secondary beneficiaries, most of whom are from marginalized caste/ ethnic groups and families that fall below Nepal's national poverty line    · Reduction in death/ casualties: This is difficult to measure, but in an average flood year approximately 5-6 people per VDC perish. This can generally be reduced to 0 - 1 deaths in a VDC with good DRR knowledge, or over 50 lives in the project area in times of severe flooding      I

Outputs: Major Total Expected Outputs of Projects:         Approximately 15000 farmers HHs (70,000 people) will have access to resilient livelihood and sustainable food security services and preparedness from disaster through 90 farmers field schools/groups         Around 10,000 farmers empowered to have regular access to government food security and DRR programmes         At least 15000 potential migrants and their families made aware on safe migration process         Approximately 1000 returnee migrant workers receive legal aid, referral services, shelter and other services and claim their entitlements from recruiters and government         300 women and 500 men from Dalits, Madheshi, Muslim are developed as community leaders for their inclusion and participation at local governance bodies and structures         Approximately 10,000 women and men from Dalits, Madhesi and Muslim communities have increased access to government programmes and services
Impact: 5.2.2 Project Objectives:      Overall Objective:    Contribute to poverty reduction of the poorest and vulnerable communities from highly food insecure and disaster affected areas of Nepal through resilient livelihood, safe migration and empowerment.      Specific objectives         Improve resilient livelihoods and sustainable food security of most vulnerable and food insecure communities in disaster prone and food insecure areas in far western region of Nepal         Enhancing safer migration through empowerment of potential migrant workers, family members and returnee migrant workers, support to make government policies and systems effective, and strengthening migrants' civil society organisations.         Increase participation of women and men from vulnerable/discriminated communities in furthering accountable governance and fostering a culture of equality and diversity
Outcome: Major Expected Outcomes:         More than 15,000 HHs from excluded and marginalized communities adopt, promote climate resilient and sustainable livelihood/agriculture technologies (low cost, replicable, easy to manage, innovative) reducing the food insecure periods from 180 to 50 days    Local govt. line agencies acknowledge and promote climate resilient livelihood models in their development programs    Increased access of excluded and marginalized women and men (more than 10,000 HHs) to govt. programmes /provisions on food security, natural resources, disaster mitigation, preparedness, and response    Increased legitimate representation and active engagement of excluded and marginalized communities including women in relevant local decision making bodies and CSOs by 50 %    Increased number of migrants who access services and assistance, including interventions from government through the legal system    Increased active participation of migrants, particularly women, in public actions, lobbying activities and decision making processes.    Enhanced effective implementation of existing policies and UN convention on migration and foreign employment policies    Increased women leaders from discriminated communities (Dalits and other excluded groups) that are elected and actively represented in local governance structures    Increased influence on gender sensitive policy priorities and resource allocation by a range of women from discriminated groups,    Increased formal and informal spaces in govt and social institutions for Dalits and other excluded groups to participate and access justice, programmes and resources as per govt. policies and commitments    Increase in the access to protection measures for safeguarding rights of women/ men human rights defenders and their organizations
District: - Achham (Mangalsen) - Banke (Nepalgunj) - Bardiya (Gulariya) - Dadeldhura (Dadeldhura) - Doti (Dipayal) - Kailali (Dhangadhi) - Kanchanpur (Mahendara Nagar) - Kapilvastu (Taulihawa) - Kathmandu (Kathmandu) - Morang (Biratnagar) - Salyan (Salyan Khalanga) - Sunsari (Inaruwa) - Udayapur (Gaighat)
Secondary Sector Sub-Sector: - Agriculture, forestry, fishing and hunting - Social exclusion n.e.c.
Primary Sector: - AGRICULTURE - LABOUR - WOMEN, CHILDREN & SOCIAL WELFARE

Outputs: Expected Total Programme Outputs Component 1: Disaster Risk Reduction: Major Outputs:  1.  At least 3 small-level schemes on structural mitigations works/schemes for flood control/river erosion constructed benefitting at least 5000 HHs.  2.  4 schemes ofboat support to disaster affected communities provided.  3.  At least 5 schemes ofcommunity based Early Warning System established and made functional  4.  At least 100 disaster affected households supported with agriculture inputs (such seeds, fertilizers, technical support) for their livelihood.  5.  At least 10,000 targeted marginalized at-risk women, children, elderly, people with disabilities are  r enabled and empowered to participate in hazard specific mitigation and disaster preparedness activities through ORR training.  6.  At least IS Community Disaster Management Committees (CDMCs) of project area will have their own Disaster and Climate Risk Adaptation Plan in place and implemented accordingly.  7.  At least 300 officials, and members from govt. and DMCs and CSOs are trained and sensitized on mock drills, DRR, climate and preparedness plans, contingency plans etc  8.  At least 800 students from 4 schools ofproject area will be sensitized on DRR messages.  9.  The representation of women, socially excluded and ethnic minority in CDMCs and other community groups will be increased by at least 40% and participation in community activities by 50%.  10.  Strengthened coordination with VDC, DDC, DDRC, Red Cross etc for effective humanitarian response at VDC and district levels.  II. 7 VDcs adopted and enhanced the practice of mainstreaming DRR approach in their development activities by the government and non-government organizations working in the project area  12.  The local government body (VDCs) of the project area will start at least one joint initiative on disaster risk reduction measure.  13.  Enhanced knowledge and capacity of organization's members and project staffs to work on the issue of right based DRR and climate change.  Component 2: Safe Migration: Major Outputs:  I. At least I migrant's information booth/centre will be established and made functional in international airport departure terminal.  2.  At least 100,000 migrants, potential migrants and their family members will have correct and authentic information, awareness and knowledge on safe migrations through information booths, radio programmes, IECs and Hotline services.  3.  At least 500 cases of victimized and vulnerable migrants will receive legal support services, counseling and referral services  4.  At least 450 migrants receive pre-employment training and enhanced confidence.  5.  At least IS returnee migrants' forums formed and strengthened and supported.  6.  At least 20 listeners' clubs of direct potential migrants and potential persons formed and strengthened reaching more than 2000 migrants and potential migrants .  7.  Migration issue will be featured regularly in policy dialogues related to labor, trade, and trafficking through various advocacy events.  8.  Increased access to justice and govt. entitlements for vulnerable and women migrants.  9.  At least 500 officials and members from govt. agencies, CSOs and different networks will be made aware and sensitized on the migrants rights, migration and development issues and prepare them for ratification of CMW through various thematic capacity building training and advocacy initiatives

Project Title: Making Markets for the Poor
Input: Baseline study and AKAP analysis    Employment market studies    Assessment of infrastructure, management and financial systems of stakeholders and training providing institutions;    Technical assistance to stakeholders and training providing institutions;    Partnership between stakeholders and training providing institutions; and financial service providers to design appropriate financial products    Technical assistance to financial service providers to design and deliver appropriate financial services    Assessment of products and services being offered to trainees and its effectiveness    Facilitation of workshops, meetings and visits between job placement agencies, stakeholders and training providing institutions and trainees    Technical support to initiate job fairs and on site job placement services within stakeholders and training providing institutions;    ToT on MECD for targeted youths to initiate self-employment    Initiation of JRC within local CCIs    Joint initiative between DoLEP, stakeholders and training providing institutions; and other market actors to update information on job placements, demand, market trends, new courses and pedagogy;    Rural jobs information web portal developed and embedded within Practical Answers services    Training needs assessment and conduct customised ToT in joint partnership with stakeholders and training providing institutions;    Facilitation of workshops, meeting and interactions amongst key public line agencies and stakeholders and training providing institutions; to design and develop quality standards for course design and certification    Cross learning visits for participating stakeholders and training providing institutions; and key stakeholders    Formation of LENs within VDC clusters    BLOP training and group counselling    Technical and resource assistance for LENs start up and development of sustainability plan    Facilitation of linkages between LENs and JRC for access to information, resources and business registration/start up related support    Facilitation of events such as trade shows, market fairs and matchmaking through JRCs and LENs    Value chain analysis to identify appropriate sectors and products suitable for small rural enterprises and MECD/SIYB training for rural youths    Joint initiatives with local financial institutes to design, pilot and deliver rural youth appropriate financial products and services    Capacity building and technical training to local agro vets and other agriculture inputs providers    Participatory Market Mapping (PMM) workshops    Formation and regular meeting of PAC and DPAC    Policy analysis and development of policy briefs and communication campaigns     District, regional and national level events targeted at policy influencers
Outputs: · Non State Actors (training providing institutions, input service providers, financial institutions and CCIs) are able to design, develop and deliver appropriate market based training and courses   · Public (Cottage and Small Industries) and private sector have better access to information to update revise and manage their courses and delivery systems   · Rural youths build confidence, skills and networks to utilise skills development training for employment   · Rural youths have better access to critical inputs and services, and rewarding markets   · Influence policy makers and other stakeholders for the development and support for inclusive and pro-poor employment services and opportunities
Impact: To improve the livelihoods of poor and marginalised rural communities through better employment opportunities
Outcome: To strengthen the capacity and network of private and public technical and vocational training institutes to provide demand based skills and trainings to 5,000 rural youths from Achham, Doti and Kailali

Project Title: Local capacity building for arsenic mitigation in Nawalparasi
Input: Capacity building activities of the community organization for arsenic mitigation and awareness buliding of community members in arsenic and supporting for construction of safe water provision system.
Outputs: 1. Community organization for arsenic mitigation. 2. Community members trained for arsenic mitigation. 3. Information diffusion on arsenic contamination. 4. Preparation for construction of safe water provision system.
Impact: Target communities are motivated to address the arsenic contamination problem and initiate concrete actions for that purpose.
Outcome: Target communities recognize effects of arsenic contamination, set up community organization for arsenic mitigation and train community members for arsenic mitigation.

Project Title: A Collaborative Approach Promoting Child Rights, Non-discrimination and Child Participation
Input: Child Rights Governance
Outputs: The overall objective of the action is "to reduce discrimination against children, including increasing their access to social security schemes, enhancing their protection and their participation in decision making on issues related to them, through the joint cooperation of the civil society and the government".
Impact: The project intends to reduce discrimination against children, including increasing their access to social security schemes, enhancing their protection and their participation in decision making on issues related to them, through the joint cooperation of civil society and the government
Outcome: The action will create a platform for a collaborative partnership between civil society coalitions and civil society organisations (CSOs) working on children's issues, the government, media and the NHRIs to address identified gaps in government policy formulation and implementation of child rights.

Project Title: Regional TA: Integrating the Right to Adequate Food and Good Goverance in National Policies, Legistation and Institutions
Input: 1. Hold Awareness building and capacity development seminars for parliamentarians, government officials, judges and representatives from civil society organizations on how to implement the right to food and good governance in the context of their work.   2. Provide technical assistance and policy advice on the right to food in view of the development of right to food legistations, policies, programmes and strategies in Nepal.   3. Undertake advocacy, monitoring and information activies in collaboration with CSOs.
Outputs: The right to food and human rights principles are integrated in the Constitution and other relevant legistation.
Impact: Right to Adequate Food and Good Goverance in National Policies, Legistation and Institutions be integrated.
Outcome: Strengthehed institutional and Technical capacities to integrate the right to food into legistation, strategies and programs.

Project Title: The Food Security Project for Underprivileged Farmers- 2012(KR2)
Input: 1. Procrument of fertilizers.   2. Providing services necessary for the trasportation of the products to Nepal and those for internal transportation.   3. Providing agent's fees necessary for the employment of the agent.
Outputs: The status of underprivileged farmers will be improved and the food security as well.
Impact: To improve food security and livelihood.
Outcome: Agriculture production to enable Nepal to meet growing demand for food be improved.

Project Title: Enhancing Capacity of DoCPR
Input: The central record keeping practice has been modified and improved to develop effective service delivery.The system is sub-divided into several sub -components:personnel information system, post management system; payroll management system,pension and gratuity management system, property tracking system.
Outputs: The project shall be named  Enhancing capacity of DoCPR in developing and maintaining an inclusive diversity profile of civil personnel and effective HRMIS for the Government of Nepal. The Department of Civil Personnel Records under the Ministry of General Administration shall be the implementing agency. The system records personal details of government empoyees with sex dissaggregation but does not reflect other important social components e.g. the caste\ethnicity, regional identity, geographical remoteness and disability. These elements are essential for the Government to understand the existing diverstiy profile within the civil service and to identify areas for improvement.
Impact: This project exists folloing impacts:   * Help in data update in PIS.   * Improve service delivery through strengethening of infrastructure.   * Enhance MIS capabilities for effective HR Administration and policy-making in context of social equality and federal government structure.
Outcome: The key aim of this project is to develop authentic and primary information regarding inclusiveness of civil service in Nepal. The specific objectives are:-   * Develop a common understanding on social identity categorises to be applied across Government bodies.   * Design inclusive personnel record system base on self-identification by goverment employees.   * Build capacity for maintaing inclusive personnel record system as part of the personnel information system (PIS) and for informing government policies.

Project Title: Water Guard - Safe Water System (SWS)

Outputs: Increase acccess to Water Guard    Increase opportunity, ability and motivation to correctly and consistently use water guard to prevent diarrheal diesease in childern under five    Increase knowledge of importance of safe drinking water to reduce incidence of diarrhea in childern under five.
Outcome: Reduce morbidity due to water borne disease in childern under five years of age    Increase percent of houeholds with childern under five years of age using water treated at point og use by a safe water system    Increase the percent of households with children under five years of age who cover thier drinking water container

Project Title: Sustainable & Efficient Industrial Development (SEID)
Nepal District Health Programme
Input: Construction/Rehabilitation of Bheri Zonal Hospital    Construction/rehabilitation of Dhading and Bardia District Hospitals    Construction/Rehabilitation of Gajuri Primary Health Care Center (PHC) of Dhading District; Sourahawa PHC and RajaPur PHC of Bardia District.

Project Title: Biogas Support Program - Phase IV
Input: Human Resource  Financial Resources  Physical Resources  Organizational Resources
Outputs: The overall objective of BSP-IV is to further develop and disseminate biogas plants as a mainstream renewable energy solution in rural Nepal, while better addressing poverty, social inclusion and regional balance issues and at the same time ensuring enhanced commercialization and sustainability of the sector. The project outputs are as follows:   Quality biogas plants construction in rural areas scaled up and their proper operation ensures.  Pro-poor orientation and outreach of the programme enhanced through applied research and studies for optimized designs, operation and benefits of the biogas technology.  Gender mainstreaming and social inclusion practices are applied in the programme  Systematic and sustainable progress made towards developing a commercially viable and market oriented biogas sector.  Sectoral players strengthened for sustainable development of the biogas sector  Mechanisms and capability strengthened for availability of micro credit facility to farmers for credit financing biogas plants in rural Nepal.  Biogas CDM projects developed, promoted and implemented to meet fund gap in the phase IV and beyond.
Impact: Drastically improved the socio-economic and environmental condition.
Outcome: Reduction of the workload mainly women and girls by about 3 hours/day/household. The saved time is used for education, income generation activities.  Generation of district and indirect employment to some 12,000 persons  Fuel wood used for cooking @ 2 tons/plant  Agriculture waste @ 0.35 ton/plant  During cakes @ 0.60 ton/plant  Annual saving on kerosene @ 25 ton/plant  Annual reduction of GHG emissions @ 7 ton/plant  Annual production @ 1.75 ton/plant bio-slurry and bio compost.  Proper usage of bio-slurry and bio-compost 90% households  Improved agriculture yields and reduced use of chemical fertilizers.  Improvement of rural sanitations by connecting in 75% plants  Reduction of indoor air pollution due to kitchen smoke reduces incidence of illness and expenses on health.

Project Title: Renewable Energy for Rural Livelihoods (RERL)
Input: The main activities of the project is to support Government of Nepal/Alternative Energy Promotion Centre (AEPC)'s commitment to meet the World Bank target of 4.25 MW; provide policy advisory support to enable GON/AEPC to take lead on programme implementation beyond 2012; and promote sustainable livelihoods through energy-linked value chain enterprises which preferentially encourage participation of women and marginalized communities.
Outputs: To contribute to increase the access of energy services and promote productive end uses by creating favorable institutional and policy environment in Renewable Energy sector. Technical assistance will be provided to create planning, executing, monitoring and evaluating capacities within AEPC and DDCs and at community level as relevant.
Impact: RERL is to contribute to economic, environmental and social benefits of the rural people by removing barriers that have hindered the wider promotion and use of renewable energy resources particularly in rural areas of Nepal.
Outcome: Provided support to install 4.25 MW of power generation from micro hydro in 40 districts and increased income of communities living in those districts.
