Project Title: Safe Practices on Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (Safe-WASH)
Input: Community based interventions to encourage construction of household latrines and community water supply, and improve hygiene behaviors.    Capacity building of the implementing partners. preparedness plans    · Conduct trainings, drill and simulations for Plan and its partners
Impact: · Girls, children with disabilities, children of Dalit families, and children belonging to the most marginalised ethnic groups will have improved health status and grow up in an environment conducive to good health.    · Girls, children with disabilities, children of Dalit families, and children belonging to the most marginalised ethnic groups will have access to and complete their basic education in a child-friendly, good-quality learning environment in which they have a voice.   · The very poorest and most marginalised families will achieve sufficient economic security to ensure that children's rights to education, health, and protection are fulfilled.   · All children in Plan working areas, but particularly children at risk, will be protected from exploitative working conditions, trafficking and gender-based violence, and will exercise their rights to identity and participation.   · Children and youths will live in an environment that is resilient to disaster and be able to secure their rights to education, health and protection even during disasters and conflict-induced emergencies.
Outcome: · To reduce neonatal and maternal mortality rates   · To prevent PMTCT of HIV and support the treatment and care of infected mothers and children through PMTCT-plus services    · To reduce the incidence and severity of disabilities through prevention, treatment, and rehabilitation    · To increase access to an adequate and reliable supply of clean water and to promote the treatment and multiple use of water    · To increase access to sanitation facilities and to promote good hygiene   · To increase access to and completion of basic education (ECED to grade 8), especially among girls, children from marginalised and excluded communities, Dalit children, children with disabilities, and children at risk.    · To improve the quality of basic education by developing the capacity of schools and educational system to effectively introduce child-friendly and non-violent teaching and learning methods.    · To improve educational governance by ensuring that the most marginalised children, parents and communities participate meaningfully in decision_making and by advocating for the effective implementation of free and compulsory basic education.   · To expand the outreach of microfinance services to very poor and the most marginalised of households, especially women, to increase their economic security.   · To economically empower the very poor and most marginalised of households, especially the landless, to access communal and government resources for group-based productive activities.    · To empower youth, from very poor and the most marginalised households, especially girls, by creating access to financial and non-financial services.   · To protect working children from exploitation and provide opportunities for formal education or better employment    · To prevent the trafficking of women and children and to protect those who are trafficked   · To protect women and girls from gender-based violence   · To promote children's right to an identity through birth registration    · To promote children's and youth's right to meaningful participation in decisions that affect their lives   · To help all children and their families and communities, especially the most vulnerable, to become more resilient to disasters, particularly floods and earthquakes    · To strengthen the capacity of local government bodies to incorporate and implement child-centred disaster risk reduction in the local level development and planning processes.   · To build the capacity of Plan and its partners for effective disaster preparedness and emergency response.

Project Title: Reducing the risk of HIV/AIDS spread in project areas
Input: -Male and female drug users will get residential counseling, treatment and rehabilitation as well as day care services from rehabilitation center and Baglung hospital.   -The clients who visit the rehabilitation center for day care services and all the graduated and positively discharged clients will receive counseling, follow up support and implement their respective rehabilitation plan for the successful rehabilitation.   -Drug, HIV and AIDS Prevention and Control Committee at selected 3 VDCs of Kaski district, 6 wards of Pokhara Sub Metropolitan City and two wards of Lekhnath Municipality will be actively mobilized.   -Women, youths, students and migrant population of the targeted community will get knowledge on drug, HIV/AIDS, STI and SRHR.
Outputs: -Reduce HIV transmission among the drug users by providing them quality treatment and social rehabilitation services, carrying out family follow up and community awareness and advocacy.   -To help reduce incidence and prevalence of HIV, TB and sexually transmitted infection among migrants, youth, women and children and improve quality of life of those who are already infected and affected.   -Reduction of Spread of HIV infection and improvement of health and quality of life of people living with HIV and AIDS (PLHA) in Kaski, Baglung and its adjoining districts.
Impact: Improved HIV/AIDS situation of the country.
Outcome: Minimized risk of HIV/AIDS infection and transmission and improved lives of infected and affected people in project areas.

Project Title: Crop Protection and Pesticide Development - National Integrated Pest Management Program (IPM) Phase II
Input: 1. Regular IPM Component implemented through MoAC 2. Intensive IMM Component implemented through FAO
Outputs: The Goal of the programme is to contribute to sustainable broad based poverty reduction and food security while contributing to human health and environmental protection The Objectives of the Programme are ( i) To contribute to institutionalize a sustainable national IPM Programme in Nepal by strengthening the capacity of PPD, collaborating national, regional and district level training and extension institutions in the government and non-government sectors to integrate IPM training and support programme for small holder farmers. (ii) To empower rural farmers including women to increase production and productivity efficiently, while protecting the environment, conserving the bio-diversity and avoiding health hazards for betterment of their livelihood and linking with markets. Quick Info- This project is run under assistance of Norwegian Goverment's grant assistance.  Commitment amount: (NOK 27 million)  Project Closing Date: 27 October 2013 Mode of Payment: Direct Payment. Executing Agency: MoAC Implementing Agency: Plant Protection Directorate with assistance from FAO
Impact: Outcome: National IPM Programme institutionalized and supporting community-based sustainable agriculture Outputs:  Regular Component: 1. The National IPM Programme is well institutionalized and fully functional 2. Existing IPM training capacities are maintained and enhanced in all districts 3. Information on the use and impact of pesticides is available and reflected in national policies  Intensive Component: 1. Institutional capacities to provide pre- and in-service training in IPM-FFS are enhanced 2. IPM-FFS farmer groups trained and organized to promote community-based sustainable agriculture 3. Support services for farmer groups result in optimized appropriated technologies, more efficient production and better access to markets 4. An information and coordination system is in place to monitor progress, support policy and ensure transparency and accountability
Outcome: To build on the existing institutional and programme strengths acquired by Nepal, both in the governmental and non-governmental sectors   To scale up IPM programme in commercialization of agriculture covering selected districts of Nepal

Identify appropriate technology on software, hardware and power    Enhance currently available e-content at www.telecenters.org.np    Construction of CeC buildings    Installation of software, hardware, network(s) and power equipment    Recruitment and training of operators.    Awareness workshop to sensitize on CeCs    Develop training materials and update operators' manual    Explore avenues to strengthen CeC activities in Nepal for better coordination.
Outputs: Employment generation and creation of new economic activities using ICT    Ensure good governence in rural areas    Reduce turnaround time    Fully functional UISCs, CCs, CeCs and VDCs
Impact: 1. Enabling and empowering rural people with the necessary tools to improve their living standard/livelihood by generating socio-economic development activities and access to faster and affordable information and public services.   2. To reduce poverty
Outcome: Provide efficient and effective e-services

Project Title: Bharatpur-Madi 33kv Sub Transmission Line & Rural Electrification Project
Input: Government of India provided USD 100 million loan assistance from Dollar Line of Credit Scheme to the Government of Nepal for Road, Rural Electrification, Power Transmission and Hydropower Projects. Of which USD 50 million is has been allocated on electricity sector and of this, USD 1.5 million has been apportioned to Bharatpur-Madi 33kv Sub Transmission Line & Rural Electrification Project   33kv Overhead Sub transmission line - 22KM from Chanuali to Madi Basantpur of Chitwan District, Nepal.  33kv Underground Line 8KM  3MVA (33/11kV) Sub-station in Madi Basantpur Bazar.  11kV Line - 30 KM & 400/230V Distribution Lines-50KM including transformers -1 Lot.
Outputs: This project is for electrification of 4VDCs of Southern Chitwan of Madi Area. The Government of India(The Export-Import of Bank) has agreed to provide loan assistance of US$1.5m under line of credit.
Impact: The economic benefits are expected to accure satisfactorily from the commissioning of Sub transmission Lines, substation and its distribution systems, including their capacity to fulfill the future demand and at the same time rapid growth of economic activities in the Area. the people at Madi regard electrification of the area as a step towards their economic prosperity and developments.
Outcome: The project will give benefit to more than 60000 population (more than 11000 households) living in 4 VDCs of Southern Chitwan of Madi Area located in border with INDIA and is without electricity still.

Project Title: Health and Nutrition
Input: 1) Nutrition Rehabilitation Homes,   2) Nutrition Outreach Program   3) Dieatician Training   4) HIV and AIDs care and treatment
Outputs: 1) Identiy and provide treatment for malnourished chidlren   2) Provide training to caretakers and other stakeholders on nutrition, care and support   3) Provide diet management training to health professionals, especially those working in government hospitals, NRHs and others.   4) Provide treatment, care and support to children living with HIV and AIDS and give training to the caretakers
Impact: The health of malnourished children will be improved and the life of children with HIV and AIDS will be prolonged and enhanced.
Outcome: Malnourished children will have gained proper weight/height through proper food, nutritional care and support.    Caretakers and relevant stakeholders will have received education on nutrition, care and support.    Increased capacity of NRH staff and government health professional towards nutritional education and diet management.    Infrastructures will have been built to offer quality and planned nutritional care and support services.     Children living with HIV/AIDS will have received care, treatment and counselling services.    Children living with HIV/AIDS and their caretakers will have receive education on basic health, hygiene and nutrition.

Project Title: Avian Influenza Control Project (Human Health Component)
Input: Year round surveillance   Building laboratory capacity for diagnosis and case detection   Prevention and containment activities including social distancing and use of vaccines   Curative interventions, including case management and antiviral drugs in the event that human infections occur
Outputs: Capacity to identify, report, laboratory diagnose and investigate possible human avian influenza anywhere in Nepal   Improved system capacity to prevent the occurrence and spread of HPAI among human population   Health care systems strengthened and readied to cope with increased demand for services and contingency plan for an epidemic
Impact: To Prevent, Control & Contain Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI)
Outcome: Minimize the threat posed to humans by HPAI infection and other zoonotic diseases by controlling such infections among domestic poultry and to prepare for, control and respond to an influenza epidemic and other related infectious diseases

Project Title: Support to Center for Constitutional Dialogue
Input: Providing the means to ensure that the members of the CA, the Secretariat, technical advisors, and support staff have the infrastructure, information, advice, training, outreach capacity and other tools.  Facilitating dialogue between the CA and the public. Establishing a resource centre as a democratic dialogue space; providing expert advice, training, facilitated meetings and public information  Public outreach programs through television, radio and community mobilisation activities focused on increasing public knowledge of the constitutional process.
Outputs: Provide capacities of Constituent Assembly delegates and technical advisors developed; produce a new constitution; Support selected civil society organizations to facilitate participation of excluded groups in the development of the new constitution.
Impact: Expected impact: Increased access to and participation in constitution building, and to support the people of Nepal in building through an inclusive process a constitution that meets their needs.
Outcome: Strengthened Capacities of Constituent Assembly (CA) delegates and technical advisors to produce a new constitution and the Constituent Assembly Secretariat and committee systems and procedures to support the CA; Ensured that selected civil society organizations are supported to facilitate political empowerment of excluded groups and their participation in the development of the new constitution; Increased access to and participation in constitution building and free and fair electoral processes.
Secondary Sector Sub-Sector: Executive and legislative organs, financial and fiscal affairs, external

Project Title: Carter Senteret 2010
Input: Observe Peace Process and Constitution Drafting; conduct regional and district observation to track the peace process; track CA and government activity; issue regular reports to raise awareness; engage with national and local political leaders to address political challenges; conduct regular briefings with international stakeholders; coordinate closely with national stakeholders; communicate national findings to local level. Conduct a limited observation of voter registration; deploy existing observation teams to observe voter registration, hire short-term expert consultants to assist and collaborate with the ECN, UNDP, IFES, domestic observer networks and civil society organizations.
Outputs: N/A
Impact: Expected impact: contribution to a consolidated post-conflict democracy in Nepal through assessing and monitoring the peace process and constitution drafting process; key Nepali and international stakeholders kept regularly informed of the findings; gender perspective incorporated into the activities and reflection of this issue in the reports (c.f. res. 1325)
Outcome: Completed impartial assessment of the peace process and constitution drafting process with key Nepali and international stakeholders regularly informed of the findings.  International support demonstrated for the peace process and constitution drafting, as well as for public participation and representation in the democratic process.  Observations of the Election Commission's voter registration undertaken in efforts to support the process and offer recommendations for how the process could be strengthened.

Project Title: Integrated Pest Management Phase II
Input: Field work
Outputs: Government component ("regular") · The National IPM programme is well institutionalised and fully functional. · Existing IPM training capacities are maintained and enhanced in all districts. · Information on the use and impact of pesticides is available and reflected in policies. FAO component ("intensive") · Institutional capacities to provide pre- and in-service training in IPM-FFS are enhanced. · IPM-FFS alumni groups trained and organized to promote community-based sustainable agriculture. · Support services for farmer groups resulting in optimised appropriate technologies, more efficient production and better access to markets. · An information and coordination system in place to monitor progress, support policy and ensure transparency and accountability.
Impact: The overall programme goal is to "contribute to sustainable broad-based poverty alleviation and food security while contributing to human health and environmental protection".
Outcome: i. To contribute to institutionalise a sustainable national IPM in Nepal by strengthening the capacity of the PPD, collaborating national, regional and district level training and extension institutions in the governmental and non-governmental sector to integrate IPM training and support programme for smallholder farmers; and  ii. To empower rural farmers, including women, to increase production and productivity efficiently, while protecting the environment, conserving the bio-diversity and avoiding health hazards for betterment of their livelihood and linking with markets.

Project Title: Theatre Partnership Nepal-Norway – Exit Phase
Input: 1) Performances (target groups: Nepali people (audience) including rural villagers, dalits, ethnic minorities and other marginalized groups, in addition to theatre groups and social activists  2) Workshops (Target groups: theatre artists from Aarohan and national and regional partners  3) National, regional and international exchanges (Target group: artists and workers from Aarohan, other national, regional and international artists and theater workers),  4) Documentation (Target groups: local communities, researchers, universities, theatre people, media and the general public)
Outputs: Workshops for Gurukul and other persons on various themes(light/corography/etc); Workshop for marketing and arts management in the region held; 4 new Nepali plays produced and performed ; 3 new Norwegian plays in Nepali language produced and preformed; 540 Kachahari (forum)/ Legislative theatre performances; Developed and implemented a marketing strategy; Exchange of theatre activities between Norway and Nepal; Exchanges with local theatre groups; Documented 3 cultures of Nepal; Publication of 8 theatre books in Nepali; International Theatre Festival held in Kathmandu; Training and support for local theatres in Biratnagar and Terai conducted
Impact: To develop and innovate Nepali theatre language based on the various traditional performances of indigenous and ethnic groups
Outcome: To achieve financial and institutional sustainability; to preserve and promote the traditional and indigenous cultures and performance forms; to strengthen other theatre groups in Aarohan's national and international network

Project Title: Strengthening Implementation of the Women, Peace and Security Agenda in Nepal: Towards Implementation of the National Action Plan on UNSCRs 1325 and 1820
Input: Training on women's empowerment and gender equality, gender mainstreaming, leadership development, and results based monitoring      Provide equipment to the MoWCSW gender unit        Provide technical assistance to develop relevant guidelines on institutional framework, monitoring, knowledge sharing, project design integrating NAP on UNSCRs 1325 and 1820        Capacity development training to district level responsible partners of the project        Provide support in the organization of NAP Implementation Committee meetings        Support on-going monitoring of NAP implementation by MoWCSW and DWC        Facilitate one 3-day training for DCC members on UNSCRs 1325 and 1820 and NAP in Dhangadhi        Support on-going monitoring of NAP at the district level from WCOs and DCCs        Support bi-monthly meetings of DCCs        Support one workshop to finalize the annual work plan in Dhangadhi        Organize three workshops with DCC and government stakeholders in Dhangadhi        Facilitate exchange visits for poor conflict affected women and other vulnerable groups of three districts        Strengthen safe house at the district headquarter with integrated legal and psychosocial components        Capacity development of the Women and Children Service Centres to address SGBV and other issues related to women and girls        Support district level workshop with police, prosecutors, health professional and law professionals, human rights organizations        Organize leadership/facilitation training to women facilitators, social mobilizers to work as change agent, and LRPs
Outputs: Women's leadership in peace, security and humanitarian response and AWP of UN Women Country Level Outcome result 4.1. Monitoring and reporting mechanisms on NAP UNSCR 1325 and 1820 in place. It is in line with the Outputs: 4.1.1 Government agencies, local bodies and civil society have enhanced capacities for the planning, implementation, monitoring and reporting on the NAP for UNSCRs 1325 and 1820. 4.1.2. Conflict affected women including ex-combatants have enhanced capacities to access justice and other services such as economic recovery, relief, reparation and psychosocial counseling.
Impact: to enhance the collective capability of national and local level government stakeholders to implement and monitor the NAP on UNSCRs 1325 and 1820;    to empower conflict affected women and former combatants in three districts through comprehensive and innovative programmes; and    to enhance the leadership and participation of women in key decision-making structures in the project districts
Outcome: Ministry of Women, Children and Social Welfare (MoWCSW), and District Coordination Committees (DCCs) have enhanced collective capability at both the national and local levels to implement and monitor the National Action Plan (NAP) on UNSCRs 1325 and 1820.    Conflict affected women and former women combatants in the three project districts are economically and socially empowered    Enhanced leadership and participation of women in key decision-making structures in the three project districts
Donor Agency: United Nations Development Fund for Women

Project Title: Supporting the achievement of the Millineum  goals in Asia and the Pacific(Phase III)
Input: Develop a templete for generating MDG-related disaggregated statistics and indicators developed:    Apply the template to the latest ppopulation and housing census data and produce in selected countries and disseminate disaggregated stastistics;    Develop a methodology for generating estimates of selected health or education-related MDG Indicators;    Apply the SAE methodology in producing estimates in selected countries;    Conduct a regional inception workshop to share knowledge and good practices among member states and arrive at a common understanding among all country teams on the objectives, mtethodologies and implementation process of the initiative.    Conduct a regional training /workshop to share knowledge and experience on census data tabulation, small area estimation and master sample construction among countries and to plan possible future capacity development work on data disaggregation.
Outputs: Selected Countries are able to produce and disseminate a set of disaggregated stastistics on MDG indicators based on the 2010 round of population and housing census.    Selected Countries are able to produce and disseminate a set of disaggregated stastistics through small area estimation(SAE) techniques developed under the initiative.    Selected Countries are able to design and apply a master sample for house-hold surveys.    Good practices, knowledge and experience gained during implementation of the initiative are shared with member states in the Asia-Pacific region.
Impact: Strengthened the capacity of national statistical system in Nepal to produce and disseminate disaggregated stastics in support of inclusive development, including the acheivement of the MDGs.
Outcome: Countries in improving the capicity of their national systems to produce and disseminate disaggregated stastics in support of inclusive development, including the achievement of the MDGs are supported.
Donor Agency: The United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific

Project Title: Scaling up coverage and quality of malaria prevention and control in targeted high risk districts in Nepal (2008-2013)
Input: Targeting the country's 13 high-risk districts, the program is building capacity in both public and private health care facilities for the improvement of the coverage and quality of early diagnosis, distributing insecticide-treated nets and ensuring prompt and effective treatment of malaria right down to the community level. In addition to the provision of training and the supply of antimalarial drugs, the program's objectives include regular surveys of antimalarial drug quality, as well as studies of therapeutic efficacy and resistance to inform the updating of national malaria drug policy.
Outputs: By end of year 2: Number of LlINs distributed to pregnant women through antenatal clinics: 74,105 Number of houses covered by indoor residual spraying: 26,000 Number and percent of public sector health facilities in 13 districts with no stock out nnalionafty recommended antimalarials (continously for 1 week during transmission season): 542 (90%) % of public heatth lacililies in 13 districts that have clinical staff trained in the use of ACT: 90% # of confirmed malaria cases treated according to national guidelines: 6489
Impact: By end of year 5: Incidence of clinical malaria: 2/1000 Annual parasite index: 1 (in 13 districts)
Outcome: By end of year 5: Percentage of children under 5 sleeping under LLIN the previous night : 70% Percentage of househlds with at least one LLIN: 100%
District: - Banke (Nepalgunj) - Bardiya (Gulariya) - Dadeldhura (Dadeldhura) - Dhanusa (Janakpur) - Ilam (Ilam) - Jhapa (Chandragadhi) - Kailali (Dhangadhi) - Kanchanpur (Mahendara Nagar) - Kavrepalanchok (Dhulikhel) - Mahottari (Jaleswor) - Morang (Biratnagar) - Nawalparasi (Parasi) - Sindhuli (Sindhuli Madhi)

Project Title: High Value Agriculture Project in Hill and Mountain Areas (HVAP)
Input: Pro-Poor Value Chain Development   Inclusion and Support for Value Chain Initiatives  Project Management (gender & poverty targeted value chain development)
Outputs: The IFAD support-project benefits about 66,000 poor and vulnerable households living in the project areas. The target groups are the members of poor and vulnerable households of 114 VDCs that lack the access to resources and opportunities. The project aims at reduction of poverty and vulnerabality of women and men in the hill and mountain areas of mid western and far western development regions. The project will be implemented by Minstry of Agriculture in the 10 districts of mid western and far western development regions. The project will serve to total numbers of 114 VDCs to uplift social and economical conditions of poor farmers. Loan from IFAD: 7.25 million US Dollar (SDR 4.75 million) Grant from IFAD: 7.25 million US Dollar (SDR 4.75 million) GON counter part fund: 1.724 million US Dollar Loan repayment installment : every six months Service Charge: 0.75% Final repayment: within 1 December 2049 Aproval from cabinet: 2066/12/29  Agreement signed on: 5 July 2010 Completion date: 30 September 2017 Financing closing date: 31 March 2018
Impact: The project benefit directly and indirectly about 66,000 households. Apart from this, a positive gender impact through improvements to women's income generation of employment for women's empowerment and advances in women's literacy will be seen.
Outcome: To integrate rural poor, especially women and marginal groups in high value agriculture and non-timber forest products, medicinal and aromatic plants value chains and markets  To improve income, employment opportunities and lability to respond to market demand and opportunities based on marketing agreements with private agri-businesses.

Project Title: Detailed Engineering Study for the Upper Seti Hydropower Project
Input: The Project shall comprise: 1. development of design options, specifications and drawings for the civil works 2. development of design options, specifications and drawings for the electro-mechanical, hydro-mechanical works and transmission facilities; and 3. preparation of detailed designs, specifications, cost estimates and bidding documents.

This is a water storage type of the project with a with a potential power generation capacity of 127 MW. This is Techincal Assistance Grant for geological and hydrological studies, and thorough due diligence works. ADB also administering PPTA for project structuring with a sum equivalent to US$ 2 million from JFPR source.
Impact: Increased generation capacity for Nepal to sustain inclusive economic growth.
Outcome: The Objective of the Project is to complete a detailed engineering study for the Proposed Project, which, together with the outputs of the Technical Assistance, will form the basis for the Proposed Ensuing Project.

Project Title: Support to the Implementation of Nepal's National Plan on the Elimination of Child Labour
Input: - technical assistance to amend the National Child Labour ( prohibition) Act 2001;   - advisery services to determine the list of hazardous child labour;   -awareness raising against child labour;   - technical and financial support to stakeholders to implement acativities to combat child labour in selected sectors.   -
Outputs: Capacity of the CLES is strengthened    A Child Labour Resource Center (CLRC) is developed and Operational    CLES Officials trained and capacitated on developing direct (and mainstreaming) Project Documents and programs against child labour    Resources mobilization strategy is produced to mobilize funds on the basis of planned, developed and promoted dicret (and mainstreaming) programs against child labour.    A list of Hazardous Child Labour (HCL) for Nepal is prepared for endorsement by the Government.    Review of and recommendations on amending national chilld labour legislation is prepared and furthered for endorsement    A National Child Labour Policy (NCLP) in Nepal is produced and prepared for endorsement.    A capacity Development Strategy (CDS) is prepared that provides input for the development of effective training modules    (Non)-training activities are undertaken to stakeholders on knowledge, skills and competencies to combat child labour, including on governance, coordination, gender and caste versus social inclusion.    Child Labour Reports (CLR) on gender disaggregated information and statistics are compiled and disseminated.
Impact: The Project will contribute to the elimination of the worst forms of child labour in Nepal by 2016, and all forms by 2020.
Outcome: 1. By end of the Project, there will be more informed and conducive policy and legal framework for child labour elimination and prevention, with a priority on its worst forms 2. Governmental and non-governmental agencies, social partners and development partners will be engaged more rigorously in concerted and effective implementation of the NMP 2011-20 on child labour elimination and prevention, with a priority on its worst forms

Project Title: Delivering Essential Reproductive Health Care for Women, Men and Adolescents of Mid and Far Western Districts of Nepal through Mobile Reproductive Health Camps.
Input: Providing comprehensive reproductive health (RH) clinical and surgical services, mainly focusing on uterine prolapse, to the women of underprivileged and conflict affected communities in remote rural areas; Awareness raising activities in communities; Capacity building of local health facility staff/institutions.
Outputs: Increased access to essential reproductive health services including counselling to the communities most affected by conflict through mobile health camps; Capacity of health care providers strengthened in districts and sub district level through hands-on and on the job orientation/coaching and training on delivery of essential RH services in conflict and post conflict settings; Increased understanding of and capacity to address of gender based violence among health care providers and health volunteers; Increased knowledge, more positive attitudes and access to quality STI/HIV/AIDS services by the community, especially youths and women; Increased advocacy, information, education, and awareness raising activities for clients/patients and targeted population on RH preventative care, general RH care and SGBV prevention through dissemination of IEC/BCC materials.
Impact: Improved reproductive health status of the most vulnerable; populations of mid and far western districts affected by conflict in the post conflict period.
Outcome: Strengthened sustainable service delivery systems for RH concerns, including response mechanisms for SGBV.
District: - Bajhang (Chainpur) - Dadeldhura (Dadeldhura) - Jajarkot (Khalanga) - Kailali (Dhangadhi) - Salyan (Salyan Khalanga)

Project Title: Experimenting HIV/Youth Frendly services integration to health services in Nepal -Project Acceleration Fund (PAF)
Input: Capacity building of service providers and district level stakeholders;   Service delivery and peer mobilization;  Creating conducive environment at health facilities;  Building Enabling Environment;  Communication with Adolescents and youth.
Outputs: Increased HIV risk awareness and adoption of safer sexual behaviors among adolescents and youth of MARPs ( i.e. migrants)  YFS implementation Guide experimented and lessons learnt documented;  Existing peer networks strengthened and linked to the health facilities and outreach services.
Impact: Reduced HIV prevalence among young people
Outcome: Increased utilization of HIV prevention and care services among adolescents and youth of most at risk populations (MARPs, i.e. migrants and their families).
Donor Agency: Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS

Project Title: Ensuring recognition of sexual violence as a tool of conflict in the Nepal peace building process through documentation and provision of comprehensive services to women and girl victims/survivors (SGBV).
Input: Documentation of cases of sexual violence including the victims current situation.  Focus group discussions  Training of district stakeholders  Conducting reproductive health camps  Trainings of local health providers.  Workshops on issues relating to reproductive health and rights  Psycho-social counseling sessions in connection to the medical camps. Training of community psycho-social workers   Workshops on general awareness relating psycho-social issues  Information submitted to the TRC and other relevant transitional justice mechanisms.  Interactions with Commissioners concerning the findings of the report  Legal counseling to victims referred by medical camps   Training for stakeholders such as police, CDOs, PLC's, local lawyers
Outputs: Report on the use of sexual violence during the conflict in Nepal and the current status of the victims  Evidence of support for victims of sexual violence in targeted communities  Reproductive health services provided to # women and girls in 14 districts.  Women provided with psycho-social counseling.  Submission of findings to the TRC and other relevant transitional justice mechanisms.  First Information Reports filed with the Police
Impact: Strengthen the monitoring, reporting and protection of children affected by conflict, in line with UNSCR 1612 and1882   Strengthen the capacities of national institutions to promote women's participation in the peace process and protect the rights of women affected by conflict in line with UNSCR 1325 and 1820.
Outcome: Identify and document incidences of sexual violence against women and girls during the time of conflict and post conflict in Nepal.  Support access to reproductive health care and psycho-social counseling for victims of sexual violence in target areas.  Promote recognition of the incidence of sexual violence in Nepal peace process through access to justice for victims of sexual violence, including through participation in transitional justice processes.
District: - Achham (Mangalsen) - Bajura (Martadi) - Bardiya (Gulariya) - Dang Deukhuri (Ghorahi) - Dhanusa (Janakpur) - Kalikot (Kalikot) - Kanchanpur (Mahendara Nagar) - Kapilvastu (Taulihawa) - Mahottari (Jaleswor) - Rolpa (Liwang) - Rukum (Musikot) - Saptari (Rajbiraj) - Siraha (Siraha) - Surkhet (Surkhet)

Project Title: Emergency Life saving mobile reproductive health services in the remotest and conflict affected districts of Nepal (CERF)
Input: Organize medical camps and provide critical RH care for the population in project districts;  To detect uterine prolapse in the camp and provide surgical services at appropriate institutions;   Build capacity of local health providers through onsite coaching and raise RH awareness of the community by using innovative IEC techniques during the conduct of camps.
Outputs: Availability and accessibility of life saving emergency reproductive health services to men, women and adolescents of Achham, Bajhang, Bajura and Mugu districts of Nepal
Impact: Decrease in maternal mortality and morbidity and strengthening RH services in district.
Outcome: Increased access to life saving RH services in project districts.

Outputs: Increased utilization of reproductive health and basic public health services by conflict affected and disadvantaged population through mobile RH camps and other support services such as advocacy activities and capacity building for skill enhancement.

Outcome: Improved reproductive health, general public health, and protection status for vulnerable, neglected populations in districts affected by conflict and remoteness.

Project Title: Providing Emergency Reproductive Health Assistance to conflict affected and vulnerable populations in Far and Mid Western Nepal (ECHO IV)
Input: Service delivery through RH mobile camp; Capacity Building of the local health service providers, representatives from HFOMC, DDRC and RRT members;  Advocacy and Awareness.
Outputs: Increased utilization of reproductive health and basic public health services by conflict affected and disadvantaged population through mobile RH camps and other support services such as advocacy activities and capacity building for skill enhancement.

Outcome: Improved reproductive health, general public health, and protection status for vulnerable, neglected populations in districts affected by conflict and remoteness.

Project Title: Delivering Essential Reproductive Health Care, Education and Counselling to Vulnerable Women and Adolescent Girls of Nepal affected by conflict (HSTF)
Input: Community and Stakeholder Orientation   Mobile Outreach Camp;   Hands on coaching of health care providers during mobile clinics   Strengthening of referral system between mobile health clinics and hospitals   Training of formal and informal health care providers   Skilled Birth Attendants (SBA) training for district health staff   Provision of essential obstetric drugs and equipment for training  Development of advocacy and health education materials  Conducting advocacy campaign on health care and education   Production of an Information Education Communication (IEC) and Behaviour Change Communication (BCC) package for media   Reintegration of school children through provision of EFA scholarships [arranged by Women's Federation with technical support from Women Development Office   Provision of out of school adolescent girls with literacy classes through the Choose Your Future development course (12 day course on RH and literacy)   Provision Adolescent girls (out of school) with Life Skills education   Provision of out-of-school adolescent girls with skills development and Livelihood opportunities   Sensitization/ training workshops for public service personnel and NGO staff on the prevention of and attention of abuse, violence against women and early marriage   Establishment of networking with the Para-legal committees   Development of IEC materials for prevention of and attention to interfamily violence and abuses.
Outputs: Increased availability to emergency reproductive health services by the conflict affected and vulnerable population through mobile health camps  Strengthened capacity of formal and informal health care providers, including Female Community Health Volunteers, to deliver Essential Health Care Services (EHCs)  District and regional health skilled birth attendant (SBA) training sites strengthened  Awareness of the importance of health care and education increased  Capacity of the media to report on and advocate for social empowerment, protection, health, education increased  Availability of basic education and /or skills development for women and girls increased  Rights support mechanisms have been established for women and adolescents.
Impact: Improved reproductive health of vulnerable women, men, and adolescents in conflict affected districts of Dadeldhura, Dang, Kapilvastu, Rautahat, Mahottari and Saptari.  Improved protection status of vulnerable women, men, and adolescents in conflict affected districts of Dadeldhura, Dang, Kapilvastu, Rautahat, Mahottari and Saptari.
Outcome: Access to quality essential reproductive health services including comprehensive gender based violence care increased  Demand for quality essential reproductive health services, especially by women, young people, and other vulnerable groups, including populations of humanitarian concern increased.  Human rights protection systems strengthened to protect reproductive rights of women and adolescent girls, including the right to be free from violence.
District: - Dadeldhura (Dadeldhura) - Dang Deukhuri (Ghorahi) - Kapilvastu (Taulihawa) - Mahottari (Jaleswor) - Rautahat (Gaur) - Saptari (Rajbiraj)

Outcome: Access to and utilization of quality maternal health services increased in order to reduce maternal mortality morbidity.

Outcome: Improved utilization of quality reproductive health services by men, women and adolescents, including socially excluded groups

Project Title: Support to the Rehabilitation of Verified Minors and Late Recruits (UNIRP).

Project Title: Multi-Sectoral Gender Based Violence Response at the District Level in Nepal (EVAW)

Outputs: Improved quality and utilization of multi-sectoral GBV services for the benefit of women and girls;   Capacity of local service providers to provide multi-sectoral GBV services improved;   Community networks and mechanisms strengthened to support GBV survivors;  Multi-sectoral response, resource and information points for GBV survivors increased;  Awareness and knowledge of rights-holders increased.
Impact: Decrease in GBV incidences
Outcome: Increased the utilization of GBV prevention and protection services by women, men and children for the improved protection status of women/girls as well as supportive attitude by all community members for prevention management of GBV.

Project Title: COUNTRY PROGRAMME ACTION PLAN (CPAP), 2008-2010 (extended to 2012) for the Programme of Cooperation between The Government of Nepal and The United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA)
Input: Reproductive Health   Advocacy with politicians, policy makers, civil society, community leaders—and emphasizing the involvement of men—to address key RH, ASRH, prolapse, gender and social-inclusion issues.   Strengthening the institutional capacity of Divisions under the Department of Health to deliver RH services.   Strengthening the technical proficiency of health-service personnel to provide client-friendly RH services including safe motherhood, family planning, ASRH and GBV.  Strengthen partnerships and capacity of I/NGOs for technical advisory services on BCC and communication strategies for uterine prolapse, quality of care, ASRH and FP.  Enhancing the institutional capacity of implementing partners at district level and below to deliver quality RH services including support the establishment of BEOC sites; (g) strengthen the referral system at district level; (h) support the revitalization of PHC ORCs at district level;   Enhancing the skills of service providers in providing quality RH services.   Support for mobile outreach services.  Training district/community level on RH, gender and social inclusion;   Establishing a supportive environment for ASRH activities. A key activity will be to orient community gatekeepers on ASRH issues.  Capacity building of sex workers in combating HIV-AIDS, increase women's negotiation skills for safe sex, ensure the availability of condoms, disseminate information especially on the feminization of HIV/AIDS, and integrate HIV issues into RH services at the district level.  Support for "Choose Your Future" programme for girls, peer education programme;   Strengthening the technical proficiency health-service providers on youth- friendly ASRH services and teachers on ASRH and HIV/AIDS using student-friendly methodologies.  Population and Development   Support training needs assessment and train staff of statistical offices and Implementing Partners at central and district levels;   Equipment for census data production and dissemination to line ministries at national level and DDCs of project districts;   Development and implementation of a plan for the 2011 population census;  Development of advocacy materials for policy makers, religious leaders, uniformed forces and the general public on emerging population and development issues;  Develop and institutionalize an integrated data and information management system, including DPMAS for monitoring of indicators at district level;  Establish baseline and endline information for monitoring and evaluation of the CPAP;   Provide technical support for the 2011 Population and Housing Census;  Conduct surveys on RH, migration, SGBV and conflict-related issues to inform policy decision on IDPs, ex-combatants, refugees and persons affected by emergencies;   Undertake evidence-based advocacy and sensitization of policy and decision makers and civil society on emerging PD issues such as migration, urbanisation, youth, aging, sex ratio at birth;   Building capacities of partner institutions to integrate population, gender, RH, social inclusion, peace-building and emergency concerns into their plans and programmes;   Integration of the Nepal Population Perspective Plan into the Government's development plans;   Training to national and district level staff on programme management, M&E evaluation and integration of population concerns into development plans and programmes.   Gender    Support to (a) the GoN's programmes for reintegration of ex-combatants and internally displaced women, and implementation of UN Resolution 1325;  Mainstream SGBV in training modules of health sector;   Enhance capacity in community-based monitoring initiatives with health facilities for tracking SGBV;   Conduct evidence-based capacity-building of police, lawyers and media on caste and GBV;  Increasing public awareness about role of males in violence prevention;   Strengthening local capacity to monitor and respond to SGBV together with other actors;  Building capacity of women, especially of excluded groups, to participate in design and implementation of peace-building initiatives;  Develop and implement a National Action Plan on UNSCR 1325; (b) develop directives and action plan on reintegration of women affected by conflict; and (c) support analytical evidence-base submissions to the CA on gender and women's protection and reintegration issues;  Support access to justice and rehabilitation for women affected by GBV during conflict in selected districts;  Develop a national action plan on UNSCR 1325;   Mainstreaming gender in planning and monitoring mechanisms in the health sector and in the police will be supported;  Strengthen gender-responsive mechanisms in the police and justice sectors; (d) develop a database for evidence-based advocacy on GBV;   Strengthen community-based gender- and social-inclusion monitoring systems;   Conduct evidence-based advocacy for integration of GBV in planning and M&E mechanisms of select institutions.
Outputs: Reproductive Health:   Improved capacity for reproductive health policy formulation, revision and implementation;  Increased capacity of health service providers and local bodies to deliver quality reproductive health services, including in humanitarian situations;  Increased capacity of women, young people and other vulnerable groups including populations of humanitarian concern to demand for quality reproductive health services;  Increased capacities of communities especially among excluded groups to participate in local level planning, monitoring and evaluation of quality RH services.   Population and Development:   Strengthened central and district capacity to collect, analyze and disseminate socio demographic disaggregated data;  Improved availability and accessibility of socio demographic data on population, reproductive health that is disaggregated by age, sex, ethnicity/caste, economic status and geographic location for evidence-based planning and monitoring (including in humanitarian situations);  Capacity of government institutions strengthened to mainstream population, youth, reproductive health, gender and social-inclusion and peace building in policies, plans and budgets, as well as in programme implementation and monitoring;  Gender:   Capacity of women especially of excluded groups, improved to participate in design and implementation of peace building initiatives.  Tools, mechanism and skills developed to operationalize UNSCR 1325 and 1820.  Improved capacity of health service providers, police lawyers, media, community women and men to respond to gender based violence including in humanitarian situations.
Impact: Systematic use of population dynamics analyses to guide increased investments in gender equality, youth development, reproductive health and HIV/AIDS for improved quality of life and sustainable development and poverty reduction.  Universal access to reproductive health by 2015 and universal access to comprehensive HIV prevention by 2010 for improved quality of life.  Gender equality advanced and women and adolescent girls empowered to exercise their human rights, particularly their reproductive rights, and live free of discrimination and violence.
Outcome: Reproductive Health:   Reproductive health integrated in public policies of development and humanitarian frameworks to promote reproductive health and rights;  Improved utilization of quality RH services by men, women, and adolescents especially socially excluded groups  Population and Development:   Relevant line ministries and local governments have evidence-based plans, including gender-sensitive and socially inclusive components in support of decentralization.  Central and local government institutions mainstream population, reproductive health, gender, youth, social-inclusion and peace building in policies, plans and budgets, as well as in programme implementation and monitoring.  Gender:   Gender Dimensions (including UNSCR 1325 and 1820) are addressed in the post conflict transition period including the participation of women and girls:   Responses to GBV, particularly domestic and sexual violence, expanded through improved policies, protection systems, legal enforcement, and sexual and reproductive health and HIV prevention services, including in emergency and post emergency situations.
District: - Achham (Mangalsen) - Arghakhanchi (Sandhikharka) - Baitadi (Baitadi) - Bajhang (Chainpur) - Bajura (Martadi) - Dadeldhura (Dadeldhura) - Dang Deukhuri (Ghorahi) - Kapilvastu (Taulihawa) - Mahottari (Jaleswor) - Pyuthan (Pyuthan Khalanga) - Rolpa (Liwang) - Rukum (Musikot) - Rupandehi (Bhairahawa) - Saptari (Rajbiraj) - Sarlahi (Malangwa) - Sindhuli (Sindhuli Madhi) - Sunsari (Inaruwa) - Udayapur (Gaighat)

Project Title: Implementing Activities of the Project “Strengthening Implementation of the Women, Peace and Security Agenda in Nepal: Towards Implementation of the National Action Plan on UNSCRs 1325 and 1820” - MWCSW
Input: Training on women's empowerment and gender equality, gender mainstreaming, leadership development, and results based monitoring    Provide equipment to the MoWCSW gender unit    Provide technical assistance to develop relevant guidelines on institutional framework, monitoring, knowledge sharing, project design integrating NAP on UNSCRs 1325 and 1820    Capacity development training to district level responsible party of the project    Provide support in the organization of NAP Implementation Committee meetings    Support on-going monitoring of NAP implementation by MoWCSW and DWC    Facilitate one 3-day training for DCC members on UNSCRs 1325 and 1820 and NAP in Dhangadhi    Support on-going monitoring of NAP at the district level from WCOs and DCCsSupport one workshop to finalize the annual work plan in Dhangadhi    Organize three workshops with DCC and government stakeholders in Dhangadhi    Facilitate exchange visits for poor conflict affected women and other vulnerable groups of three districts    Strengthen safe houses at the district headquarter with integrated legal and psychosocial components    Capacity development of the Women and Children Service Centres to address SGBV and other issues related to women and girls    Support district level workshop with police, prosecutors, health professional and law professionals, human rights organizations    Organize leadership/facilitation training to women facilitators, social mobilizers to work as change agent, and LRPs

Project Title: Implementing Activities of the Project “Promoting Gender Responsive Security Sector (PROGRESS): Towards Implementation of UNSCRs 1325 and 1820” with the Ministry of Defence, Government of Nepal

Outputs: A set of concrete recommendations plan to promote a gender responsive and sensitive security sector    Resource centre established at the Gender Unit of MoD to promote gender responsive Ministry of Defence

Outcome: Enhanced capacity of security forces and concerned government authorities for integration of gender perspectives into the security sector (conflict prevention, peace building and security operations)
Donor Agency: United Nations Development Fund for Women

Project Title: To enhance the capacity of local stakeholders on women, peace and security agenda in Kavre, Ramechap and Sindhuli districts on the implementation of the National Action Plan (NAP) on UNSCRs 1325 and 1820 in the districts - (WHR)
Input: Districts Coordination Committees: The selected organization will be engaged in sensitizing the DCCs. The tasks will comprise of the following:         Hold consultation meetings with the DCCs in the three districts (6 half day meetings in each district) to coordinate for the implementation of the NAP in the districts    Use the sensitization package developed for DCCs on UNSCRs 1325 and 1820 and the NAP by UN Women in 2012 and hold one session on sensitizing the DCCs on UNSCRs 1325 and 1820 and their roles for the implementation of the NAP in the districts (1 half day workshop in each district)    Prepare the pre- and post-test analysis of the sensitization sessions and the changes observed amongst the beneficiaries or measured after the sessions. The pre- and post-test analysis should be reported by the selected agency to UN Women.    Support the DCCs to prepare action plans for coordinating the implementation of the NAP in the project districts (one action plan in each district)    Facilitate the DCCs in creating synergy between the activities of the three agencies(UN Women, FAO and ILO)
Outputs: Increased community awareness on issues of GBV, human rights and gender equality      Enhanced capacity of conflict affected women on organizational leadership and social harmonization    Increased capacity of local bodies and concerned delivery agencies for gender responsive planning and implementation mechanisms
Impact: Community sensitization on social, cultural and economic issues that affect women's lives    Enhance the capacity of conflict affected women in the area of organizational leadership and social harmonization    Strengthen the capacity of Local Peace Committees (LPCs) in the areas of gender responsive processes and procedures, mediation skills and conflict management    Strengthen the capacity of government local bodies and line agencies in the areas of gender sensitization, gender responsive planning, implementation and monitoring mechanisms
Outcome: Conflict affected women and their families are recovered from specific post conflict hardship   Gender responsive community-based economic recovery initiatives are designed and implemented
Donor Agency: United Nations Development Fund for Women

Project Title: Development of a Booklet and Video on Sustaining the Gains of Foreign Labour Migration through the Protection of Migrant Workers’ Rights-Interface Nepal
Input: The selected organization will be responsible for the following: The incumbent party will be responsible for carrying out the following activities:      · Conduct a meeting with the Reference Group to understand the context and to select key 3 districts for the screening.   · Summit a Treatment Note (concept on how creatively the film and Booklet is visualized) including a work plan with specific timeline and fine tune it with the EE unit at UNW.   · Capture on photo, film and in writing both programme processes and achieved results Documentation will capture the followings:   1. Training of WMW in select programme districts,   2. Meetings of the Community Alert Group   3. Interview with select district level stakeholders (Related government bodies, returnee WMWs, media persons)   4. Interview with few key stakeholders   5. Action undertaken on collective actions: among returnee WMWs, being mobilized to provide support to distressed migrants, CAG responding to local level issues related to foreign labour migration, VDC or district level development processes including the returnees and the CAG members, VDC and DDC prioritising safe migration interventions   6. Other footages of the programme activities under the EC/UNW project   · The exact lists of contents for the video will be determined in the initial meeting with Reference Group, but it is envisioned that the video will also highlight the short segments on the following:   · General scenario of women and foreign employment in Nepal and some voices of WMWs highlighting the cost and gains of foreign employment and their contribution.   · Context of foreign employment in Nepal from gender perspective and the policies and actions that has been supported to protect the rights of WMWs.   · roles and responsibilities of different actors to ensure the protection of the rights of WMWs    · Edit the documentary for length, relevant content and overall aesthetic quality; deliver both a long and short version.    · Provide and assure international quality standard of documentary English subtitles.   · The agency will be responsible for design, formatting and layout of the booklet, documentary and documentary cover.   · The agency will work with selected press to ensure proper layout and printing of all materials.
Outputs: · A Treatment Note (concept on how creatively the film and Booklet is visualized)   · Booklet including high resolution pictures in Nepali and English (1000 pcs)   · A five minutes edited film of the major activities in Nepali with voice over, photos, graphics and music in DVD format with English sub titles   · A DVD with the mixed tracks as well as rushes / footage of all the shooting   · A copy of all raw footage in the Beta version of the films will be delivered to UN Women      The film DVD should have a sticker and nicely designed DVD cover. These films would form a part of ongoing documentation of project processes and future advocacy and up scaling efforts. This footage could also be used by the regional and sub-regional migration related programme for crafting short films to support resource mobilization and communications for the participating cities.
Donor Agency: United Nations Development Fund for Women
Secondary Sector Sub-Sector: General economic, commercial and labour affairs

Project Title: For conducting Women’s Safety Audits in one selected VDC in each of the six project districts in Mid, Far and Central Region to promote safe communities for all-Didibahini
Input: · Identify specific criteria for intervention sites (such as level, scope, forms and intensity of sexual harassment and violence, availability of services for the victims, political will of local administration to address this issue, availability of grassroots women's groups willing to lead this work, etc.)   · Map key stakeholders at selected VDC levels   · Applying the above criteria, undertake consultations with local government and other key stakeholders with the goal to engage them in partnership to ensure sustainability of the projects,   · Using the criteria and based on the consultations with stakeholders, identify up to 1 VDC within each selected VDCs (the VDC should be selected VDC for project implementation) per district to conduct the WSAs,   · Identify, inform and involve key stakeholders in the area in the WSA   · Brief and train the group on WSAs. Demonstrate how WSAs are a part of the comprehensive programming on community safety, violence and crime prevention and women's empowerment.   · Conduct the safety walk with community women and girls (including marginalized and vulnerable groups), local authorities and service providers during the day and night   · Develop a template and outline map of the routes for documentation   · Undertake focus group discussions to triangulate the data   · Undertake an analysis of the recording and draft recommendations for interventions   · Set up meetings with all stakeholders, including relevant authorities to present recommendations and to further advance their security action points and their own safety projects   · Disseminate the finding to the media and highlight positive changes as and when they occur during the project period   · Assist local stakeholders in setting up an ongoing monitoring and implementation mechanism by providing information on best practices, links to other cities undertaking similar work and web-based resources   · Undertake one intervention as per the recommendation of the audit in collaboration with the local authorities   · Define how success of this project will be measured, including via quantitative, qualitative and participatory methods (M&E strategy)      Guiding principles in designing the safe cities interventions     From Protection to Rights - developing safer communities based on women's right to the community and right to safety as opposed to emphasizing the burden of protection on women (protecting oneself by dressing/behaving in a certain manner)    Sensitivity to the intersection of identities    Involving women and girls in the making of decisions that affect their safety    Recognising the value of the knowledge generated from the lived experiences on women and girls    Focus on both the actual and perceived sense of safety    Recognition that gender affects one's experience of the city    Involvement of community, men and boys, and stakeholders
Outputs: Project Beneficiaries have enhanced capacity to carry out women's safety audits and develop security action points in select VDCs in 6 districts of Nepal (two in Far-West, two in Mid- West and two in Central)
Impact: · Use the methodology of WSAs as a tool to trigger local development and implementation of NAP commitments specially contributing to prevention and protection against violence of the communities.   · Assess effectiveness of WSA as a tool for local diagnostic of safety in public spaces, for women's political empowerment, and as an advocacy and planning tool for introduction of practical measures to prevent crime and sexual violence in public spaces.   · Enhance the capacity of project beneficiaries to carry out women's safety audits.
Outcome: Government's NAP for UNSCR 1325 and 1820 implemented at national and district levels.   Government agencies, local bodies and civil society have enhanced capacities for the planning, implementation, monitoring and reporting on the NAP for UNSCRs 1325 and 1820   Number of key ministries that develop work-plans for coordinated implementation of NAP on UNSCRs 1325 and 1820
Donor Agency: United Nations Development Fund for Women

Outputs: OUTPUT 1: Study analyzing the implementation of in-camera hearing supported by UN Women.   OUTPUT 2: SOP and in-camera hearing guideline available   OUTPUT 3: Comprehensive training manual on in-camera hearing guidelines including (Standard Operating Procedure)  OUTPUT 4: A comprehensive set of IEC/BCC materials on in-camera hearing developed   OUTPUT 5: Government officials (law enforcement officials, judiciary and women children officers) in the project/ programme districts have enhanced knowledge on in-camera hearing guidelines and their implementation
Impact: Conduct study analyzing the implementation status of in camera hearing including Standard Operating Procedure(SOP);    Develop in-camera hearing guideline incorporating recommendations of the study;    Develop a comprehensive training manual on in-camera hearing guideline (including Standard Operating Procedure);    Develop a set of comprehensive IEC and BCC materials on in-camera hearing process    Organize training workshops to Government officials (law enforcement officials, judiciary and women children officers) on in-camera hearing guideline and their implementation
Outcome: Vulnerable groups benefit from strengthened legal and policy frameworks and have improved access to security and rule of law institution   vulnerable people are better enabled to access fair and effective security and justice institution.

Project Title: CONDUCTING AWARENESS CAMPAIGN IN THE CONSTITUENCIES FOR GENDER RESPONSIVE ELECTORAL PROCESS - (PRO-PUBLIC)
Input: Prepare an interactive voter and civic education orientation/ package for potential women, vulnerable and excluded groups, community leaders to increase women's role and participation in the upcoming CA election as voters and candidates in Nepali.    The content of the awareness package should include but not be limited to the following:      Citizens' rights and duties as a voter and as candidates    What is constitution? Why should citizens be involved in constitution building, specially the disadvantaged groups and gender?    Why should we vote? How are we represented in the constitution drafting through elections?    Mixed election system, what does it mean?    How to caste our vote in proper way? How to make sure the votes we caste are valid?    How to become responsible citizens to ensure free and fair election? etc.             Organize a one day orientation/workshop for civil society organizations (including the media) on women's participation on election as voter and as a candidate highlighting the importance of women and socially excluded groups' participation in the elections in 75 districts;    Organize one day orientation workshop in each of the 240 constituencies targeting at least for 35-40 women.
Outputs: Election Commission of Nepal has the capacity to conduct credible, inclusive and transparent elections
Outcome: Institutions, systems and processes of democratic governance are more accountable, effective, efficient and inclusive   Institutions /Mechanisms for implementation of national and international gender equality commitments strengthened.
Donor Agency: United Nations Development Fund for Women

Project Title: Empowering Women Migrant Workers through Effective  Policy Response
Input: Develop a National Strategy on Safe Migration along with Three Year National Plan of Action on Safe Migration with special focused on protection of rights of Nepali WMWs and finalise it from the National Consultation.  Develop a Directive to mobilize local governance on safe and dignified foreign migration.  Undertake mapping of safe labour markets to ensure protections of WMWs and development of strategy for MOL&TM to access safe labour markets to protect the rights of WMWs.  Conduct a Learning and Sharing mission to the countries of Origin.  Capacity development of CA members, political party leaders, Inter-ministerial senior officials, Civil Society on International Convention on the Protection of the Rights of All Migrant Workers and Members of Their Families and CEDAW GR 26.  Support the functioning of the Committee at DOFE and organize roundtables with the representatives of the judiciaries.  Supporting the government for celebrating International Migrant Day
Outputs: National Strategy on Safe Migration
Outcome: National Strategy integrates the promotion and protection of rights of WMWs
Donor Agency: United Nations Development Fund for Women
Secondary Sector Sub-Sector: General economic, commercial and labour affairs

Project Title: Conducting Baseline Survey on the Status on the Conflict Affected Women
Input: Preparation of inception report containing literature review, detailed study methodology and study plan with time lines    Development of data collection tools and implementation of data collection:     - Finalise data collection tools and instrument—for both quantitative and qualitative data collection   - Identification of methodologies—who are the direct beneficiaries of NAP, their total numbers (disaggregated by sex and age), their level of contribution and participation in the programme and the benefits they will derive from the programme   - Implementation of field work—identification of key performance indicators on which to collect data, including, but not limited to direct beneficiaries, government officials, CSOs, number of interventions under NAP etc.     Preparation of draft report and sharing of key findings and analysis with UN WOMEN, OHCHR and other agencies involved in the process    Finalization of the baseline survey report incorporating the feedback and comments from UN WOMEN, OHCHR and other agencies involved in the process
Outputs: Baseline data/information on the status of conflict affected women developed and disseminated
Outcome: Gender responsive policies and plans adopted and implemented in post conflict and humanitarian emergencies
Donor Agency: United Nations Development Fund for Women

Project Title: Mainstreaming Gender in Institutional Practices of Political Parties

Organize central and district level advocacy consultations/workshops to share the findings and recommendations involving the key leaders of concerned political parties with a view to get their commitment    Document the processes, good practices and lessons learnt towards engendering the institutional practices of political parties
Outputs: · Gender equality experts, advocates and their organizations or networks have strengthened their capacity to advocate for gender responsive laws, policies and strategies at national, regional and global levels.
Outcome: The objective of this initiative is to contribute to integration of gender responsive provisions into the policies and practices of political parties.

Project Title: Development of a Booklet and Video on Sustaining the Gains of Foreign Labour Migration through the Protection of Migrant Workers’ Rights

Capture on photo, film and in writing both programme processes and achieved results Documentation    The exact lists of contents for the video will be determined in the initial meeting with Reference Group, but it is envisioned that the video will also highlight the short segments    Edit the documentary for length, relevant content and overall aesthetic quality; deliver both a long and short version.     Provide and assure international quality standard of documentary English subtitles. The agency will work with selected press to ensure proper layout and printing of all materials

Project Title: Policy assistance for bio-secure agro-food supply chain enhanced market access and food security for the small holding rural sector
Input: -FAO will provide the project with technical services of Technical Cooperation among Developing Countries (TCDC) and National Consultants.   -A budget of US$ 76,000 is made for the training and workshops
Outputs: -Policy framework which will facilitate adoption of bio-secure measures and practices by the small and marginal farmers and the other actors in the entire agro-food supply chain, based on clear understanding of the dynamics of change taking place in the agro-food sector.   -An analytical report on the relative role of public sector in tranforming the agriculture sector into bio-secure will be clearly defined and mutually complimentary framework led by private sector established.   -Capacity (technical, institutional, policy) of the public and private sectors on bio-security enhanced.   -Capacity of national food control system of Nepal strengthened.
Impact: To contribute to the transformation of Nepalese agro-food supply chains into bio-secure through capacity building of public and private sectors, policy and regulatory support thereby creating an enabling environments for unhindered market access and enhanced livelihood generation for small holder farmers.
Outcome: Strengthened capacity, along with claer identification of what needs to be done, in terms of policy and institutional reform and support mechanicms to the small farmers, to integrate the small farmers into a bio-secure agro-food supply chain for unhindered market access and enhanced livelihood generation.

Project Title: Combating Citrus Decline Problem in Nepal
Input: 1. Institutional Capacity Building · Design and Conduct need based ToT training for DoA officers/Junior technicians  · Arrange study tour for two technical government officers from DoA  · Support in conduction of 6 monthly meetings/workshops of inter-departmental cooperation within DoA  · Implement HLB/greening management programs · Establish Bud wood/scion certification system to produce and distribute disease free saplings. · Upgrade capacity of Government and private nurseries  · Preparation of a proposal on a sustainable Bud Wood/scion Certification system   2.Capacity building of Farmer Groups · Provide basic training to selected farmers groups on citrus production and rejuvenation technologies and GAP for citrus growing. · Conduct survey to identify, collect and document good practices · Implement local awareness and social mobilization campaign  · Train self-help groups, associations and cooperatives to enhance their organizational and managerial capacity. · Conduct Field demonstrations of proven technologies for improved citrus production and rejuvenation of declined orchard · Up-scale the anti-citrus decline technology (good agriculture practices)   3. Upgrading Monitoring and Information System · Establish monitoring system at district and regional level · Establish databases and information system at district and regional level · Implement Mid-term evaluation on project outcomes  Prepare Project completion report with achievements and suggested strategies and plans to combat citrus decline.
Outputs: Output 1 Technical and institutional capacity strengthened within DoA for disease prevention, preparedness and management and improved mechanisms established for cross-sectoral coordination with other stakeholders.  Output 2: A set of suitable location specific technological options for disease management identified, and capacity of citrus growers enhanced to cope with the citrus decline problem through a participatory learning process Output 3. Monitoring and information system is in place for better planning of citrus development and decline management in the districts and region Output 4. An acceptable proposal on establishment of a sustainable Bud Wood/scion Certification system.
Impact: National Citrus production and productivity restored or even improved and more incomes generated
Outcome: Sustainable options to combat citrus decline problem identified, institutional and technical capacities of stakeholders/citrus growers enhanced and support services regularized to the citrus growers for a sustainable citrus production in the major citrus growing districts
District: - Dhankuta (Dhankuta) - Gorkha (Gorkha) - Kaski (Pokhara) - Kavrepalanchok (Dhulikhel) - Lamjung (Bensi Sahar) - Syangja (Syangja) - Tanahu (Damauli)

Project Title: Trade Promotion Programme (TPP)
Input: Strengthening the private sector and service provider to increase exports    Dialogue between the public and the private sector in order to identify the key trade barriers and overcome them    Developing the capacity of the Enhanced Integrated Framework (EIF) / National Implementation Unit (NIU) with regard to deveoping individual and institutional skills for National Trade Integration Strategy (NTIS) implemntation, project management, monitoring and evaluation, resource mobilisation, communication, and information -sharing regarding NTIS and Aid for Trade (AfT)
Outputs: 70% of companies benefiting from implementation of the Action Plans agreed by the Project Advisory Groups for promoting trade in the Medicinal and Aromatic Plants, Honey and Silver Jewellery value chains confirm that the implemntation of these Action Plans has had a positive impact on their export opportunities.    Three key trade barriers, which were identified during public-private dialogue, have been removed by the private sector and the government.    The Ministry of Commerce and Supplies has secured funding for the implementation of 70% of the activities in the Action Matrix of the Nepal Trade Integration Strategy (NTIS).    A capacity assessment (conducted by the Programme) attests that the Enhanced Integrated Framework National Implementation Unit (EIF NIU) has improved its skills with regard to resource mobilisation, project management and monitoring and evaluation.
Outcome: Increment of Nepalese trade    Quality and marketing of Nepalese exportable products will be strengthen.    Capacity development of Ministry of Commerce and Supplies (MoCS)
Secondary Sector Sub-Sector: General economic, commercial and labour affairs
