Project Title: Health Sector Support Programme (HSSP)
Input: Technical advice, trainings / orientations, consultancy services, advocacy, financial support in organizing workshops/seminars
Outputs: MoHP Maintenance strategy for physical assets endorsed, Local Health Infrastructure Developed (LHID) guidelines(for construction and maintenance at district and below level) endorsed, Health Infrastructure System (HIIS) established in HSSP districts, Evidence in build on health financing and social health protection (SHP) both at national and district level and distributed among key stakeholders, Inclusive stakeholder (Ministries, EDPs and private sector) consultations on strategic direction for health financing and SHP have taken place, Options for implementation modalities for risk pooling and pre-payment mechanisms are developed, Health facilities are operating Adolescent Friendly Services ( AFSs) in selected districts in line with the national ASRH programme, Advocacy on SRHR of young people has been implemented at central and district level, new and innovative IEC/BCC intervention are developed, Research on SRHR of young people and evidence for effective intervention in Nepal is improved, National information system collects data pertinent to SRH of adolescents
Impact: Contribution towards MDG 4, 5
Outcome: Strengthening and institutionalizing the decentralized health infrastructure management at local level (NHSP II, Chapter 6.4), Sexual and Reproductive Health Rights of Adolescent is improved, Improved health financing system that enables access to needed services without the risk of financial catastrophe

Project Title: Inclusive Development of the Economy (INCLUDE) Programme
Input: Promoting dialogue between economic actors, the state and society  Local/regional economic development (LRED)    Financial services for MSME
Outputs: National-level PPD and Policies: Transfer business and LRED relevant issues to national-level PPD, to national policy level   District-level PPD: Regional PPDs involving civil society, sensitization of companies to peace building and social inclusion, CSR   LRED Processes: Cooperation with DDCs, jointly elaborate development plans (as part of the joint LRED initiative)   Strengthening District Private Sector Institutions, Civil Society and Poor: Capacity building of business representatives (BMO, cooperatives, sector associations)  Value Chain Development and Projects: Value chain and cluster development, design and implementation of projects   Business Services: Develop business services with various stakeholders  Entrepreneurship Development: Enterprise creation, entrepreneurship development, skills development / vocational training   Financial Services: Financial services and facilitating access for different groups
Impact: Promotion of socially balanced economic development in Nepal
Outcome: The framework conditions for balanced and socially fair economic growth are improved in selected regions, whereby the anticipated results are:   A decrease in unemployment and/or underemployment amongst different groups, particularly women, youth, ethnic minorities and/or lower castes, in the selected locations/regions.  An increase in household income of disadvantaged families in the selected sectors of the selected locations/regions.  Positive trends in new business opportunities and employment opportunities, availability of financial services for micro, small and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs), availability of other relevant services for MSMEs, and decrease of 'red tape' and other administrative obstacles for businesses as well as engagement of the private sector for social activities.

Project Title: Janajatis Social and Economic Empowerment Project (JANSEEP) - Nepal (CTR 119627)
Input: The project aims at empowering the highly marginalized Janajatis (HMJs) through improved livelihoods, strengthening the capacity of their Indigenous People's Organizations (IPO) and through increased awareness of their own cultural and political rights. These activities are in line with the government policy of social inclusion and poverty reduction as mentioned in the Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (2002-2007), which explicitly states that one of the four pillars of the Tenth Five Year Plan is social inclusion and targeted programs. Empowering Highly Marginalized Janajatis will contribute to the government's efforts to achieve the Millennium Development Goal by 2015 A.D.
Outputs: Increase awareness and capacity of HMJs to assert their rights to identity,  Increased household income of HMJs through diversification of income opportunities and building on their indigenous skills and knowledge.  Improved access of HMJs to basic services (health, education and natural resources) Enchanced capacity of Indigenous People's Organisations (IPOs) for protection, promotion and fulfilment of their rights through policy dialogue (formulation, implementation and monitoring)
Impact: Changes in the social status of the Indigenous people; increased livelihood options
Outcome: Equitable, social development with the mainstreming of the marginalised Indigenous people

Project Title: UNCERF (Central Emergency Response Fund) -Multi-year Commitment 2010 - 2013 - UNOCHA
Input: Financial support to the UN Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF) to enable more timely and reliable humanitarian assistance to those affected by natural disasters and armed conflict. The Fund aims to: promote early action and response to reduce loss of life; enhance response to time-critical requirements; and strengthen core elements of humanitarian response in underfunded crises. The Fund is managed by the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA). The total value of this multi-country initiative is $58.0 million over 4 years, starting 2009-10.   PARTNER : UNITED NATIONS OFFICE FOR THE COORDINATION OF HUMANITARIAN AFFAIRS (OCHA)

Project Title: Crisis Prevention and Recovery Support to Nepal
Input: Support UNDP's Peacebuilding and Recovery Unit, and its incubation and development of catalytic peacebuilding initiatives
Outputs: The Crisis Prevention and Recovery Support to Nepal (CPRSN) project aims to provide support to UNDP Nepal in two phases, with the goal of strengthening the promising but still fragile peace process. In the first phase, the project will provide targeted strategic support that will address the immediate needs of UNDP Nepal to engage with peacebuilding support opportunities and help prepare for a significant scaling-up of UNDP peace support activities in the post-election period, in view of the ongoing, substantial, downsizing of UNMIN. In the second phase, when the political situation will hopefully be less fluid, the project will support the operationalization of the Crisis Prevention and Recovery (CPR) component of the Country Programme Action Plan (CPAP). Specifically, the project will consolidate UNDP's peace-building efforts by:     Providing immediate support to implement priority peace-building activities  Consolidating Country Office's capacity to provide technical and programmatic support to the peace process  Developing a longer-term, comprehensive programme strategy/framework for addressing key CPR issue areas
Impact: Strengthening UNDP capacity to support the peace process, and development of new catalytic peacebuilding initiatives.
Outcome: Programmes, strategies, policies and systems that promote post-conflict recovery

Project Title: South Asia Water Initiative - Climate Change and Water
Nepal Water for Health Program
Input: 3 million (AUD) through WaterAid Nepal for Nepal Water for Health Program
Outputs: 25,900 poor people from 58 villages of four districts in mid far west and eastern region will have access to safe drinking water, improved sanitation and health conditions  58 new water schemes developed and handed over to community users group  District coordination committee in WASH initiated in four project districts  29 schools will have its own latrine facilities  54 communities have been open defecation free communities  10 local NGOs' capacity will be developed in delivering WASH
Impact: Sustainable access and governance in rural WASH sector   Sustained hygiene behavior (i.e. hand-washing with soap, management of water, faces and food hygiene)  Overall improvement in livelihood of rural population in the project areas
Outcome: Access of poor and excluded communities towards sustainable supply of safe and adequate water in the project areas  Improved capacity of selected NGOs and local government agencies to enable WASH services to be targeted at poor and excluded communities  Strengthen effect district level coordination and mechanism for WASH services

and resource sharing in vegetable seed sector development           Mapping of available seed processing, storage and quality testing infrastructure in public and private sector and its present use Outputs: Output 1.1: Farm families from poor and DAGs produce quality seeds. The main targets suggested for this output are: 12,000 HHs with 60% DAGs are organised in seed production and marketing groups; 800 tonnes of vegetable seeds produced; and at least 75% of all seeds produced get truthful label by 2014.  Output 1.2: Farm families from poor and DAGs sell seed through seed cooperatives and entrepreneurs. The main targets suggested for this output are: 20 pre-contracts are signed between cooperatives and entrepreneurs annually to sell seeds; and 6000 farmers receive services of inspection through licence holders by 2014.  Output 1.3: Seed cooperatives are capacitated to ensure internal seed quality system. The main targets suggested for this output are: 6000 poor and DAGs farm families and 3000 women represented in seed cooperatives by 2014; and at least 20 cooperatives apply internal seed quality control system by 2012.  Output 1.4: Cooperatives establish functional market linkage with private seed entrepreneurs. The main targets suggested for this output are: Vegetable seed marketing network of cooperatives and entrepreneurs established in each project cluster; and 20 seed producing cooperatives and entrepreneurs sell seed through contractual agreement.    Output 2.1: NSB, NARC and DoA develop and enforce/apply decentralised seed production system to produce breeder's and foundation seeds. The main targets suggested for this output are: Endorsed directives and procedures for decentralised seed production system are available by 2012; and at least five open pollinated (OP) varieties are released through participatory research by 2014.  Output 2.2: Public and private institutions obtain seed quality assurance mandate and licence. The main targets suggested for this output are: Trained 40 breeders, horticulturist and experts authorised for field inspection, sampling and seed testing by 2012; and at least 20 cooperatives produce truthfully labelled seeds by 2014.
Impact: Poor and Disadvantaged Households (HHs) in remote areas of Nepal have improved food security and income
Outcome: Outcome 1: Farm families from poor and DAGs produce and sell quality seeds; Outcome 2: National Seed Board (NSB), Nepal Agriculture Research Council (NARC) and Department of Agriculture (DoA) enforce decentralized seed production and quality control through both public and private institutions.

[1] Discriminated and poor as defined by SDC   [2] Cost-effective, technically sound, labor based and locally adaptable

Outcome: Farm households in the hills of Nepal, especially of poor and disadvantaged groups, have improved food security and income.

Project Title: Scaling up coverage and quality of HIV AIDS prevention targeted to most at risk populations and treatment care and support services to PLWHA / Family Planning Association
Input: The program's interventions target mobile populations, injecting drug users and men who have sex with men, as well as people who are HIV-positive. Under the program, prevention efforts and community outreach through peer education and interpersonal communication will be scaled up to reduce the stigma related to HIV and to lower the barriers to accessing HIV and AIDS treatment and counseling services.
Outputs: By end of year 5: 400,000 labour migrants and their spouses reached with targeted HIV prevention 3,000 IDUs reached with targeted HIV prevention 30,000 MSM reached with targeted HIV prevention 89,100 MARPs and vulnerable people counseled and tested for HIV 4,300 people with advance HIV infection currently receiving ARV treatment
Impact: By end of year 5: 1% of MSM HIV infected 20% IDU HIV infected 1% labor migrants HIV infected 90% of adults and children with HIV still alive 12 months after beginning of ARV treatment
Outcome: By end of year 5: 90% of MSM reporting use of condoms last time they had sex with a male partner (past 6 months) 80% of IDUs avoided sharing injecting equipment over past month 80% migrants reporting use of condom last time they had sex
Donor Agency: Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

Project Title: Economic growth for social justice: supporting non-timber forest product (NTFP)trade and business development in Karnali
Outputs: NTFP incomes are increased and better shared by enhancing entrepreneurial skills of NTFP producers, processors and traders in business development, marketing, quality assurance and quality control.                    Sustainable management and harvesting of NTFPs is improved through better management systems for 30 Community Forest User Groups (CFUGs) and increased skills of the producers.                 NTFP trade stakeholders in Karnali are better organised enabling stronger negotiation capacity towards export companies in Nepalganj and Kathmandu and local government                Vulnerable groups have increased opportunities to access employment in NTF trade sector, better access to trade information and knowledge on forest use and sustainable NTFP resources exploitation.
Outcome: To promote sustainable and equitable exploitation of high value Non Timber Forest Products (medicinal plants and essential oils as per NTIS list of priority products) in Humla, Mugu and Jumla districts of Karnali region

Project Title: Bringing inclusive CBDRR models into remote communities of Karnali, Nepal
Input: Activities related to result 1     Implement baseline & endline KAP survey on inclusive DRR    Set up and train 6 LDMCs as per LDRM guideline, including production of Inclusive Disaster Preparedness and Response Plan (IDPRP)    Capacitate District chapter of Red Cross to mobilise volunteers for enhanced preparedness and response capacity of the Kalikot branch, in coordination with CARE    Train 126 Community groups for mainstreaming DRR into their activities.    Awareness of inclusive CBDRR at community level is disseminated by Kalikot NGOs    Technical support to 30 Community groups of high risk communities to produce inclusive CBDP    Support 12 small scale mitigation activities (2 per VDC) devised by Communities and LDMC    Link representatives of communities at risk with National Network of Community Disaster Management Committees to strengthen their representation at national level    Participatory monitoring for compilation of best practices of inclusive CBDRR and dissemination in other Karnali districts via Karnali Kachahari       Activities related to result 2     Organisation and participation by ME and partners staff to the DIPECHO workshops on standardisation of inclusive CBDRR process    Devise training and advocacy training for inclusive CBDRR for 3 implementing partners and the 7 NGO in Kalikot    Training and implementation of DRR mainstreaming into local development NGO practices    Capacitate local community FM Radio for disaster preparedness and response in coordination with DDRC    Preparation of an earthquake awareness campaign and a one-day EQ simulation exercise at district headquarter by local CSOs and authorities       Activities related to result 3     Run induction workshop for local authorities on DIPECHO project and CBDP standards model (including flagship 4 minimum criteria) and LDRMP guideline    District and VDC workshop to mainstream CBDRR in annual district and VDC development plan including budget estimation for implementation    Monitoring and reporting on lessons learnt from implementation of landslide monitoring and EWS and reporting to DIPECHO partners and EWS consortium    Participation in joint DIPECHO advocacy campaign on DRR mainstreaming and EWS national strategy
Outcome: Result 1    Communities in 6 VDCs of Kalikot District mainstream inclusive CBDRR in their development initiatives and communities at high disaster risk implement preparedness and mitigation measures                Result 2    Civil Society actors of Kalikot advocate for Inclusive CBDRR and mainstream it in their mandate and practices.                Result 3    Village and District Development Committees of Kalikot have mainstreamed standard CBDP model into their annual development plan and allocated budget to implement it.

Project Title: Empowering women in humla and mugu, Nepal

Inclusion of Vulnerable women into WGN    Advocacy activities to ensure that most vulnerable women gain access to social support from civil society and relevant authorities.
Outcome: Vulnerable women have access to Human Rights and Inclusion based literacy classes, to improve their capacity and confidence, to raise their voices and claim their rights.                200 women are engaged in profitable income generating activities            40 Women's groups in Humla and Mugu are better organized and connected to advocate for women's rights and promote women's access to natural resources and income generating opportunities            Most vulnerable women, such as women with disabilities, have better access to social protection through better information on their rights and dialogue with government officials.

Project Title: IR 3.4 In selected districts and municipalities, adolescent girls and boys are applying age, sex, and issue appropriate life skills to influence decisions that affect their development
Outputs: Adolescent Development and Participation (ADAP) Programme that aims to ensure the systematic, ethical, meaningful and regular participation of adolescents at critical levels to make national policies, plans, and budgets adolescent-sensitive. The ADAP programme contributes to: UNDAF Outcome 1 - vulnerable and disadvantaged groups get improved access to basic essential social services and programmes in an equitable manner; and UNDAF Outcome 3 - vulnerable groups experience greater self-confidence, respect and dignity. ADAP aims to empower adolescents, especially girls, to initiate and sustain activities and interventions that create positive transformation in their families, communities and society and bring about realization of their rights. Three key strategies include: (1) ensuring active and meaningful participation of adolescents, especially girls and the younger age group (10-14 years), at every stage of the programme; (2) ensuring that core interventions address the age, sex, and situational diversity among adolescents, specifically those who are most-at-risk and especially vulnerable to HIV and different forms of violence; and (3) generating and sharing evidence including participatory behavioural monitoring and district level bottleneck analysis.
Impact: By 2017, in selected areas, children, adolescents, women and men, and all relevant duty-bearers are engaged in social change and action to realize the survival, development, protection and participation rights of children, adolescents and women with equity in all contexts, including humanitarian situations
Outcome: 3.4 In selected districts and municipalities, adolescent girls and boys are applying age, sex, and issue appropriate life skills to influence decisions that affect their development

Project Title: Improving Livelihood for Poor Farmers and Disadvantaged Groups in the Eastern Development Region (JFPR Project No. 9101-NEP)
Input: The project include four components    Social Mobilization and Adult Literacy  Strengthening of Income Generation  Support to Capacity Building of Stakeholders   Project Management, Monitoring and Audit.
Outputs: The purpose of the Project is to reach 12,000 very poor people in Dhankuta, Morang, Saptari and Sunsari, districts, to increase their incomes, and to enhance skills for effective participation in development efforts:   The social mobilization program and awareness campaign will reach 12,000 poor people and develop 600 self-help groups in the four districts, develop leadership skills, increase confidence and self-esteem, and improve the adult literacy rate for 6,000 people (50% of the target group). If residents do not move out of poverty, they will achieve literacy and leadership skills, participate in the development process, and become aware of their rights.  Income-generating activities for 50% of the target group (6,000 people) will be sustained by access to the income generation fund and links to the commercial agricultural fund being developed by the Commercial Agriculture Development Project. Improved income generation will impact the extent and severity of rural poverty in the four districts: 25% of the very poor will move out of poverty on a sustainable basis; 25% of the very poor will be better off.  The skills of service providers (at least 2 non-government organizations and community-based organizations per district) will be developed for social mobilization, income generation in commercial agriculture and marketing, effective reporting and monitoring, financial management, and beneficiary evaluation techniques.
Impact: 454 self-help groups (SHGs) organized, capacitated and mobilized covering 12158 HHs in the project area  Out of total of 12,158 beneficiaries HHs covered 70% are women, 40% are Dalit, 50% are ethnic, and rest 10% are other HHs.   All 454 SHGS received project support to initiate livelihood activities.  Income of household from 133 SHG which supported in previous season has increased.   Capacity of least 12 local NGOs/CBOs/Cooperatives improved  Awareness campaign (information dissemination on CADP and JFPR Project) organized for 12,000 poor people.
Outcome: 600 new/existing self-help groups (SHGs) capacitated and mobilized,  6,000 people's skills on leadership, literacy and numeracy levels, and self-esteem level enhanced,  6,000 families linked with micro-finance services,  At least 3,000 families, which are below the poverty scale at the time of baseline survey, come out of it,   Capacity of at least 8 local NGOs/CBOs/Cooperatives improved  Awareness campaign (information dissemination on CADP and JFPR Project) organized for 12,000 poor people.
District: - Dhankuta (Dhankuta) - Jhapa (Chandragadhi) - Morang (Biratnagar) - Saptari (Rajbiraj) - Siraha (Siraha) - Sunsari (Inaruwa)

Project Title: Embankment projects under Indian grant assistance including Bagmati, Kamala, Khando and LalBakaiya
Upper Trishuli 3A Hydroelectric Project
Input: The major components are:   1. EPC (Engineering, Procurement and Construction),   2. Supervision Works; and   3. Transmission Line.   The framework agreement and the loan agreement for 1 and 2 component were concluded on February 28, 2011and the same for component 3 were done on August 17, 2011. Date of Effectiveness of the component 3 is January 2012.        Disbursement update on 11 July, 2013 covers from 27 July, 2012 to 11 July, 2013 (Power House)    Disbursement update on 9 July, 2013 covers from 26 November, 2012 to 0 July, 2013 (Transmission Line)
Outputs: This is a run of river type of the power generation project identified by NEA in 2004/05. This Project is located in Rasuwa and Nuwakot districts. This has an installed capacity of 60 MW and will generate 460 GWh of annual energy. Major structures comprise of a 25 m high diversion weir, intake, desander, 4.1 km headrace tunnel, surge shaft, inclined shaft, underground powerhouse, tailrace, switchyard, 48 km long 220 Kv transmission line, 4 circuit 1 km 220 Kv underground cabling and ancillary structure.   For the implementation of the Project, the Government of Nepal had requested the Government of People's Republic of China for a financial (Soft Loan) assistance of US$ 120 million on July 31, 2006. Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) to this effect was signed between Nepal and the Export-Import Bank of China on November 04, 2009 for US$ 200 million (US$ 120 million for this project and the remaining portion for other projects).   As per decision of BOD/NEA on Oct. 11, 2009, China Gezhouba Group Company Ltd (CGGC) was selected as the EPC Contractor with a bidding amount of US$ 89.231692 million (exclusive of VAT). The MoU and Contract Agreement between the Contractor and NEA was concluded on December 29, 2009 and May 28, 2010, respectively. The agreed contract price, excluding VAT, for foreign portion and local portion are US$ 81.639498 million and NRs. 606.464468, respectively.    Similarly, Financial Proposal of the North West Hydro Consulting Engineers was selected on June 29, 2010 to carry out the construction Supervision works with a sum not exceeding US$ 4.443926 million.   EIA Report has been approved by the Ministry of Environment on August 26, 2010 and forwarded to China Exim Bank on August 31, 2010.   Commercial Contract Agreement for the construction Supervision works was signed between UT3A HEP and NWH, China on 21.09.2010.   For EPC and Supervision works, the Framework Agreement between the Government of Nepal and the Government the People's Republic of China, and the Government Concessional Loan Agreement between the Government of Nepal and the Export-Import Bank of China were concluded on February 28, 2011. Similarly, a MOU on Transmission Line and Bay Extension was also signed between the Government of Nepal and the Export-Bank of China on May 10, 2011.   Note: As per request made by the Exim Bank of China and recommendation made by the implementing and executing agencies, the Government of Nepal, on May 24, 2010, decided to request the Bank to provide upto the amount of US$ 8.917790 (10 percent of the Commercial Contract) as contingency in unallocated heading on the Loan Agreement to be concluded, if not, the said amount will be made available by the Government of Nepal in case of requirement. The Bank vide letter August 11, 2010, informed that they are not providing the said contingency amount so requested. 20/09/2010
Impact: Additional 60MW made available for the socio-economic development of Nepal.
Outcome: Construction of Upper Trishuli 3A Hydropower project (60MW)Completed.  Kathmandu 220 kV Transmission Line and 132 kV Extension line will be constructed.

Project Title: TA 9110-NEP: Strengthening Decentralized Support for Vulnerable and Conflict-Affected Families and Children
Input: Indepth assesment   Legal support for better service standard  Capacity development  Piloting quality services  Monitoring, Evaluation, management and administration

The government and other availaible basic services like education and health care have been assessed and show improved availaibility, accessibility and relevance to people's life, which are measurable through the increased number of recipients.

Project Title: Air Transport Capacity Enhancement Project
Input: The Air Transport Capacity Enhancement Project will enhance safety and capacity at Tribhuvan International Airport (TIA) in Kathmandu, three domestic airports in Lukla, simikot and Rara. TIA's airside will be reconfigured and upgraded to international safety standards including   About 1400 meters of new main taxiways and link taxiways  Runway end safety area and extension  Runway approach lights  Instrumental landing system/localizer  Air traffic communication equipment  Additional international and domestic aircraft parking apron area  TIA's landside infrastructure will be rehabilitated to enhance capacity with existing international terminal refurbished and upgraded and a new temporary domestic terminal of about 10,000 square meters.
Outputs: TIA's airside reconfigured for safety, landside infrastructure improved, and the CNS/ATM equipment upgraded  Basic safety infrastructure improved at three domestic airports in Lukla, Simikot and Rara  Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal (CAAN)'s organizational and management capabilities enhanced
Impact: Improved transport connectivity in Nepal - By 2017: Annual numbers of international and domestic passengers increase 75% and 55%, respectively.
Outcome: Improved safety and capacity at TIA: Safety standard is enhanced in accordance with the best international practices, including   Runway - parallel taxiway meet safety separation distance of 182.5m  Runway strip is clear of obstacle  International apron meets safety separation requirements  Category 1 precision approach lights are operational for Runway 20 and simple approach light are operational for Runway 02; and airport emergency service improves from ICAO's Rescue Fire fighting Category 8 to 9.  TIA's annual passenger handling capacity is increased from 1.8mppa to 2.9mppa(international) and from 1.0 mppa to 1.5mppa (domestic) Level of service for domestic terminal improved from IATA's grade 'D' to 'B' standard CAAN is reorganized and staffed, and staff policy and training program are implemented VAGS and APAPI are operational at Lukla airport and RTIL REL and ATC/MET equipment are operational at simikot and Rara airports
Secondary Sector Sub-Sector: General economic, commercial and labour affairs

Project Title: Enhancing the health sector crisis preparedness in the event of a high intensity earthquake in Kathmandu Valley and selected districts of Nepal.
Input: Development of Emergency Trauma Guidelines on Head and Burn Injuries including institutionalization.    Training manual development on emergency trauma guidelines, and roster mechanism and early deployment mechanism of health human resources.    IEC materials development and production cost    Training and workshops (materials, Resource Person/consultant Fee, refreshments, venue charge, stationaries etc.)      First aid to community health volunteers    Training on emergency trauma guideline to health professionals    Training on roster mechanism and early deployment mechanism of health human resources        Cost for studies on the potential role of FVHVs and traditional community institutions in emergency    Human resources (regular staffs and consultants)    Accidental Insurance
Outputs: The project specifically is focused to enhance the capacities of MOHP, health facilities and catchment communities around the targeted health facilities to respond effectively to a major disaster in Kathmandu and selected districts of Nepal.   There are basically 3 components of the project:     Capacity building of health facilities to manage mass causality incidents,     Establish and strengthen the institutional linkage    Community level initiatives, and information, education and communication
Impact: The principal objective of the project is to contribute towards prevention, avoidable loss of life and disabling consequences through effective mass casualty management system.
Outcome: MoHP provides effective leadership and guidance to health care providers to implement comprehensive mass casualty management.    Increase capacity of health service providers to manage mass casualty events, through training on trauma protocols, institutionalizing roster and early deployment mechanism and development of contingency plans.    The preparedness and response capacities of the community in the catchment area of the target health facilities strengthened to manage disasters risks.

Project Title: Strengthening the Sustainability of the Physical Rehabilitation Sector for Greater Access to Services in Nepal
Input: Materials/consumables for service delivery (assistive devices and physiotherapy services):     Complimentary additional tools and accessories for the production of 4,370 orthopaedic aids and 39,000 rehabilitation therapy from 5 Rehabilitation Centres to ensure optimal working of their existing facilities;    Necessary consumable, components, and stocks for the optimization of orthopaedic production and physiotherapy services in each Centre;    For distribution of mobility aids to persons with disabilities (wheelchairs, mobility aids, canes, crutches).       Logistic means for organization of:     20 sets of Rehabilitation Mobile Camps (each set of camp includes 1 Assessment, 1 Fitment and 1 follow up camp) in the remote, isolated and rural areas to increased access of people to services;    Short term and formal trainings sessions, capacity building initiatives and supports for Nepali rehabilitation professionals;    Organization of 80 corrective surgery services on specialized hospitals;    Sensitization sessions and campaigns to raise awareness about the services, disability issues and prevention, interactive meetings, monitoring visits;    60 monitoring and technical support visits, 6 CPAC meetings and 1 mid-term and 1final evaluations of the project.       Human Resources     International Staff    1 Physical Rehabilitation & sustainability Coordinator   1 Disability Coordinator   1 P&O Coordinator        Local staff    10 Project Managers/Assistants/Logisticians   10 P&O Qualified Technicians   3 Qualified Physiotherapist   1 Qualified Occupational Therapist        Partner Technical Staff    13 Management Staff   23 skilled techncial staff   24 semi-skilled technical staff   32 Community Workers
Outputs: 1: Strengthened quality and sustainability of service delivery: Technical, managerial, fund raising capacities of the partner organizations (managing the 5 rehabilitation centres and 3 satellite units) are further strengthened to ensure quality and sustainability in delivery of the physical rehabilitation services to persons with disabilities. ,.    2: Extended access to services: Rehabilitation services (Orthopaedic and physiotherapy) for person living with disability are extended to underserved areas of the country through decentralized actions: outreach mobile rehabilitation camps, mobilising community disability workers, provision of socio-economic supports, developing better coordination and referral mechanisms in districts.   3: Strengthened physical rehabilitation sector: Physical rehabilitation sector in Nepal is strengthened through: promoting national coordination, assisting the association of service providers, supporting in development of national plan/policy for long term functioning of rehabilitation services in the country.   4: Promotion of the UNCRPD implementation: Effective implementation of the Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) is advanced to promote and ensure the rights and benefits of persons with disabilities.
Impact: Persons living with disabilities in Nepal are functionally independent and participate in all sectors of society with enjoying their rights and benefits.
Outcome: Sustainable, accessible and quality physical rehabilitation services provided are provided for isolated and vulnerable persons living with disabilities by capacitated local service providers in the country.

Project Title: Save the Children Strategic Framework for Cooperation 2010 -2012
Input: Education: The focus of the education program is to reach the most marginalized communities. High priority is given to achieve universal primary education with a focus on gender parity and ensuring access to quality learning opportunities to all with a focus on girls and marginalized groups.   Child Protection: All vulnerable and survivor children will benefit from advocacy and capacity building of law implementing agencies program conducted at the national level. While the focused program to be implemented in the Mid and Far Western regions will particularly reach to the following children:     30,000 vulnerable children including orphans, Badi, and socially and economically poor;    5,000 survivors of violence;    6,000 conflict affected children; and 5,000 women vulnerable to Chhaupadi.     Child rights: The primary beneficiaries of the project are children up to age of 18 years. SCNN ensures that no children are discriminated however; SCNN will focus its target to children who are from most marginalized and disadvantaged population, including promoting girls participation. The secondary target group of this component of the project are:        The Ministry of Women, Children and Social Welfare and the focal points on child rights implementation    The networks for child rights and participation    The child clubs and their networks    The National Human Rights Commission and any other HR monitoring bodies    National Non Governmental Organizations
Impact: Project objectives:   1. Quality education  a. Provide access to quality education for girls, children from marginalized community and deprived areas in a child friendly environment.  2. Child protection (including HIV/AIDS and youth focus)  a. Create a safe and protective environment for children, especially in the Mid and Far Western regions.  b. Protect children from the impact of AIDS  3. Child rights governance and youth participation  a. Strengthen child rights governance in Nepal.  b. Strengthen the participation of youth in social reconciliation, peace building and livelihood development.
Outcome: Goal: Advance the rights of children to grow and to develop to their full potentional in a safe, supportive and productive environment, by brining lasting change in the lives of the children

Project Title: 64-11204012-KAT (Culture) Enhancing national capacities for the effective implementation of the World Heritage Convention 1-4
Input: JUSTIFICATION  1. Regular monitoring need for Nepal's WH properties is reflected in frequent requests for interventions/changes related to properties  2. Need to monitor the implementation of the IMP for Kathmandu Valley and its possible review to tackle emerging challenges, including disaster risk reduction and tourism initiatives for sustainable heritage management;  3. Need to increase the awareness/participation of communities in heritage protection to address challenges of living with and around WH properties, targeting members of communities who are unacquainted or not well-informed of the opportunities, processes and protection needs of the properties as community assets  4. Need to assist the national authorities in the process of nominating new sites for inclusion in the World Heritage List  5. Little understanding of the role of cultural heritage as a contributor to the sustainable development of local communities    MODALITIES  1. Technical assistance in monitoring and assessment study  2. Capacity building and awareness raising workshops  3. Exploring extra-budgetary funding for  3.a Integrating disaster risk reduction strategies in management plans and its implementation  3.b Up scaling self-sustaining initiatives with community  3.b.1 Survey to review Manual for traditional home-owners for Kathmandu Valley and possible new edition  3.b.2 Exploring the potential of heritage to contribute to sustainable development  3.c Establishing coherent information /knowledge management system (for Lumbini in view of establishing documentation centre)  4. Strengthening partnership with local municipal offices, among others for promoting the application of UNESCO Recommendation on Historic Urban Landscape (HUL), especially in Kathmandu Valley  5. Strengthening inter-ministerial coordination to enhance understanding of and ensure support for WH protection at different levels  6. Cluster and regional exchanges for learning from international experiences  7. Leaflet Publication promoting World Heritage properties in Nepal and re-production of translated operational guidelines in Nepali  8. Advocating for Nepal's possible accession to Hague Convention and its two protocols    TARGET GROUPS    Policy makers    Site managers    Community at large/ civil society and community leaders    RISK    Possible interventions impacting the OUV of the World Heritage properties    Loosening of credibility of UNESCO's action in the field
Outputs: MLA expected result(s):      ER 2: Contribution of World Heritage properties to sustainable development enhanced        Grouping expected result(s) (as appropriate):      Promote heritage conservation as an essential vector for sustainable development    Promoting the application of UNESCO Recommendation on Historic Urban Landscape (HUL) in the Asian context; Mitigate the impacts of Climage Change on World Heritage sites.
Outcome: Key expected outputs of this Activity:      End of 1st Quarter:  Deliverable 1: Ensured timely deliver of State Party reports requested by 1 February 2012 (communication, US$ 0 involved)  Deliverable 2: First phase review and/or consultation meeting organized with line ministeries and relevant departments for greater understanding of World Heritage management (presentation of relevant sections of operational guidelines, lesson learnt from IMP preparation (Lumbini) and reveiw implementation (Kathmandu Valley)  Deliverable 3: Leaflet promoting the World Heritage properties in Nepal published (layout prepared in 2011)  Deliverable 4: Initial consultation meeting organized with municipalities for reproduction of Heritage homeowners preservation manual and handbooks  Total indicative amount US$ 2,900 for temporary assistance and US$ 1,000 for programme related and other operating costs    Summary of Other Key Expected Outputs:  1. Continuous communication/correspondences with relevant authorities to follow-up the World Heritage Committee decisions  2. Reports and minutes of follow-up training workshops for World Heritage site managers and review meetings with line ministries, also in view of promoting the application of UNESCO Recommendation on Historic Urban Landscape (HUL)  3. Reports on stakeholder consultation for nomination of Lo Manthang  4. Reproduction and dissemination of translated references such as operational guidelines (translation completed in 2011 but review needed for inclusion of modification adopted in 2011 operational guidelines), leaflet to promote World Heritage in Nepal etc  5. At least two community awareness initiatives, one for cultural and other for natural World Heritage properties, in partnership with related site management authority in view of enhancing public understanding about the importance of World Heritage protection  6. Community Survey results for re-production of Heritage homeowners preservation manual and handbooks
Donor Agency: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

Project Title: 61-13104012-KAT (Education) Promoting education for sustainable development with a particular focus on integrating disaster risk reduction and management in the education sector
Input: Initial meetings and consultations were held with Nepal National Commission for UNESCO, teacher training centres, curriculum development centres and other key stakeholder in order to prepare modalities to build the capacity of education officials on DRR and its integration in education sector.    Participating regularly in Education Cluster Group Meeting on emergency on disaster risk reduction and emergency support response    A 2 days' workshop was jointly organized by MOE, UNICEF, SC and UNESCO with the support of UNESCO Bangkok Office on DRR in education sector with a view to reach agreement on a coherent and holistic approach to DRR in the education sector and to explore strategic options for integrating DRR into education sectorial planning, and how partners can support this. 70 participants from MOE, UN agencies, development partners and I/NGOs participated in the workshop. Workshop was facilitated by UNESCO, UNICEF and Nepal Risk reduction consortium's expert      With the support of NRC secondee a mapping of DRR activities in Nepal's Education Sector has been undertaken and shared during the 2 days joint workshop on DRR in education sector held in January 2012.    A flyer on DRR in Education an imperative for education policymakers prepared by UNESCO Bangkok has been chosen by education cluster group for its adaption and translation into Nepali language as an advocacy materials.      Meetings with key stakeholders have contributed to enhance understanding on the importance of DRR in education and bring all key stakeholders on board and work together to build the capacity of education officials on DRR in education including integration of DRR into teacher training and curriculum.      A 2 days' workshop contributed to enhance understating on DRR in education among education officials and other key stakeholders. The workshop agreed on 10 key actions to be undertaken in next 12 months as road map for DRR in education.   Analysis of mapping and other materials shared during the workshop further contributed in raising the awareness among participants on DRR in education.      Integrating DRR in education demand huge capacity including conceptual clarity among key stakeholder      Collaboration with Nepal National commission for UNESCO, MOE, UN agencies contributes brings key stakeholders to work together and also ensures cost effectiveness and sustainability of teh programme.

Project Title: 72-40113101-KAT (Culture) - Enhancing national capacities for the effective implementation of the 1972 Convention
Input: MLA expected result(s):      ER 2: Contribution of World Heritage properties to sustainable development enhanced        Grouping expected result(s) (as appropriate):      Promote heritage conservation as an essential vector for sustainable development    Promoting the application of UNESCO Recommendation on Historic Urban Landscape (HUL) in the Asian context; Mitigate the impacts of Climage Change on World Heritage sites.
Outputs: Expected Result N°1:   National authorities and site managers have increased capacity to monitor, manage and conserve the World Heritage properties in Nepal          N°    Performance indicator(s)  (a maximum of three)    Means of verification  (data source)    Programmed benchmark  (on basis of baseline data if available (1))        1    State of Conservation (SoC) reports and information requested concerning the implementation of the recommendations by the World Heritage Committee and /or advisory and monitoring missions timely submitted    State party's reports and correspondences to UNESCO World Heritage Centre    Lumbini : 1 status report;  Kathmandu Valley : 1 SoC report and 1 status report on 2011 March advisory mission;  Sagarmatha National Park : 1 SoC report; and  Chitwan National Park : 1 optional report on implementation of IUCN recommendation on EIA of Jagatpur - Madi 33 KV Sub-Transmission Line Project)        2    Number of workshops engaging competent national authorities and related line-ministries/departments in discussion and application of required measures to address existing and emerging challenges for conservation and management of World Heritage properties    Reference made to the existing or developing integrated management framework for Kathmandu Valley and Lumbini    Workshop report/review document including list of registered participants, workshop material etc    Dissemination of related guidelines with increased understanding of their implication (relevant sections of operational guidelines and national byelaws/guidelines reflected in management plans of properties)    Site managers/authorities from 2 cultural heritage sites and 2 natural heritage sites including local management bodies    Other officials from related line-ministries as necessary        3    Number of wide variety of stakeholders consulted in preparing appropriate management and legislative provision for the nomination of Lo Manthang by 2014    Workshop review reports  Experts/mission recommendations Participation    At least 20 stakeholders including policy-makers, site managers, local bodies, communities or their representatives and interested non-governmental organizations (including 30% women) consulted        (1) The baseline is to be indicated next to the benchmark in brackets.                Expected Result N°2:   Community members have greater understanding about the World Heritage concept and act proactively in heritage protection          N°    Performance indicator(s)  (a maximum of three)    Means of verification  (data source)    Programmed benchmark  (on basis of baseline data if available (1))        1    Community survey in urban core of Kathmandu Valley, basically covering the three durbar squares of Hanuman Dhoka, Patan and Bhaktapur    Review workshop among three municipalities    Publication - re-production or new edition of Heritage homeowners preservation manual and handbooks    Partnership with at least one municipality established for managing the reproduction        2    Community awareness initiatives to explain the value of the World Heritage movement and its impact on their day to day life, including in-come generation possibilities for the most vulnerable members of the communities    Publication and dissemination of leaflet promoting the World Heritage properties in Nepal and related guidelines (relevant sections of operational guidelines and national byelaws/guidelines reflected in management plans of properties)    Community participation in future conservation and development plans related to the properties in view of greater recognition of culture as an essential component of development process    At least 2 initiatives        (1) The baseline is to be indicated next to the benchmark in brackets.       Key expected outputs of this Activity:      End of 1st Quarter:  Deliverable 1: Ensured timely deliver of State Party reports requested by 1 February 2012 (communication, US$ 0 involved)  Deliverable 2: First phase review and/or consultation meeting organized with line ministeries and relevant departments for greater understanding of World Heritage management (presentation of relevant sections of operational guidelines, lesson learnt from IMP preparation (Lumbini) and reveiw implementation (Kathmandu Valley)  Deliverable 3: Leaflet promoting the World Heritage properties in Nepal published (layout prepared in 2011)  Deliverable 4: Initial consultation meeting organized with municipalities for reproduction of Heritage homeowners preservation manual and handbooks  Total indicative amount US$ 2,900 for temporary assistance and US$ 1,000 for programme related and other operating costs    Summary of Other Key Expected Outputs:  1. Continuous communication/correspondences with relevant authorities to follow-up the World Heritage Committee decisions  2. Reports and minutes of follow-up training workshops for World Heritage site managers and review meetings with line ministries, also in view of promoting the application of UNESCO Recommendation on Historic Urban Landscape (HUL)  3. Reports on stakeholder consultation for nomination of Lo Manthang  4. Reproduction and dissemination of translated references such as operational guidelines (translation completed in 2011 but review needed for inclusion of modification adopted in 2011 operational guidelines), leaflet to promote World Heritage in Nepal etc  5. At least two community awareness initiatives, one for cultural and other for natural World Heritage properties, in partnership with related site management authority in view of enhancing public understanding about the importance of World Heritage protection  6. Community Survey results for re-production of Heritage homeowners preservation manual and handbooks
Impact: 14. Overall, the low priority given for heritage , low capacity at management, monitoring and reporting tasks, lack of strong role by heritage-department, sections within municipalities for coordinating with related line agencies/ministries etc, lack of enforcement and lack of community-partnership heritage initiatives are some of the most challenging part for the implementation of 1972 convention in Nepal.    15. Capacity assessment at all levels and developing strategy for capacity building is a need for long-term management of Nepal's WH sites. A joint DoA-DNPWC interaction about site/national level implementation plan to follow up the Suwon Action Plan for Asia, especially focusing on capacity building in partnership with similar WH properties in the region or sub-region (UNESCO category II institute) shall be explored for the new biennium.    16. The office participated in an ICRC seminar advocating government stakeholders about different provisions of The Hague Convention and its two protocols. The desirability of their accession by Nepal has already been studied by the IHL Committee that has recommended the government to accede to the Convention and its Second Protocol. The study report has been forwarded to the concerned ministry for further action.    17. The progress of achievement by the key outputs to the beneficiaries and the progress towards contribution to the C/5 results seem at the required level given that particularly very little funding available for regular program implementation.    * For information: A proposal Linking heritage protection and community development in Nepal's Dailekh district developed in 2012 for a site on the Tentative List located in mid-western Nepal amounting US$ 80,000 was submitted to Prince Claus Funds for Culture and Development was not successful.
Donor Agency: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

Project Title: Modernization of Customs Administration

Enhance the Customs process capacity fo DoC by developing and establishing (a) Clearance Management System composed of Agent module, Valuation module, and Passenger clearance module, (b) Risk Management System and (c) Data Warehouse based on the BPR/ISP.   Improve the ICT operating condition and capacity of DoC through provision of ICT equipment.   Transfer necessary technology, knowhow, and knowledge to the officials and staff of DoC through the invitational program and dispatch of experts.
Outcome: Developing and establishing clerance management system, Risk management system and data warehouse would increase speed of clearance process, expose rate of false claims and smuggling and ultimately cause increase in tax revenue. The customs administration modernization would enhance the capacity of customs officials and increase in tax revenue in the short run and effective administration of state affairs and improved service to public are expected in the long run as the result of the Project.

Project Title: “Linking high risk and especially vulnerable adolescents with PMTCT”
Input: 1. Train outreach workers from NGOs providing services to MARPs on issues related to most at risk and especially vulnerable adolescents and ways of improving referral mechanism. 2. Train health workers, FCHVs and CMs on PMTCT and ASRH.  3. Train PMTCT workers on delivering HIV/ASRH services for young people. 4. Conduct orientation to DACC on the need of making PMTCT services youth friendly. 5. Conduct orientation to NGOs/ CBOs on the issues pertaining to most at risk adolescents and especially vulnerable adolescents.  6. Mobilize communities for linked response and enhance referral linkages. 7. Advocate for the provision of contraception for most at risk and especially vulnerable adolescents to prevent unintended pregnancy among HIV positive MARA and EVA. 8. Conduct coordination meetings to strengthen referral.
Outputs: 1. 100 PMTCT workers trained on delivering HIV/ASRH services to MARA  2. 2000 FCHVs and CMs capacitated to enhance referral of MARA to PMTCT services 3. Train 100 outreach workers of partners implementing activities/services for MARP on HIV/ASRH and referral
Outcome: By 2011, 20% of MARA and EVA girls from the targeted communities (3 DACAW districts) will receive PMTCT services.

Carry out participatory research to monitor behaviour change among the adolescents    (In 2008 - 2010 CPAP, the funds were managed based on the projects whereas the funds for 2011-2012 has been allocated based on the IRs. Therefore, the budget in this AID management platform is reflected only for 2011-2012).   [1] In Nepal context MARAs are identified as - CSW, IDU and MSM
Outputs: Adolescent girls and boys specifically MARAs and EVAs have comprehensive knowledge and skills to protect themselves from HIV in intervention areas.
Impact: The MOHP goal of health sector is to improve the health and nutritional status of the Nepali population and provide equal opportunity for all to receive quality health care services free of charge or affordable thereby contributing to poverty alleviation. (NHSP-IP II 2010 - 2015)   The aim of three year interim plan in health is to ensure citizens' fundamental right to have improved health services through access to quality health services without any discrimination by region, class, gender, ethnicity, religion, political belief and social and economic status keeping in view the broader context of social inclusion.
Outcome: Children, Adolescents and pregnant women, specifically the most at risk and disadvantaged have access and increasingly utilize relevant services to prevent HIV and mitigate impact of HIV & AIDS.

Project Title: Sustainable Sanitation and Hygiene for All (SSH4A) - AusAID
Input: Advisory Capacity Development Services to Government, Non-government and Civil Society Organisations in the fields of:    Multistakeholder process facilitation  developing organisational and management capacities of sanitation stakeholders   Technical inputs in planning, designing and m&e of sanitation programmes and campaigns  Linkages and networking at local, national and regional/international level
Outputs: Methodology development and capacity development in sanitation demand creation  Analysis of sanitation value chains in different local contexts and tailored support to value chain development, specifically businesses  Introduction and facilitation of learning of local agencies around innovative behavioural change communication approaches and strategies  Facilitation of local multi-stakeholder sector development and learning around WASH governance related to sanitation
Impact: Enhanced access to improved sanitation and improved hygiene practices of 26,600 rural people in Nepal
Outcome: Local implementing organisations are capable to do sanitation demand creation activities with quality.  Market-based supply chains for a variety of rural sanitation and hygiene consumer needs are developed and/or strengthened.   Local line agencies have developed behavioural change communication strategies for their area that are based on formative research and include non-health messages.   Local (district level) WASH governance has improved with respect to the enabling environment for sanitation business development and pro-poor support mechanisms.

Project Title: Sustainable Sanitation and Hygiene for All (SSH4A)

Project Title: High Value Agriculture Project (HVAP) in Hills and Mountains Areas
Input: In this High Value Agriculture Project in Hills and Mountains of Mid-western Region, funded by IFAD, SNV is responsible for implementation of Component 1 in which it will work together with the Local Capacity Builder Agro-Enterprise Center (AEC).    The Component 1 covers selection of companies for contractual production, value chain analysis, selection of producers, baselines and actual signing of contracts between the agribusinesses and the producers.   SNV also provides advisory services to Component 2 which provides the necessary support to the intended value chain development: formation/strengthening value chain producers groups, initiatives to promote gender and social inclusion, support for high value commodity production and post-harvest activities, establishment of a grant-based value chain development fund, and support for district operations and inclusion of remote communities. SNV has a small implementation role in Component 2 to promote gender and social within the project and among project stakeholders and contracted implementers.   Component 3 provides for project management and linked activities including M&E and knowledge management. Next to providing advisory services to Component 3, SNV is also responsible for the implementation of its knowledge management component.
Outputs: Contractual arrangements between producers groups and agribusinesses functioning effectively, sustainably and benefiting both parties in about 18 value chains   Strengthened institutional capacity for delivery and facilitation of market opportunities, information and support services   Women, dalits, janajatis and other poor and vulnerable groups well represented, actively involved and benefiting from participation in project value chains  Group Formation and Strengthening: Small scale producers organized in groups, with a high proportion of women and vulnerable groups, are better able to respond to market demand and opportunities  Social and Gender Inclusion: High portion of risk adverse persons/households and landless in project communities participate in the project  Production/ Post Harvest Support: Incremental volumes of agricultural commodities and NTFPs/MAPs are being produced in the quantities and qualities specified in contracts with agribusinesses  Value Chain Fund: Infrastructure, equipment and certification financed by the Value Chain Fund is contributing to the profitable production and marketing of the project's high value commodities  District Participation and Spatial Inclusion: Infrastructure projects that improve accessibility of remote communities completed and facilitate marketing of high value commodities  Project management, advisory and coordination systems operating effectively   A functioning gender strategy that guides gender mainstreaming and facilitates project response to gender issues  Increased capacity within government to guide value chain development
Impact: Reduction of poverty and vulnerability of women and men in hill and mountain areas of the Mid-Western Development Region
Outcome: Improved commercial relations and partnerships between agricultural/NTFP/MAP market operators and producers result in profitable, efficient, market-orientated production of high value commodities for 13 500 beneficiary households and 1800 entrepreneurs beside 37,000 HH taking benefit out of replication effects.  Increased participation and access of poor marginal producers in high value commodity value chains and agricultural/NTFP markets  Small poor farmers and other rural producers benefit from sustainable increases in volume and value of production of as a result of improved production/collection, value addition and sales of high value niche market products   Enhanced environment and strengthened local capacity to support market driven/value chain initiatives
District: - Dolpa (Dolpa) - Humla (Simikot) - Jajarkot (Khalanga) - Kalikot (Kalikot) - Mugu (Gamgadhi) - Salyan (Salyan Khalanga) - Surkhet (Surkhet)

Project Title: PCR5, IR-3: Legislation, social protection, social budgeting, child poverty
Input: A description of the main activities of the project  3.1 Lead DP working Group and provide technical inputs & capacity building to NSC SP to finalize national social protection framework 3.2 Support for Joint Review, assessment of child grant and revision of guidelines 3.3 Provide technical inputs and support Parliamentary Forum to ensure full incorporation of women and children's rights in drafting & adopting Constitution 3.4 Facilitate,support and provide technical inputs into preparation and submission of CRC, CEDAW reports 3.5 Develop child friendly version of child poverty study and conduct social budget study 3.6 Monitoring and Supervision
Outputs: Child and equity prioritized legislation, social protection policies and budget developed and implemented that are evidence based and in line with CRC and CEDAW
Impact: To enable economically vulnerable and socially excluded marginalized individuals, groups & community to cope and manage risks and vulnerabilities by providing them minimum level of social protection, promote fundamental rights of children by strengthening policies , legislations and institutional reforms.
Outcome: Children and Women, with a particular focus on the disadvantaged, increasingly benefit from improved governance, at both local and national level, legislation and policies that are based on evidence and the voice of children and young people.
District: - Dolpa (Dolpa) - Humla (Simikot) - Jumla (Jumla Khalanga) - Kalikot (Kalikot) - Mugu (Gamgadhi)

Project Title: NPLJ96 “Technical assistance for a coordinated response to prevent HIV among injecting drug users and in prison settings in Nepal : advocacy, capacity building and monitoring and evaluation”
Input: Conduct advocacy workshop/event for Government officials (Ministry of Home and Health, Prison authorities, other relevant Departments) at central level and regional level  Form technical Working Group on Oral Substitution Therapy,   Provide technical support to review and update drug control, prison and harm reduction policies  Build harmonized operational procedures for relevant stakeholdersand implementing partners  Develop manual for operational procedures  Develop specials tools and guidelines as suggested by the findings of needs assessment  Develop and adapt protocols for procurement of controlled substances e.g. methadone, buprenorphine  Document and publish evidence-based practice when activities are rolled-out   Organize trainings jointly with WHO   Provide specific services for IDU partners  Carry-out impact research and evaluation of MMT Emergency Response  Conduct a thorough technical needs assessment across the range of activities in consultation with all relevant stakeholders and partners (at central level and local, in collaboration with MOH, NCASC, local Districts AIDS Committees, Prison authorities). Depending on the results of the needs assessment, submit a set of recommendations for action to the relevant Government / UN / civil society working groups in Nepal  Carry-out the TOT sessions   Recruit and train an M&E Officer to be based in government office (MOHA/DCP)  Undertake rapid needs assessments / Rapid Assessment and Response (RARs) and baseline studies among IDU and prisoners to document socio-behavioural patterns and HIV prevalence, including consultation with drug users to ascertain their needs,
Outputs: Output 2.1.1 harmonized operational procedures for relevant stakeholders and implementing partners developed     Output 2.2.1 Thorough technical needs assessment across the range of activities in consultation with all relevant stakeholders and partners (at central level and local, in collaboration with government stakeholders conducted   Output 2.2.3 Carry out epidemiologic assessments in selected prisons/closed settings, pending on Government authorizations   Output 2.2.4 Conduct geographic mapping of IDUs in all districts that are among the priority list for the national response by ensuring participation of communities.   Output 2.2.5 Conduct End of Project Evaluation   Output 2.3.1 Social Support Unit supported    Output 2.3.2 Continuation of comprehensive NSEP in 7 sites    Output 1.1: Advocacy workshops/events for Government officials, civil society (Ministry of Home and Health, other relevant Departments,) at regional level
Outcome: Outcome 1: Renewed advocacy and support to the national response for HIV prevention, treatment and care for IDUs. Advocacy and communication strategy delivered and successfully geared towards opinion and decision makers, and communities.)    Outcome 1.2 Institutional framework for a multi-sectoral and coordinated partnership is strengthened, IDU targeted activities are mainstreamed with the national HIV/AIDS response   Outcome 2.1: Quality Standards are developed   Outcome 2.2: Monitoring and Evaluation: Improved availability & utilization of data on programme impact and trends over time & related behaviours driving the epidemic   Outcome 2.3: HIV/AIDS and drug use interventions delivered in selected community and prisons/closed settings

Project Title: USAID/Nepal Transition Initiative (NTI)
Input: Project staff, materials and equipments, technical assistance, trainings, small grants
Outputs: Conducted public fora/educational events to teach public about peace process; facilitated events geared toward strengtheining understanding among conflict-affected groups; trained print and radio journalists on topics ranging from basic reporting to complex constitutioal topics; provided equipment support and production and technical training to readio stations to increase their programming capacity ; conducted assessments; community small infrastructure constructed or rehabilitated, information materials dissemminated; Established a media outreach center a the Constituent Assembly building which allowed beter coordination between media and the constitution-writing body
Impact: Increased access to information and diversified public debate on issues critical to the political transition; and increased local-level engagement an participation in the peace process
Outcome: Strengthed the linkages between citizens and the government of Nepal and peace dividends during this fragile transition period. Youths were trained and mobilized to sperad awareness about the comprehensive peace agreement, progress on the constitution-writing process, and on government services.; Increased public awareness and engagement in the peace process and political transition.

Project Title: Scaling Up Nutrition Initiative -Technical Assistance (SUNITA)
TA 4962-NEP: Support to Anticorruption Institutions
Input: 1. Finalize needs assessment for NVC, PAC, OAG, CIAA, and Special Court    1.1. Review mandates of each agency 1.2. Assess capacity in institution to carry out mandates 1.3. Assess gaps in capacity (including any enabling mechanisms, such as legal framework, as well as internal processes) 1.4. Specify the needs to be filled in each institution to strengthen them to fulfill their mandates better 1.5. Collect benchmark data on the work of all five institutions     2. Finalize capacity development plans for each of the five institutions    2.1. Evaluate the overall context of capacity development options 2.2. Evaluate any human resources, technical, and technological development options 2.3. Complete plans for overall capacity development, including recommending changes to enabling mechanisms 2.4. Complete the human resource, technical, and technological capacity development plans     3. Train technical auditors for the NVC at the district level    3.1. Complete selection of first batch of trainers 3.2. Identify districts to be covered 3.3. Complete selection of trainees 3.4. Prepare training materials 3.5. Conduct training sessions in selected districts, with post-training follow-up after each  3.6. Revise training materials and modalities, if necessary, based on information from the post-training follow-up     4. Train PAC personnel on auditing, auditing review, financial analysis, and general committee affairs   4.1. Prepare relevant training materials based on needs analysis and capacity development plans 4.2. Conduct training (including on-the-job training and briefing sessions) 4.3. Organize a study visit to a neighboring country on how a PAC operates 4.4. Conduct post-training follow-up and evaluation, including ascertaining specifically how positive experiences elsewhere can be replicated 4.5. Project Title: Conservation and sustainable Use of Wetlands in Nepal (CSUWN )
Input: a, Wetland biodiversity conservation values integrated into national policy and planning framework . b, Strengthened national institutional , technical and economic capacity and awareness for wetland biodiversity conservation &Sustainable use. c, Enhanced collaborative management of wetland resources for conservation and sustainable livelihoods .
Outputs: Conservation and Sustainable Use of Wetlands in Nepal (CSUWN) is a joint undertaking of the Government of Nepal/MFSC, Global Environment Facility (GEF) and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP). The project is executed by Ministry of Forests and Soil Conservation (MFSC). The project is being implemented in two Ramsar sites of Nepal: Koshi Tappu Wildlife Reserve (KTWR) & Ghodaghodi Lake Area (GLA) since 2008. It is providing support in three major dimensions: policy & planning, capacity enhancement, and collaborative management for wetlands conservation and sustainable use.
Impact: Community institutions have been brought into forefront to promote collaborative management of wetlands at grass-root level. Likewise, Community Based Anti-Poaching groups, Teacher’s Network and entrepreneurs groups have been formed and being mobilized to safeguard the wetland resources and their wise use. Trainings and skills are imparted and post training supports are provided for improved livelihood of Wetland Dependent Communities [WDCs]. Quick Impact Programs [QIPs] are implemented to flood affected beneficiaries of Koshi Tappu Wildlife Reserve and its Buffer Zone when their properties were lost by Koshi breach of August 18, 2008. Various livelihood initiatives e.g. pater [cattail]/water hyacinth fiber weaving and marketing, fish/mushroom farming, pig/goat raising, carpentry/electric appliance repairing, bio-briquette, biogas etc. have been provided to the tagged WDC households. A total of 463 [308 at KTWR and 155 at GLA] have been tagged as WDC HHs in order to increase their income by 15% by 2012.  A total of 6 Km of solar electric fence has been erected [2 Km completed & 4 Km under construction] along the high impact zone of Reserve boundary to minimize local discords. Additionally, CBOs have been strengthened for taking ownership and stewardship of the resources.
Outcome: To ensure the maintenance and enhancement of wetland biodiversity & environmental goods and services for improved local livelihoods in Nepal
District: - Kailali (Dhangadhi) - Kanchanpur (Mahendara Nagar) - Rautahat (Gaur) - Sunsari (Inaruwa) - Udayapur (Gaighat)
Donor Agency: - Global Environment Facility - United Nations Development Programme

Project Title: Safer Migration Project Phase I
Input: The Safer Migration (SaMi) project will contribute to decreasing the socio-economic and psychosocial costs by building the migrants' knowledge about the migration process and their rights and by providing legal and psychosocial support to those who were victimized in the migration process. SaMi aims at increasing the benefits of migration by providing skills trainings for potential migrants especially to people from poor and socially discriminated groups (DAG) of Khotang district. The Government of Nepal together with civil society partners will be supported to identify a strategy to better implement the Foreign Employment Act (FEA).
Outputs: Output 1.1: Women and men migrants from Khotang access relevant information and orientation regarding safe migration; Output 1.2: Victims of migration related exploitation and fraud have access to justice; Output 1.3:Victimized women migrants develop confidence to return to their families or to continue their life in a different environment; Output 2.1: Effects of migration on family and communities are better understood and mitigation measures identified; Output 2.2: Civil society actors advocate for implementation of the FEA, regulations and directives with the MoLTM and other stakeholders.
Impact: Contribute to safer and more beneficial migration for men and women".
Outcome: Outcome 1: Women and men from Khotang make informed decisions about their foreign employment migration. Outcome 2: The Ministry for Labour and Transport Management (MoLTM) and other key stakeholders[1] act on priorities to improve the implementation of foreign employment policies.    [1] MoLTM, DoFE, Foreign Employment Promotion Board, NAFEA, UNIFEM, ILO, IOM and civil society actors
Donor Agency: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation
Secondary Sector Sub-Sector: General economic, commercial and labour affairs

Project Title: Safe Drinking Water for Ramechhap District
Input: This project will contribute to ensuring access to improved and safe drinking water supply for 40'000 people in the Ramechhap district including DAGs, which will enhance their physical well-being by consumption of safe water; not having to carry water from distant sources; and investing their time on productive uses. It also contributes to gender equity by saving women's time in fetching water and encouraging their participation in other development activities in the districts.
Outputs: · Output 1: People, including DAGs in the programme VDC's capacity to organize themselves for the construction and maintenance of safer drinking water supply is strengthened.  · Output 2: People in the programme VDCs are provided with hardware to build and maintain drinking water supply schemes with appropriate technology[1]  · Output 3: DDCs capacity to implement, manage and monitor construction and maintenance is strengthened. - Output 4: People in the programme VDCs are better informed about hygiene behaviour, sanitation     [1]Cost-effective, safe and locally adaptable, i.e. the scheme proposed is a gravity flow system from a distant spring source with intake tanks and piped distribution
Impact: People, including DAGs in the Programme VDCs of Ramechhap district are healthier as a result of safe drinking water supply and sanitation
Outcome: Population of 12 villages[1] have better access to safe drinking water supply  Population of 12 villages have improved sanitation and adopted better hygiene behavior      [1]Villages include Kathajor, Sukajor, Bhaluwajor, Sunaripani, Ramechhap, Salu, Sunarpani, Okhreni, Rampur, Himganga, Deurali and Tiplung
