Project Title: UN Joint programme of support to LGCDP
Input: Empowering communities and community organisations to participate in local governance   UNDP will draw on its more than ten years of experience of mobilising local communities to help citizens and communities engage more actively with local governments and for them to hold local governments to account. An important activity will be developing a mechanism for local bodies to systematically involve communities in planning and implementing programmes.     Enabling local body capacity building   The Ministry of Local Development will be assisted to establish and implement a system for building up the capacity of local bodies to provide basic services inclusively and equitably. Two key support areas will be enabling DDCs to better backstop and mentor VDCs, and funding training programmes for local governments, community organisations, user groups and other service delivery agencies. These programmes will emphasise gender sensitivity and social inclusiveness and enable Nepal's 3,915 VDCs to make the best use of the grants of 1.5 million rupees plus ($20,000) they receive each year.     Enabling central government and national NGOs to support local governments   UNDP, UNICEF, UNFPA, and UNCDF will work together to strengthen the policy and national institutional framework for decentralisation, devolution and community development. This will include strengthening the capacity of the Ministry of Local Development to facilitate sector-wise devolution, to design and use a local government performance monitoring system and to mainstream gender equality and social inclusion issues into decentralisation processes. Other key tasks are to support the implementation of the national capacity building strategy for local bodies and to support the three local government associations (ADDCN, MuAN, NAVIN) to work on behalf of their member DDCs, VDCs and municipalities.
Outputs: To empower citizens and communities for their active engagement with local governments and for strengthening downward accountability.    To fund DDC, municipality and VDC-led local development.    To develop the capacity of local governments for effective service delivery.    To provide policy support for decentralisation and local governance.    To promote gender sensitivity and social inclusion in local government affairs.
Impact: Local Governance and Community Infrastrucure will be developved.
Outcome: To enhance effective participation of people in the local governance process and ensuring improved access to socio-economic services by the rural poor particularly women, dalits and other disadvantaged groups .
Donor Agency: - Denmark - Department for International Development - United Nations Capital Development Fund - United Nations Development Programme

Improving the environment for financial sector reforms in areas such as credit information and financial news reporting through specialized training and capacity building.
Outputs: Part A: Reengineering of the Nepal Rastra Bank (NRB)   Strengthening NRB's human resource management capabilities.  Strengthening NRB's supervisory and regulatory capacity with respect to banks and non-banking financial institutions.  Supporting NRB's comprehensive legislative and regulatory reform efforts in the financial sector.  Strengthening NRB's accounting and auditing capabilities to produce better quality and more timely financial and accounting information.  Supporting Internal audit functions.  Conducting a training program for professional development of the staff of NRB and that of member banks of the Nepal Bankers' Associaiton including in-house training and attendance at external seminars and conferences.  Part B: Restructuring Rastriya Banijya Bank Limited and Nepal Bank Limited   Controlling bank day-to-day operations.  Stabilizing their operational and functional positions.  Strengthening the accounts of these institutions and improving their accounting system.  Designing a human resources program that will include, among other things, a training program, a retrenchment program and a revised remuneration package for bank staff, and  Preparing these institutions for divestiture from the public sector by way of hiring a bank restructuring advisor.  Part C: Other Financial Sector Assistance   Strengthening the Banker's Training Center.  Strengthening the Credit Information Bureau and the means through which credit information is disseminated.  Supporting training and capacity building among local journalists to assist them in conveying financial and business news and issues to the public.  Supporting the coordination Support Team in implementing and supervising the Project, especially in relation to financial management, procurement and coordination capabilities.  Supporting the establishment of a secured transaction registry for registering movable collateral.  Strengthening the capacity of the Debt Recovery Tribunal to improve loan recovery of banks and financial institutions.
Impact: Diligence and efficiency and in conformity with appropriate administrative, Banking, Economic and Financial practices and shall provide or cause to be provided, promptly as needed the funds, facilities, services and other resources required for the project. Under the supervision of qualified and experienced management assigned by competent staff in adaquate numbers and in accordance with the NRB Act.
Outcome: The financial performance of two public sector banks, NBL and RBBL has been improved. Such as, Non-performing asset has been reduce, both banks have been earning net profit; they are conducting their audit on time and publishing financial results on time. Both banks have substantially reduced number of employees through Voluntary Retired Scheme (VRS). The both banks are almost automated their financial transaction.
Donor Agency: - Department for International Development - International Development Association

Project Title: Scaling Up Coverage and Quality of HIV & AIDS Prevention targeted to Most at Risk Population and Treatment Care and Support Services to PLHA

Outputs: Expansion of diagnosis and testing in 30 district hospitals and primary health care centers;   On going support to existing diagnostic and testing sites in public sector and to existing ART sites;   Update of national protocols and development of standards of practices for VCT services and development of quality assurance manual:   Review of national guidelines (taking account of MSM STI screening needs) - technical assistant;   Review ofNational Guidelines on Anti-Retroviral Therapy;   Review of National Pediatric HIV/AIDS Guidelines and practices;   Review of current sites, patient loads at existing sites, staffing and protocol to enhance quality;   Upgrade of existing ARV sites infrastructure, equipment and management;   Oversight/management/M & E capacity of central and district health officers in managing ART at ART sites;   Update 01 guideline and training package;   Revise/Develop National Protocol on national laboratory quality assurance;   Technical Assistance to develop a plan for External Quality Assurance System (EQAS);   Recruitment of staff at National Public Health Laboratory (NPHL);   Contract agency to manage supply chain management;   Technical assistance to realign inventory management system at central warehouse;   Procurement of Pharmaceuticals (ARVs, STI & 01 Drugs) products;   Procurement of CD4, laboratory equipments, laboratory reagents, test kits;   Procurement of harm reduction supplies and condoms;   Undertaking an assessment of the needs of children affected by AIDS;   Development of Strategic plan/policy for children affected by AIDS;   Strengthening of Strategic Inforn1ation Unit in government institution;   Establishment of database at the Government institution;   Strengthening ofhuman capacity at the district level ARV sites;   Conduct review of the functioning, scope and composition of the NAC and NACC;   Strengthening of the capacity of National Entities to take over the Principal Recipient to administer this grant in phase two;   Development of terms of reference and operational guidelines for District AIDS Coordination Committees.
Impact: Reduce HIV transmission in Nepal and enhanced quality of life of people living with HIV&AIDS in the country
Outcome: Strengthened national capacity for governance and coordination of AIDS response Local government and line agencies more effectively mobilized, resources managed and services delivered efficiently with regard to HIV & AIDS

Kabeli Transmission Project
Input: This Project intends to support the addition of transmission capacity to the intigrated power system, and to provide access to electricity and cooking fuel to communities in the area of the Kabeli 132 kV transmission line.The project consists of the following three parts: 1. Kabeli Corridor 132 kV Transmission Line, 2. Community - based Rural Electrification-Grid Extension, and 3. Rural Enhanced Energy Services.
Outputs: Support the additional of transmission capacity to the Recipient's integrated power system; and  Provide access to electricity and cooking fuel to communities in the area of the Kabeli 132 kV transmission line.
Impact: After implementation of the project the capacity of the transmission line will be improve and enhanced access to electricity and cooking fuel to communities in the area of the Kabeli 132 kV transmission line.
Outcome: The Kabeli Transmission Project will support the addition of transmission capacity to Nepal's integrated power system and provide access to electricity and cooking fuel to the communities of the Kabeli 132 kV transmission line area.

Project Title: Load Dispatch Center Extension
Input: Construction and equipment for a load dispatch center, in particular for SCADA equipment, telecommunication equipment, training measures and consulting services as well as for expanding the Balaju substation for connection of an additional 132 KV and an 66 KV line to the load dispatch center.
Outputs: On the bases of agreement dated June 23, 1993 and Exchange of Notes dated October 17, 1996 on Financial Cooperation, Federal Republic of Germany extended a grant assistance amounting DM 40 million to establish a new Load Dispatch Center (LDC) and associated communication network and extension of Balaju Substation as well.
Impact: Improved the reliability and the economically viable operation of interconnected electricity supply system in Nepal.
Outcome: The objective of the project is to contribute to the improvement of the reliability and the economically viable operation of the interconnected electricity supply system in Nepal. These targets shall be reached by:   Optimisation of operation of the various types of power plants according to merit order;  Reduction of supply interruption due to contineous supervision of the electricity system;  Faster restoration of the electricity supply after faults in generation and transmission.

Output 3: Results-based budgets implemented by two public agencies   3.1 Assess the readiness of agencies for RBB using ADB's MfDR readiness tool. 3.2 Develop RBB modules for two agencies, with performance indicators on delivery of effective and efficient services. 3.3 Support, guide, and monitor the implementation of RBB, and report regularly to MOF and NPC. 3.4 Design and conduct a survey to assess the impact of pilots on service delivery improvements, and organize dissemination programs.   Output 4: Capacity of staff in selected agencies to apply MfDR approaches enhanced   4.1 Assess MfDR capacity in NPC and pilot ministries and establish baseline data on capacity. 4.2 Specify training needs of institutions (including scope/content of external training), and design capacity-development programs and training materials. 4.3 Organize capacity-development programs for strategic managers and for the operational level, and training-of-trainers programs. 4.4 Undertake training impact assessment and reflect improvements in competency in applying core MfDR skills.

Project Title: Reintegration of Children/Youth formerly associated with Armed Forces and Armed Groups and Children Affected by Armed Conflict in Nepal – Phase IV
Input: ensuring education and health services in the community,   promoting community-based psychosocial care and support,   reintegration of CACD,   provision of immediate/humanitarian support to children and their families,   promotion of community-based child protection systems,   establishment of children as zones of peace as a social norm  children/youths' participation at all levels to ensure their contribution in social development and peace building and  strengthening community capacity for child protection and peace promotion
Outputs: Facilitate durable socio-economic reintegration of informally /self released and verified minors and late-recruits through an integrated and holistic approach that will provide peace dividends to the community as a whole, with special focus on gender and social inclusion.  Strengthen the capacity of the government and community organizations (child/youth clubs, women groups etc) to protect, prevent and respond to the core rights violations of children especially those affected by the conflict and support their participation in peace building activities.  Support and mobilize children and young people for their involvement and contribution to peace building initiatives.
Impact: Support the overall peace process through the promotion of the rights of children and youth within an integrated child protection system.
Outcome: Socio economic living condition of informally and self released CAAFAG, CAC, VMLR and other at risk children/youth are improved through the provision of an integrated and sustainable reintegration support implemented in coordination with government and non-government stakeholders.  Successful reintegration cases are identified and support phased out.  The psychosocial needs of CAAFAG /CAC are addressed through the provision of psychosocial support through trained psycho social counselors  Cases are identified, reported and referred to appropriate service providers and adequate assistance is provided.  Incidences of child recruitment by armed groups and misuse of children and schools by political parties in the districts are reported  Children and young people from vulnerable community are able to organize and contribute to peace building activities in their community.

Project Title: Enhancing Access to Financial Services - EAFS
Input: 1. Establishment of Funds for Inclusive Finance (FIF), 2. SMART Subsidies and technical assistance to Financial Service Providers/Microfinance Institutions received,  3. Saving and Credit Groups linkage to the Microfinance Institutions (MFIs)/Financial Service Providers (FSPs), 4. Financial Literacy Campaign.
Outputs: Napal Rastra bank-implmented the Enhancing Access to Financial Services project was launched at the end of 2008 to increase the use of formal financial services by micro-, small and medium enterprises and low income households. This four-year project is being implemented by the Nepal Rastra Bank with support from UNDP and the United Nations Capital Development Fund (UNCDF). It is part of a larger proposed World Bank initiative.    An important initial activity is for the Nepal Rastriya Bank to establish a new technical assistance fund (the Fund for Inclusive Finance â€" FIF) that will increase both the quality and quantity of formal financial services (credit, savings and micro-insurance) to the project's target group.    The Nepal Rastra Bank is responsible for overseeing the growing number and type of financial service providers. These include the commercial and development banks, finance companies, microfinance development banks, Grameen Bikas Banks (regional rural development banks) financial intermediary NGOs, saving and credit cooperatives and small farmers cooperatives limited. The new fund will make use of and strengthen this growing network to serve previously unreached populations.
Impact: 330,000 new clients have access to formal finanacial sector.  10,000 SCGs promoted by UNDP and other development programmes linked with FSPs/MFIs.  Appropriate microfinance models for hills and mountain where outreach is small.
Outcome: Increase the use of formal financial services from profitable financial institutions by urban, micro, small and medium enterprises and urban and rural low income households

Project Title: TA 9135-NEP: Establishing Women and Children Services Centre
Energy Sector Assistance Programme Phase II (ESAP II)
Input: Grant from:     Government of Denmark : 150 million DKK    Government of Norway : 125 million NOK + Addendum: 22,4 million NOK and 18,2 million NOK    Government of Germany : 8.5 million Euro    Government of Nepal : 554 million NPR in Cash and Programme    Operation Support Services in Kind(kind support not included)
Outputs: The second phase of the Energy Sector Assistance Programme (ESAP) was signed by Government of Nepal, Denmark & Norway on 15 March 2007 with an aim to provide institutional and technical support to the Government of Nepal to strengthen its capacity to deliver energy services mainly solar energy, Mini micro hydro, biomass Energy (biomass efficient stoves) in rual areas. The overall objective of the programme is to improve the living conditions of the rural population by enhancing their access and affordability to rural energy solutions that are efficient, environment-friendly and socially justifiable. The main outputs of the programme are:     Coherent Rural Energy Policy.     Capacity Building of Public and Private sectors, NGOs etc.    Energy solutions to 1,050,000 households mainly in rural areas    Financial & Tech Supports: Solar PV Home Systems-215,000 HHs, Small Solar systems - 100,000 HHs, mini and micro hydro power of up to 1000KW-150,000 HHs Improved Cook Stoves CS & other Biomass Energy Systems - 325,355 HHs.
Outcome: Coherent Rural Energy policy implementation in Nepal    Public and private Sector, NGOs etc. are capable of implementing the energy programs.    Improved in education, health, improved living standards of 1050,000 HHs of the rural areas.    Increased electricity access to 460,000 households in rural areas and access to improved cook stoves to 325,355 HHs.
Donor Agency: - Denmark - Department for International Development - Kreditanstalt für Wiederaufbau - Norway

Project Title: Janajati social and economic empowerment project
Input: Awareness and capacity building of HMJ on social, cultural and identity issues    Conducting participatory assessments to identify economic opportunities for HMJs and support them to enhance their capacity to utilize those opportunities with focus on women & youth groups    Capacity building of HMJs and developing linkages with service providers to improve basic services eg. Health, water, education, NR    Strengthening the capacity of IPOs , to establish linkages with NEFIN, NEFDIN and other civil society networks    Survey , reviews and evaluations
Outputs: Enhanced understanding and awareness among 400 households of HMJs about their rights to identity and legal and policy framework.    3 IPOs actively engaged in mobilization of HMJ communities to generate broader support for their cultural and political rights.    At least 3 primary schools include curricula that reflects history, culture of Janajatis and use selective curricula in mother tongue of 3 HMJs.    At least 50 HMJ houselholds have increased production and sale of cash crops, livestock, traditional cultural items and NTFPs    At least 50 HMJ households have increased income through employment (small business, skilled human resource).    12 saving and credit groups are formed, trained and run saving and credit programs.    At least 600 HMJ households participate in the saving and credit schemes.    HMJs establish 3 endowment funds for addressing critical needs and crisis.    Participation and representation of HMJs (particularly women) in Schools Management Committees increased.    Enrolment of HMJ children in formal schools increased by 20%.    600 women complete functional literacy classes.    600 HMJ households have increased awareness on sexual, reproductive, child health and HIV/AIDS, including provision of health services in health facilities and communtiy outreach services.    900 HMJ households improved access to safe drinking water.    Increased access and control over common property resources by HMJ households through representation and participation in natural resource user groups (e.g. CFUGs)    Enhanced capacity of 3 IPOs (leadership, management skills and knowledge, resource mobilization, linkage).    Enhanced understanding and awareness among 3 IPOs about HMJ rights, existing legal and policy framework.    3 IPOs demonstrate capacity to represent and mobilize HMJs for their rigths and their credibility among HMJ improved.    3 IPOs are actively engaging village, district and national level leadership, district line agencies, civil society in policy formulation, enforcement and monitoring in upholding HMJ's interests and rights.    3 IPOs' linkage with NEFIN, NFDIN established and further strengthened for micro-macro linkages of HMJ's issues and policy advocacy.
Impact: Perception of HMJs about improvement in their economic status and access to basic services3.    Self esteem of HMJs enhanced and power relation between HMJs and other groups changed in favor of HMJs.    Local development plans and policies are responsive to HMJ's needs and priorities4.
Outcome: Increased representation of HMJs in local and district level social, economic and political institutions and active participation in decision-making process.    Increased networks and linkages of IPOs5 with NEFIN and other civil society organizations, including human rights organizations for advocating their cultural, economic and political rights.    Enhanced capacity of IPOs and NEFIN to promote and advocate for the rights of HMJs.    Number of income sources increased/diversified resulting in increased household income.    Increased access and utilization of health and education services by HMJs.    Increased access and control over common property resources and equitable benefit sharing by HMJs.

Project Title: Churiya Livelihood Program
Input: Empowerment of PVSE women and men    Capacity Building    Community Based Natural Resource Management    Livelihood Improvement    Formal Education Support    Policy Advocacy    Local Participatory Democracy and Good Governance
Outputs: · 50 women and 50 men from the marginalised community trained in community mobilization, facilitation and communication skill.    · 250 REFLECT centres established and are functional -addressing various social and community issues resulting in increased ownership of assets by women, reduction in incidence of physical violence and psycho-social wellbeing of women, improved access to and control over productive assets by women.   · 250 women groups formed and networked at VDC, district and national level for social/political inclusion and rights.   · 750 PVSE trained on Leadership skills and reached to various decision making position in CBNRM and other networks.   2,500 people trained on gender and social inclusion resulting change in attitude and behaviour towards women, Dalit and Janajaties, ethnic and marginalized groups.   · 2,875 individuals affiliated with LEBs, service providers, CBNRM groups and CSOs trained on UCP analysis, pro-poor livelihood improvement and good governance; 1,200 users affiliated with CBNRM groups oriented on revised guideline and policies of government related to NRM.    Capacity building of the 5 partners and staffs   · 60 CBNRM groups received capacity building and resource management support.   · 500 PVSE households received livelihood support by rehabilitation and management of 100 hectares of public land.   · 50 DRMC/ groups received support on disaster risk reduction and preparedness.   2500 individuals sensitized on upstream downstream linkage   · 1,000 poor households (focusing women) received livelihood improvement support through the development of livelihood.   · 1,000 households received livelihood improvement support through management of local common property resources.   · 500 individual received livelihood improvement through skill development/ enhancement.   · 10,000 individual receive awareness on HIV/AID and basic health services   50 VDCs initiated CLTS program   · 900 people receive awareness on affirmative actions in education   a) 5,200 students receive grants for schooling support   37,500 students have sessions on environment, natural resource management, social inclusion and harmony.   a) 6,200 people receive rights based and advocacy training and interaction.   b) 18,000 people receive capacity building support on land tenure and land right.   c) Budget analysis of 50 VDCs.   600 individuals (policy makers, executives, Groups, Networks, stakeholders) involved in policy analysis and national level policy discourse.   a) 50 VDCs receive participatory and pro-poor planning support   Studies conducted on participatory local development planning and UCP analysis
Impact: Increased access to assets and services by PVSE women and men    Improved social status for PVSE women and men through: i) equitable and sustainable access to forest and land resources; ii) increased awareness of and capacity for exercising their rights and iii) reduced discrimination and exclusion based on caste, gender and class    Increased resilient capacity against natural disasters    Increased access to formal education by school age girls and boys from PVSE households    Diversified livelihood options and enhanced skills for PVSE women and men    Strengthened cooperation and synergies among stakeholders     Improved local democracy and governance practices
Outcome: a) Leadership and participation of PVSE women and men in CBNRM groups, CBOs, NGOs and networks increased by 10%.    b) Reduced cases of gender based violence and harassment at household and community level    c) Reduced instances of social malpractices like dowry and early marriages   d) Increased percentage of budget allocated and spent on women and PVSE focussed activities by CBNRM groups, CSOs and service providers in their programs   Increased percentage of CBNRM groups' plans and constitutions that ensure inclusion of PVSE men and women in terms of allocating group resources to address their needs and representation in decision-making position   a) Increased and diversified income and assets by PVSE women and men at household level   b) Increased access to and use of basic services by PVSE women and men   c) Ownership of land by women increased by 5%    d) Increased allocation of CBNRM groups and LEBs' fund on Women's Empowerment and pro poor livelihood improvement activities by 20%   e) Increased availability and equitable distribution of forest products such as fuel wood, timber and fodder to PVSE households   f) Improved community capacity on disaster risk reduction and emergency preparedness   g) Increased number of PVSE households not included previously in CBNRM groups   h) Number of landless people organized into land rights groups and running campaigns for land rights increased by 50%.    i) Mechanisms for upstream and downstream linkages piloted and adopted   Increased school attendance of girls and boys from PVSE households by 10%.       a) Number of PVSE women and men demonstrating service seeking behaviours and use of services increased by 15% percent.   b) Improved accountability, responsiveness and transparency from CBNRM groups to exercise social inclusion, equitable access to and allocation of resources   c) Number of CSOs with good governance practices increased by 20%   d) Increased capacity of PVSE women and men to take part in discussions, negotiations and decisions in favour of their rights and benefits   e) Number of PVSE women and men who perceive that the attitude and behaviour of dominant groups[1] towards them are positively changing increased by 10%   Number of CBNRM groups, CSOs and LEBs adopting methodologies for identifying and analysing underlying causes of poverty and social injustice increased by 20%            [1] dominant groups will be identified during baseline

Project Title: Improving the quality of life of vulnerable target groups in the Eastern Region of Nepal by improving eye care and sight restoration. (CRT 133557)
Support to the Local Governance and Community Development Programme (UN joint project)
Input: citizen participation/empowerment    building the capacities and procedures of local bodies and their financing arrangements    capacity building and institutional support at the central level and policy support
Outputs: (i) citizen participation/empowerment: promote more active and effective interaction by citizens, especially the more marginalised, with their local governments, in order to better articulate citizen/community voice and to hold their local governments accountable for the services they are supposed to deliver;   (ii) building the capacities and procedures of local bodies and their financing arrangements: promote more effective delivery of basic infrastructure and services, including the piloting of a range of activities; (iii) capacity building and institutional support at the central level and policy support: feed lessons into the national debate on decentralisation and local development, and help develop a national "sector framework", and common basket funding arrangements for future donor support to local government.
Impact: Contribute towards poverty reduction in Nepal
Outcome: Improved access to locally and inclusively prioritized public goods and services
Donor Agency: - Denmark - Department for International Development - United Nations Development Programme

Project Title: Project to Prepare the Public Administration for State Reforms (PREPARE)
Input: Strengthen the existing government system and for the implementation programmes for the federalization of public administration.
Outputs: Output 1: Government-led public service reform strategy for shift to federal structures and capacity building of government institutions and future parliamentarians.   Output 2: Core government functions supported to ensure smooth transition of staff and services.   Output 3: Consultations between political and administrative actors on key public administration transition issues in the state restructuring process.   Output 4: A coordinated donor support strategy, backed by a multi-donor financing mechanism, for the federalisation implementaiton plan.   Output 5: Ensure accountability, transparency and responsiveness of the civil servants and the legislative bodies.   Output 6: A full-fledged longer term (5 years) umbrella programme form to support the development of the capacities of the new institutions at federal, provincial and local level will be developed.
Outcome: Tiers of government are established and function to meet the provisions of the new federal constitution.

Project Title: Promotion and Protection of Rights of Nepali Migrant Women (Shuva Yatra)

Outputs: Organization and capacity building of returnee women migrants    Capacity building of implementing partner organization and other local organizations    Establishing linkages at local levels and at transit for collaboration and solidarity between non state actors and state agencies.    Policy Advocacy for enabling informed and reasoned choice by women Activities    Establishing and strengthening linkages between migrant women in the selected host countries with Nepal Non Resident Associations (NNRA), Embassies and other support networks    Provision of information on rights and safe migration through PE, information desk, transit and departure points (India/Kathmandu)    Provision of psychosocial support to potential/migrating/returnee migrants in order to enable reasoned and rational decisions
Impact: To promote safe migration and protect rights of female migrant workers through mobilization and strengthening response of civil society
Outcome: To strengthen capacities and linkages of CSOs along the mobility continuum to prevent and address exploitative migration and trafficking    To empower potential female migrants to make informed choices/ decisions about migration

Project Title: South Asia Food and Nutrition Security Initiative (SAFNSI)
Input: South Asia Food and Nutrition Security Initiative (SAFANSI) forms part of the Government's commitment to advance Millennium Development Goals (MDG) in South Asia: MDG 1C reduce hunger; MDG 4 reduce child deaths; and MDG 5 improve maternal health. Malnutrition's most devastating impact is on foetal growth, and during the first two years of a child's life. Malnutrition accounts for up to 40% of child deaths each year. Despite healthy levels of economic growth, many of South Asia's countries have persistent and unacceptable levels of malnutrition with complex causality. South Asia has both the highest rates and the largest numbers of malnutrition in the world. Gender inequality and social exclusion are at the heart of the malnutrition problem in South Asia. About 23% (336 million) of the population in South Asia are routinely hungry, without access to enough calories, every day. This is greatly undermining human development and limiting South Asia's productivity with potential GDP loss estimates up to 3%. The funding of this initiative for SAFANSI will be a grant payment to a multi-donor trust fund administered by the World Bank, who will oversee activities to advance MDGs 1c, 4 and 5. The total value of this multi-country initiative is $5.77 million over 3 years, starting 2010-11.

Project Title: Strengthening Capacity of the department of National Parks and Wildlife Conservation for Effective Management of Mountain Protected Area

The partnership will: ensure continued access to international cutting edge research, analysis and intellectual policy expertise ; ability to draw on international best practice and lessons learned from fragile, complex and conflict affected environments; provide an opportunity to input and steer direction at international policy discussion level; access to international products and materials including guidance notes, analysis and toolkits. This initiative contributes to two of the Crisis Prevention, Stabilisation and Recovery (CPSR) Group's objectives: international and whole of government engagement by leveraging best practice and analysis for the Australia aid program from strategic partnerships; and strategic advice guidance that draws on cross-Agency experience, international analysis and lessons learned from fragile, complex and conflict affected areas. The total value of this initiative is $11.9 million over 8 years, starting 2008-09.

Project Title: Public Financial Management Support Multi-Donor Trust Fund Contribution (Nepal)
Impact: The objective of the MDTF is to strengthen the performance, transparency and accountability in public financial management in Nepal.   The Key Results expected from the projects to be funded through the MDTF are:  1. Improved resource management as a result of strengthened PFM systems and processes, 2. Increased awareness and oversight of government PFM processes by diverse constituencies ,  3. Better knowledge of value for money challenges and PFM governance gaps, contributing to improved design of PFM interventions at the country and sector level.  The trust fund PDO will be attained through implementation of various sub-projects designed and implemented with support from the MDTF. The MDTF will be used as a vehicle to support a wide range of activities based on priorities set by the government and development partners broadly categorized under three broad dimensions: Supply, Demand and Knowledge.   The MDTF will support activities that will: (a) strengthen the PFM systems and processes (the supply side); (b) strengthen institutions of accountability and civil society to enhance their oversight of PFM processes and performance (the demand side); and (c) deepen knowledge about current PFM practices and options for improvement.

Project Title: Reducing social tensions and social crimes and enhancing telerance for sustainable peace conciliation process in North-west communities of Kapivastu district (CTR 234000)
549NEP5000 (CI) - Empowering people to enjoy their Right to Information for greater accountability of Nepal's power holders
Input: 1.2.3. Describe and define the target groups and final beneficiaries, their needs and constraints and how the action will address these needs    Target groups:  The three main target groups are journalists, local change agents (teachers, lawyers and civil society activists) and government officials.  The 250 journalists to be selected to participate in the training provided by the project come from the areas mostly affected by press freedom violations. These incidents have been, since 2007, most intense in Nepal's central plains and the eastern hills. Therefore, while journalists in the capital and urban centres have been largely secure, those working in the plains in general and in the eastern hills have been attacked, threatened, or continuously harassed by different interest groups, many of which are also armed. Therefore this project will focus mainly on these areas, where, according to FNJ estimates, there are around 1,500 journalists in the eastern region and around 1,500 to 2,000 journalists in the central plains. These are the areas where working as a journalist is most dangerous, and where the journalists need most support in building their capacity both in investigative journalism and personal safety. Many of these journalists have not had any training in journalism, and do not understand their possibilities and responsibilities in serving the public with accurate, non-partisan information. Therefore through building their capacity, we can improve the access to information for people on district level. The journalists will be selected in cooperation with the local chapters of Federation of Nepali journalists, ensuring equal representation of women, lower castes and other marginalized groups. A special focus will be given to journalists who have already made attempts to practice investigative journalism, but who do not necessarily have the necessary skills yet.  The 250 local mediators (teachers, lawyers and civil society activists, depending on the area) are people who are active in their community and to whom people come to ask for help. These mediators will be trained as local focal points to raise awareness on the RTI Act and its relevance locally as well as for helping local people with their information requests to the government offices. In order to increase the synergies between project components the local mediators will be selected from the same areas as the journalists. That way the journalists and mediators can support each other's work.  The third target group of the project are government officials who are responsible for the implementation of the Right to Information law. Many government offices have information officers, but in many cases their capacity remains low. By organizing local level orientation sessions for the government information officers the project seeks to build their capacity and to orient them to their public service task. In addition, through linking the trained journalists and mediators to these sessions, the project aims at building local level multi-stakeholder networks that on a local level work jointly to increase and improve people's access to public information.    The project mainstreams gender throughout all its activities. In addition, the project will ensure women's equal participation in all training programmes. Individual women will be identified and encouraged to apply, and the trainings will be organized in a manner that suits the time constraints of women.  It is much more challenging for a woman to step up and speak for herself because of the cultural and social norms of gender in Nepal, let alone to demand for information from government officials who often are men. In addition, a woman is likely to be treated differently from a man if she approaches a government office and requests for information. This specific approach will be emphasized in the training of local mediators, so that they will be able to offer locally-relevant solutions - e.g. cooperating with local women's groups, where the information request does not come from an individual woman but a group of women could help ease the social challenges. In addition, the issue of gender equality and women's specific needs will be addressed also in the orientation given to government officials.  The gender equality aspect will also be covered in the handbook for journalists and the handbook for local mediators, both to be published in the course of the project. In addition, the project will ensure all promotional products, such as posters or leaflets, go through a gender analysis, ensuring the material is also suitable for women and doesn't support gender stereotypes.    The overall objective of this action is to improve the transparency of Nepal's government and the accountability of decision-making through a broader implementation of the Right to Information Act. The action also has three specific objectives: 1) Citizens have access to information that is relevant to them and are hence motivated to exercise their democratic rights; 2) Journalists recognize their role as the watchdogs of the power holders and proactively seek and publish correct and timely information and 3) Local level government officials understand their role as public servants and are more willing to share public information.    Activity group 1: Building the capacity of journalists on investigative journalism / RTI / personal safety  The activities of this group include training of trainers with an international trainer, training of 250 journalists on RTI and safety, a handbook for journalists on RTI and a fellowship programme and competition for best investigative journalism using RTI Law  Output: Journalists have the capacity to use RTI in investigative journalism and to protect themselves while using it.  Result: Journalists are actively using RTI for the purposes of investigative journalism and simultaneously protect their personal safety.    Activity group 2: Raising public awareness on right to information and how to use the RTI Law  The activities of this group include public awareness campaigning, network of local mediators and a handbook and advocacy material for local communities on how to use the RTI Law for obtaining locally relevant information  Output: People have the knowledge of their constitutionally protected right to information and of the importance of the RTI Law to their lives as well as of how to submit requests for information.  Result: People actively utilize the RTI Law by making information requests to relevant public agencies.    Activity group 3: Improving the general climate for the successful implementation of the RTI Law  The activities of this group include local meetings with journalists and government information officers, high-level seminar on the implementation of the RTI act and establishing a loose network of civil society organizations and other potential stakeholders promoting RTI  Output: Power holders understand the possibilities and limitations of the RTI act and their role in its implementation  Result: Journalists, civil society activists and local mediators jointly work towards ensuring open and transparent society where public information is shared freely and without problems.
Outputs: Journalists have the capacity to use RTI in investigative journalism and to protect themselves while using it.  People have the knowledge of their constitutionally protected right to information and of the importance of the RTI Law to their lives as well as of how to submit requests for information.  Power holders understand the possibilities and limitations of the RTI act and their role in its implementation

Project Title: Nepal India Electricity Transmission and Trade Project (NIETTP)2011, + Additional Financing 2013
Nepal Bridges Improvement and Maintenance Programme
Input: Major components:   a) Planning, technical design and quality control of bridges   b) Major and monor maintenance of existing bridge assets   c) Imvestments in new bridge construction.
Outputs: Major Maintenance 716 bridges, 35476 m    Construction backlog completion 11 bridges    New crossings 267 bridges    Minor maintenance 100 bridges    Routine maintenance 711 bridges
Impact: To provide safe, reliable and cost effective bridges on Nepal's Strategic Roads Networks.
Outcome: Increased share of bridges on SRN meeting minimum loading requirements    Improved condition of bridges on SRN    Strengthened performance management in the bridge sector.

Project Title: Orientation and Sensitization of District and VDC Level Stakeholders in Sector Coordination Planning and Implementation in Sindhupalchowk District
Input: To orient the targeted participants about latest sector policies, strategies and plans, ongoing trends of sanitation sector and the roles and responsibilities of stakeholders in national, regional, district, municipality and VDC levels.    To form/reform D-WASH-CC and V-WASH CC in a representative manner and to seek participants' commitments for the mobilization of budget of DDC, VDCs, government line agencies and other development partners in sanitation.    To localize the Master Plan by formulating district and VDC level Strategic Plan/Plan of Action in GSF programme districts with specific consideration of target, resources, responsibilities and monitoring and follow up frameworks.    To prepare ground works in order to link up GSF programme with local level planning process of D-WASH-CC and V-WASH-CC for programme activities implementation by building the ownership ofthe government.    To draw stakeholders' joint commitments by means of district and VDC level declarations and/or plan ofaction for future endeavour and its' monitoring and follow up.
Outputs: A. District level     D-WASH-CC formed/reformed/activated/strengthened for overall coordination of sanitation and hygiene activities    A total of 30 stakeholders including chairpersons of all political parties and their DDC representatives capacitated and enabling enviromnent created for collaborative planning, financing, implementation, monitoring and follow up of sanitation programme.    Stakeholders, local resources, strategic approaches, activities and tools identified to back up ODF/total sanitation initiatives.    A total of 1110 stakeholders (VDC secretaries and local level actors and front line workers) capacitated to create an enabling enviromnent for collaborative planning, financing, implementation, monitoring and follow up of sanitation programme.    District level Strategic Plan/Plan of Action on sanitation formulated/updated/revised/modified, endorsed and disseminated to local level in line with the Master Plan.    A conducive environment prepared for the integration of GSF programme activities with district and VDC level planning frameworks.    At least 12 numbers ofdistrict level key learning and success storied documented and shared.    Regular monitoring and follow up mechanism established within D-WASH-CC in coordination with district level sector partners.    B. VDC level     V-WASH-CC formed/reformed/activated/strengthened in 37 VDCs for overall coordination of sanitation and hygiene activities.    VDC level Strategic PlanJPlan of Action on sanitation formulated/updated/revised/modified and endorsed in 37 VDCs for implementation in line with district level Strategic PlanJPlan of Action.    Local level norms, rules and regulations formulated in 37 VDCs.    Local level stakeholders such as schools, Forest Users' Groups, micro finance institutions,mothers groups, etc. identified trained and mobilized for sanitation and hygiene promotion through ODF campaigns    A conducive environment prepared for the integration of sectoral activities in general and GSF programme activities in particular with VDC level planning frameworks.    At least 12 numbers of VDC level of key learning and success storied documented and shared out of 37 program VDCs

Project Title: Capacity Building on Total Sanitation and Behavioral Change to Schools, Communities and Local Level Stakeholders in Sunsari Districts
Input: To capacitate school teachers, representatives from SMC and PTA, district level line agencies, NGO/CBOs, local level line agencies, front line workers and stakeholders who have working linkage with policy makers in districts, and also between implementers and actual beneficiaries in the communities for the promotion ofsanitation and hygiene.    To promote institutionalization of sanitation and hygiene related activities and related promotional activities for continuation and sustainability with optimal mobilization of human resources at local level for stimulating ODF campaign and scaling up sanitation    To create conducive environment to ensure participation, support, ownership and endorsement from the school families, specifically teachers and students/child clnbs for the promotion of sanitation and hygiene in school and towards community.
Outputs: Schools and community stakeholders made aware about their responsibility and accountability for improved sanitation and hygiene situation in their communities.    At least 1320 numbers ofHMs, SMC and PTA Chairpersons,VDC secretary, V-WASH-CC and SWASH-CC chairpersons including RPs and SIs trained and mobilised to support adoption and replication of improved sanitation and hygiene behaviour and the ODF campaign    At least 660 numbers of teachers 3-4 per school on an average from each school including RPs and SIs trained and mobilized to support adoption and replication of improved sanitation and hygiene behaviour and the ODF campaign    Child club members 30 numbers in an average from each school trained, oriented and mobilized for sanitation campaign and monitoring.    At least 80 % of the students practice hand washing with soap in all schools which have sanitation facilities within 35 programme VDCs.    220 school catchments area level Plan of Action prepared and implemented as to complement and supplement the ODF campaign set under VDC level Strategic Plan/Plan of Action.    Local resources generated to support hygiene and sanitation promotion    Self-monitoring mechanism of school and community for monitoring sanitation and hygiene status established through enhanced coordination with V-WASH-CC and concerned stakeholders.    70 local level sanitation champions trained, oriented and mobilized 2 each from 35 program VDCs.    1050 members from 175 civil society organizations 6 per school on an average within 35 program VDCs trained, oriented and mobilized for sanitation promotion.    At least 630 numbers of FCHVs trained, oriented and mobilized for sanitation promotion    Established at least 176 functional resource centers in 176 schools out of 220 equipped with norms, disciplinary rules, brochures, social map for visibility and motivation in close coordination with relevant Sub-grantees

Project Title: Open Defecation Free Campaign and Sanitation and Hygiene Behaviour Promotion in Bajura District
Input: Triggering and mass sensitisation    Advocacy and Awareness    Community mobilisation    Establishment of matching fund for sanitation improvement    ODF declaration    Reward and recognition
Outputs: 1. Fixed place defecation practice increased by 20% through construction and use of toilet in 15 selected VDCs in the district.   2. ODF declared in at least 3 wards in each VDC and at least 3 VDCs from the 15 selected VDCs and momentum generated for the achievement of the target set in plan of action in all communities with the inclusion of poor and socially disadvantaged communities specifically slums and squatters.   3. Practice of hand washing with soap increased by 25 % in the community and by 80% in schools where relevant hardware facilities exist.   4. Existing sanitation facilities used, operated and maintained by 100% users in schools, health posts, VDC offices, community institutions, etc.   5. Cost shared by VDC through its regular budget source to back up hygiene and sanitation movement.   6. Municipality level strategic plan/plan of action on hygiene and sanitation promotion implemented.   7. Functional linkage established between V-WASH-CC and D-WASH-CC for strategic support to speed up ODF initiative in Bardiya District in totality through joint planning, programming and implementation arrangements.   8. The resource centres equipped in at least 120 schools and VDC office/Health Post and Sub-Health posts.   9. 70% community people are sensitized through advocacy and communication channels and 10% of them are directly engaged in total sanitation movement.   10. Collected, compiled and shared at least 15 success stories through electronic and print media and knowledge base on programme events and local level sanitation for influencing communities as well as sector actors.
Impact: Local authorities of Bardiya district prioritize sanitation to retain ODF status in sustainable manner
Outcome: ODF status of Bajura District

Project Title: Open Defecation Free Campaign and Sanitation and Hygiene Behavioural Promotion in Arghakhanchi
Input: To trigger people and create awareness for proper hygiene and sanitation behaviours;    To strengthen institutional arrangements for ensuring collaboration, building local capacity and ownership and sustaining sanitation interventions;    To empower communities to construct and use of improved sanitation facilities and achieve    ODF status with proper consideration of gender and social inclusion.    To facilitate easy access to materials for constructing toilets through strengthening local supply chain.
Outputs: Fixed place defecation practice (defecation in a hygienic latrine instead of indiscriminate defecation in open spaces, fields, road sides, river banks, etc.) increased by 20% from base line data through construction and use of toilet as per the indicators of JMP (WHO and UNICEF) and GSF programme log frame.    ODF status achieved and declared in at least IS communities in each 32 program VDC and 10 VOCs out of 32 program VDCs and momentum generated for the achievement of the    ODF target through effective mobilization of school, institutions and communities with the inclusion of poor and socially disadvantaged communities.    Hand washing with soap practiced by additional 25 % community people and 80% students within the project area provided relevant hardware facilities in place as a result of school and community level sanitation interventions.    At least 80 % use, operation and maintenance of existing sanitation facilities by users in schools, health posts, VDC offices, community institutions, etc.    Cost shared by 32 program VOCs through its regular budget source to back up hygiene and sanitation campaign.    Implemented 32 VDC level Strategic Plan/Plan ofAction on sanitation.    Established functional linkage with D-WASH-CC for strategic support to speed up ODF initiative in Arghakhanchi district through joint planning, programming and implementation arrangements.    Established Resource Centres in at least 240 schools out of 300 schools and in 26 VDC offices out of 32 VDCs equipped in maintaining and disseminating database on ODF/total sanitation initiatives.    At least 80% community people Sensitized through advocacy and communication channels and 10% of them directly engaged in total sanitation campaign.    Collected, compiled and shared at least 10 success stories through electronic and print media to strengthen knowledge base on programme events and local level sanitation initiatives for influencing communities as well as sector actors.    Generated critical mass at local levels to run advocacy, awareness and mass sensitization activities and back up ODF/total sanitation campaign.    Strengthened supply and demand chain for sanitation goods and services through engagement of private entrepreneurs at local level.    Regular data base and monitoring system on progress and approach to be maintained by subgrantee

Input: Orientation and training activities    Establishment of child clubs    Preparation of plan of action    Mobilisation of trained human resources
Outputs: 1. Schools and community stakeholders aware about their responsibility and accountability for improved sanitation and hygiene situation in their communities.  2. At least 4590 persons trained and mobilised to support adoption and replication of improved sanitation and hygiene behaviour and the ODF campaign  3. At least 80 % of the students practise hand washing with soap in all schools within 15 programme VDCs.  4. 120 school catchments area level plan of action prepared and implemented.  5. Local resources generated to support hygiene and sanitation promotion.  6. Self monitoring mechanism of school and community for monitoring sanitation and hygiene status established.  7. School catchments area level plan of action prepared and implemented
Impact: Trained human resources capacitated through orientation and training irrespective of gender, social and educational status with representation from every section of society
Outcome: 1. capacitate the school teachers, representatives from management committee, district level line agencies, NGO/CBOs, local level line agencies, front line workers and stakeholders who have working linkage between policy makers in district level with actual beneficiaries and implementers.  2. promote institutionalization of sanitation and related promotional activities for continuation and sustainability with optimal mobilization of human resources at local level for scaling up sanitation is a must.  3. create proper environment in order to ensure participation, support and endorsement from part to whole right from the school families specifically teachers and students/child clubs along with women and children from and within the community including civil society members

Project Title: Capacity Building for Strategic Planning for Municipal Solid Waste Management including understanding of Climate Change and Clean Development Mechanism
Input: Capacity Building of municipal staffs of five selected municipalities on Climate Change, CDM and SWM;          Development of Long Term SWM strategies and Short Term Action Plan of five selected municipalities;  Technical support to five municipalities during implementation of pilot projects by the municipalities;   Determination of existing situation of SWM and developing a data-base of all the fifty eight municipalities.
Outputs: Develop of mechanisms to increase public involvement in SWM in all phases (segregation, collection and safe disposal) including developing SWM Long Term Strategic Plans and Short Term Action Plans acceptable to all stakeholders;  Build capacity of government and municipalities on CDM for sustainable management of solid waste through revenue generation and demonstrate mitigation approaches to climate change;   Enhance capacities of Municipal staffs in various aspects of SWM so that they are able to formulate SWM strategies and action plans by them and explore and tap global opportunities;  Identify and implement appropriate management and technological options suited to social, economic and cultural context;  Preparation of situational assessment and status reports and data-base of all the 58 municipalities to support GoN in planning and monitoring progress on SWM.
Impact: Strengthened National agency as technical center for Municipal SWM and improved SWM system of Municipalities through long term strategic planning process.
Outcome: Cities are cleaner;  Increased understanding and confidence among stakeholders and local authorities on SWM;   SWM activities following strategic and action planning implemented in five municipalities and dissemination of knowledge in all 58 municipalities;  Increased capacity of municipalities and municipal key staff on SWM service delivery and able to face different problems / issues associated with SWM;  Well accepted SWM Long Term Strategic Plans and Short Term Action Plans of five municipalities;    Improved understanding and awareness of Climate Change issues and CDM.
District: - Baglung (Baglung) - Dang Deukhuri (Ghorahi) - Dhankuta (Dhankuta) - Dhanusa (Janakpur) - Kanchanpur (Mahendara Nagar) - Kathmandu (Kathmandu)

Project Title: Improved Municipal Solid Waste Management through Institutional Capacity Building of SWMRMC of Nepal - II
Input: Organizational development of Solid Waste Management and Resource Mobilization Center (SWMRMC);  Capacity building at SWMRMC level and at municipal level;  Establishment of a municipal level SWM forum at regional and national level;  Establishment of monitoring mechanism of municipal SWM;  Research / study and information dissemination system;  Preparation of municipal strategy and action plans on SWM;   Conducting few pilot scale activities in municipalities as identified by prepared action plans of municipalities.
Outputs: Enhancing the capacity of SWMRMC through organizational strengthening to develop it as a lead technical institute to support all municipalities and emerging towns of Nepal in the field of Solid Waste Management (SWM);  SWMRMC functional as a technical resource centre in the field of SWM to provide technical support to cater the needs of municipalities for providing effective and efficient SWM services for local residents;  Guide and encourage municipalities to adopt appropriate technologies suitable to local conditions through SWMRMC;  Preparation of Municipal Level SWM Long Term Strategic Plans and Short Term Action Plans of 10 selected municipalities;  Establish regular capacity building mechanism / trainings to municipalities to be capable of providing basic SWM services as per local need;  Establish a platform / forum to share and learn local initiatives conducted as well as issues and problems at local levels;  Development of coordination and cooperation mechanisms with all the stakeholders/NGOs at municipal and national levels to develop transparency, confidence in private and public participation among the stakeholders;   Establish a municipal solid waste management monitoring mechanism through establishment of database of municipalities in regards of SWM.
Impact: Strengthened National agency as technical center for Municipal SWM and improved SWM system of Municipalities through long term strategic planning process.
Outcome: Establishment of SWMRMC as a leading GON institute in the sector of urban solid waste management;  SWMRMC functioning at national level with clear vision, goals, and strategy with strategic operational approach;  A strong Municipal level SWM Forum established for advocacy, network and lobbying the urban SWM issues and policies;  Increased understanding and confidence among GoN, Ministry of Local Development, SWMRMC and local authorities on SWM;   SWM Long Term Strategic Plans and Short Term Action Plans of ten municipalities prepared in consensus with all the stakeholders;  SWM with strategic action planning implementation piloted in ten municipalities and dissemination of its knowledge and lessons in all 58 municipalities and emerging towns;  Increased capacity of municipalities and municipal key staff on SWM service delivery and able to resolve different problems / issues associated with SWM;  Municipal SWM services are monitored through information base;   Municipalities started adopting appropriate technologies.
District: - Dang Deukhuri (Ghorahi) - Dholkha (Charikot) - Ilam (Ilam) - Jhapa (Chandragadhi) - Kailali (Dhangadhi) - Kaski (Pokhara) - Kavrepalanchok (Dhulikhel) - Palpa (Tansen) - Surkhet (Surkhet)

Project Title: District Level Master Triggerers’ ToT on Total Sanitation in Bajura District
Input: · Discussion and participatory exercise for participatory planning, alliance building, sanitation marketing and community sensitization.   · Application of field-based triggering and community sensitization tools in order to enable the participants to instigate communities for prompt actions for ending open defecation.   · Monitoring and follow up of the field-based triggering activities and generating community demands for improved sanitation in the nearby areas.    · Facilitation of district level sensitization workshops for enhancing inter and intra sectoral collaboration in planning, implementation and monitoring.    · Backstopping of the District, Municipality, VDC and school level activities on capacity development and ODF initiative.
Outputs: · District level pool of trainers equipped with proper knowledge, attitudes, skills, confidence, capacity and competence to trigger communities for adopting improved hygiene and sanitation behaviours through total sanitation campaign.     · Training participants well capacitated for identification of strategies and approaches to promote demand and supply chains for sanitation promotion at local level in coordination with other GSF partners and wider sector actors at the district level.     · Locally appropriate target audience-based triggering tools for achieving ODF status and behavioural change identified and compiled.    · Triggering plan of action formulated to speed up ODF campaign in the district in collaboration with relevant sub-grantee/s.    · ODF initiatives recorded in the selected communities where triggering tools were applied by the participants as the part of the triggering training.
Impact: Develop a cadre of triggers in GSF Programme districts to sensitize District, Municipality, VDC, school and community level stakeholders for ending open defecation and adopting improved hygiene behaviours through collaborative efforts
Outcome: · Understand commonly practiced concepts and approaches of hygiene and sanitation promotion.   · Identify and apply locally appropriate audience-based triggering/sensitization tools and techniques for behavioural change.   · Promote demand and supply chain for improved hygiene and sanitation through sensitization and mobilization of communities and local level private entrepreneurs.   · Stimulate ODF initiatives in some selected communities as a part of the training package.

Project Title: Capacity Development of Stakeholders on Sector Coordination and Planning in Bajura
Input: Sensitisation workshop of political parties and other stakeholders    Sensitisation workshop of VDC secretaries and women member representing VDCs    Strengthening of D-WASH-CC    Strengthening of V-WASH-CC    Formulation of district level strategic plan and VDC level plan of action
Outputs: Commitments garnered from political party members in planning, programming, budget mobilization and social mobilization.    Commitments garnered from VDC secretaries and women representatives from 15 program VDCs in planning and resource mobilization.    D-WASH-CC formed/reformed and strengthened.    District level strategic plan/plan of action formulated/updated and disseminated.    V-WASH-CC formed/reformed in 15 programme VDCs.    VDC level plan of action formulated/updated and disseminated in 15 program VDCs    Disciplinary rules and regulations put in place to back up ODF/total sanitation campaign and monitoring performed accordingly in 15 program VDCs    A strong base is prepared for the integration of GSF Programme activities with District and VDC level planning frameworks.
Impact: Sensitize the participants about the implications of hygiene and sanitation in public health and development and to create an enabling environment for total sanitation movement by means of effective sector coordination, joint planning and financing and institutional strengthening
Outcome: sensitize the participants about the importance of sanitation in national and local contexts.    familiarize the participants about the ongoing trends of sanitation along with the roles and responsibilities of stakeholders for ODF campaign.    capacitate the stakeholders to formulate strategic plan/plan of action on sanitation with specific consideration of target, resources, responsibilities and monitoring and follow up frameworks.    seek the commitments of political leaders, government line agencies, government local bodies and D-WASH-CC for the allocation of budget for sanitation.    develop the District strategic plan/plan of action on sanitation and seek their consensus and support to form V-WASH-CC as well as to formulate VDC level joint plan/plan of action in line with Sanitation and Hygiene Master Plan.

Project Title: Institutional Strengthening of Water Users Committees and Accelerating Water and Sanitation Coverage of Five Eastern Small Towns Trijuga, Itahari, Surunga, Buddhabare and Fikkal
Input: Capacity building activities in various disciplines to WUSCs for sustainable delivery of safe drinking water supply and sanitation services;  Support for pro-poor service delivery by establishing modest financial mechanism;  Establishment of water quality monitoring system and improvement in water quality;  Development of Billing Software;  Initiate awareness program for private tap connection and toilet construction.
Outputs: Increased technical and management capability of WUSCs for better service delivery;  Increased sanitation and water supply coverage for the poor through establishing a mechanisms of Revolving Fund;  Improved environmental sanitation conditions through implementation of Community Led Total Sanitation (CLTS) programmes and awareness programmes;  Acceleration of private tap connection Establishment of water quality monitoring system.
Impact: Sustainable pro poor service delivery by WUSCs
Outcome: Capacity of WUSCs in technical and management aspects has been enhanced and water and sanitation services are delivered to communities more efficiently and adequately;  Health and Hygiene conditions of the communities have improved through the utilization of revolving fund schemes to establish tap connection and sanitation facilities at the poor households also;  Poor and disadvantage communities will have access to improved drinking water and sanitation services with enhanced knowledge and capacity through CLTS and SLTS;  Water and sanitation services have reached as target set by the STWSSSP;  Water Quality Monitoring System operated and managed by community;  Sustainable functioning of water supply facilities installed by the project with improved water quality;  Management Information System (MIS) of all 29 towns developed and updated regularly to maintain database system for progress monitoring of the STWSSSP.

Project Title: Isolated Water Supply System for Urban Poor Communities in Kathmandu Valley
Input: Tokha Integrated Water and Sanitation intervention to ensure right of low income consumers to safe drinking water and a comprehensive sanitation master plan for planned sanitary intervention;  Water Bottling System for affordable drinking water access tp urban poor communities of Koteshwor and Chyasal;  Rehabilitation and Conservation of Traditional Water Sources and Harvesting Rain water;  Advocacy and Network on Low Income Consumer Support for affordable water supply.
Outputs: The Socio-economic Status of Tokha prepared;    Detailed Design of Tokha Water Supply Scheme;  Establishment of Tokha Water Supply Scheme;  Pro Poor Water Supply Service Approach through Community Taps;  Sanitation Master Plan of Tokha;  Capacity Building of Local Authorities and Communities in Tokha;  Establishment of the Water Bottling System in Koteshwor.
Outcome: Access to adequate and safe water supply to residents of Tokha;  Access to affordable and safe water to poor communities to Koteshower;    Reduce in water collection time;  Improve in sanitation through adequate water supply;  Establish and sustainable operation of community based water supply system.

Project Title: Provision of Total Coverage of Safe Drinking Water and Sustainable Sanitation Facilities in Urban Poor Communities in Hetauda Municipality
Input: Institutional and local level training;  Campaign for sanitation coverage;  Pro poor financing mechanism;  Community managed water supply system.
Outputs: Capacity building of municipality and local community based organizations in water and sanitation planning and service delivery;  Sanitation improvement;  Municipal Revolving Fund for total sanitation;  Local Water Source Improvement and Management;  Capacitate Hetauda Municipality for municipal owned water supply management.
Impact: Institutionalize pro poor water and sanitation governance at municipal authority through integrated approach
Outcome: Achieved total toilet coverage through municipal revolving sanitation fund in 21 identified poor clusters;  Promotion of the toilet attached bio gas to scale up the use of environment friendly technologies;  Promotion of community based sanitation in identified ultra poor settlements through Community Led Total Sanitation (CLTS) and School Led Total Sanitation (SLTS);  Entrepreneurship skill development for income generation and be able to afford for better water and sanitation facilities;  Capacity building of municipality and local community based organizations on water and sanitation programme for improving water supply and sanitation with active support from communities;  Improve existing locally functioned water supply systems and health and hygiene condition of the communities through conservation of traditional water sources and establishing small scale water supply systems. This skill is enhanced by trained local communities on water quality monitoring and water supply management;  Feasibility study to strengthening municipality to take over the water supply management system (water supply managed by local government).

Project Title: Cities and Climate Change Initiatives
Input: Climate Change Vulnerability assessment of Kathmandu;  Development of adaptation plan of Kathmandu.
Outputs: Climate Change Vulnerablity assessment findings of Kathmandu Valley;    Climate Change Adaptation plan.
Impact: Local authorities initiative actions for adaptation of climate change
Outcome: Local authorities, local stakeholders and public awared and sensitized on the climate change impact and adaptation plan on water and sanitation and health sector;  Identification of tangible adaptation plans and actions for implementation by local authorities and support by stakholders and public for mitigation of climate change impact of water and sanitation;  Provide inputs to other ongoing climate change adaptation activities (e.g. NAPA, PPRC) in Kathmandu Nepa.

Project Title: GEF Small Grants Programme - SGP
Input: Environment Conservation and Climate Changes
Outputs: 50 Arsenic mitigation filters in use in Rautahat and Nawalparasi.
Impact: Land degradation
Outcome: To secure global environmental benefits in areas of biodiversity conservation, climate change mitigation, and protection of international waters through community based approaches that also generate local benefits.     To promote conservation and sustainable development strategies and to support projects to protect the global environment with the understanding of and practice by the communities and other key stakeholders.

Project Title: PCR 1, IR 3: Access & utilization of micronutrients (Vitamin A, iron tablets, MNP Powder, Iodized salt) with focus on children, adolescent girls & mothers in disadvantaged groups and urban areas increased.
Input: · Technical assistance and funding support for quality vitamin 'A' supplementation for 6-59 months girls and boys provided and coordinated with partners biannually in all 75 districts.   · Technical assistance and funding support for micronutrients supplementation to adolescents, pregnant and lactating women provided and coordinated with partners in Kapilvastu, Nawalparasi, Udaypur, Dang, Tanahu, Dadeldhura and Kavre districts. · Technical assistance and funding support for MNP distribution along with IYCF promotion to 6-23 months children provided and coordinated with partners in Rupandehi, Parsa, Makanpur, Rasuwa, Gorkha and Palpa districts. . Technical assistance and funding support for monitoring and social marketing of adequately iodized salt use at household level provided and coordinated with partners in Dhanusha, Sarlahi, Mahottari, Siraha, Bara, Rautahat, Sunsari, Jhapa and Saptari districts.
Outputs: The health and nutrition status of mothers, children and adolescents improved with focus on socially excluded and economically marginalized groups and equitable and participatory approach and implementation of high-impact cost effective proven interventions.
Impact: The Health and Population Ministry's vision or goal of the health sector is to improve the health and nutritional status of the Nepali population and provide equal opportunity for all to receive quality health care services free of charge or affordable thereby contributing to poverty alleviation (NHSP II); Enhance utilisation of quality health services by ensuring access and service utilisation of all citizens from various groups, areas and community. Reduce malnutrition problem by including it as multi sectoral issue to implement approaches effectively ( Approach Paper for 3 years interim plan, GoN, 2010)
Outcome: Socially excluded and economically marginalized groups including adolescents improved with focus on socially and economically marginalized group and equitable and participatory approach and implementation of high impact cost effective proven interventions.
