Project Title: PCR 3, IR 1: Pregnant women and adolescents from MARP groups in intervention areas , who need ARV treatment are empowered to opt for appropriate services for themselves and their children.
Input: Strengthen and scale up on site and community based PMTCT and Paediatric HIV and AIDS services.  Conduct relevant studies in the area of PMTCT service utilization by MARP, MARAs and EVAs; and stigma & discrimination to HIV positive pregnant women. Provide technical support for developing next NSP; integrating PMTCT and Paediatric HIV and AIDS services in the government MNH and IMCI services; reviewing ad revising HIV and AIDS policy, VCT guidelines; developing and finalizing EID guidelines as well as other relevant policies and documents Provide technical assistance for developing and implementing a social mobilization and community sensitization package on stigma and discrimination as well as support for MARAs and EVAs to access HIV services Monitor the programme implementation from both quantitative and qualitative aspect. (In 2008 - 2010 CPAP, the funds were managed based on the projects whereas the funds for 2011-2012 has been allocated based on the IRs. Therefore, the budget in this AID management platform is reflected only for 2011-2012).
Outputs: Children, Adolescents and pregnant women, specifically the most at risk and disadvantaged have access and increasingly utilize relevant services to prevent HIV and mitigate impact of HIV & AIDS
Impact: The MOHP goal of health sector is to improve the health and nutritional status of the Nepali population and provide equal opportunity for all to receive quality health care services free of charge or affordable thereby contributing to poverty alleviation. (NHSP-IP II 2010 - 2015)  The aim of three year interim plan in health is to ensure citizens' fundamental right to have improved health services through access to quality health services without any discrimination by region, class, gender, ethnicity, religion, political belief and social and economic status keeping in view the broader context of social inclusion.

Project Title: NPLJ80: HIV Prevention, Care and Treatment for Female Injecting Drug Users, Female Prisoners and Women living with HIV and AIDS in Nepal
Input: · Conduct rapid situation assessments needs analysis of female injecting drug users& female prisoners in specific locations, using existing secondary data, supplemented by second generation surveillance surveys. · Conduct operational research on drug use &sexual networks, & HIV risk behaviours. · Carry-out studies on lessons learned & best practices. · Conduct Epidemiological assessment in Prison Settings · Develop gender and culture sensitive advocacy and communication materials. · Promote gender & culture sensitive & rights-based programme approaches among govt. and civil society service providers. · Advocate with policy makersfor recognition of the need to establish female-specific interventions for injecting drug users and in prison settings. · Form self-help groups among female injecting drug users, prisoners and other HIV positive women. · Establish new drop-in-centre/s for PHC, sexual & reproductive health etc & continuation of the existing sites · Modify and continuation of the existing centres for the provision of HIV services · Conduct training and skills-needs assessment among existing and potential service providers · Develop gender sensitive training materials and manuals, locally adapted to specific social and cultural contexts. · Develop skills, including for peer educators, in specific technical areas (e.g., needle and syringe prog., condom promotion, HIV counselling, referral to other services). · Conduct training of peer educators on HIV and STI prevention, early detection and treatment measures. · Develop & distribute gender and Project Title: Empowering Women in the Churia to Improve Their Livelihoods
Input: The project focuses on empowerment of poor vulnerable and socially excluded women in 3 districts of Churia as well as building capacity of partner NGOs to promote sustainable socio-economic change for these women.     The project will be implemented through a national network called Himalayan Grassroots Women's Association for Natural Resource Management in Nepal (HIMWANTI) and three district level NGOs    Forum for Social Development (INDRENI), Nepal Rural Self-Reliance Campaign (NRUSEC) and Nari Ship Shrijana Kendra (NSSK).     The project will reach 7,500 poor vulnerable socially excluded women and their families and community based organizations, natural resource management groups, mothers groups, government line agencies and womenâ€™s networks at local and national.     The Project's major activities are:    - Awareness raising and empowerment of PVSE women to access natural management resources    - Identification and usage of income generating opportunities    - On-farm and off-farm training, vocational training    - Awareness raising on gender based violence and reproductive health    - Training on disaster risk reduction, development of emergency plans and small scale mitigation measures    - Capacity building of local partner NGOs and local resource.
Outputs: strengthen the organizational and technical capacity of the 3 NGOs and one network for women empowerment and livelihood improvement.
Outcome: improved livelihood of the poor, vulnerable and socially excluded women in Churia.

Project Title: Tatopani Frontier Inspection Station Project
Enhancing Capacities for Climate Change Adaptation and Disaster Risk Management for Sustainable Livelihoods in the Agriculture Sector
Input: National Expert on CCA and DRM          Field Monitors          Contracts           Training support and preparation of district DRM plans in agriculture          Demonstration of CCA and DRM practices          Hazard and Vulnerability Mapping          Evaluation of e-learning tool on CCA          Enhancing EWS Information products           Economic Impact of CCA/DRM practices          Follow-up project proposal development          Locally Contracted Labour           Casual Labour - Temporary Assistance          Capacity building, training and workshops          Regional training participation for 2 DOA staff          International field trips (Bangladesh)          Participation in national level training          Field trip within Nepal to other project districts          Training/workshop expenditure including local travel          Project workshop          Final synthesis workshop          Resource mobilization workshops          Expendable Equipment          Seed supply and storage systems          Inputs for field demonstrations          Non Expendable Equipment          Computers for the district (2)          Project vehicle          Disaster impact data base management system          Upgrading meteorological observatories          Technical Support Services          Report Costs          Travel TSS          Honorarium TSS          General Operating Expenses           General Operating Expenses Budget
Outputs: Output 1: Enhancing technical capacity within DoA for Climate Change Adaptation and Disaster Risk Management (DRM) in Agriculture    Output 2: Strengthening basic support services for Climate Change Adaptation (CCA) and Disaster Risk Management (DRM) in Agriculture sector in two selected pilot districts   Output 3: Demonstration of prioritized location specific technologies for Climate Change Adaptation (CCA) and Disaster Risk Management (DRM) within the agriculture sector through a participatory learning by doing process at district and community levels      Output 4: Economic impact analysis of adaptation interventions, lessons learned and policy implications
Outcome: The overall expected outcome of the programme is enhancing capacities for Climate Change Adaptation (CCA) and Disaster Risk Management (DRM) for Sustainable Livelihoods in the Agriculture Sector. The specific objectives are:      (1) to assist the Ministry of Agriculture and Cooperatives (MoAC) in testing and operationalizing the process of shifting from an reactive emergency response focused intervention approach towards a pro-active natural hazard risk prevention/ preparedness oriented approach in the agricultural sector; and   (2) to demonstrate viable climate change adaptation practices in two selected pilot districts to address impacts of climate variability and climate change and to increase awareness and resilience needed to address the future risk by the communities.

South Asia Water Initiative (SAWI)
Impact: The South Asia Water Initiative (SAWI) aims to promote regional cooperation in the sustainable management of the water resources of the Himalayan rivers to address the challenges of development and climate change. The program will be structured around five key focus areas: (1) Ganges Basin, (2) Brahmaputra Basin, (3) Indus Basin, (4) Sundarbans Landscape, and (5) Regional Cooperation. To promote more effective and cooperative water resources management, SAWI will facilitate multi-stakeholder dialogue and policy deliberation; enhance knowledge and capacity on issues of regional, and in particular trans-boundary water resources management and climate adaptation; and promote cooperative actions such as policy reforms, institutional development, and investment in water resources management. The total value of this multi-country initiative is $9.0 million over 5 years, starting 2008-09.

Impact: The Plan of Operation of the project was signed between UNESCO and the Ministry of Federal Affairs, Constituent Assembly, Parliamentary Affairs and Culture on 16 July 2010.   Launching of the project and organization of the International Scientific Steering Committee (ISSC) meeting  The project was officially launched in Lumbini on 3 August 2010 in the presence of the Minister of Federal Affairs, Constituent Assembly, Parliamentary Affairs and Culture, the Vice-Chairperson of the Lumbini Development Trust, the Ambassador of Japan and the International team leader.  The launch was followed by four expert group meetings on 3 and 4 August 2010 with the participation of members of the international expert group and representatives of the national counterparts, to determine activities, related needs and challenges for the four project components.  A consultation meeting with stakeholders was held on 5 August 2010. It included representation of local communities, VDCs, Lumbini institutions and private sector and was organized to brief them on the project and to provide a platform to discuss concerns related to the development of Lumbini.  Further to the consultation meeting with stakeholders, the first meeting of the International Scientific Steering Committee (ISSC), under the chair of Team Leader, Yukio Nishimura was held on 5 August 2010. It reviewed the terms of reference of its work, project coordination arrangements, main project activities and outputs, and the implementation plan and project coordination arrangements for August 2010 to July 2011.   Establishment of a web presence  A collaborative workspace for all project partners was established in August 2010. It aims to facilitate project implementation including management of project activities and coordination of works of all international experts.  Also in August 2010, a public website on project activities was established with links to websites of relevant international and national organizations.
Outcome: Organization of activities in the first year  Contractual and organizational arrangements are underway for the start of the work of the three international expert teams responsible for the activities as described in the project document who will undertake first missions in December2010/January 2011.   Related to Activity 1, a restoration team was established, composed of international restoration experts and local trainees including three scientists (chemist, biologist and physicist/geologist) and six archaeologists (Department of Archaeology (DoA) & LDT) to be trained in restoration activities in January/February 2011.  Restoration activities will be performed as practical workshops including restoration of the Nativity Sculpture, the Ashoka Pillar, the Marker Stone and initiating micro-climate monitoring.   Related to Activity 2, an Implementation Partnership Agreement is being established with Durham University, UK, to undertake a 35 day mission to Kathmandu and Lumbini from December 2010 to February 2011 to:    Confirm the presence of Pre-Asokan levels in the Temple, assess their nature and preservation, and map them on GIS to prevent future damage,    Confirm the presence of early natural and cultural levels in the Sacred Area and map them on GIS to prevent future damage,    Confirm the presence of early cultural and natural levels in the Southwest Village Mound, assess their nature and preservation, and map them on GIS to prevent future damage and consider the impact of the Police Station's location.  Related to the above two activities, the office space for the two teams was identified, which needed minor repair work. The repair work is underway and is nearing completion for the teams to start work in December.   Related to Activity 3, a consultant contract is being established with Yukio Nishimura, University of Tokyo, Japan, to undertake a 12 day mission to Kathmandu and Lumbini to collect data from Japan and Nepal and review the present state of the Sacred Garden in respect to the concept formulated by Kenzo Tange Master Plan.  Activity 3 will be supported by a study on the Sacred Garden reviewing eight components (Kenzo Tange's master plan, world heritage inscription, environment, impact on archaeological zone, historical and religious texts, activities and expectations) is presently being carried out by a team of experts with a contribution of the NGO Orient Cultural Heritage Sites Protection Alliance that was included as an additional appropriation to the Regular Programme and budget allocated to the UNESCO Kathmandu Office.   Project Results achieved during the reporting period    Three experts' missions planned from December 2010 to February 2011 to undertake the activities included in the project document.    Local support team identified from DoA and LDT to be trained in restoration activities and archaeological activities.    The Sacred Garden study in terms of various overlaying components initiated with the additional contribution from Orient Cultural Heritage Sites Protection Alliance.   Lessons learned and Sustainability  Regular communication and technical support to the national project partners is very crucial for smooth implementation of the project.

Project Title: Himalaya Glacier Monitoring Project
Input: Research and capacity building
Outputs: Output 1.1 Long-term monitoring of glacier mass balance and surface motion, and measurements of glacier geometry and snow course established and fully operational on two appropriate glaciers selected under the Project; Output 1.2 An operational system established for comparison of data with other representative glaciers in the HKH region. Output 2.1 Strengthened and expanded long-term monitoring of hydrological and meteorological variables established and made fully operational for the sub-basins catchment of selected glaciers in Nepal; Output 2.2 Short-term intensive hydro-meteorological campaigns conducted to obtain specialized information and parameterization for glacio-hydrological modelling Output 2.3 Glacio-hydrological and snow melt model set-up for the catchment of selected glaciers in Nepal and expanded to the sub-basin level. Output 2.4 Scenarios of climate change are downscaled for the catchment and sub-basin scales, applied to the glacio-hydrological model and future water availability scenarios are obtained. Output 3.1 The multi-level Remote Sensing system for representative basins / sub-basins for regular mapping and monitoring of glaciers and snow in the HKH region strengthened and fully operational at ICIMOD Output 3.2 Detailed investigations in prioritized representative basins / sub-basins with glaciers regarding area change, glacier mass balance and variation of snow line carried out  Output 4.1 Operational system at ICIMOD's for the Cryosphere Knowledge Hub in accordance with the regionally and internationally agreed standards; Output 4.2 A web-based interactive mapping and visualization system established and internationally recognized; Output 4.3 Regular bulletin board services established and in use by relevant regional and international subscribers; Output 4.4 Regional/international knowledge sharing platform and procedures organized through workshops and conferences. Output 5.1 Participants in training courses are applying their new and improved knowledge in their daily work to improve the ability of their institutions to carry out sustainable glaciological and glacio-hydrological programs;  Output 5.2 Participants in study tours are utilising their improved competence and knowledge in their daily work;  Output 5.3 MSc course in Research of Glaciology and Himalayan Environment developed and incorporated in the study plan and curricula of KU; Output 5.4 The graduates from the MSc. course have found relevant employment in operational services in the HKH region or continued to pursue PhDs; Output 5.5 Participants in personnel exchange schemes and on-the-job training are utilising their improved competence and knowledge in their daily work; Output 5.6 The Nepali partner institutions WECS and DHM are fully operational in relation to the stated outcomes of the Project; Output 5.7 ICIMOD has improved its competence and capacities for sustained planning, management and monitoring of the CMP operations and as a Regional Cryosphere Knowledge Hub in line with the stated outcomes of the Project.
Impact: On basis of the rationale and outlined scope of the CMP and in respect of the anticipated impact of the Project the following goal has been developed: Contribute significantly to improved knowledge and understanding on cryosphere by analysing changes in glaciers, snow and glacio-hydrology in relation to impacts of climate change for water resources management in the HKH region.
Outcome: 1) Relevant and reliable cryospheric data (glacier and snow) timely produced and used forwater resources assessments by operational services and research institutions. 2) Relevant and reliable glacio-hydrological data and current and future water availability scenario timely produced and used for water resources assessments by operational services and research institutions 3) The multi-level remote sensing system at ICIMOD fully operationalized for sustained mapping and monitoring of snow and glaciers for basins and sub-basins in the HKH region. 4) Strengthened and acknowledged ICIMOD as a Regional Cryosphere Knowledge Hub for storage, analysis, sharing and disseminating knowledge for relevant operational services andresearch in the HKH region and internationally. 5) Enhanced institutional capacity and competence of national partners in Nepal and the HKHregion for sustained glaciological monitoring, glacio-hydrological modelling and scenariodevelopment and remote sensing of the cryosphere.

Project Title: Support to discharge of disqualified maois combattans
Input: According to the Comprehensive Peace Agreement (CPA) the disqualified Maoist combatants shall be discharged and rehabilitated into society. These 4008 individuals were disqualified through the UNMIN led verification process because they were either under the age of 18 at the date of the peace accord or they were recruited to the Maoist army after this date.      The primary objective of this project is to have as many of the VMLRs as possible involved in gainful employment or livelihood opportunities. To achieve this, the project is framed around two complimentary outcomes:      1) VMLRs were supported in their socio-economic rehabilitation; and   2) Communities were engaged in supporting the rehabilitation of VMLR participants.
Outputs: The aim of the UN peace Fund for Nepal is to support Nepal's peace process by delivering coordinated, focused and time limited UN assistance for critical peace building and recovery activities requested by the Government of Nepal.
Impact: The specific objective of the funding is to discharge and rehabilitate the 4006 disqualified maoist combatants according to a process agreed to by the GoN, UCPN (maoist) and the UN. The funding will be earmarked for this purpose.

Project Title: IPWA Ensuring Equal Representation in Policy and Decision Making
Input: The primary target groups of this project are the IPWA central committee members, district and local network members from all the 75 districts of the country. The secondary target groups would be all the political party leaders, organization related to women and their sister organizations, media persons, policy makers and implementers, national security agencies, national commissions, national committees, human rights defenders and, civil society organizations, working for the cause of women and their rights.
Impact: The goal of the project Ensuring women's equal representation at all the policy and decision making level is to "Ensure Women's equal and meaningful participation of women in the development of policies and decision making level".   Objective for ODC: The broad objective of the project management of ODC is to see the smooth implementation of the project activities as defined in the project document along with effective and efficient fund management support.
Outcome: Objectives for the project:     Contribute to a gender sensitive constitution and a just state structure regarding the fulfillment of women's rights    Contribute to proportional representation of women at all the political parties and state mechanisms at all levels, interim goal would be a minimum of 33%     Ensure effective implementation of laws that are affecting the position of women in the spirit of the constitution and international laws, signed and ratified by Nepal       Expected results:   - Rights of women and their proportional representation ensured in the Constitution   - Established gender responsive rule of law   - Women representation in the bylaws of all the parties established and ensured   - Laws developed to ensure women's rights in the spirit of the constitution and international laws   - Discriminatory laws against women revised and abolished   - The rights provisioned in the law regarding women's rights effectively implemented.

Project Title: Support to Transitional Justice efforts in Nepal
Input: ICTJ: The objective of the project is to work toward that transitional justice mechanisms in Nepal are designed and implemented in a way that is consistent with international best practice, thereby making a significant contribution to peace, justice and reconciliation. Through the project, ICTJ implements a number og activities that support the Nepal Government to pass truth-seeking bills that are in accordance with international standards and best practice; contribute to increased understanding amongst key stakeholders of the roles and relationship between the truth and reconciliation commission (TRC), disappearance commission (DC) and the courts; enable victims of conflict-related crimes and gross human rights violations to receive reparations in accordance with international standards; and, enable victims to effectively participate in all transitional justice mechanisms. RNE has previously funded and worked with ICTJ since 2007 and are of the opinion that ICTJ fulfil their obligations according to the targets of the proposals goal and targets.
Impact: ICJ: The goal of ICJ is to (1) protect and enhance the role of the judiciary in securing rights and combating impunity through targeted litigation and direct support; (2) improve currently distorted public discourse on justice issues (including rights accountability, gender justice and abuse of power) through an integrated media strategy; and (3) maximize the impact of proposed transitional justice mechanisms and long-term justice sector institutions through advocacy and technical assistance in three substantive areas (accountability for human rights violations; independent and transparent processes; victim and witness protection). Through the project, ICJ implements a number of activities that contribute to protecting the strengthened but fragile position of the courts; strengthening public debate and advocacy on the right to remedy and reparations; and, ensuring effective measures that will strengthen justice sector institutions.

Project Title: Promoting Participatory Democracy - MIREST
Input: Inclusive and participatory grassroots-level interactive sessions; Roundtable Seminars on Critical Constitutional Issues; Publication and Dissemination of Information Packages including Annual Book on Accountability; Conduct Rapid Governance Assessment: Organize public dialogue sessions on Red Book (National Plan), District/VDC Development Plans and related policy provisions; and Organize Policy Discussion Café: Organizing and establishment of 'Change Forum/s'
Outputs: Inclusion of the concerns and rights of especially women and marginalised/disadvantaged groups in the constitution making; Women and marginalised/disadvantaged communities in particular are empowered for good governance at local level; Emerging young leaders are empowered to correct downward accountability of local bodies; Basic service delivery at local level are improved.
Impact: Strengthened, stable and sustainable system of democratic processes for effective governance.
Outcome: Enhanced knowledge; awareness and capacity of the Nepalese society and increased participation on constitutional process that enables them to ensure their voices and rights; Strengthened participatory democracy by increasing demand for information and increased attention on local governance and public programmes/policies through constructive dialogue, reflection and knowledge sharing; and Increased participation of young emerging leaders from women and marginalised sections of the society to internalize accountability mechanisms in broader democratic and governance processes.

Project Title: Fish Farming Development in Nepal
Input: Fish Production technology and river management.    Fish biology
Outputs: 1. Fish ponds are constructed and operative.   2. Current NARC fish pellet production is operative.   3. Farmer and women groups are trained in crap production routines.   4. Fish fry production and distribution are operative.   5. Restocking with fish is tested and monitored in several regulated rivers.   6. Restocking with insects and non-insects is tested in regulated rivers.   7. Out of season carp maturation is developed and controlled .   8. New handling and rearing procedures for maturing fish are in place.   9. New handling and transport procedures for carp fries are in place.   10. Improved dissemination or results.   11. Extruder produced plant fish pellet feed is formulated.
Impact: To improve food security and livelihood.
Outcome: 1. Livelihood of more than 1000 deprived, marginalized fishermen, women groups and rural households are sustainably improved.   2. The capicity of farmers, techinicans and researchers in the fisheries sector is enhanced.   3. Extruder technology and formulation of pellet feed based on plant material is available.   4. Brood stocks of indigenous fish are maintained.   5. Restocking of regulated rivers has been implemeented and monitored. Results will constitute a first step in ecological improvement of rivers affected by hydropower development.   6. Local knowledge and capacity on fish biology and fish production technology is anhanced and used.

Project Title: Strengthening Water, Air, Sanitation and Hygiene Treasuring Health (SWASHTHA) - I
Input: The project includes urban and peri-urban clusters of 3 western districts-the cluster covers 5 municipalities and 3 small towns. The major activities include-   Develop participatory WATSAN Master Plans for 5 municipalities\ 3 VDCs;  Promotion of 4 appropriate point of use- Simple Household Water Treatment Technologies from Practical Action's "Healthy Homes" approach;  Empowering and Capacity Building of 200 female community health volunteers (FCHV) and 25 mother leaders from mother groups for better sanitation and hygiene behavior. Each FCHV will further deliver the message to 50 women while the mother leaders reach out to 10,000 target women;   Behavioral change campaigns (hand-washing campaigns, street theatres, community radio programs and inter community group competitions) in 16 communities, 20 health centers and 4 municipalities.
Outputs: Preparation of participatory water and sanitation master plans;  16 pilot demonstration projects (8 water system and 8 sanitation facilities) - water and sanitation facilities that will support in improving the environmental health and sanitation situation and sanitation practices of the target communities;   Increased coverage and access of water and sanitation facilities resulting through increased awareness and capacities of both state and non-state actors to deliver services as per plans.
Impact: Institutionalization of pro poor water and sanitation governance by municipal authorities
Outcome: Improved access to safe drinking water, better sanitation facilities and hygiene practices among 50,000 people including women and children;   Improved partnerships between state and non-state actors; and institutionalization of environmental health improvement measures through improved linkages between state, non-state and private sector actors;  Reduction in the incidences of water-borne diseases and health costs among target households by 25%.

Project Title: Strengthening Water, Sanitation and Hygiene Treasuring Health (SWASHTHA)- II- in Tikapur and Guleriaya, Nepal.
Input: The project area includes 11 communities in the urban and peri-urban clusters of 2 municipalities-Tikapur and Gularia;  Preparation of Municipal WATSAN Master plans;  Community level water safety plans;   Preventive Measures for water source Contamination with emphasis on mitigation options at massive level in Gulariya municipality for its high arsenic presence in ground water;  Promotion of 4 appropriate point of use- Simple Household Water Treatment Technologies from Practical Action's "Healthy Homes" approach;  Empowering and Capacity Building of 100 female community health volunteers (FCHV) and 10 mother leaders from mother groups for better sanitation and hygiene behavior. Each FCHV will further deliver the message to 50 women while the mother leaders reach out to 1000 target women in the cluster;  Behavioral change campaigns (hand-washing campaigns, street theatres, community radio programs and inter community group competitions) in 11 communities, 10 health centers or clinics and two municipal authorities.
Outputs: Preparation of participatory water and sanitation master plans of the cluster area;   Implementation of 6 community based pilot demonstration projects (4 water schemes and 2 sanitation schemes) - water and sanitation facilities that will support in improving the environmental health and sanitation situation and sanitation practices of the target communities;   The pilot projects will also demonstrate good practices and technologies for wide-scale replication in other neighbouring small towns and municipalities;  Reduction in the incidences of water-borne diseases and health costs among target households by 25%;  Increased coverage of water and sanitation facilities resulting through increased awareness and capacities of both state and non-state actors to deliver services as per plans.
Impact: Institutionalization of pro poor water and sanitation governance by municipal authorities
Outcome: The overall objective of the project is to contribute to sustainable improvement in health and well being of vulnerable population especially, women and children residing in the urban and peri-urban clusters of Tikapur and Gularia Municipalities.  The specific outcome envisioned are:   To improve access to safe drinking water;   To improve access to better sanitation facilities;   To improve hygiene practices among 5,000 people including women and children;   To improved partnerships between state and non-state actors;  To institutionalize environmental health improvement measures through improved linkages between state, non-state and private sector actors.

Project Title: Output 2 (NPL7U102): Improved data availability and analysis for evidence-based decision-making and policy formulation on population dynamics, adolescent sexual and reproductive health, and gender equality (Off Budget)
Legal Aid to Improve People's Access to Criminal Justice
Input: 1.1 Provide Direct legal representation to 800 new clients over two years (including 4800 meetings, court hearings, and detention center visits). ILF-Nepal lawyers visit detention centers and courts to identify and represent women, men and children eligible for free legal aid, obtain copies of the case file and other relevant documents, conduct independent investigation of the facts where necessary, research and review litigation strategy with supervisors, prepare and conduct witness examinations, prepare and file petitions as necessary, and appear and argue at all court/quasi-judicial proceedings on behalf of the client.   1.2 Organize 16 legal aid network meetings in the Janakpur, Hetauda, Nepalgunj, and Kanchanpur, and 12 national-level legal aid network/outreach meetings in Kathmandu, to share knowledge, identify training needs, and generate productive discourse on the future and direction of legal aid reform in Nepal. Participants to be identified, contacted, and invited to participate in meetings, agendas will be prepared in advance, minutes will be prepared and distributed post-meeting, and follow-up discussions and coordination activities as determined in the meetings will be conducted.   1.3 Conduct five 7-day trainings annually with 12 participants at each training. Training preparation and follow-up activities include revision and publication of training documents, publication of practice manual for trainees, identification and invitation of diverse participants, invitation and training of ILF-N and external trainers, arrangement of accommodation and travel for participants and trainers, design participant satisfaction surveys, design and oversee participant follow-up case studies and surveys, provide legal support as necessary to trainees after trainings.   1.4 Research criminal legal aid delivery models for Nepal, and assess access to justice in SDC cluster districts. Solicit feedback on research from relevant district and national level stakeholders. Make research available at workshops/roundtable discussions of national and district level stakeholders stimulate dialogue about legal aid policy.
Outputs: Output 1.1: Poor women and men in detention in at least 13 districts have access to quality criminal defence services. Output 1.2: Coordination and exchange among the stakeholders providing legal aid services is established, especially at the district level. Output 2.1: Government and civil society lawyers have access to quality training and expertise on criminal defence law and best practices. Output 2.2: Research on criminal legal aid delivery models is available and discussed
Impact: Contribute to the development of an effective criminal legal aid system in Nepal that ensures access to justice for all women and men
Outcome: Outcome 1: Poor women and men in detention exercise their rights including their right to a fair trial   Outcome 2: The Judiciary, Government and civil society legal aid providers start to deliver better quality criminal legal aid services
District: - Banke (Nepalgunj) - Dhanusa (Janakpur) - Kanchanpur (Mahendara Nagar) - Kathmandu (Kathmandu) - Makwanpur (Hetauda)
Donor Agency: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation

Project Title: Strengthening the Accountability of Local Government
Input: This project will be a mandate project of SDC implemented by a national NGO. A national implementing partner (NGO/consulting firm) will be selected through a two stage national competitive bidding process. Local NGO(s) at the district level will be selected by the national implementing partner. The national NGO(s) will coach, guide, give directions, backstop, monitor and guarantee the quality of the activities of the local NGO(s). The local NGO(s) will work with the citizens groups through CACs, WCFs, local media, mother groups, local youth clubs etc. The possibility of backstopping through international consultants is also provisioned for in the project.   A bilateral agreement will be signed with GoN and a strategic partnership will be formed with the MFALD at the centre, which will allow for policy inputs and opportunity for institutionalisation of the learnings of the project. At the national level, a steering committee under the chair of MFALD will be formed to provide strategic guidance to the project. At the district level, the project will closely work in coordination with appropriate district monitoring and supervision committees which will increase the ownership of the process by government authorities at the operational level.   All of the 1.3 million people (census 2011) of the seven districts and especially the DAGs amongst them (average 45% of the total population) will benefit. Given its nature, the project primarily supports right holders in exercising their right to development and services. In order to hold their government accountable, no new institutional arrangement will be created at an operational level. Projects will work within the social mobilisation framework of LGCDP and use CAC, WCF as entry points for project implementation. The other SDC projects such as SBLL, LGCDP and other sectoral projects are working more directly to strengthen the supply side thereby complementing SLGAP.
Outputs: People, especially DAGs, are informed about their public service PS entitlements and about their civic roles and responsibilities.    CSOs and media strengthen their capacity to monitor VDC's compliance with CC guidelines and commitments by using complementary set of SA tools                Project generates and documents relevant data and lessons learned to support SDC's policy dialogue initiatives on LG and SA
Impact: The overall goal of the project is to contribute to 'people benefitting from a state that is responsive to the demands of DAGs and provide more effective and inclusive public services at the local level' in the project supported districts.
Outcome: 1: People, especially from DAGs, exercise their right to development by increasing their engagement with local bodies (LBs) and line agencies (LAs).    2: CSOs hold local bodies (LB) and line agencies (LA) accountable.             3. Government of Nepal (GoN) creates an enabling environment for a better (mandatory) application of SA tools ensuring transparency and accountability at the local level as a result of project field experiences
District: - Achham (Mangalsen) - Dailekh (Dullu) - Jajarkot (Khalanga) - Kalikot (Kalikot) - Khotang (Diktel) - Okhaldhunga (Okhaldhunga) - Ramechhap (Manthali) - Sindhuli (Sindhuli Madhi) - Surkhet (Surkhet)
Donor Agency: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation

Project Title: Trial Bridge Sub Sector Programme III
Input: Districts are the main implementers at the operational level. It supports the local communities in building their own bridges. As the beneficiaries themselves can best assess the need for a bridge, the communities initiate the bridge demand along with their commitment to mobilise local resources (labour and local materials), plus their willingness to assume responsibilities, prove the feasibility of the venture, and finally they construct a bridge. In this context, a comprehensive bridge demand of over 6000 bridges across the country has been compiled. Every year, according to the budget availability, these are screened and prioritised through a set of criteria such as distance gained, population served (giving higher weightage to DAGs), accidents occurred due to the absence of the bridge. The UC then takes the lead role for the completion of a bridge. For this purpose, an Agreement is established between the concerned UC and the DDC. Transparency is maintained at all stages through various tools like: public hearing/auditing, fact sheets, third party technical audit and participatory decision making process. Only local people are given the opportunity to work on the construction and the maintenance work of trail bridges. Another important aspect is the monitoring to ensure that equal wages are paid for equal work. Efforts are made to ensure that labourers are insured against death and accidents. Formation of an inclusive UC is one of the major tasks to ensure conflict sensitivity. The representation of women in the UCs is aimed at 33% with executive posts provisioned for DAGs in order to help address the needs of the DAG members.      Trail Bridge SWAp Coordination Committee (TBSCC) is established as an apex level body comprising representatives of GoN as well as that of all development partners supporting TB SWAp, to give direction/guidance to the implementation of the TB SWAp. DoLIDAR is the executing agency on behalf of GoN and Trail Bridge Support Unit (TBSU)/Helvetas is the TA provider on behalf of SDC. SDC proposes to continue with Helvetas for this final phase (without going into a tendering process), because of their legacy and leading expertise in this field. Infact, SDC would not foresee a next phase without the involvement of Helvetas.
Outputs: 1200 trail bridges are built and 4000 bridges maintained; 3 mio people have safe-river crossing facility; 3 million person days of employment created at local level; 33% women are represented in User Committees (UCs).     Capacity of local bodies and communities strengthened to implement trail bridges locally, 550 technical personnel, 25 fabricators and 30 consultants are trained, Capacity of Department of Local Infrastructure Development and Agriculture Roads (DoLIDAR) enhanced to enforce the trail bridge strategy, Public audit/hearings conducted at 90% bridge sites;
Impact: To contribute towards poverty reduction through improvement of access to social and basic services and economic resources and opportunities of the local people by building trail bridges within one hour detour
Outcome: ) Local communities engage in the construction and operation of trail bridges to improve safe access to basic services (Health, Education, Markets, Farms and Employment Opportunities) at local level.      b) Institutional frameworks at national level enforce Trail Bridge Strategy/Local Infrastructure Development Policy 2006 in the construction and maintenance of trail bridges

Project Title: Nepal Energy Efficiency Programme (NEEP)/Support to Energy Efficiency
Input: Component 1:Policy Support Major activities · Provide information on international good practice for strategy design, policy and implementation Programs · Support and facilitate selected stakeholder consultation to enable a structured stakeholder-policy dialogue · Support the formulation of a biomass energy strategy(BEST) including identification of industrial use of biomass and agricultural residues as part of or complementary to the overall energy strategy · Provide information and support for initiatives aiming at the introduction of energy efficiency issues and targets into the next 3 year development plans · Support intermediaries to create public awareness on energy conservation groups issues Component 2: Energy Efficiency in Households This component has two subcomponents. A. To reduce the specific electricity consumption of grid connected households B. To reduce the biomass consumption of rural households Major activities for subcomponent 2A · Provide information on international good practice on minimum standards and energy efficiency labeling for electric household appliances · Study financial benefits and burdens on consumer and utility side on basis of drafted minimum standards. The study will also analyse the conditions in isolated electricity grids. · If required support NBSM to devise minimum standards and labeling for household appliances · Support awareness raising for households and capacity building for institutions implementing and enforcing the mandatory minimum standards  Major activities for subcomponent 2B · Support a study to conceptualize the accelerated dissemination of improved efficient cooking stoves. The study takes socioeconomic, gender and cultural aspects of the target groups into account. · Support management, implementation and monitoring of scaling up programmes under AEPC. Component 3:Energy Efficiency in Industry Major activities: It is envisaged that relevant private sector institutions found and operate an Energy Efficiency centre. The centre shall operate and provide services on commercial principles while being supported to perform the following activities · Training of energy auditors and energy managers · Capacity development of chambers of Industry and the financial sector · Quality control of energy audits and clearing house for disputes · Evaluation and monitoring of impacts resulting from investments in energy efficiency in industry with regard to productivity and profitability. . A supplier's forum offering services and products relevant to energy efficient use of energy.
Outputs: 1. The efficient use of energy is a constituent of the national energy strategy of Nepal  2. Strategies for the trial of energy efficiency measures among the 'urban households' target group are in place. 3. Strategies for the implementation of energy efficiency measures among the 'rural households' target group are being tested. 4. Advice from accredited energy auditors is adopted by industrial enterprises and commercial banks.
Impact: 1. Energy Efficiency targets set out in the respective Year Plan by 2015 and budgets for specific measures are set  2. 100,000 efficient cook stoves disseminated annually in rural households. 3. A fuel consumption of at least 30% lower achieved in control groups using ICS in comparison to control groups using traditional stoves. 4. At least 60% of 500 users (control group users) asked report lower smoke pollution levels in the air in the dwelling. 5. Three frequently used household appliances (including lamps) have specific energy consumption significantly below those preceding years. 6. At least one commercial bank offers credit on competitive market terms for investments in energy efficiency measures.Cost
Outcome: The energy use for domestic and productive purposes in Nepal is more efficient
Primary Sector: - ALTERNATE ENERGY - ELECTRICITY - ENERGY - INDUSTRY - POLICY AND STRATEGIC

Project Title: River Protection Works in East Chitwan
Input: i) Rehabilitate/constructe Launching aprons and spurs of the 18 Kms long dykes at appropriate locations ; ii) Increase Height of the dyke at appropriate places ; iii) Debris collected below the Lothar bridge is removed and is used for increasing the height of the dyke; iv) Appropriate protection works on some inner streams are carried out.v) Intake of the irrigation canal is adjusted to the new river levels; vi) a study for a long term and sustainable solution with recommendation is available; ii) DDC representatives and the main political parties lobby for budget for the implementation of the recommendation of the study.
Outputs: Output 1: Local communities along Rapti River and in the project VDCs build and rehabilitate river protection works. Output 2: Local communities rehabilitate the irrigation canals originating from Rapti river Output 3: User's committee and its sub committees formed to implement the works. Output 4: Communities, VDCs and the DDC strengthen their capacity to engage in dialogues with the central Government on the need to undertake larger integrated watershed management initiatives.
Impact: Safeguard the people and assets of eastern Chitwan from flood related disaster and improve their livelihoods and food security.
Outcome: Local communities are safe from water induced natural disaster   Local communities safeguard their livelihoods in an inclusive way   The Central Government is aware of Chitwan's specific needs for watershed management
Donor Agency: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation

Project Title: Strengthening the Conservation and Management of Lumbini, the Birthplace of the Lord Buddha, World Heritage Property (Phase II)
Input: MLA 1: Protecting and conserving cultural and natural heritage through the effective implementation of the 1972 Convention
Outputs: Lumbini is the birthplace of the Lord Buddha founder of one of the world's great religions, and is a major source of national pride as well as one of the most important cultural sites of Nepal with a great attraction for pilgrims and other visitors. Its proper preservation, management and development are imperative for both its sustainable utilization and the maintenance of its cultural values, notably the sacred atmosphere that should be experienced at the site. Its valuable archaeological vestiges, including the Ashoka Pillar, are a significant part of that atmosphere and must be correctly identified, protected and researched in order to properly plan the site.    ha's life included on Nepal's Tentative Lists     Tilaurakot, the archaeological remains of ancient Shakya Kingdom, located 27 kilometres west of Lumbini on the eastern bank of the river Banganga, was included by Nepal in the World Heritage Tentative List since 1996. The site consists of a fortified 'citadel' of about 500 metres by 400 metres and is surrounded by a series of associated monuments.      Ramagrama, the only surviving relic stupa of Lord Buddha, located 40 kilometres east of Lumbini was included by Nepal in the World Heritage Tentative List since 1996. The visible remains at the site consist of a large stupa measuring about 10 metres high and 24 metres diameter in the bank of the river Jharahih.
Outcome: The project has been designed based on the findings of a great number of consultations and discussions on the preparation of the Phase II project, including those held on the 19 July 2012 in Lumbini during the third International Scientific Steering Committee meeting. The project activities will address issues of conservation, archaeology and overall planning related to the three sites, Lumbini, Tilaurakot and Ramagrama. It takes into account the most urgent works focusing on preserving the heritage sites of the Lumbini Development Area.
Donor Agency: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

Project Title: Empowering the Poor through increasing access to Energy - ADB Regional Energy
International Planned Parenthood Federation (IPPF) South Asia Strategic Plan 2010-2015
Input: This initiative supports the International Planned Parenthood Federation (IPPF) South Asia Strategic Plan 2010-2015 and forms part of the Government's commitment to advance Millennium Development Goal (MDG) 5 (improve maternal health) in South Asia. The South Asia region has the highest rates of maternal and neonatal deaths and unmet demand for contraception in the Asia-Pacific. The funding of this initiative helps reduce maternal deaths in South Asia by improving equitable access for underserved groups to a range of reproductive health services and education including family planning. These goals are met by IPPF's South Asia Strategic Plan which focuses on 4 priority areas: 1) ensuring young people have access and rights to services and education; 2) reducing social, cultural and economic barriers that impede access; 3) HIV/AIDS prevention and care; and 4) reducing unsafe abortion. The total value of this multi-country initiative is up to $11 million over 3 years, starting 2010-11.   PARTNER : INTERNATIONAL PLANNED PARENTHOOD FEDERATION

Project Title: South Asia Public Sector Linkages Program (PSLP) initiative
Koshi Basin Program Phase 1 (ICIMOD)
Input: The Intergovernmental Centre for Integrated Mountain Development (ICIMOD) initiative provides funding for a 'multi-disciplinary river basin resource management programme' targeting the Koshi River Basin, covering parts of China, Nepal, and India. The overall goal is to contribute to inclusive poverty reduction and enhanced resilience to climate change by securing and sustaining freshwater ecosystem services. Australia's contribution will: develop a basin wide knowledge based in a web-based information sharing platform; propose options for improved agriculture in different geo-climatic parts of the basin; and provide detailed case studies of the underlying causes and management options for a range of water hazards. Improving the management of the waters of the Himalayan Rivers is critical to improving the livelihood of more than 500 million of the world's poorest people. The total value of this multi-country initiative is $3.0 million over 4 years, starting 2011-12.

Project Title: Strengthen BOG secretariat
Input: In the changed context of a complex Nepal, the worsening political situation with the risk of peace process failing, the need of a more in-depth information sharing amongst the BOG members with a stronger response capacity for any situation with proper tools through a strengthened BOGs secretariat becomes increasingly necessary. As SDC has played an important role in making the BOGs what it is today, it is only natural that SDC continue to support the BOGs by fully financing a BOGs Coordinating Officer who will report to the chair of the BOGs Group and based in the Risk Management Office (RMO), a project so far co-financed by DFID and the GTZ. In terms of institutional set-up, there will be an agreement between DFID, the GTZ and SDC to co-finance RMO.
Outputs: A. BOGS ARE FURTHER DISSEMINATED ACCROSS NEPAL B. BOGS SIGNATORIES++ DEVELOP A JOINT UNDERSTANDING OF THE NEPAL (FRAGILE) SITUATION. C. BOGS VIOLATIONS ARE IDENTIFIED BY THE BOGS GROUP D. BOGS VIOLATIONS ARE ADDRESSED AT LOCAL AND/OR POLICY LEVEL
Impact: Operational space as well as security and safety of development workers in Nepal are ensured.
Outcome: Outcome 1: Issues on BOGs violations are identified within the BOGs group. Outcome 2: Issues on BOGs violations are taken up at policy level

Project Title: Peacebuilding and collaborative leadership, phase 1
Input: Catalytic funding is sought for two activities related to the transition from the needs assessment to a longer term programme of activities through the UNDP's CLD Programme:      A. Three consultative workshops in March on collaborative leadership challenges in Nepal, targeting youth, women, and political party actors.    B. The development and early implementation by the CLD Programme staff of a detailed two-year plan of action based on the CLD needs assessment, including a national mapping of all related donor-funded activities, and including the inputs received from the March consultative workshops.      Timeline   Three workshops will take place in March 2011. The CLD Programme will host a meeting in early April 2011 of all actors, national and international, in order to share findings and support sustained coordination on issues regarding collaboration, leadership and dialogue.      In April 2011, on the basis of programme planning, the CLD Programme will hire a core team of three to six Nepali facilitators and trainers who can initiate activities. This core team will be needed for at least six months as partnerships with national and local actors as well as government, are established.
Impact: The project aims to contribute towards lasting and sustainable peace in Nepal
Outcome: - Direct engagement with beneficiaries through training, accompaniment and metoring, as well as intervention in emblematic cases that might arise from immediate crisis issues   - Strengthening and expansion of networks of CLD trainer and facilitators for the purpose of regular exchange of experiences, strategies and coordinaton of programmes.   - Engagement with national and local media to develop and support TV and radio programming that creates a conductive environment for collaborative leadership and dialogue in target areas prone to conflict and with the potential for such engagement.

Project Title: Sediment handling and headwork design of hydro power stations
Input: Hydraulic research and modelling
Outputs: Sub-component objectives:   Strengthen and upgrade the capability of the hydraulic laboratory to serve the need for physical hydraulic model studies of water resources projects in Nepal.   Strengthen and upgrade a technically capable sediment laboratory for providing services to sediment related studies and research in the field of water resources development.  Enhance Hydro Lab's capability for the field study and instrumentation regarding flow, turbine efficiency and sediment measurement.  Train and develop required skill of the staff to perform the research activities in a professional manner.  Develop technical and research management competency through transfer of know how and technology.   Establish professional and research cooperation among the institutions  Enhance knowledge in the design and operation of headworks in steep sediment loaded rivers.  Establish a database required for the optimum sediment handling in RoR hydropower plants.  Assist small hydropower promoters/developers to build confidence on the design of headworks structures.  Share the acquired knowledge and experience for the benefit of the water resources projects in Nepal.  Identify and initiate potential research projects for the improvement of the performance of water resources projects.
Impact: The Goal of the Project is to contribute to a sustainable development of water resources in Nepal for the benefit of the Nepalese people
Outcome: The Purpose of the Project is to support Hydro Lab so it will become a centre of excellence in water resources development in steep sediment-loaded rivers with focus on hydraulics and sediments.

Project Title: Rehalibitation of Critical Trail Bridges
Input: The proposed fund shall be utilised to procure the required steel parts including steel decks, anchorage parts, gabion mesh etc. required to rehabilitate the 'critical' trail bridges. SDC will procure the materials through a local bidding procedure and hand over the materials to the respective District Development Committees (DDC). The Trail Bridge Support Unit managed by Helvetas shall provide all the required technical and administrative support to SDC.      Districts are the main implementers at the operational level. Once they receive the steel parts from SDC, they shall allocate adequate budget for labour and other materials such as cement, sand and aggregate. It is also the responsibility of the DDC to organise the contribution from communities wherever applicable. All other approaches concerning social inclusion, transparency and governance, conflict sensitivity, insurance of labour, timely payments, steering, monitoring etc will be applied as usual
Outputs: District Development Committees rehabilitate 137 'critical' trail bridges that has been identified by the Bridge Condition Investigation.
Impact: The proposal's goal is to contribute towards rehabilitating 137 'critical' trail bridges. This will provide and improve the 'safe' access for an estimated 275'000 rural people of Nepal to social services and economic opportunities.   This initiative is limited to the celebration of the completion of 5000 trail bridges in Nepal.
Outcome: a) Local communities engage in the rehabilitation of critical trail bridges to improve safer access to basic services at local level.      b) National and district governments strengthen their institutional capacities for maintenance of trail bridges.
Donor Agency: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation

Project Title: Support to the electoral process in Nepal. Building electoral capacity and promoting electoral legal reform
Input: To assist in the development of a well considered legal framework that meets the needs and aspirations of the Nepali people and conforms to international standards  Provide key stakeholders with information and technical advice on electoral issues related to the constitution and election and political party laws  To build the capacity of targeted stakeholders on the electoral legal framework  Support and strengthen the EC of Nepal as an independent electoral management body, including support to a potential revised structure of the Commission subsequent to the ratification of the new constitution  To facilitate rapid conduct of elections under the new constitution
Outputs: A well considered electoral framework that is able to be easily interpreted into a consistent set of electoral and political party laws and related legislation  Strengthened capacity of the Election Commission of Nepal  Stakeholders provided with the tools and knowledge to positively comment on the electoral related elements of the constitution during drafting and discussion phase of the process, including presenting related systems options  Enhanced knowledge of key stakeholders on electoral issues within the constitution and electoral and political party laws and related legislation  Analysis of the electoral framework with the resulting electoral and political party laws and related legislation meeting democratic standards and addressing the need for electoral legislation consolidation and consistency
Impact: Establish a legal electoral framework through and transparent and participatory process that meets the needs and aspirations of the Nepali people and international standards, thus furthering the goals of the Comprehensive Peace Accord and the ongoing peace process and the holding of future credible and accepted elections.
Outcome: Establish a legal electoral framework through and transparent and participatory process that meets the needs and aspirations of the Nepali people and international standards, thus furthering the goals of the Comprehensive Peace Accord and the ongoing peace process and the holding of future credible and accepted elections.
Secondary Sector Sub-Sector: Executive and legislative organs, financial and fiscal affairs, external

Project Title: Support to Constitution Making and Implementation
Input: Continue and deepen dialogue among key political actors with a view to building trust and forging consensus on contentious constitutional issues;Facilitate processes which aim at including in the constitution aspects which support managing diversity, accountability, and public participation; Support the transition from constitution making to the next elections by continuing through the period of transition to facilitate dialogues and support preparations for implementing the newly agreed constitution;Support the implementation of constitutional design which accommodates diversity, especially affirmative action legislation and policies and language policies; and Assist and encourage the new legislature in implementing the institutional framework established by the new or revised constitution.
Outputs: Legislation, institutions, processes required by the implementation identified; and Common understanding on the content of the constitution and on requirements for its implementation emerging;Common understanding on standing orders/ rules for procedure; Improved understanding by the new members /staff on the role Legislature in implementing the constitution; and Informed and increased debate about the role of interest caucuses and about citizens' participation in the legislature/parliament's work..
Outcome: Shared understanding by the political party leaders about the need for consensus culture to prevail in the aftermath of constitution promulgation; Improved understanding by the party leaders on content of the constitution, and on possible contentious provisions and implications of them; and Improved understanding by the women and IP groups about the content of the new constitution and possible constructive ways to improve it -should it be deemed necessary.
Secondary Sector Sub-Sector: Executive and legislative organs, financial and fiscal affairs, external

Project Title: Sankalpa - Empowerment of Women for Political and Social Justice
Input: capacity building of various women leaders at grass roots level and women parliamentarians: advocacy and awareness raising on women's representation; Capacity building to national leaders and grass roots women activists on NAP and transitional justice; and through strengthening Sankalpa as an organization by appraising and restructuring its systems and procedures.   The primary target groups are thus the district and village level women, key women activists and women's rights organization leaders and Women Human Rights Defenders (WHRDs), conflict affected women and parliamentarians. Civil servants, central level political leaders, local journalists, rural population and CA committee members are the secondary target groups.Purpose: support the implementation of the National Action Plan of UNSCR 1325 and 1820; and increase representation of women in political parties, civil service and national and sub-national governance structures.
Impact: The goal of the project is to help increase and enhance women representation and rights in the government, political parties, private sectors, at all levels, and ensure that conflict affected women have access to social justice
Outcome: Results: See attached results chain (Annex1)   Outcome 1: Women and men are better organized and demonstrate unity in diversity to ensure representation at national and sub national governance structures, political parties and civil service.      Outcome 2: Women activists and organizations are increasingly lobbying for women's rights and transitional justice using UNSCR 1325 and 1820 NAP as a tool.      Outcome 3: Sankalpa demonstrates significant institutional and organizational transformation in terms of human resources and project management cycle.

Project Title: Social Inclusion Research Fund Assistance Programme, SIRF II
Outputs: Quality research on social inclusion agenda supported; Capacity Building: Researchers from excluded groups (women, Madhesi, Dalits and Janajati) capacitated to carry out research on social inclusion agenda; Advisory & Research Management; Public & policy debates based on social inclusion research findings stimulated; Coordination mechanism established with civil society and excluded groups' initiatives for policy and public dialogue; Establishment and operationalisation of a national level institution supporting social inclusion research facilitated;National authority's capacity to develop cooperation and linkages with research councils of Norway including international institutions facilitated.
Impact: Excluded and vulnerable communities' rights and access to opportunities are ensured in state institutions in Nepal
Outcome: National Authority (NA) having increased institutional capacity to gradually strengthen and consolidate social inclusion research financing and agenda setting; National Authority (NA) taking the lead in facilitation of public debate and policy analysis and development on inclusion in state agencies.

Project Title: Support to Human Rights, Strategic Plan of INSEC
Input: INSEC's mission is to work towards the promotion of policies, institutions and capacity that contribute to the protection and promotion of human rights and democratic freedoms and peace. This will be done through various instruments such as human rights monitoring, capacity building and policy advocacy.
Outputs: Monitoring the human rights situation across the country and publishing the findings. Promote awareness and mobilize people, their representatives, law-enforcing agencies, government line agencies and other key stakeholders sensitized to protect and promote human rights. Providing education to promote human rights, peace and democratic culture at the local level. Writing shadow reports, lobbying and advocating campaigns aimed at policy and legislative reform or enactment of new legislation to ensure compliance with international standards. Enhancing institutional capacity and competencies of community based organizations and social movements engaged in promotion of human rights, peace and democratic culture.
Impact: Expected impact is that citizens are aware of human rights and democratic freedom and the government fully respectful of human rights of its people.
Outcome: Build updated mass knowledge to stop human rights violation as it emerges, by collecting information through the local human rights activists and organizations working at the local level; Provide target groups with properly documented information or conclusion of every collected incident and to ensure a follow up by monitoring such incidents in the future; Keep the target groups informed by analyzing minutely the incidents and enhancing the general public knowledge on the basic level of human rights violations. Provide strategies and solutions against human rights violation to the different Human Rights actors; Publicize up-to-date human rights violation reports and human rights movement achievements. The publication of these issues is a continuous process.

Project Title: Energy Access and Efficiency Improvement Project (EAEIP)
Input: The project has 9 components under three (Energy Access, Clean Energy and Capacity Building) main categories; 5 components for Loan portion and 2 components for Grant portion. Asian Development has provided a Loan of SDR 41.127 million (equivalent to US$ 65 million) and a Grant of US$ 4.5 million. The Loan portion consists of following components:  1. Facilitating Access to Clean Energy 2. Energy Access Quality Enhancement 3. Clean Energy Improvement 4. Supply-side Energy Efficiency Improvement; and 5. Capacity Building. The Grant portion consists of following components: 1. Energy Efficiency in Lighting; and 2. Renewable Energy for Street Lighting. Budget Head Name of the Project Allocated amount (in Rs. 'ooo)  Loan Grant   87-4655 132 kv and Other transmission Line Expansion Projects:  i) Dumre-Damauli-Marsyangdi 132 kv TL (loan)   ii) Butwal- Kohalpur- Mahendranagar 132 kv TL (loan)   iii) Matatirtha S/SExpansion Project (loan)   iv) Chapali 132kv Subststion Project (loan)   v) Distribution System Augmentation Project (loan)   vi) Loss reduction in Kathmandu, Birjinj and Simara Corridor (loan)   vii) Street Light Rehabilitation (grant)   viii) CFL Program (grant)   ix) Capacitor Bank (loan)   x) Distribution System Consuling Service (loan & grant)  87-4-714 Power Station Reinforcement and Maintenance & Repair Projects:  i) Marsyangdi HPS (loan)   ii) Gandaki HPS (loan)
Outputs: Nepal has        The Bank's interventions in the Nepal's power sector have mostly focused on transmission, distribution and small hydropower. The proposed Project is also seems to be a largely transmission and distribution focused. This Project will support the Government of Nepal's long term vision to provide universal coverage using grid-based and off-grid supplies by 2027.
Outcome: This grant and loan assistance will address the urgent needs attributed to the electricity supply crisis in the country, to a large extent. In the short term, the transmission network strengthening will add supply capacity by increasing evacuation of power from hydropower stations in the mid western region and allow increased energy imports across the eastern border, and in the medium term, it will allow cross border energy trade. Moreover, the project also lead to improve financial performance of Nepal Electricity Authority (NEA). In other words, there would be a reliable and an energy efficient power supply with increased access and operational efficiency.

Project Title: Child Friendly Local Governance CFLG
Input: Provide overall guidance to the government in realizing and mainstreaming the rights of children (Survival, Development, Protection and Participation) into the local government system, structure, policies and process   Facilitate and coordinate the realization of Rights of Children with National (Macro) and Sub-national level (Meso and Micro) along with LGCDP

Project Title: Electricity Transmission Expansion and Supply Improvement Project (ETESIP)
Input: Proposed an Electricity Transmission Expansion and Supply Improvement Project is critical for reliability of Energy supply in Nepal and its capacity for power import and export across the border. Project Title: Information and Communication Technology Development Project (ICTDP)
Input: The Project comprises the following parts: Part 1: Rural e-Community  - Wireless Broadband Network  - village Networks  - Telecenters  -Community Mobilization and Capacity Development Part 2: Government Network  - Government Information and Data Center  - Government Groupware Part 3: e-Government Applications Part 4: Human Resource Development for e-governance
Outputs: The Project comprises: 1. Modernizing rural communities, particularly in remote areas, by improving rural connectivity through wireless broadband networks, mobilizing community socio-economic activities through village network portals, and building telecenters to improve service access in remote rural areas; 2. Building a government ICT network, which allows government-to-government exchange of data and information and central level management of government data information; 3. Developing various priority e-government applications; and 4. Designing and implementing human resources development programmes.
Impact: Delivery of government services improved through ICT Networking.
Outcome: The Project will help the Government of Nepal in economic and social development and reduce poverty by making ICT more accessible to remote and rural areas, and improving the delivery of government services through ICT network.

Project Title: Melamchi Drinking Water Project
Input: Has two sub projects  ( 1)Melamchi Water Diversion Subprojects : Components: 26.5Km long diversion tunnel and water treatment Plant (2) Kathmandu Valley Water Supply and Sanitaion subprojects Components: Bulk distribution system and distribution Network improvement Works and Waste water Improvement Works and Institutional Reforms and Capacity Building of KUKL.
Outputs: Melamchi Water Ssupply project abstracts water from Melamchi River (Sindhupalchowk District) and will pass it through a 26.5 Km long tunner delivering to Sundarijal Water Treatment Plant. The first phase will draw 17 million liters of water from Melamchi River. The second phase and the third phase will draw water from Yangri and Larke river adding again 17 million liters per day from each river in second and third phase respectively. Thus, in the first phase 17 million litres of treated water will be added daily to Kathmandu Valley.
Impact: At present, Kathmandu Valley suffers from many water borne diseases time to time. After successful completion of this project there will be qualitative and sufficient safe drinking water supply and improved sanitation facilities in Kathmandu Valley. Consequently, this will reduce the incidence of water borne diseases with improving the health of the people in Kathmandu Valley.
Outcome: Better Water supply and sanitation facilities will be available for about five million people in Kathmandu Valley.
Donor Agency: - Asian Development Bank - Japan International Cooperation Agency - Nordic Development Fund - Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

Project Title: TA 7504-NEP Increasing Access to Energy in Rural Nepal
Input: Phase 1 (months 1-6)   1.1 Draft report outlining mechanism for transferring SMB model to the IWMP and establishing revolving fund   1.2 Confirm revolving fund host, sign MOUs, and select districts for project implementation   1.3 Establish a revolving fund that would provide a menu of -gap filling finance_ (equity, debt, bridge financing, lease-toward-purchase, guarantees) to facilitate bringing bank debt financing to the IWM and other energy services investments. Release initial tranche of funds to the revolving fund host upon signing of the MOU   1.4 Transfer SMB expertise, including sample documentation, to CRT/N, RF host, and other relevant partners.      Phase 2 (months 7-36)   2.1 Provide training to banks to develop agents and correspondent models to overcome the lack of experience in local microfinance and financial institutions    2.2 Conduct trainings to familiarize local microfinance and financial institutions with improved water mill and other energy service investments and to help them develop an investment pipeline   2.3 Conduct training for ghatta owners' associations and improved water mill entrepreneurs to transfer technical skills and expertise   3.1 Release additional tranches of funds rup to $500,000 total to capitalize the revolving fund   3.2 Deploy RF funds for IWM investments in project implementation districts   3.3 Complete Clean Development Mechanism project preparation   3.4 Long-term plan for managing and sustaining the revolving fund on a commercial basis in place
Outputs: 1. SMB model piloted in some IWMP districts   2. Capacity built among local partners, e.g., entrepreneurs and microfinance and financial institutions, to implement sustainable energy service delivery programs   3. Revolving fund capitalized and deployed on a pilot basis to provide gap-filling finance for energy service investments.
Impact: Access to sustainable, reliable, and affordable modern energy services improved in target communities in Nepal
Outcome: Results of SMB approach to financing improved water mills demonstrate the viability of scaling up access to energy projects

Project Title: School sector Reform Program (SSRP)
Input: Basic Education  Secondary Education  Institutional Capacity Strengthening
Outputs: To ensure equitable access to quality basic education for all children in 5-12 age group.  To improve the access, equity, quality and relevance of secondary education.  To enhance functional literacy and basic competencies among youths and adults.  To equip secondary level students with TVET soft skills.  To enhance teachers' qualifications and professional competencies to better facilitate students learning processes.  To improve the performance of the MOE service delivery system and develop the capacity to implement critical reforms.  To monitor programme inputs, processes, and outputs and evaluate the impact of the Plan.  To improve the efficiency and effectiveness of aid available for SSRP implementation  The program runs from 2009-10 to 2013-14. Total budget is USD 2626.01 million, out of which donors provide USD 624.99 million (23.8%).
Impact: To contribute to Nepal's socio-economic development through a continuous development of its human resources capacity.
Outcome: To provide opportunity to all Nepali citizens to become functionally literate, numerate, and develop the basic life skills, vocational skills and knowledge required to enjoy a productive life. Major objective is to increase access to and improve quality of school education, particularly of basic education, especially for children and youths from marginalized groups.

Enhanced Reporting and Feedbacks on M&E results among Pilot Districts, Partner Ministries and NPCS   4. Enhanced Coordination Mechanisms amoung NPCS Divisions and between NPCS and Partner Ministries
