Project Title: Gender Mainstreaming and Social Inclusion Project
Input: The project supports piloting Gender Equality and Social Inclusion Policy at the planning process of VDCs and DDCs, disseminate the learnings and feedbacks to the national policy.
Outputs: 1. GM/SI understanding of persons concerned of VDC, Municipality, WDO and DDC in collaboration with GM/SI related Coordinating Committees in the two districts, DWD, MoLD, MoWCSW and GFP/SIFP at the national level are enhanced through trainings. 2. DDC, WDO, Municipality, VDC and other members of GMCC and GESI Implementation Coordination Committee in the targeted two districts are able to carry out GM/SI Appraisal on development plans and GM/SI Audit ion budget of implementing plans in accordance with GM/SI related guidelines. 3. DDC, WDO, Municipality, VDC and other members of GMCC and Implementation Coordination Committee in the targeted two districts are able to formulate GM/SI responsive development plans in accordance with GM/SI guidelines. 4. GM/SI Monitoring team consisting of DDC, WDO, Municipality, VDC and GMCC and GESI Implementation Coordination Committee members in the targeted two districts are able to periodically carry out GM/SI Monitoring on implementating plans and projects. 5. GM/SI responsive practical operational manuals for local bodies and WDO are developed in the two districts based on processes, practices and lessons gained by the project. 6. Dissemination strategies of GM/SI practical operational manuals for local bodies and WDO to other districts are developed jointly by MoLD, MoWCSW, DWD and GFP/SIFP at the national level. 7. Function of GM/SI related coordinating committees are enhanced and networking is strengthened at the central level.
Impact: GM/SI responsive programs are developed and implemented in Nepal.
Outcome: GM/SI responsive programs are implemented at the national level and two targeted districts (Syangja and Morang)

Project Title: Strengthening Community Mediation Capacity for Peaceful and Harmonious Society
Input: The project implements the provisions of community mediation made through Local Self Governance Act and Mediation Bill at the pilot VDCs and disseminate the learning.
Outputs: 1. Situation on dispute management mainly through community mediation are assessed in Nepal and project target area. 2. Skills, knowledge and mechanism for dispute management mainly through community mediation are strengthened. 3. Experience on dispute management mainly through community mediation by the project are shared with central and local stakeholders.
Impact: Knowledge on dispute management mainly through community mediation for peaceful and harmonious community is disseminated in Sindhuli Road corridor area.
Outcome: Capacity and mechanism for dispute management mainly through community mediation are enhanced in Sindhuli and Mahottari districts.

Project Title: Participatory Watershed Management and Local Governance Project
Input: The main activities are strengthening capacity of DSCWM and DSCO based on the review of SABIHAA activities and review institutional arrangement for the implementation of watershed management in line with local governance.
Outputs: 1. Capacity of DSCWM and DSCO on participatory watershed management in the targeted area is improved.   2. Institutional arrangement for the implementation of participatory watershed management is reviewed in line with local governance.
Impact: Improved participatory watershed management in better collaboration with DSCO and local bodies is applied in other districts by the initiative of MoFSC and MoLD.
Outcome: Improved participatory watershed management in better collaboration with DSCO and local bodies is implemented in the target districts.
District: - Baglung (Baglung) - Kaski (Pokhara) - Kavrepalanchok (Dhulikhel) - Myagdi (Beni) - Parbat (Kusma) - Sindhupalchok (Chautara) - Syangja (Syangja) - Tanahu (Damauli)

Project Title: Project for Capacity Development on Water Supply in Semi-Urban Area
Input: The main project activities will be baseline survey and needs assessment; capacity building training to WUSCs, WSSDO and ERMSO; support to preparation of Small and Medium-sized Water Supply Support Model for technical support of WUSC and Small and Medium and Medium-sized Water Supply Support Management Model for WUSC based on the trainings conducted.
Outputs: 1. Basic information for the project and necessary information for indicators are collected, and water supply management of the project is appropriately executed and implement periodically monitoring for appropriate water supply management. 2. Small and Medium-sized Water Supply Support Model and Small and Medium and Medium-sized Water Supply Support Management Model are collected as models for WSSDO/ERMSO and WUSC. 3. Model of output 2 is disseminated in Jhapa and Morang districts.
Impact: DWSS technical support model for WUSCs established by the project will be disseminated to all over the country by MoPPW and DWSS
Outcome: DWSS technical support system to WUSCs is improved in Morang and Jhapa districts

Outcome: Promote clean energy utilization and achieve emission reduction. On interrupted power supply to dhobi ghat reservoir.

Project Title: Revitalization of Remote Villages through Community Forest Conservation
Input: 1. Nursery garden establishment 2. Capacity development activities to utilize forest resources in a sustainable way and selling of forest products

Outcome: Natural environment preserved and livelihood of community improved

Project Title: Tanahu Hydropower Project
Input: The input involves funding like Loan and Technical assistance grant from various donors to this projects which inturn helps in building a medium-sized hyderpower plant (140 megawatt (MW)) with ample storage transmission lines to evacute its power and a reform plan for the national utility, The NEA (Nepal Electricity Authority)
Outputs: 1. Hydropower plan transmission system construction     140 MW hydropower plant constructed by 2020    37km transmission line and a 220 kV substation constructed to evacuate the plant's power by 2020    Gender equility wareness consultations for 1000 persons including 500 women    2. Atleast 17636 households connected to power supply by 2020(including 30000 women)   3. Community livelihood program in the project area     3732 households in project benefit from CDS programs by 2020 (including 10000 women)    4. NEA restructing implemented     NEA's financial and operational restructing plan impleted by 2016    NEA's management program finalized and implemented by 2016    5. Other Sector reforms and project management operational     Revised tariff regulations and cost recovery mechanism for distribution, transmission and generation issused by 2015    Autonomous and independent regulator established for comprehensive tariff setting by 2015    THL's comprhensive corporate policies using commercial priciples and informed by GESI considerations established bu 2015    6. PPP and equlity sales scheme for hydropower development initiated     A divestment program put in place between 2013-2015,including the sale of equlity in THL, the project company for Tanahu    A PPP program targeting domestic supplies and exports put in place by 2015
Impact: Expanded access to clean and sustainable energy supply in Nepal   Performance Targets and indicators with baseline are as follows     Increase hydropower generation capacity to 2000 MW by 2023 (Baseline : 706 MW in 2012)    Increased access to electricity to 70% of households by 2023 (from 56% in 2011)    Reduce fossil fuel imports by %)% by reducing dependence in the use of generators by 2023(from 531 MW equivalent in 2011)    Reduce national carbondioxide emissions by additional 466,475 tons per year by 2023
Outcome: Improved Hydropower sector Efficiency   Performance Targets and Indicators with baseline are     Increase in hydropower capacity available year round by at-least to 245 MW in 2020 from 92 MW in 2012    Increase in additional electricity generation of 588 GWh/year from the Tanahu hydropower plant in 2020    Winter's power shortage alleviated by 2020 (from loadshedding of 18hrs in 2011)
Donor Agency: - Asian Development Bank - European Investment Bank - Japan International Cooperation Agency - Nepal Electricitiy Authority

Project Title: Shangrila Underprivileged Children Support
Input: Provide adequate shelter to all resident beneficiaries.    Provide food, psycho-social counseling, clothing and access to medical care to resident and non-resident children.    Provide occupational therapy to street-adolescents for rehabilitation purpose.    Provide access to education to all beneficiaries: formal (in educational institute) and informal (conducted in the program), academic (school and college) and vocational (training institutes and workshops), long-term (long-term child care program) and short-term (rehab/reintegration program).    Establish and maintain a clear daily social structure with rules and regulations by which all resident beneficiaries abide.    Provide job + give access to training (tailoring + literacy classes) to 15 women within the programs.
Outputs: In 5 years' time:     Shelter, health care and nutrition delivered to 275 children.    Job-income-training provided to 15 mothers    Access to education established for 350 children    Social development structure installed for 275 children    Social re-integration and financial independence achieved for 125 children
Impact: To contribute to the rights of children to health, education and protection
Outcome: Improve the living standard of children    Reintegrate children into society

Project Title: Promoting Peace Building and Democratization Through The Capacity Development of The Media Sector
Input: The project supports the Ministry of Information and Communications to prepare media policy, acts, regulations and guidelines. It also supports MoIC and Radio Nepal to transform Radio Nepal toa public broadcasting institution by supporting human resources development and preparing guidelines, manuals, etc
Outputs: Drafts of the revised policy, acts, regulations and guidelines are formulated by MoIC. The functions of Radio Nepal as a public broadcasting institution are enhanced.
Impact: Environment to respect the principle of accuracy, impartiality and fairness of media is enhanced.
Outcome: A model of accurate, impartial and fair media in the democratizing process is established.

Project Title: Promoting Reproductive Health Rights and Justice in Nepal
Input: OBJECTIVE ONE:   Provide technical assistance to the government for the development and implementation of appropriate legal and other strategies to promote social justice and a rights-based approach to women's reproductive health.   OBJECTIVE TWO:   Increase understanding of local actors, both right holders and duty bearers, on reproductive rights in relation to reproductive health concerns prioritized by the government.
Outputs: OUTPUTS ONE:     Government obtains technical assistance to develop reproductive health laws and policies in accordance with a rights-based approach that will promote and protect women's reproductive rights (i.e. Center will a draft a comprehensive abortion law in collaboration with local experts and produce a human rights report that establishes the right to contraceptive access, discusses the government's obligations in relation to this right and makes key recommendations for action).      Increase in implementation of Supreme Court decisions (i.e. Center creates a strategy roadmap for implementation of the Lakshmi Dhikta decision and other reproductive rights decisions. in collaboration with the NWC).    Develop and publish a report that establishes a right to contraceptive access and discusses government's obligations and key recommendations to fulfill them.    Prepare and submit a comprehensive draft bill on access to safe abortion to the government.    OUTPUTS TWO:      Advocacy material with information on international and comparative reproductive rights law and reproductive health issues including translation of concluding observations of the CEDAW Committee relating to women's reproductive health and rights into Nepali and one other local language developed.    Trainings on reproductive right.
Impact: To enhance the enjoyment of women's reproductive rights and assist the government in achieving its commitments under international human rights treaties and the Millennium Development Goals.
Outcome: Outcome One:      Increased examples of use of rights languages in laws and policies;    Number of legal strategies developed to address barriers to contraceptive access;    Increased examples of rights language in the media;    Number and type of requests for support and technical assistance from local organizations;    Number of requests for assistance, including from partners, government officials, academics, lawyers and advocates;    Number of requests for assistance on litigation and amicus briefs; and    Number of press and social media outputs, such as print and online communications and other conventional social networking tools.    Outcome Two:      Number of participants from different sectors trained;    Material on reproductive rights including relevant Supreme Court decisions and Concluding comments compiled and shared; and    Number of press and social media outputs, such as print and online communications and other conventional social networking tools.

Project Title: "Project for Maternal and Child health care in West Terai Region"
Input: Increase the capacity of Siddharttha children and Women Hospital(SCWH) to respond to the increased patient flow.    Enhance development of human resources and stengthen quality of medical services that is friendly from the patients' point of view.    Promote awareness and local medical/health care through community empowerment.
Outputs: SCWH plays a role as referral center among the target area.     More than 50,000.00 people who visit to SCWH per year are satisfied with the mother friendly services.    changes are promoted in aawareness and behaviour towards mother and child health    People's demands seeking quality medical services are increased    Health situation of females and children is improved among target area.
Impact: Knowledge and behavior seeking better MCH are improved.    Personal hygiene and sanitation are improved and maintained    Socio economic aspects are strengthened among target women    Primary health care services are effectively and efficiently operated in public health institutes    Quality of perinatal care servic in SCWH is improved
Outcome: To enhance the health status of womenand children    To empower women financially    To empower decision making role of women    Enhance the quality of life of the people

Project Title: Supporting Investments in Water Security in River Basins
Input: This is a Regional TA funded by Asian Development Bank for Indonesia, Nepal and Uzbekistan. Estimated cost of TA is US$ 2.43 million of which US$ 2.00 million will be financed by ADB on a grant basis from Japan special Fund. JWA (Japan Water Agency) will contribute US$ 0.43 million equivalent through in-kind support. It has two components: I. Preparation for future water resources management programs that combine structuralo and non-structural investments to increase water security in three pilot basin areas and to improve exiting river basin management plans. II. In-country and regional capacity development activities to prepare government agencies, river basin organizations and other stakeholders for these future investment programs, including demonstrating activities to start implementating innovative approaches to increase water securitiy in the three basins. In the case of Nepal, the TA will help to identify investment needs in preparation for future feasibility studies for projects to increase water security in the pilot river basins of Bagmati.
Outputs: TA is expected to:   Review and assess the Bagmati Action Plan.  Conduct a study and demostration activities.  help expand the Bagmati Action Plan to increase water security in the middle and lower reaches drawing on the result of past studies and projects and a consultative process with stakeholders.  Assist in prioritizing the extended action plans candidate investment and capacity building.
Impact: Eeconomic growth accelerated and the living standards improved in river basins through efficient, effective and sustainable water resources management, environmental conservation, and water-related disaster risk mitigation.
Outcome: Bagmati Action Plan (BAP) strengthened.

Project Title: Support and Protection for Street Children and Vulnerable Families of Nepal
Input: Financial Support: As per SWC contract.    Technical Support: As per need    Training:     Training for the Team of Educators and Social Workers    The team of educators and social workers of VOC is highly motivated and all possess a great sensitivity to the problems of these children. Follow-ups and training sessions have allowed to evaluate their performance level, as well as to develop their capabilities and desire to progress.        Street children project    Several training sessions will be conducted either by external organizations or by EED. It aims at strengthening the capacity of VOC's educators, social workers and managers. The trainings topics could cover child development, child sexual abuse, language development, computer and language skills, etc.    Prevention project  The FDP approach has been successfully implemented in countries such as Cambodia and Philippines, but is quite new to Nepal. This new approach is being introduced by VOC, and hence, the staff from VOC will need to be trained on this new methodology.         Followup, Supervision and Monitoring: As per the provision in the agreement.
Outputs: Expected Project Output:   Street Work     To build relation with 780 (260 X 3 years) street children and find out their real situation and socio economic background over the project's period;    To provide emergency services - first aid to 288 (96 X 3) children and direct rescue to 144 (48 X 3) children over the project's period;    To generate awareness and provide psychological services to 720 (240 X 3) children;       Welcome Center     To provide 780 (260 X 3 years) children with basic needs and support for their physical,/mental/educational skills each year over the project's period;    To conduct family visit of 180 (60 X 3) children to assess their family background with a view of a further reintegration over the project's period;    To refer 105 (35 X 3) children to the Preparation Center and 21 (7 X 3) children to families or other organizations over the project's period.       Preparation Center     To provide services and collect the information/ data for further process of 165 (55 X 3) children from the Preparation Center over the project period;    To promote the intellectual and emotional development of all the children as well as responsibility and creativity of 220 children over the project's period;    To prepare 105 (35 X 3) children for reintegration in their family or society/ Children Home over the project's period.       Family Reintegration     To develop and monitor the educational activities and follow up families of 120 (40 X 3) children over the project's period;    To conduct Family visit of 75 (25 X 3) working youth over the project's period;    To provide Medical support for 45 (15 X 3) children and 6 (2 X 3) families over the project's period;    To provide Psychological Counseling to 30 (10 X 3) children/ youth and 15 (5 X 3) families over the project's period;    To conduct regular meetings and special programs of the child club    To conduct 60 (20 X 3) family group meetings for savings and micro credit program over the project's period;    To Increase the capacity of the family to be responsible towards their children through Training/Workshop for 25 family members    To increase the intellectual ability of the children through 75 (25 X 3) outdoor visits and other activities as per need over the project's period;    To assist 15 children/ youth and their families in legal procedures such as acquiring citizenship, birth registration, etc.    Vocational Training and job placement     Develop the professional and life skills of 165 (55 X 3) youth from the street children and Family development projects.    Assist 165 (55 X 3) youth to build their self-reliance and provide job placements opportunities.    Family Development in Urban poor areas     To conduct regular family visits to 100 families the first, 200 families the second year and 300 in the third year;    To provide counseling and information to urban poor families regarding health, education, legal matters and family welfare.    To coordinate with at least 150 (50 X 3) existing services and organizations in order to refer urban poor families to improve their access to services    To organize awareness sessions or focus group discussions and social permanencies to 600 (200 X 3) families in the social centers about health, education, family relationships, family welfare and legal documents
Impact: Rates of street children cared for by various organizations in comparison to the numbers of street children still living in the street     - Preventive and therapeutic measures taken by authorities to prevent the problem of street children    Rate of children's reinsertion (in housing, families, vocational training, work) in comparison to total number of children taken in    - Number of families who had accessed to existing services
Outcome: Children are removed from marginal status and reintegrated into the society    Children will have received a basic education and acquired professional competence    Families are more capable to protect and respect the needs of their children and support for the development of their children is increased    Educators and social workers better trained to take charge of children and their families    Families identify and respond to their own needs    Families use the existing available services

Project Title: Rural Water & Sanitation Programme (Gurkha Welfare Scheme) Phase V

Percentage of Water and Sanitation Management Committee (WSMC) are functional and maintaining WATSAN    Hygiene and sanitation awareness programme conducted in each scheme enabling community to build HH and school latrines.    Project outputs sustained under localGovernment umbrella.

Project Title: Enabling State Programme
Outputs: Output 1: Voice and Accountability: Increase in the ability of civil society partners to hold decision makers to account and access their rights and entitlements   Output 2: State Capability: Selected state institutions are more capable   Output 3: Capacity Development: Increased capacity of ESP staff and partner organisations to measure gender equality and social inclusion, and promote accountability and transparency   Output 4: Information and Evidence: ESP supports the production of public information, sound evidence and analysis for state institutions, civil society and donors
Impact: State institutions are effective, inclusive and accountable contributing to peace and security in Nepal
Outcome: State institutions and citizens work together to promote inclusive policies and programmes

Project Title: Rights, Democracy and Inclusion Fund (RDIF)
Outputs: 1. Increased recognition by leadership of political parties of the importance of intra-party democracy, inclusion and inter-party cooperation.   2. Women, youth and other marginalized and excluded groups have increased awareness of and capacity to participate in and influence political process, including constitution making.   3. Increased knowledge and constructive engagement of civil society for civil, political and cultural rights of people.   4. Increased capacity of partner organizations (POs) to effectively implement projects on democratization process, inclusion and human rights.
Impact: To achieve a governance system characterised by democratic norms, respect for human rights and political and social inclusion of all groups
Outcome: Political decision makers* better informed and more responsive to democratization, the civil, political and cultural rights of Nepalese people, and inclusion of marginalized and excluded groups. ------------------------ * Political parties, parliamentary bodies, government/bureaucracy
Donor Agency: - AusAid - Denmark - Department for International Development - Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation

Project Title: Promoting the Effective Governance of Labour Migration from South Asia through Actions on Labour Market Information, Protection during Recruitment and Employment, Skills, and Development Impact
Input: Establish and test the information web portal -to be based in India    Periodic assessment of labour market information in destination countries (5 times)    Integrated employment services for the national and foreign labour markets will be introduced in two MOLE-job centres in Nepal    Study on labour market assessment in destination countries -    Establish information kiosks and establish a mobile team    Review of existing pre-departure orientation course and upgrade it    Support to strengthen: online registration at DOFE and its connection with missions abroad    Study on recruitment cost by country and occupation    Carry out a feasibility study to design a rating mechanism for recruitment agencies in India, Nepal and Pakistan.    Registration of sub-agents in India, Nepal and Pakistan and more effective regulation.    Blue-print and advocacy for reform of the recruitment mechanism in destination countries in GCC.    Assessment of complaints mechanisms in Nepal    Technical support for review of legislations;    TU/NGO Migration resource centre strengthened    Carry out an assessment of job requirements (skills and qualifications)    Consultation to develop a roadmap for better alignment and compatibility between job requirements (skills and qualification) in high demand occupations: construction, hospitality, trade and domestic work.    Upgrade the capacity of skills training institutes    Include skills recognition in standardised pre-departure training and issue of skills/employment passports    An assessment of trends and patterns in skilled emigration and return    A survey on remittances and financial products to attract savings and economic investments from migrants    Diaspora projects    A pilot programme: creation of a small fund leveraging diaspora contribution to development    An annual survey of key informants to monitor any significant outflows of health professionals from Nepal and corrective measures to be taken if necessary.
Outputs: Provide reliable information on overseas employment opportunities, and build capacity for matching qualified job seekers with the demand from foreign employers.    Reduce migration costs and recruitment abuses in countries of origin and destination by improving recruitment services; and increase protection of migrant workers during employment.    Enhance training, portability of skills for outgoing and returning migrant workers, and to promote the development
Impact: The effecetive of governance of labour migration from South Asia through actions on labour market information, protection during recruitment and employment, skills and development impact.
Outcome: To promote well-managed labour migration from South Asia, to ensure effective protection of the rights of vulnerable migrant workers, enhance the development impact of labour migration and reduce irregular flows.
Secondary Sector Sub-Sector: General economic, commercial and labour affairs

Project Title: ILO-DFID Partnership Programme on Fair Recruitment and Decent Work for Women Migrant Workers in South Asia and the Middle East
Input: National/District Level     Mapping of current interventions in target Districts, existing local groups and organisations; programmes and identification of target beneficiaries (the project aims to complement a range of existing initiatives).    Produce materials specific to women migrant workers and disseminate through MRCs across the country.    Migrant Domestic Worker Pre-departure Training Course to be offered by FEPB in source districts following a revision of the existing training-manual; including country specific basic language and financial literacy (1500 women)    TOT for Pre-departure Orientation institutes and trainers.    Produce country specific information guides for domestic workers to UAE (similar to Information Guide for Domestic Workers in Lebanon in Nepali) disseminate through various stakeholders      Financial literacy manual for pre-departure orientation    Run radio messages through local FMs targeting to women, girls and children who are vulnerable to trafficking for labour exploitation.    Strengthen the network of journalists and enhance their knowledge on the nexus between migration, labour migration, forced labour and trafficking (national and district level training)    Local/Village Level     Strengthen/establish migrant information centres at the Chief District Offices in selected districts including counseling service in partnership with the MOLE/FEPB    Establish information kiosks and establish mobile team from the MRCs for outreach to potential women migrants and girls in villages    Training to Social Mobilization Officer, Social Mobilisers, VDC Secretaries and Concerned officials at District Level on Relevant laws and Preventive Measures.    Establish booths to disseminate information during mass gatherings at villages on the occasion of various festivals or similar events.    Capacity building programmes for the existing community level groups such as mothers' group, community forestry groups and community health offices to provide information on labour market, safe migration and financial planning.
Outputs: Output 1: Women migrant workers and girls are empowered, in key source areas   Output 2: Recruitment agencies adopt ethical practices and are subject to improved monitoring and enforcement by state authorities   Output 3: Improved workplace practices and support services to safeguard the rights of women and girls   Output 4: Laws and policies in place and implemented to protect women migrant workers and girls   Output 5: New and better evidence is available on labour trafficking of women & girls within and from South Asia and on effective preventive measures
Impact: The aim of the project is to contribute towards bringing about a sustained situation where women and girls from South Asia are less vulnerable to situations of labour trafficking. To reach this goal the project will tackle root causes of trafficking at the community, national and international levels.
Outcome: Migrant women and girls are empowered and prevented from being trafficked by:     Ensuring decent working conditions at destination    Increasing benefits of migration for workers and their families through regular remittances and a reduction of migration costs    Enhancing knowledge, skills, and employability of migrant women and education of girls
Secondary Sector Sub-Sector: - General economic, commercial and labour affairs - Unemployment

Project Title: Gender Responsive Recovery for Sustainble Peace
Input: Training need assessment of tartget groups for promotion of entrepreneurial and vocational skils; mapping of BDS/Vocational trating institutions; support trainningon entrepreneurship and vocational skills development; facilitate linkages with business service providers including micro finance; post training support and sensitization and training on gender equality.
Outputs: Enhanced knowledge base on gender equality at the work place; report on training need assesment of target groups;report on mapping of BDS/Vocational Training Institutions; ptential women entrepreneurs trained; enhanced knowledge on micro-finance.
Impact: More job opportunities created in the labour market; enhanced technical and entrepreneurial skills of conflict affected women and their families, capacity enhancement of local bodies and service delivery agencies.
Outcome: Gender responsive community-based economic recovery initiatives are designed and implemented.

Project Title: Towards Achieving the Elimination of the Worst Forms of Child Labour as Priority (ACHIEVE)
Input: - Review the report and data of the 2010 Child Labour Survey and prepare estimates to identify areas of high concentration of hazardous child labour at the district level.   - Prepare a District Mainstreaming Strategy in a from of a briefing note and identify key entry points in the various plans and frameworks (including those related to the economic and social empowerment of the families).   - Identify most feasible monitoring and reporting mechanisms to integrate child labour issue, particularly those linked with district/national planning mechanisms.   - Prepare a simple and low-cost 'how-to' manual (including tools and estimations) to serve as guidance for replication/adaptation of the model by other districts/sub-districts.   - Identify the most appropriate survey for purposes of identifying the number of children in the worst forms of child labour, age-group, gender, socio-economic status of the family, education status, workplaces where children are working including mapping of services and service providers for referrals and mainstreaming purpose.    - Develop social mobilization strategy to bring community members (including community leaders, families, school teachers, hospitals, youth, human rights groups and children among others) on-board.   - Through involvement of social partners, seek participation of employers and workers and their groups in programs, campaigns and referral processes in the two districts to ensure that children of legal working age are protected and those below working age are not involved in the worst forms or hazardous forms of child labour.   - Identify and facilitate linkages through joint programmes with schools, training and other services in cooperation with the DWCB and Child Protection/Welfare Committees   - Organize ToT for 50 national trainers using the Capacity Development Training Module prepared under Child Labour Phase I Project in cooperation with the MoLE/CLERS.   - Reach out to 200 individuals and relevant stakeholders from various agencies to mainstream child labour elements in their programs and curricula based on the Manuals and Guidelines developed by the Project.   - In collaboration with the CLERS, social partners, prepare a campaign module on workplace corporal punishment, Occupational Safety and Health and other workplace issues related to child labour and children at legal working age to contribute to the efforts of the SAIEVAC campaign in Nepal which can be replicated in other countries.   - Review national laws on child labour and those related to child labour.
Outputs: Output1.1 A brief report prepared that includes a listing and explanation of priority geographical areas of concentration of the worst forms of child labour in Nepal   Output 1.2 District Mainstreaming Strategy prepared for integrated area-based approaches at the operational level in the two selected districts.   Output 1.3 Monitoring and reporting templates developed for the integration in the District monitoring and reporting   Output 1.4 Mainstreaming strategies and model(s) reviewed, documented and disseminated with a view to replication and scaling up   Output 1.5 Specific child labour related information generated as part of the district/sub-district surveys (baseline and monitoring) on children   Output 1.6 Community members are mobilized to make their communities child labour free and ensure children's education and development.   Output 1.7 Linkages are established with service providers for the withdrawn and prevented children from child labour, and families are socially and economically empowered   Output 2.1 Public and private sector official, social partners, child labour focal points, the media, and other stakeholders trained.    Output 2.2 Networking and partnerships on child labour issues are enhanced   Output 2.3 Programmes and activities developed with a view to educating and capacitating the employers and workers in the formal and informal economies on the applicable laws and on the ILO child labour Conventions ratified by Nepal.   Output 2.4 A synthesis report is produced on the findings of research on child labour and trends over the years are highlighted.   2.5 Enabling Policy Environment established for child labour elimination
Impact: Elimination of worst form of child labour in Nepal and creation of decent work to adult workers.
Outcome: 1. Integrated area-based models for child labour-free communities are tested in selected communities in two districts and available for scaling-up in others.   2. The policy environment is conducive and institutional capacities are strengthened for the prevention and elimination of child labour, with a priority on its worst forms.

Project Title: Way out of informality: Facilitating formalization of informal economy in Nepal.
Input: Technical Assistance, Policy Advice, Finanacial, Administrative & Logistic support.
Outputs: Output 1.1: The incentives and the disincentives to formalizing unregistered small firms and own-account workers analyzed and addressed. Output 1.2: The incentives and the disincentives to formalizing informal workers and informalizing workers analyzed and addressed  Output 2.1: Job-rich growth strategies implemented at the target local areas  Output 2.2: The ready-to-formalize groups better linked to the upgradation and risk mitigation services  Output 3.1: A web-based knowledge sharing and monitoring platform developed and kept functional  Output 3.2: Good practices documents and videos from the project shared  Output 3.3: The national constituents and other key stakeholders are better exposed to the international experiences of formalization efforts
Impact: The project is expected to contribute to the shift in growth and employment policies to those that facilitate accelerated expansion of formal sector, curb the growth of informal economy and reduce vulnerable employment.
Outcome: Outcome 1: The regulatory and policy environment in the target local areas made more conducive to formalization and protective to the risks of informalization. Outcome 2: Formal job growth promoted through job-rich growth strategies and an integrated formalization assistance in the target local areas. Outcome 3: Good practices and tools of promoting formalization better understood by the constituents and key stakeholders at the national level in South Asia

Project Title: Development Democracy in Nepal Responsive Facility (DDNRF) - Nepal
Input: The DDNRF Nepal facility is a responsive mechanism designed to support sub-projects submitted by Nepali organisations. Project activities support Nepal in developing democratic processes leading to the election of a Constituent Assembly (CA) and the subsequent drafting of a new Constitution.
Outputs: Increased access by Nepalese, particularly women and socially excluded, to accurate information related to the upcoming Constituent Assembly elections, including its mandate, procedures and membership. Increased awareness and ability of Nepalese, particularly women and the socially excluded, to participate in informed debate related to democracy and constitutional issues. Nepalese, particularly women and the socially excluded, have increased understanding of and participation in the development of fair electoral practices. Increased ability to communicate effectively unbiased election messages and to facilitate informed public debate. Increased media coverage on issues of concern to all sections of Nepali society, particularly women and the socially excluded, to rural and remote areas. Increased access by the people, independent electoral bodies, and the Government of Nepal to international/Canadian experience and technical knowledge on equitable democratic governance systems and processes.
Outcome: Enhanced participation of the people of Nepal in ongoing democratic processes, supporting and leading to the election of socially inclusive Constituent Assembly and drafting of a new Constitution;  Unbiased reporting and improved communication of messages related to the upcoming election and drafting of the Constitution.  Increased capacity of election official to conduct peaceful, inclusive and unbiased elections

Capacity of grassroots level community-based organizations to access adn monitor resources at the locla level enhanced.  Social inclusion and women's representation in membership and governance of community organizations interfacing with government enhanced.
Impact: CSOs assert their right to development and hold local government accountable
Outcome: Communities and community organizations participate actively in local governance processes.

Input: Basic human needs, good governance, community infrastructure

Enhanced strategy with the CIDA bilateral initiatives.

Project Title: Peace Building from Below (PBB)
Input: The project activities are contained in four broad components namely CBPOs' capacity strengthening, livelihoods improvments, reconciliation and reintegration and project management.
Outputs: 1. CBPOs (150) practise enhanced gender equality and social inclusion, human rights, right-based programming, good governance and conflict mitigation as well as they identify and effectively mobilize local (including local government) adn other resources and implement projects according to community demand enhanced. 3. Effectiveness of CBPOs to collaborate with a broad range of agencies on peace building initiatives improved. 4. Conflict affected people (1195) have improved access to basic human needs improved. 5. target groups (600 persons), including youth and women, have enhanced income generating and employment opportunities 6. Target groups (400 persons), including youth and women, have enhanced access to and control over community resources and better articulate thier rights and responsibilities with enhanced motivation for peace building. 8. Community infrastructure (193) developed and rehabilitated as well as community members (2800) practice conciliatory living (low tendency towards hostilities and revenge) 10. Local Resource Persons (245) from CAPs/P&E are developed for effective delivery of services, including monitoring. 11. Project lessons are shared widely with stakeholds and CBPOs collaborate with government organized local peace committees. 12. Project activities are managed effectively adn efficiently; project financial systems and procedures ensure accountability and transparency.
Impact: Improved peace and harmony  Improved livellihoods of the target population.  Improved gender equaltiy and social inclusion.
Outcome: 1. Strengthened CBPOs' capacity to initiate and manage community reconciliation and development activities in ways that improve and make gender equality and social inclusion. 2. Assets and capacity of local communities to cope with and recover from shocks and stresses caused by conflict enhanced 3. Conflict-affected persons (including IDPs and former combatants) reconcile and work together and with the government entities for the development of their community. 4. A model for community-based reconciliation is developed that can be replicated nation-wide. 5. Capacity of the project staff to manage project effficiently and effectively.

Project Title: Agriculture-Based Micro-Enterprise Development Project
Input: The project with UNDP/MEDEP will train 2,500 individuals (60% women, 30% dalits, 40% indegenous nationalities, 60% youth aged 16-35) in enterpreneurship and technical skills; create 1,500 new agro-nased micro-entrepreneurs and scale up the production of 1,000 existing agro-based micro-entrepreneurs in 18 districts.
Outputs: The project will have following outputs:  · Improved entrepreneurial skills of target population, particularly among women · Increased access to financial services for target population, particularly for women.  · Increased access to new technologies for target population, particularly for women. · Increased marketing skills and linkages of micro-entrepreneur groups with other value-chain actors. · Increased capacity of women and men from targeted communities to advocate for improved agro-based marketing policy reforms.
Impact: Reduced poverty of poor, socially excluded and marginalized groups,with a specific focus on women, in 18 districts of Nepal.
Outcome: · Increased number of agro-based micro enterprises, being operated by members of socially excluded and marginalized groups, with a specific focus on female-operated enterprises.  · Increased productivity of agro-based micro-entrepreneurs operated by men and women from marginalized groups, with a particular focus on women. · More conducive and gender-equitable business environment for agro-based micro-entrepreneurs.

Project Title: USRP Project for Bhutanese Refugee
Input: After languishing in refugee camps in eastern Nepal for 18 years, 108,000 registered Bhutanese refugees became eligible for third country resettlement in late 2007 due to the concerted efforts of a Core Group of resettlement countries, UNHCR and the Government of Nepal. IOM assists in the resettlement of Bhutanese refugees from Nepal to the United States (and other countries) by 1) interviewing refugees and completing US Government forms; 2) conducting health assessments; 3) providing cultural orientation courses and 4) organizing transportation for refugees from the camps in eastern Nepal to their final destination in the United States.
Outputs: 1) IOM interviews and completes US Government forms for 17,000 Bhutanese refugees per year and schedule them for interviews with US immigration offers.   2) IOM conducts health assessments for 17,000 refugees per year and, when required, organize further investigations and treatment. Further, IOM provides pre-embarkation health checks on the day prior to the resettlement flight.   3) IOM provides Cultural Orientation courses for 10,000 refugees aged 14 and above annually who are selected for resettlement to the United States.   4) IOM organizes charter flights from eastern Nepal to Kathmandu and commercial flights from Kathmandu to the final destination in the United States for 15,000 Bhutanese refugees annually.
Outcome: This project provides a durable solution for the Bhutanese refugees. In August 2011, the 50,000th Bhutanese refugee will have resettled in a third country. By the end of 2014, it is projected than 45,000 more will have departed. An additional outcome is that the Government of Nepal and the international community will be relieved of the burden of maintaining the refugee camps in eastern Nepal at the closure of the resettlement operation.

Project Title: Harmonization of Protocols for Tuberculosis Diagnosis and Treatment of the Bhutanese Refugees in Nepal (HAPT
Input: International Organization for Migration (IOM) will work with Association of Medical Doctors, Asia (AMDA) in seven camps in the south east part of Nepal to provide tuberculosis (TB) screening and treatment for Bhutanese refugees. Currently TB screening and treatment protocol implemented in the camps differs from the protocol of the resettlement countries. The purpose of this project is to ensure that the refugees who apply for resettlement and those who have not yet entered resettlement programmes receive the same effective TB diagnosis and treatment.

Project Title: SNV Regional and Corporate Programmes (SNV)
Input: Strengthening SNV regional and corporate coherence and coordination in identified programmatic and thematic areas  Strengthening quality and performance of SNV services
Outputs: SNV programmes are aligned to its regional and corporate choices, framework and guidelines  SNV Nepal programmes are aligned to Nepal's national development priorities and choices
Impact: SNV's contribution to Nepal's development recognised (in selected sectors and programmatic areas)
Outcome: Relevance, effectiveness and efficiency of SNV services enhanced

Project Title: Trafficking Risk Reduction in Nepal (TRRIN)
Input: Lack of economic opportunities is one of the major factors driving people to migrate and giving traffickers the opportunity to lure potential victims. In cooperation with the Government of Nepal, NGOs and private sector businesses, IOM provides economic rehabilitation to returned victims and potential victims of trafficking through skills training, job placement and micro-enterprise setup. NGOs are responsible for psychosocial counseling of the beneficiaries and supporting them in day to day management of their Micro-enterprises. The corporate houses extend business opportunities / franchisees to the beneficiaries and assist them by providing - business specific training, market linkages, skils training and job placements. The Government extends legal and infrastructural support to the initiatives. In addition to the financial inputs IOM is involved in the overall planning and coordination among various stakeholders, including Implementation and monitoring of all the project activities.
Outputs: 100 victims or potential victims of trafficking receive counseling, skill development training, and other training as required, and are supported into sustained income generating activity.  Increase in the level of support from private sector and training organizations in economic rehabilitation of potential victims and survivors  Increase in the level of understanding on importance of corporate social responsibility in addressing the problem of trafficking in a sustainable way  20 NGOs and CBOs staffs are trained to effectively deliver the economic rehabilitation model developed in the project that includes aspects of psychosocial counseling, financial literacy, entrepreneurship development and handling credit and savings activities.   A network of NGOs and CBOs involved in economic rehabilitation and income generation activities in Nepal is promoted and is meeting at regular intervals to share experiences and best practices.  Government officials are familiar with international best practices on rehabilitation of survivors.  Economic rehabilitation model processes and impact document is available as a tool for disseminating information about and learning from the project.  Increase in participation of the GoN in the discussions, meetings and focus group activities dealing with rehabilitation.  Increase in the businesses and marketing opportunities of the participating private sector in the project
Outcome: This project provides a sustainable economic opportunity to the trafficking survivors and potential victims of trafficking. As at June 2011, 63 survivors and potential victims have been successfully rehabilitated in collaboration with 5 corporate houses. By the end of 2011, it is projected that 100 women and girls will be engaged in sustainable income generating activities. The economic rehabilitation model process including learning of impact document will be available for wider dissemination.

Project Title: Peace through Justice (PtJ)
Input: The project intends to support the establishment and effective functioning of the transitional justice mechanisms, namely Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC) and Commission of Inquiry on Disappearances (CoI-D). It also intends to strengthen civil society to provide appropriate support to victims and participants to the Commissions.
Outputs: The project has 4 outputs: i) Ministry of Peace and Reconstruction conducting effective preparations for the creation of the Commissions and providing necessary support in the work of the Commissions; ii) Transitional Justice Commissions established in accordance with international human rights standards; iii) Mapping document/s with research and analysis on conflict-related international human rights and humanitarian law violations; and iv) Civil society and national human rights institutions are supporting the work of the Commissions.
Impact: Ensure a successful transitional justice process in Nepal
Outcome: Enabled the Government of Nepal to establish functioning Commissions responsible for addressing transitional justice through the implementation of the CPA and other peace agreements.

Project Title: To enhance national capacities for scaling- up HIV prevention, treatment, care and support.
Input: Activity # 5.1 Support to develop, implement and monitor the annual JTA workplans (including UN Joint program of support, PAF-support, UN Cares program, support to TG, others) Activity # 5.2 Support developing country proposals (GF and others), implementation and monitoring.  Activity # 5.3 Support in strengthening the effective functioning of CCM and its Secretariat and harmonising EDP's initiatives (including IHP) Activity # 5.4 Strengthening the management and operations of UCO workplan development, implementation and monitoring, capacity building and team retreat
Outputs: UN system and External Development Partner's technical and financial support coordinated and harmonized to strengthen Nepal's response on HIV and AIDS.
Donor Agency: Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS

Project Title: A57846 - Improving the quality of clinical management of HIV and AIDS cases by documenting and experience sharing among doctors providing ART services
Input: Organize national level workshop to share experiences from the field level among HIV clinicians from the country  Documentation of Practices, experiences and case studies from the field  Sharing of out put of workshops to relevant National Technical Working Groups, NCASC and the UN partners
Outputs: 2national level workshop of HIV clinicians from the country to share field experience sharing for better management of the HIV care and treatment services and documentation of the shared experiences and case studies
Outcome: 1. Clinicians providing ART services become informed of the latest technical updates and learnt experiences of fellow clinician's work on presenting symptoms, clinical and laboratory investigations, interpretation of results, choice of drugs, management of side effects and complications in management of HIV and AIDS cases in Nepal setting 2. Documentation of the case studies for future use such as CME, presentation to the regional forum/ international forum if relevant and feasible  3. Improve management of ART and OI cases at the service delivery points
Donor Agency: Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS

Project Title: Canadian Immigration Medical Examination and Pre-departure Medical Screening of Bhutanese Refugees in Nepal (CIMEP)
Input: Immigration and Citizenship, Canada (CIC) identified a group of approximately 5000 Bhutanese refugees located in seven camps around Damak, Nepal, for resettlement in Canada in 2008-2013. One of the steps in the resettlent process is related to ensuring that appropriate measures are in place to address the health needs of these refugees prior to their departure from Nepal, during travel and after arrival in Canada. CIC requested IOM Nepal to conduct Immigration Medical Examination (IME) and Pre-departure Medical Screening (PDMS). Besides, IOM is requested to provide diagnosis treatment for tuberculosis to these refugees.

Project Title: Exploring Livelihood Options for Trafficked Women in Nepal (LOPS)
Input: To date there has been little research on post trafficking livelihoods or how the issues raised by trafficking intersect with development agendas. IOM in collaboration with Newcastle University, UK and the Non Governmental Organization "Shakti Samuha" is undertaking a research to explore the situation of returnee trafficked women. A key aspect of this research is to gain knowledge that is grounded in the actual experiences of the Nepalese trafficked returnee women themselves and how returnee livelihoods intersect with sexuality and citizenship. Furthermore project facilitates the current debates on the citizenship in the Constitution writing process through ongoing dialogue with relevant subject committees of the Constituent Assembly and Women's Caucus of the legislative parliament.
Outputs: 1) Provide comprehensive qualitative data on returnee trafficked women's livelihoods strategies    2) Enhance the advocacy ability of scholars, policy makers and anti-trafficking campaigners to inform national policy makers to develop polices and approaches that go beyond the immediate 'rescue' of returnee trafficked women.
Outcome: Help generate new policy paradigm for understanding the relationship between sexuality, gender and development and combine a focus on returnee livelihoods with the need to address the issues related to their right to citizenship

Project Title: Fairness and Efficiency in Reparations to Conflict-Affected Persons (FERC)
Input: Over 14,000 people lost their lives and thousands more were the victims of gross human rights violations during the ten-year conflict which began in 1996 and ended with the signing of the Comprehensive Peace Agreement in 2006. IOM Nepal in partnership with OHCHR-Nepal is working with the Ministry of Peace and Reconstruction (MoPR) to develop and implement a comprehensive reparation policy in line with international human rights and humanitarian law standards. In addition to developing reparations policy, the project will increase the capacity of relevant government agencies including MoPR as well as TRC and COI-D to develop and implement the needed procedures, processes and guidelines including a database essential for the successful implementation of a reparations program.
Outputs: 1. Comprehensive Policy on Reparations Prepared  2. The capacity of the Relief and Rehabilitation Division of the Ministry of Peace and Reconstruction and selected districts enhanced to support reparations program.  3. Processes, guidelines, SOPs, forms, procedures for various reparations benefits prepared and tested.
Outcome: Government has effective and transparent structures and procedures in place to implement reparations program

Project Title: SENEP1004004 - To combat HIV/AIDS
Input: 1. Integrated and decentralized systems for ART, VCT, HIV/AIDS prevention and care with thealth services strengthened. 2. Capactiy of Public Health Workforce enhanced. 3. Strengthened capacities HIV, TB collaborative activities. 4. HIV SGS system strengthened to support monitoring and analysis of HIV epidemic and response. 5. Laboratory services and public health laboratory networks strengthened to support monitoring and anlysis of HIV epidemic and response. 6. Partnership with government and development partners including civil society promoted. 7. Inter/National resource mobilized.
Outputs: Review of existing malaria guidelines, policy, and strategy documents with updates based on the current national context which allow for the integration of international standards and targets.          To support and strengthen systems of ART, VCT, HIV/AIDS prevention and care with health services, and to enhance capacity of public health workforce.
Impact: To combat HIV/AIDS
Outcome: Policy and technical support provided to countries towards expanded gender-sensitive delivery of prevention, treatment and care interventions for HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria, including integrated training and service delivery; wider service-provider networks; and strengthened laboratory capacities and better linkages with other health services, such as those for reproductive health, maternal, newborn and child health, sexually transmitted infections, nutrition, drug-dependence treatment services, respiratory care, neglected diseases and environmental health..  Global, regional and national systems for surveillance, evaluation and monitoring strengthened and expanded to keep track of progress towards targets and allocation of resources for HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria control and to determine the impact of control efforts and the evolution of drug resistance.

Project Title: Support to the Peace Process in Nepal - phase II
Progressive actions are taken toward HIV and AIDS related policy development in one or more key policy areas.
Input: National level advocacy campaign on vulnerability of specific group to HIV  Conduct leadership visibility events  Conduct an AIDS sensitization seminar to high level leader of nepal government on need of addressing HIV/AIDS issues of most at risk population by different ministries
Outputs: National political and civil society leader demonstrate public commitment to advancing policies, regulation, general directives or more and comprehensive response to the HIV and AIDS epidemics.   HIV and AIDS champions effectively advocate in advancing response to HIV and AIDS epidemics  National response is informed on policy need and effective program response
Donor Agency: Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS

Project Title: PCR 4, IR 3: Community-Based and Coordination/Referral
Input: A description of the main activities of the project  3.1 Coordination, advocacy and monitoring of the implementation of the National Plan of Action for Children with regard to child protection by a national multi-sector multi-institution child protection mechanism. 3.2 Coordination of interventions and referral mechanisms, mobilisation of resources and monitoring with regard to child protection by District Child Welfare Boards/DCPC/VCPC in 23 Child-Friendly Local Governance (CFLG) districts. 3.3 Incorporation of child protection in the plans & budgets and social mobilisation activities of district, village, ward and community structures under LGCDP in 23 Child Friendly Local Governance (CFLG) districts. 3.4 Incorporation of child protection in education and health systems in selected districts. Dissemination of information/promotion of behaviour change with all children & families, detection and referral of children at risk and children in harmful situations, case monitoring, reporting & follow-up by Paralegal Committees(PLC´s) in 75 districts.
Outputs: Children, Families, Communities and all relevant non-government and government sectors improve their knowledge, attitudes and practices with regard to child protection, mobilise and establish mechanisms to provide better protection to children.
Impact: Protect children from all forms of discrimination, exploitation and abuse. Ensure rights of children, focusing on those in especially difficult circumstances, such as children with disabilities, children affected by conflict, street children, child labourers and others. (National Plan of Action for Children 2005-2015).
Outcome: Children, especially disadvantaged children and adolescent girls, are better protected from abuse, violence, exploitation, discrimination, lack of parental care and unnecessary separation from family and the impact of armed conflict.

Project Title: PCR5, IR - 4: Participation and Partnerships
Input: A description of the main activities of the project  4.1 Creating enabling environment for participation 4.2 Building capacities and capabilities of child clubs and children networks and providing opportunities for participation 4.3 Innovation for reaching adolescent girls and the most disadvantaged 4.4 Knowledge management
Outputs: Children, especially the disadvantaged, are increasingly engaged in participatory processes which help to address the issues that affect their well-being.

Input: 1. High level policy and advocacy meetings related to MNCH, nutrition and SWAp coordinated and supported. 3. Technical assistance, financial and coordination support provided to NPC, MoHP and nutrition stakeholders for multi sectoral nutrition approach. Input: Music training and education: Improve musical (pedagogical) skills and understandings of Nepali folk/ethnic music  Events and programs: Greater awareness, understanding and appreciation of music amongst Nepali population  Internationalization and exchange: Internationalization facilitates enhancing standards of Nepali music through technical and academic exchange  Documentation: Create a reservoir of musical knowledge of various ethnic groups of Nepal is created from sources of traditional music
Outputs: Music training and education: Conducted workshops; Students have participated in pedagogical music classes; Students participated in events/festivals Events and programs: School concerts; Live music events focused on children and youth; Interactive musical programs between different ethnic communities; National folk festival; Developed a National Folk Artist Forum Internationalization and exchange: National, regional exchange; International musicians visited NMC; Academic experts from Norway worked at NMC under Fredskorpset; Academic experts from Nepal worked in Norway under Fredskorpset Documentation: Cultural material being processed and digitalized
Impact: To establish an institution that offers all-encompassing curricula for generating pedagogical interest in folk/ethnic Nepali music in order to strengthen and preserve the musical heritage of Nepal.
Outcome: Music training and education: increase in the number of classes, workshops, events, audiences, students of eastern music Events and programs: increase in the number of school concerts, audience numbers, events focused on children/youth and ethnic communities  Internationalization and exchange: Increase in the number of participants and exchange activities between Norway and Nepal and within Nepal with regional and national partners Documentation: Increase in number of processed material and digitalized material

Input: Capacity building of national Prosthetics and Orthotics and technical skills development of centers and satellite unit physical and rehabilitation staffs through formal training courses. Project Title: Inclusive Resource Management Initiative (IRMI)
Input: Funds, project staff, technical assistance, training.
Outputs: To support Nepal's transition to a more peaceful, equitable society, Inclusive Resource Management Initiative program (IRMI) aims to enhance stability through natural resource conflict resolution and inclusive natural resource management. This will be achieved through a holistic people-to-people approach that: 1) facilitates the resolution of resource-based conflicts; 2) promotes inclusive decision-making related to natural resource use and management; and 3) reduces natural resource competition through joint environmental and economic initiatives.
Impact: Ennhanced stability through natural resource conflict resolution and inclusive natural resource management.
Outcome: Strengthened ability of key stakeholders to resolve community-level natural resource conflicts in an inclusive, sustainable manner. Inclusive and participatory resource-related decision-making among community and government bodies.
